headline: 2 Israelis Charged in Deadly Attack on Palestinian Family in West Bank
text: JERUSALEM — Two young Israelis were charged on Sunday in connection with a deadly arson attack in July on a Palestinian home in the West Bank, a case that Israeli leaders condemned as Jewish terrorism and that enraged Palestinians.

headline: Obama to Hold Town Hall Meeting on Gun Violence
text: HONOLULU — Renewing his emphasis on the need for more gun restrictions, President Obama will participate in a live televised town-hall-style meeting on Thursday to discuss gun violence in the United States, according to the White House.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Japan’s Apology to ‘Comfort Women’
text: Shinzo Abe, Japan’s prime minister, supported an apology and payment for the Korean “comfort women” who were forced to serve as sex slaves for Japan’s Imperial Army.

headline: Ex-Suffolk County Police Chief’s Arrest Comes Amid a Broader Federal Inquiry
text: Even today the crime is remembered, with a shudder, across Long Island.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Needing Early Lift, Builds Iowa Ground Operation
text: DES MOINES — This fall the words of a Hillary Clinton backer were posted like a locker-room taunt on the wall at Bernie Sanders’s Iowa headquarters: “There is no Sanders organization.”

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Dance Theater of Harlem to Present New Works by Dianne McIntyre and Elena Kunikova
text: Premieres by Dianne McIntyre and Elena Kunikova, two stylistically different but longtime fixtures of New York dance, are in store for Dance Theater of Harlem’s coming engagement at City Center.

headline: A Chinese Almanac That Takes a Wary View of the New Year
text: Joanna C. Lee waved her little red book for 2016 in the face of a man she had sent its predecessors, the little red books from 2015, 2014, 2013 and maybe even 2012. For a moment the man thought about 2015, a year bookended by the Charlie Hebdo attack in January and the San Bernardino assault in December, and said 2016 had to be a better year.

headline: It’s All in the Script
text: Written by PETE DOCTER, MEG LeFAUVE AND JOSH COOLEY

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: It’s a tough choice: Return to Downton Abbey or visit the United States-Mexico border in Seth MacFarlane’s new animated comedy “Bordertown.” Jerry Seinfeld and President Obama take turns driving — and presidential candidates vie for the Oval Office seat on the Sunday morning news shows.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Warn of Obama’s Actions on Guns
text: As President Obama moves closer to using executive action to tighten regulations on gun purchases, the Republican presidential candidates hoping to succeed him are accusing him of abusing power and promising to reverse such measures if elected.

headline: A Standout Year for Deals, in Volume and Complexity
text: Of all the ways to describe mergers and acquisitions in 2015, “plain vanilla” is not one of them.

headline: Boston Globe Employees Help Deliver Paper on Sunday
text: Operating on the mantra that the news never sleeps, about 200 employees of The Boston Globe stayed up all night to help deliver newspapers to subscribers who were angry about widespread delivery problems last week.

headline: How Do Sunni and Shia Islam Differ?
text: Saudi Arabia’s execution of the Shiite cleric Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr could escalate tensions in the Muslim world even further. In the Shiite theocracy Iran, the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei,  said on Sunday that Saudi Arabia, which is ruled by a Sunni monarchy, would face “divine vengeance” for the killing of the outspoken cleric, which was part of a mass execution of 47 men. Sheikh Nimr had advocated for greater political rights for Shiites in Saudi Arabia and surrounding countries. Saudi Arabia had accused him of inciting violence against the state.

headline: Armed Group Vows to Continue Occupation at Oregon Refuge
text: BURNS, Ore. — The protesters arrived in this old lumber town to support a 73-year-old rancher and his son who had been sentenced to prison for setting fires that spread to federal lands. It was billed as a peaceful demonstration, but after “Amazing Grace” was sung and hugs were exchanged, a small, armed contingent declared outside a supermarket that it was taking a stand and asked who wanted to join.

headline: ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens’ Continues Box-Office Reign
text: Like one of its impossibly huge Imperial destroyers, “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” continued to cast a long shadow on the North American box office, collecting $88.3 million in its third weekend, as Quentin Tarantino’s “The Hateful Eight” sold fewer tickets than some analysts expected as it expanded nationwide.

headline: ‘Dark’ Funds May Bode Ill in 2016 Election
text: The 2016 presidential campaign seems certain to feature not only more money than any since Watergate but also more money from undisclosed donors since the days when black satchels of illicit cash were passed around.

headline: Hunt for Gunmen Continues at Air Base Near India-Pakistan Border
text: NEW DELHI — A shootout between Indian security forces and armed gunmen stretched into its second day on Sunday at the Pathankot air force base in Punjab, near India’s border with Pakistan. At least seven Indian personnel and at least four gunmen have been killed in the fighting so far, officials said.

headline: Cuomo Orders That Homeless Be Taken to Shelter in Freezing Weather
text: As an arctic front barreled toward the New York City region, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo signed an executive order on Sunday requiring local governments across the state to take homeless people off the streets to shelters in freezing temperatures.

headline: State Focus and Infusion of Funding Buoy Gun Control Advocates
text: ALEXANDRIA, Va. — With President Obama poised to act on his own authority to try to stem gun violence, his gun control allies are using big-money donors and shifting tactics to try to remake the political landscape in the national gun debate, challenging and sometimes even besting the powerful National Rifle Association in state-by-state battles.

headline: Worst Comes to Worst for Jets as Playoff Spot Slips Away
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — The opportunity the Jets had been awaiting for a year arrived Sunday, and they seized it as if grasping at a tornado. The game spun away from them, kicking up everything they wanted, everything they craved, until it was gone — all of it.

headline: Steelers Clinch Playoff Spot, but Could Have Achieved More
text: The Pittsburgh Steelers needed every victory they could muster in an up-and-down, injury-plagued season. In the end, they also needed some help.

headline: Giants Finish Quietly, and Tom Coughlin Has Little to Say About Future
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The tailgate parties in the parking lots around MetLife Stadium were more subdued Sunday. The music was quieter and the congregations less boisterous. Once the game began, as many as a fourth of the stadium seats were empty.

headline: Bringing U.S. Presidential Debates to a Chinese Audience
text: BEIJING — From his graduate student dormitory in the southern city of Guangzhou, Yin Hao works late into the night with an online network of about half a dozen other volunteer translators. Their task: to post the American presidential debates, with Chinese subtitles.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 4
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: ‘The Breaks,’ a TV Movie on VH1, Examines the Year Hip-Hop Found Its Flow
text: In 1990, hip-hop was a subculture striving to breach the mainstream without losing its soul. The music had matured at breakneck speed in the 1980s. Rappers pushed past boasts and chants with storytelling, complex wordplay and sociopolitical consciousness, as producers vastly extended the sound-collage possibilities of sampling. “Yo! MTV Raps,” which started in 1988, was expanding the hip-hop audience beyond its urban core, and MC Hammer had a worldwide hit with “U Can’t Touch This.” But at the same time the crack epidemic was closing down the New York City clubs that had been hip-hop laboratories, while radio stations still resisted hip-hop’s genuine innovators and major labels considered hip-hop a novelty that would run its course. Everyone involved was inventing the music and the business on the spot.

headline: Alex Brightman Rides a ‘School of Rock’ Wave
text: What kinds of backstage pleasures does a newly minted heavy-metal star enjoy these days? At the Winter Garden Theater, Alex Brightman, the lead actor of Broadway’s “School of Rock,” has furnished his diminutive dressing room with such not-so-hedonistic gratifications as a steam-inhaler mask, tasteful throw pillows and a collection of year-end award-season movies on DVD.

headline: In ‘Fiddler on the Roof,’ a Title Role Shared Onstage and Off
text: Pop quiz: Who plays the title role in the new Broadway revival of “Fiddler on the Roof”?

headline: A Healthy Diet’s Main Ingredients? Best Guesses
text: First doctor: “This morning for breakfast he requested something called ‘wheat germ, organic honey and tiger’s milk.’”

headline: Review: ‘Superstore’ and ‘Telenovela’ Play It Safe on NBC
text: Two new shows on NBC that address the shortage of Hispanic characters on television play the demographic game about as safely as it can be played, putting well-known Latina stars in nonthreatening, nonchallenging comedies. But progress is progress, and one of the shows, “Superstore,” is pretty good. The other, “Telenovela,” is just dumb.

headline: Acts of Bravery
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Well, if you are going to break into solving crossword puzzles as a New Year’s resolution, this is a pretty decent one with which to do it. This puzzle by Herre Schouwerwou is mostly easy to solve and the plethora of theme material is clued easily, so it won’t slow you down. Not only that, but you just know that any puzzle that debuts PINK FLOYD, POPPIN’ FRESH and PILLOW FIGHTS is going to be fun.

headline: Laurie Anderson Puts on a Concert for Dogs in Times Square
text: Eight years ago, Laurie Anderson recalled in an interview, she was backstage with the cellist Yo-Yo Ma at a Rhode Island School of Design graduation ceremony when she turned to him and said, “I have this fantasy where I look out, and the whole audience is dogs.” He replied: “Are you kidding? I have the same fantasy.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Cabaret of Plants,’ Richard Mabey Demonstrates Their Richness
text: Imagine a picture of a jungle. There are the familiar palms and vines, and down in a corner a monkey sitting on a branch. Ask a number of people, “What is this a picture of?” and it’s a good bet that most will say it shows a monkey.

headline: Arron Afflalo, With 38 Points, Carries Knicks Past Hawks
text: To start 2016, Arron Afflalo switched to a new pair of black Air Jordans as his on-court sneaker of choice.

headline: In Israeli City of Haifa, a Liberal Arab Culture Blossoms
text: HAIFA, Israel — At Elika, a bar in the Hadar neighborhood of this hilly port city, a 30-something psychodramatist rolled a cigarette and sipped coffee with her father, a well-known actor in Israel. The bartender poured tall beers for two women who wandered in for an afternoon pint. Nearby, a 22-year-old woman with a partly shaved head and colorful tattoos sat alone, working on her laptop.

headline: Who’d Steal Lincoln’s Hand? Art Theft Baffles Illinois Museum
text: KANKAKEE, Ill. — Someone stole Abraham Lincoln’s hand.

headline: Auto Sales, the Fed’s December Meeting and Employment Numbers
text: The first Monday of the new year will mark the first day of extended trading hours for China’s currency, the renminbi. The move, announced last Wednesday by China’s central bank, is the most recent in a number of steps taken over the last few years by Beijing to make the renminbi more international.

headline: Closing the Farm-to-Table Gap in Alaska
text: ANCHORAGE — Across much of Alaska at this time of the year, as winter tightens its grip with darkness and cold, finding a nice crisp head of lettuce at an affordable price can be like prospecting for gold. Where the farm-to-table distance is measured in thousands of miles, the odds get long.

headline: New Elections Likely in Catalonia After Separatist Leader Is Rebuffed
text: MADRID — Catalonia is likely to convene new regional elections after a far-left party there voted Sunday against allowing Artur Mas to continue as leader of the region and its secessionist movement.

headline: Under New Leader, Discovery Channel’s Brand Reboot Shows Promise
text: LOS ANGELES — Hollywood loves a comeback story. And right now, there is perhaps none better than Rich Ross and Discovery.

headline: Girl Scout Cookie Sales Go Digital, With Help From Visa and Dell
text: Now that the Girl Scouts have taken their cookies digital, companies are following them online.

headline: Raine Group Finds Deals for Clients, and Itself
text: The Raine Group may not be as instantly recognizable as Wall Street fixtures like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley.

headline: Calculated Candor Inside Obama’s Off-the-Record Briefings
text: WASHINGTON — Hours after President Obama announced in a 2014 speech that he was escalating his campaign against Islamic extremists, a number of prominent columnists suggested they knew exactly what he was thinking.

headline: Accordion Store’s Departure Signals End of Manhattan’s Music Row
text: For decades, musicians from around the world flocked to a segment of West 48th Street in Manhattan that was known as Music Row. Both sides of the block, just off Times Square, were lined with shops that sold and repaired guitars, drums, keyboards and other instruments.

headline: Peyton Manning Returns and Leads Broncos to No. 1 Seed in A.F.C.
text: DENVER — For a little over a half, Peyton Manning stood stoutly on the Broncos’ sideline, not once appearing to favor his left foot, with a torn plantar fascia that had caused him to miss six games. Manning looked fine, which caused a woolen blanket of disbelief to settle over Sports Authority Field at Mile High during the Broncos’ regular-season finale against the San Diego Chargers.

headline: A Homey Hangout for Broadway Stars Closes After 14 Years
text: Trent Rhoton was drinking a pint and a shot at the bar of Angus’ Cafe Bistro on Sunday afternoon when a friend wandered over to greet him. “It’s the end of an era,” said the friend, John McMahon, as they clinked glasses.

headline: Economists Take Aim at Wealth Inequality
text: SAN FRANCISCO — When pundits and presidential candidates talk about inequality and the tiny sliver of the population whose fortunes have soared, they often drop names like Warren Buffett, Bill Gates, Sheldon Adelson and Mark Zuckerberg.

headline: For Tom Coughlin, a Tribute; for Pat Shurmur, an Audition
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — The Giants had one big edge over the Philadelphia Eagles entering Sunday’s season finale. Their head coach, Tom Coughlin, had been in the job for 12 years. Pat Shurmur, Philadelphia’s interim coach, had been in his job for all of five days.

headline: Hocine Aït-Ahmed, a Pro-Democracy Algerian Leader, Dies at 89
text: ALGIERS — Hocine Aït-Ahmed, a leader of the Algerian war of independence against France that began in 1954 and a major opponent of the Algerian governments dominated by the military since then, died on Dec. 23 in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 89.

headline: John Holm, 72, Dies; Opened Linguistics to Creole and Pidgin Tongues
text: John Holm, a linguist who helped bring the study of creole and pidgin languages into the scholarly mainstream, died on Dec. 28 in Azeitão, Portugal. He was 72.

headline: Jets’ High Hopes End in Same Place: Out of the Playoffs
text: ORCHARD PARK, N.Y. — I’m not sure what I expected from the Jets on Sunday.

headline: Depression Leaves a Man Adrift, but a Stranger Helps Him Find Purpose
text: Thomas Torres was told he would not amount to much even before he learned at age 13 that he had schizophrenia. His brother called him slow, classmates called him retarded, and he was teased relentlessly.

headline: Cowboys’ Star on the Rise in a Dallas Suburb
text: FRISCO, Tex. — Jerry Jones does not do small. He took the money-losing Dallas Cowboys and turned them into the most valuable team in America. He built AT&T Stadium, the biggest venue in the N.F.L. With the help of lucrative licensing and sponsorship deals, the Cowboys generated $620 million last year, the highest revenue in the league, according to Forbes.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Season 6, Episode 1: Warts and All
text: This recap contains spoilers for Sunday’s episode of “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Woman’s Death in Queens Is City’s First Homicide of 2016
text: A 19-year-old woman was killed on New Year’s Day, discovered face down in her bedroom in Queens, the police said; her death is the first homicide in New York City in 2016.

headline: A Soccer Team, Its Foreign Owner and Local Discontent
text: THE HAGUE — A new Chinese owner arrived at the Dutch soccer club ADO Den Haag in early 2014, promising multimillion-dollar investments and better days ahead. Fans of the club liked the sound of that.

headline: What We Know About the Standoff in Oregon
text: Here is what is known about the armed group occupying an Oregon wildlife refuge, and their beliefs and demands.

headline: Bronx Man Dies in Apartment Fire
text: James Tutein was always around for his neighbors. He was the one who would hold the door open when they were carrying packages or make room under his umbrella if it was raining outside.

headline: In N.F.L., Black Monday Was Sort of Gray
text: By the standard of the past two N.F.L. seasons, when bullying and domestic violence scandals swamped the league, this season has been tame. But that does not mean the league has operated smoothly.

headline: 하루에 물 8잔씩 안 마셔도 됩니다. 정말이라니까요?
text: 건강에 대한 잘못된 상식 가운데 아마도 불멸의 지위를 얻은 게 있다면 “하루에 꼭 물 8잔을 마셔야 한다”는 주장이다.

headline: N.B.A. Games of the Week: Grizzlies at Blazers; Grizzlies at Thunder
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose essential games to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: Two Found Dead in Sheepshead Bay
text: Two bodies were discovered in a blood-spattered apartment in Brooklyn on Sunday night, the police said.

headline: Library of Congress Anoints Graphic Novelist as Ambassador for Young People’s Literature
text: Gene Luen Yang often mines his life for his graphic novels. He has explored being a second-generation American, and harnessed his love of computer programming. Starting this week, he will have a whole new experience to draw on.

headline: Fidelity Switches to Visa for Credit Card Branding
text: Fidelity, one of the few credit card issuers that reward cardholders with a lucrative 2 percent in cash back on every dollar they spend, is making changes to its program.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | agglomeration
text: agglomeration • \ə-ˌglä-mə-ˈra-shən\ • noun

headline: The Best of Week 17 in the N.F.L.
text: Texans defensive end J. J. Watt was back to his old self, leading a dominant defense that helped the Texans rout the Jaguars and win their first A.F.C. South title since 2012. Watt, playing without a cast for the first time since breaking his left hand on Dec. 9, had three sacks, forced a fumble and recovered another. Watt leads the N.F.L. with 17 ½ sacks. He joined Reggie White as the only players in N.F.L. history to have three 15-sack seasons in their first five years in the league.

headline: What to Watch Monday
text: The roses have been plucked and the limo lined up for a night of first impressions on the 20th-season premiere of “The Bachelor.” Second glances let love bloom in “Pride and Prejudice.” (The one starring Keira Knightley. Sorry, Colin Firth fans.)

headline: The End of Lawyers?  Not So Fast.
text: Lawyers have been described as the canaries in the coal mine in the face of a wave of automation now beginning to displace highly skilled white-collar workers.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “People have talked about returning land to the people for a long time. Finally, someone is making an effort in that direction.”

headline: No Corrections: January 4, 2016
text: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Earthquake Strikes Northeast India, Killing at Least 6
text: NEW DELHI — A powerful earthquake of magnitude 6.7 rocked northeastern India before dawn on Monday, sending tremors through neighboring countries and leaving at least six people dead and scores injured.

headline: The Growth of Contemporary African Photography at LagosPhoto
text: A new book, “Africa Under the Prism,” captures the kaleidoscope of random energy, disorder and color on the continent, from work shown during the arts festival’s first five years.

headline: The Growth of Contemporary African Photography at LagosPhoto
text: Lagos is an African megacity humming with chaotic energy. Potholed roads and even the city’s superhighways are crowded with traffic, overloaded vendors, earsplitting noise, choking pollution, piercing colors and powerful smells. Extreme wealth is set against a backdrop of grinding poverty, hope battles despair, daily acts of kindness and generosity are offset by cruelty, greed and corruption, and creativity is inspired by necessity because of the city’s broken infrastructure and the looming threat of ruin. Between these extremes, and usually to the background drone of a generator, exist the rich and textured lives of some 20 million people.

headline: Trump Did Not Break Politics

headline: France’s Diminished Liberties

headline: Accepting the Past, Facing the Future
text: How do we relate to our past, and what might this tell us about how to relate to our future? One of the most provocative approaches to this question comes from Friedrich Nietzsche, whose doctrine of the eternal return asks this: “What if some day or night a demon were to steal after you into your loneliest loneliness and say to you: ‘This life as you now live it and have lived it, you will have to live once more and innumerable times more’”? To ask myself the question of the eternal return is to wonder about the worth of what I have done, to inquire whether it would stand the test of being done innumerable times again.

headline: ‘The Defender,’ by Ethan Michaeli
text: Franklin Roosevelt held an average of 84 presidential news conferences a year — 14 times the number given by Ronald Reagan and three to four times the output of Bill Clinton, George W. Bush or Barack Obama. Roosevelt charmed the White House press corps to within an inch of its life, leaked big stories to favored reporters and still made time for writers from obscure trade journals and others who were technically ineligible for press credentials. He nevertheless shunned the Negro press, shutting it out of the White House press corps until the last of his 12 years in office. By avoiding fire-breathing newspapers like The Chicago Defender, The Baltimore Afro-American and The Pittsburgh Courier, Roosevelt insulated himself from questions about what ­African-Americans saw as the burning issue of the 1940s: the government’s decision to embrace segregation in the military. Separating military men and women — and even the plasma in the wartime blood bank — by race, the government ratified racial apartheid in the South and introduced Jim Crow segregation into parts of the country where it had been unknown.

headline: Elizabeth Strout’s ‘My Name Is Lucy Barton’
text: One of this nation’s most abiding myths is that social origins don’t matter. Each of us is Gatsby, or can be, with the potential to be reinvented and obliterate the past. This is nowhere more true than in New York City, where, surrounded by millions, each person supposedly stands upon his or her own merits. If we reach a sophisticated urban consensus on how to speak, how to dress, how to live, then who will know what lies beneath the surface? Who will know what any one of us might really mean by words like “home,” “childhood” or “love”?

headline: 1966: African-American Becomes Mayor in Ohio
text: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio — A 44-year-old undertaker and campaigner for civic integration took office as Springfield’s first Negro mayor today [Jan. 4] and said: ‘‘This is going to be a big job.’’ Mayor Robert C. Henry was the unanimous choice of the city council last night. He is the first Negro to serve as mayor of a major U.S. city. Four-fifths of the city’s population are white. There are areas where Negroes have settled predominantly, but there is no black ghetto, as in some Northern U.S. cities. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 5, 1966

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Barbaric Executions
text: The execution of the popular Shiite cleric Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr and 46 other prisoners on Saturday was about the worst way Saudi Arabia could have started what promises to be a grim and tumultuous year in the kingdom and across the Middle East. It is hard to imagine that the Sunni rulers of the kingdom were not aware of the sectarian passions the killings would unleash around the region. They may even have counted on the fierce reaction in Iran and elsewhere as a distraction from economic problems at home and to silence dissenters. America’s longstanding alliance with the House of Saud is no reason for the Obama administration to do anything less than clearly condemn this foolhardy and dangerous course with a more robust response than its call Monday for both sides to exercise restraint.

text: Every year, the N.F.L. becomes more passer friendly, in quantity and quality. That trend held true in 2015, which will go down as the greatest passing season in league history.

headline: Review: ‘The Shannara Chronicles,’ an Elfin Adventure, Debuts on MTV
text: Terry Brooks’s original “Shannara” trilogy predates much of the name-brand fantasy fiction that has been turned into box-office gold lately. You need to keep reminding yourself of that as you’re watching “The Shannara Chronicles,” MTV’s television adaptation, which begins on Tuesday night. Amberle and Eretria, the saga’s two strongest female characters, might look like Katniss Everdeen knockoffs, but chronologically, Katniss could be either’s daughter.

headline: A Reprieve for Fungus-Battered Frogs
text: After a six-year effort, researchers on the Spanish island of Majorca have rid several groups of Majorcan midwife toads of the pathogen Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis — better known as chytrid fungus, or B.d. It’s the first time the disease, which is devastating amphibians worldwide, has been eradicated in a wild population.

headline: As Justices Weigh Affirmative Action, Michigan Offers an Alternative
text: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — Kedra Ishop got results.

headline: Study Shows Larger Effect of Clouds on El Niño
text: Clouds help amplify El Niño’s effect on the atmosphere to a greater degree than once thought, a new study reports.

headline: An Artist Pays Tribute to Her Dog — in Times Square
text: Since its inception in 2012, the Midnight Moment program has presented the work of prominent artists including Tracey Emin, Jesper Just and Andy Warhol in the unlikeliest of places: on several giant screens right in the middle of Times Square. Each month, Times Square Arts and the Times Square Advertising Coalition choose one artist whose work will be showcased daily over the course of a month in a three-minute video, beginning at 11:57 p.m. and finishing at midnight — an appropriately digestible format.

headline: Amateur Sleuths on the Dinosaur Trail
text: COMANCHE NATIONAL GRASSLAND, Colo. — On a dry, chilly morning in the Southern Colorado grasslands, Bruce Schumacher led a group of AmeriCorps volunteers across the narrow, shallow Purgatoire River to an out-of-place bump in the landscape.

headline: An Examination of the Nude Figure in Turkish Art at the Pera Museum
text: ISTANBUL — As an increasingly conservative Turkey grapples with questions of free expression, it might seem to be a risky time for an exhibition examining how Turkish artists fought cultural restrictions a century ago in order to paint the nude figure.

headline: European Sympathies Lean Toward Iran in Conflict With Saudi Arabia
text: LONDON — In the days since Saudi Arabia inflamed tensions with Iran by executing 47 people, including a Shiite cleric, European observers have been quick to condemn the action, reflecting broader concern across the Continent about Saudi policy and its role in the tumult rolling through the Middle East.

headline: Healthful School Lunches Mean Healthier Students
text: Beginning in 2012, a federal law went into effect to improve the nutritional quality of school lunches. The law appears to be working, according to a new report.

headline: Chick-fil-A in Manhattan Closes to Address Health Violations
text: Chick-fil-A’s Midtown Manhattan restaurant remained closed on Monday for a fifth business day after an inspection by city health officials found several violations, including the presence of fruit flies and food stored at the wrong temperature.

headline: An Effort to Save J.M.W. Turner’s Country House
text: LONDON — J. M. W. Turner may not have been as naked in his appetites as his character was in Mike Leigh’s 2014 movie, “Mr. Turner,” but the British landscape painter certainly enjoyed life. Besides a London mansion, Turner kept a modest country house 10 miles southwest of the city in Twickenham that he designed, where he and his father relaxed, fished and entertained.

headline: ‘Design Thinking’ for a Better You
text: A strategy called “design thinking” has helped numerous entrepreneurs and engineers develop successful new products and businesses. But can design thinking help you create healthful habits?

headline: Obama to Expand Gun Background Checks and Tighten Enforcement
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will announce executive actions on Tuesday intended to expand background checks for some firearm purchases and step up federal enforcement of the nation’s gun laws, White House officials said Monday, once again trying to sidestep a gridlocked Congress on a politically divisive issue.

headline: Bombings Near Kabul Airport Add to String of Attacks Around Afghan Capital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two bombings struck near Kabul’s international airport on Monday, killing one and injuring more than 20, Afghan officials said.

headline: Hillary Clinton Tells Democrats in Iowa: ‘I Need You’
text: As her husband tried to stay on message in New Hampshire, Hillary Clinton embarked on a “River to River” tour of Iowa on Monday, with six events across the state over two days.

headline: A Warm and Rejuvenating Winter Tea Recipe
text: “One of coziest things about winter is curling up with a hot drink,” says Alissa Wagner, the co-owner and chef, along with Sabrina De Sousa, behind the chic, health-conscious Chinatown restaurant Dimes. In her mug for the new year: rejuvenating goji berry and ginger tea, which will be added to the menu this month. “It’s packed with ingredients to boost the immune system and even has maca powder for a blast of energy — a crucial bonus to help get through those long winter days,” Wagner notes. She suggests doubling the simple recipe and keeping a jar in the fridge so the tea can be warmed up at a moment’s notice.

headline: Review: ‘Killing Fields,’ on Discovery, Examines a Cold Case
text: To the bubbling mini-genre of long-form true crime — “Serial,” “The Jinx,” “Making a Murderer” — add “Killing Fields,” a new series starting on Tuesday on Discovery. At six episodes, or just over four hours minus commercials, it’s at the shorter end of the spectrum when it comes to season-long examinations of a single criminal case.

headline: Fliers Go Their Own Way With Airline Meals
text: Business travelers have plenty to think about when they fly. Once wheels come up, laptops land on the tray table. But diving into spreadsheets, business plans and email requires sustenance.

headline: Death Sentences Surge, Even as More Countries Drop Capital Punishment
text: UNITED NATIONS — The death penalty is steadily receding toward the dustbin of history worldwide, with fewer than two dozen countries relying on it at all as a form of punishment.

headline: G.M.’s Investment in Lyft Hedges Against a Future With Fewer Car Owners
text: General Motors is hedging against incursions from Silicon Valley. The Detroit carmaker’s $500 million stake in Lyft is a way into the growing ride-hailing industry and brings another partner in the development of autonomous vehicles. The deal taps into potential changes in car ownership and usage — and even employment.

headline: Hezbollah Attacks Israeli Military Vehicles
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Hezbollah attacked Israeli military vehicles on Monday in a disputed border territory, an assault the militant group said was in response to Israel’s killing last month of Samir Kuntar, a key Hezbollah operative in Syria.

headline: Review: In Julian Barnes’s ‘Keeping an Eye Open,’ Paintings Worth a Thousand Words
text: Gustave Flaubert — the subject of Julian Barnes’s magical novel-biography-meditation, “Flaubert’s Parrot” — argued that great paintings required no words of explanation. But as Mr. Barnes writes in “Keeping an Eye Open,” an illuminating new collection of essays on art, “we remain incorrigibly verbal creatures who love to explain things” — “put us in front of a picture and we chatter, each in our different way.”

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: Billybob’s Beef Brisket and the N.S.A.
text: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Activision Buys Major League Gaming to Broaden Role in E-Sports
text: Activision Blizzard, the publisher of Call of Duty and other hit video game franchises, has acquired the assets of Major League Gaming, an early organizer of professional video game competitions.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
text: Afghanistan and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

headline: Jan. 4, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Afghanistan, Egypt, Iran and India.

headline: Checking Out Pusha T’s Closet
text: Pusha T, 38, who is based in Norfolk, Va., has been involved in nearly every major facet of the hip-hop world, beginning with his early days as half of the duo Clipse. He recently signed on as president of Kanye West’s record label G.O.O.D. Music, and his latest album, “King Push: Darkest Before Dawn — the Prelude,” was released on Dec. 18. Here, five favorites from his diverse closet.

headline: Behind a Shopping Center in New Jersey, Signs of a Mass Extinction
text: MANTUA TOWNSHIP, N.J. — Behind a Lowe’s home improvement store here, scientists are methodically scraping and sifting through a quarry pit that may contain unique insights to the mass extinction that eliminated the dinosaurs.

headline: Verbatim: Hillary Clinton Won’t Respond to Donald Trump’s ‘Alternate Reality’
text: — Hillary Clinton, to a voter in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, on Monday when asked about Donald J. Trump’s attacks

headline: Review: Exploring the Work of Delia Derbyshire, an Unsung (but Often Heard) Pioneer
text: The theme from the BBC science fiction series “Dr. Who” is instantly recognizable. Less well known are the contributions of Delia Derbyshire, the pioneering British composer who arranged Ron Grainer’s score for that show into its more famous electronic incarnation.

headline: Reviews: Classical Music Albums
text: Alisa Weilerstein, cello; Inon Barnatan, piano

headline: Gianandrea Noseda to Lead National Symphony Orchestra
text: Gianandrea Noseda, an Italian conductor whose international career has recently taken off, has accepted his first major post with an American orchestra. He will be the next music director of the National Symphony Orchestra in Washington, the orchestra announced on Monday.

headline: Broadway Has a Record-Breaking Week
text: If Broadway needs a New Year’s resolution for 2016, it might try ending the year the way it did in 2015.

headline: Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington, Won’t Seek Re-election to the House
text: Representative Jim McDermott, Democrat of Washington and one of the most liberal members of the House, announced Monday that he would retire at the end of the year, ending a tumultuous 14-term congressional career.

headline: On David Bowie’s ‘Blackstar,’ Turning to Jazz for Inspiration
text: A lot of questions arose when David Bowie unveiled “Blackstar,” the 10-minute title track of his new album, as a music video in November. What was the meaning of the clip’s sci-fi surrealism? What had inspired its ominous lyrics? And, perhaps more practically, who were these musicians helping to shape its gnarly but limber style?

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Saudi Arabia, Oregon, Real Madrid

headline: Top Real Estate Stories of 2015
text: The most popular stories of the year from the Real Estate section.

headline: The Migrant Effort to Cross the English Channel
text: From Calais, France, migrants fleeing Syria’s conflict hop onto trucks or moving trains in a desperate — and often futile — effort to reach England.

headline: Birth Control Without Seeing a Doctor: Oregon Now, More States Later
text: As of Jan. 1, women in Oregon can get contraceptives directly from a pharmacy, without having to go to a doctor first. Here are answers to a few questions about the new law.

headline: Thom Browne Brings a Designer’s Eye to Cooper Hewitt Show
text: Silver-plated shoes in pairs on the floor. Spectral figures, dressed in white, lying on gurneys in an operating theater. Row after row of identically clad schoolboys, standing at attention behind identical desks. For years, the fashion designer Thom Browne has treated industry insiders to presentations that look more like art installations than like a typical runway show. This March, when the exhibition “Thom Browne Selects” opens at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum on Fifth Avenue, ordinary civilians will finally get to experience Mr. Browne’s theatrical sensibility firsthand.

headline: Report Finds Juvenile Program Failed to Reduce Robberies, but Police Are Expanding It
text: For years, the New York Police Department has tried to stop robberies before they might happen by intervening in the lives of some young offenders. The approach was heralded by the author Malcolm Gladwell in a best-selling 2013 book as an innovative way to shake up the criminal justice process. Elected leaders gave $2 million over the last two years in support.

headline: Yahoo Shuts Down Its Video Portal
text: Yahoo’s chief executive, Marissa Mayer, spent much of the last two years telling Wall Street that video was a cornerstone of her turnaround strategy.

headline: Iran, Emerging From Sanctions, Faces Crisis After Saudi Arabia Embassy Attack
text: TEHRAN — When a Saudi state executioner beheaded the prominent Shiite dissident Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr on Saturday, the Shiite theocracy in Iran took it as a deliberate provocation by its regional rival and dusted off its favored playbook, unleashing hard-liner anger on the streets.

headline: Donald Trump Finally Buys TV Ads, and Lots of Them
text: After months of waiting, Donald J. Trump has followed through on his promise to advertise, and advertise big, in early voting states in January.

headline: Bipartisan Criminal Justice Overhaul Is Haunted by Willie Horton
text: WASHINGTON — Conservatives and liberals embrace it. Some of the most influential members of the House and Senate on both the Republican and Democratic sides are pushing it. Advocacy groups across the ideological spectrum are promoting it as well.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour: A Daughter’s Tantrum, and a Lesson
text: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Saudi Arabia’s Dangerous Sectarian Game
text: WHEN Saudi Arabia executed the Shiite cleric and political dissident Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr on Saturday, the country’s leaders were aware that doing so would upset their longtime rivals in Iran. In fact, the royal court in Riyadh was probably counting on it. It got what it wanted. The deterioration of relations has been precipitous: Protesters in Tehran sacked Saudi Arabia’s embassy; in retaliation, Saudi Arabia severed diplomatic ties. More severe fallout could follow — possibly even war.

headline: G.M. Chief Mary Barra Is Named Chairwoman, Affirming Her Leadership
text: DETROIT — In a move that consolidates power at the top of the nation’s largest automaker, General Motors said on Monday that its chief executive, Mary Barra, had also been named chairwoman of its board.

headline: Streets, if Not the Air, Clear Out as Delhi Tests Car Restrictions
text: NEW DELHI — Traffic was flowing smoothly Monday morning on Outer Ring Road in South Delhi, usually jammed at that hour by subway construction and cars. An upscale market was dotted with free parking spaces. Monkeys ambled down one street in the colonial heart of the capital, easily dodging the few cars.

headline: Libya: Islamic State Attacks Oil Port
text: Islamic State militants attempted to capture an oil port along Libya’s coast early Monday, in fighting that left at least seven people dead and set fire to a storage tank of crude oil, according to witnesses. The militants began their assault on the Sidra oil port with suicide bomb attacks on a checkpoint, but by Monday afternoon, the offensive had been beaten back by guards. The Islamic State in Libya is regarded as one of the most dangerous affiliates of the extremist group outside of Iraq and Syria, and has gained strength in Libya by capitalizing on infighting among various armed factions. The attack on Monday was at least the second by the Islamic State on the Sidra port, and showed the determination of the group to expand its territory beyond its stronghold in the western Libyan town of Surt.

headline: Illinois: City Lawyer Quits After Judge Finds Misconduct
text: A lawyer for the City of Chicago resigned Monday as a federal judge found that he and a colleague had committed misconduct by waiting to turn over key evidence in a civil case about a police shooting. The lawyer, Jordan Marsh, resigned on the same day Judge Edmond E. Chang of United States District Court threw out a jury’s verdict that cleared the officers of wrongdoing and ordered Chicago to pay the plaintiffs’ legal bills. Thomas Aumann, the other lawyer, resigned in August. The ruling involves a 2011 traffic stop that ended in the fatal shooting of Darius Pinex by officers who said radio traffic had led them to pull over his vehicle. The radio recordings were not turned over to lawyers for Mr. Pinex’s estate until the trial had started, and Judge Chang said Mr. Marsh “intentionally concealed” them. Also Monday, the acting chief of Chicago’s much-criticized Independent Police Review Authority announced staffing changes that she said were designed to build trust in the agency, which has rarely faulted officers for shootings.

headline: Confidence Games
text: OK, one more round in this models versus instincts go-round. As Robert Waldmann points out over at Brad’s place, there’s a bit of bait-and-switch going on at this point; my Mundell-Fleming claim — that countries in a liquidity trap borrowing in their own currencies shouldn’t fear Greek-style confidence crises — is being transmuted into the claim that confidence never matters, and the Blanchard result that is being cited has little bearing on that assertion.

headline: Carmakers Set to Grab Spotlight at International CES
text: DETROIT — When Mark Fields attended his first consumer electronics trade show in 2007 as head of Ford Motor’s Americas division, the auto industry was hardly noticed among the thousands of tech companies gathered in Las Vegas.

headline: Woody Hochswender, Fashion Reporter, Dies at 64
text: Woody Hochswender, a reporter who covered the fashion industry for The New York Times and later wrote popular books on practicing Buddhism in everyday life, as he did, died on Thursday at his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 64.

headline: Ex-Officer Freed Pending Trial in Killing of Walter Scott
text: The former South Carolina police officer charged with murder in the April death of Walter L. Scott, an unarmed black man, was released on bond on Monday, nine months after the shooting that prompted a national outcry.

headline: Shiite Cleric Gained in Status as a Rivalry Deepened
text: BAGHDAD — In 2008, an American diplomat traveled to a poor village in eastern Saudi Arabia to visit a thin, bearded preacher who was known for criticizing the government and wrote him off as “a secondary player in local politics,” according to a report on the visit released by WikiLeaks.

headline: Arrests Begin for Migrants Who Lost Asylum Cases
text: Federal immigration enforcement agents last weekend arrested 121 migrants for deportation, Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said on Monday, starting a wave of removals of parents and children, mainly from Central America, who came during the border surge in 2014 and failed to win asylum in immigration courts.

headline: Puerto Rico Defaults on Debt Payments
text: Puerto Rico defaulted on about $174 million of debt payments on Monday, as planned, stripping cash away from its lower-ranked creditors so that higher-ranked creditors could be paid in full.

headline: Questions Over Cuomo’s Order on Homelessness
text: ALBANY — As the start of a sweeping statewide push to involuntarily remove homeless people from frigid streets loomed on Monday, questions about the practicality and impact of the plan continued to dog its architect, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

headline: A Growing Conflict in Wall St. Buyouts
text: It goes by a rather innocuous-sounding name, the sort of phrase you might breeze past in a loan document: “designated lender counsel.”

headline: Lion Point Capital to Nominate 2 Candidates to Ally Financial’s Board
text: A year after repaying taxpayers for its bailout during the financial crisis, Ally Financial, the onetime auto-lending subsidiary of General Motors, is facing new investor pressure. This time, though, it is from an upstart hedge fund, demanding two board seats and a potential sale of the company.

headline: Jason Wingreen, Actor Who Voiced Boba Fett, Dies at 95
text: Jason Wingreen, a character actor best known for playing the genial bartender Harry on the hit sitcom “All in the Family” and for voicing the bounty hunter Boba Fett in the film “The Empire Strikes Back,” died on Dec. 25 at his home in Los Angeles. He was 95.

headline: Ryan Fitzpatrick Laments After the Jets’ Big Loss, but Reflects on Returning
text: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Ryan Fitzpatrick’s eyes fluttered open around 4:30 a.m. on Monday. His weekly reflex kicked in, for the final time this season.

headline: U.S. in a Bind as Saudi Actions Test a Durable Alliance
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Monday confronted the fundamental contradiction in its increasingly tense relationship with Saudi Arabia. It could not bring itself, at least in public, to condemn the execution of a dissident cleric who challenged the royal family, for fear of undermining the fragile Saudi leadership that it desperately needs in fighting the Islamic State and ending the conflict in Syria.

headline: Vilmos Zsigmond, Cinematographer, Dies at 85; Gave Hollywood Films a New Look
text: Vilmos Zsigmond, a Hungarian-born cinematographer who helped shape the look of American movies in the 1970s, ’80s and beyond, among other things lending a hyper-real glow to the arrival of space aliens and winning an Oscar for Steven Spielberg’s 1977 science fiction extravaganza “Close Encounters of the Third Kind,” died on Friday at his home in Big Sur, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Republicans Turn Up Heat in Iowa, Setting Aside Good for Bad and Ugly
text: BURLINGTON, Iowa — Four weeks before Iowa voters start whittling down the sprawling and fractious Republican presidential field, the nomination fight is taking on a decidedly dark tenor, with candidates warning of a country left weakened by an administration that would prefer to apologize for America rather than keep it safe.

headline: The President Acts on Gun Violence
text: In the hope of combating America’s intolerable levels of gun violence, with Congress refusing to pass hugely popular gun-safety measures, President Obama is issuing a modest, limited set of executive actions on guns.

headline: Robert Stigwood, Impresario of Rock, Film and Stage, Is Dead at 81
text: Robert Stigwood, the Australian-born producer, personal manager and music executive whose blockbuster hits with the Bee Gees and work on the films “Saturday Night Fever” and “Grease” made him one of the most successful impresarios of the 1970s, died on Monday. He was 81.

headline: Bill Clinton, the Subdued Spouse, Makes His Campaign Debut
text: EXETER, N.H. — Eight years after aggressively defending his wife during her first presidential campaign, Bill Clinton was unusually understated and subdued on Monday during his first solo swing back in New Hampshire for Hillary Clinton, restraining himself even in the face of taunts from Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Family Reunites and Embraces a Fresh Set of Priorities
text: More than once when Brianna Lebron was a teenager, arguments with her mother would turn into physical fights. Ms. Lebron would leave their Harlem apartment, stay with friends or family for a week or two, and return after tensions had cooled.

headline: At Golf Outing, Furs and Friendship Trump Cold
text: With freezing temperatures finally settling into New York City on Monday, it was perfect weather for the annual Mink Open golf tournament on Staten Island.

headline: Rangers Look to Reverse Slide as Season’s Midpoint Nears
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — The Rangers, who have reached the Eastern Conference finals three of the past four seasons, seem to be at a crossroads.

headline: Saudi Arabia: A Dangerous Ally?
text: The Saudi execution of a leading Shiite cleric, and its severing of ties with Iran, has raised doubts about U.S. ties to Riyadh.

headline: Indy Winner for Sale (See Fine Print)
text: The Gooding and Company classic-car auction is usually dominated by post-World War II European sports cars from Ferrari, Porsche and Mercedes-Benz, or prewar classics from the likes of Rolls-Royce and Duesenberg.

headline: Treacherous Peak in the Alps
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — T anyone? When we last saw Jim Holland, he had made his New York Times debut with an equally alphabetic theme.

headline: Architect’s Modernist Legacy Crosses the Hudson
text: JERSEY CITY — When Charles Gwathmey died in the summer of 2009, New York City lost one of its most prolific and influential architects. Adherents of the strict rationalism of Modernist design, Mr. Gwathmey and his partner, Robert Siegel, had still managed to infuse their clean lines and grand geometries with warmth and humanity in more than 400 projects spanning four decades, including the expansion of the Guggenheim Museum and a new building for the United States Mission to the United Nations.

headline: Success Academy Principal Who Created ‘Got to Go’ List Takes Leave
text: The principal at a Success Academy charter school who created a “Got to Go” list of difficult students is taking a personal leave of absence, a Success Academy spokeswoman said on Monday.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Iowa Bus Tour:  Warm-Up Music and Leaky Pipes
text: Ted Cruz is on a six-day, 28-town swing through Iowa. These are the places, faces and culinary selections of 2016’s first proper bus tour.

headline: Cuomo Misses Point, Homeless on Streets Say
text: Bundled in blankets and enduring the frigid temperatures that arrived in New York City this week, homeless people said Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was missing the point with his executive order directing authorities to pull them off the streets when temperatures fall to 32 degrees or below.

headline: Bill Clinton Is to Campaign in Iowa
text: Bill Clinton, just off his first solo events of his wife’s campaign with two rallies in New Hampshire on Monday, will head to Iowa on Thursday.

headline: Market Regains Its Balance After Starting Year With Sell-Off
text: HONG KONG — The fears among investors that sent shares tumbling on the first trading day of the year appeared to have abated, with global markets relatively calm on Tuesday.

headline: Loss of Jarrett Jack Hangs Over a Nets Defeat
text: Before the Nets’ 103-94 loss to the Celtics on Monday at Barclays Center, Coach Lionel Hollins spoke morbidly about the season-ending injury incurred by the starting point guard Jarrett Jack last Saturday in Boston.

headline: Manager of Las Vegas Review-Journal Is Removed
text: Michael E. Schroeder, the manager of the company that purchased The Las Vegas Review-Journal last month, who became the focus of intense scrutiny after the sale, is no longer involved with the newspaper.

headline: Manhattan Apartment Prices Reached $1.15 Million Mark in 2015, Reports Say
text: In Manhattan real estate, 2015 was a year for the record books, with the median price for co-ops and condos hitting a new high of $1.15 million in the final months of the year, according to reports by major real estate firms that will be released Tuesday.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
text: If you’re looking for another true-crime series but already binge-watched “Making a Murderer,” Discovery’s “Killing Fields” begins on Tuesday night. The series unfolds in real time so you won’t be tempted to binge. If that’s a bit too real, lose yourself in the new fantasy series “The Shannara Chronicles” on MTV.

headline: Nigeria Goes to the Mall
text: WARRI, Nigeria — Groups of children wandered inside, wide-eyed at the plenty. Teenagers and adults took selfies and group photos, raving about the convenience, the security, the leisure and, not least, the air-conditioning, so silent, omnipresent and soothing.

headline: Reduce the N.F.L.’s Play Clock
text: Los Angeles — THE National Football League is looking for the safest way for its players to get smashed. How can they avoid brain injury while still getting run over by the gravy train?

headline: The Age of Small Terror
text: On New Year’s Eve some friends and family members had a drink at a bar in Tel Aviv. The next day a gunman shot up the place, killing two people and wounding at least five. When I heard about the shooting I was horrified, of course, but there was no special emotion caused by the proximity 16 hours before.

headline: Time to Talk Robots
text: Manufacturing — that is, the business of making stuff — has changed significantly over the past half-century. Perhaps you’ve noticed. While America’s share of industry has constricted, with fewer people needed to perform the same amount of work as in the past, it’s not quite time to start eulogizing.

headline: An Investment Strategy to Save the Planet
text: If one of your New Year’s resolutions was to do your part against climate change, keep reading. Now you can — with your investments.

headline: How You Can Measure a Senator as a Presidential Contender
text: Money is an easy measurement of business success. Life and death are clear signs of achievement for a neurosurgeon. Governors are rated by the laws they get passed and their state’s prosperity. Voters might use those yardsticks to choose between presidential candidates.

headline: Dalian Wanda of China May Buy Majority Stake in Legendary Entertainment
text: LOS ANGELES — The Chinese conglomerate Dalian Wanda Group, which already owns the AMC chain of multiplex cinemas, is poised to buy a majority stake in a Hollywood production company that makes blockbuster-style movies, giving the politically powerful company with close ties to the Communist Party’s ruling elite a foothold in the heart of America’s entertainment industry.

headline: News Q’s | How Do Sunni and Shia Islam Differ?
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “How Do Sunni and Shia Islam Differ?”

headline: Orange in Talks to Acquire Bouygues Telecom
text: The French telecommunications giant Orange said on Tuesday that it was in talks to acquire Bouygues Telecom, a local rival, in the latest effort to consolidate Europe’s highly fragmented cellphone market.

headline: What Are the Sounds That Make Up the Background Noise in Your Life?
text: Try the following: Take a break from whatever you’re doing, and listen closely to the sounds around you for a few minutes. What do you hear? Are you surprised by anything you hear? If you get a chance, try the same exercise someplace else, perhaps in your backyard, kitchen or classroom, or on your fire escape or street corner.

headline: How to Deal With Flight Delays and Other Travel Headaches
text: I flew out of New York City during Christmas week, when the temperature was in the 70s. I landed in southern New Mexico, hours before a giant snowstorm.

headline: Makeup That Can Withstand a Workout
text: For Eve Kessner, an instructor at SoulCycle studios in Brooklyn Heights and Union Square, getting ready for the gym each morning goes beyond brushing her teeth and pulling on a pair of leggings. Before heading out to classes that often start before 8 a.m., she applies Eyeko Sport Waterproof Mascara and a face luminizer by RMS Beauty or Josie Maran Cosmetics.

headline: Samantha Hunt’s ‘Mr. Splitfoot’
text: I wonder if the best stories are those hardest to categorize. Bildungsroman or romance? Picaresque or metafiction? Stories change shape as one reads them. Understandings are loaded in, revised, discarded. Then, when the book is closed, a kind of spirit image remains in the mind, a revenant. Sometimes a reader knows that a lasting connection has been made only by the intensity of the effect, the memory and aftershock, after the book is back on the shelf.

headline: The Cultural Contours of Saving a Life
text: A decade ago, while I was still a fledgling doctor in training, I worked in a tiny rural hospital in a village in West Africa. By our American standards, the word “hospital” would have been a fictional exaggeration of this barest-bones facility, but here, on the Liberia-Sierra Leone border, it was the only place that offered people access to Western medicine, should they seek it. The next hospital over — bigger but not much shinier — was at least a six-hour drive away in a four-wheel-drive all-terrain vehicle on a good day, without any rains melting the treacherous dirt roads. About two weeks after I arrived there, I was caring for a young woman who was seriously ill. At that point, I was bold enough to take charge medically, but still barely able to see the outline of the big picture — the cultural contours within which I should have been operating.

headline: The Empty Threat of ‘Boots on the Ground’
text: Since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, the United States has fought two very long, very costly and, in the end, not very successful wars. Barack Obama was elected president in no small part because he promised to bind up the nation’s wounds and withdraw its troops. Yet the enemy, in the forms of Al Qaeda and the Islamic State, remains and must be confronted, in part, the Obama administration believes, by the American military. The president has struggled to find a language that distinguishes between force, which most Americans want, and war, which they don’t. He and his team have therefore promised, vowed, pledged that, come what may, they will not use ‘‘boots on the ground.’’

headline: To Catch a Rapist
text: A dull, frigid winter morning. Overhead, the sky was locked in gray, only occasionally releasing an ashen, icy flake or two, more like iron shavings than snow. On the third floor of the New Haven police station, Detective Kris Cuddy had just finished interviewing the mother of a young rape victim. After escorting the woman downstairs, she was returning to her office in the Special Victims Unit. Her square-heeled boots made a quick, hard sound as she left the elevators, a tock-tock-tock that could be heard above the ringing phones and cubicle chatter. The detective had an Irish face — blue-eyed, pale-skinned, puckish, her coppery brown hair shorn close at the sides into a fauxhawk. She was one of only four investigators in the S.V.U., and she had 32 cases open at the moment. But during interviews with victims or their family members, she never displayed any sign of the pressure she was under. Her manner was steady and reassuring. So we’re here to discuss an incident that happened recently, she would begin, making only a vague allusion to the matter at hand before stepping back to allow people to tell the story in their own way. She would offer water, offer a tissue. Let them talk, circling back later to gather more details. At the end of interviews with victims, she almost always told them they were brave.

headline: 1891: Battles With Indians
text: NEW YORK — There was a severe engagement last night [Jan. 4] between the United States forces under the command of General Miles and the Sioux, near Gordon, Nebraska. The fighting was desperate, and the Hotchkiss guns were freely used by the military. The details of the engagement are not to hand. There is a rumor that General Miles was killed in the battle, but this is not credited at army headquarters. According to a telegram received late to-day at Chicago, a battle between the troops and the Indians was fought to-day near the Pine Ridge Agency. Hundreds of Indians were killed, and the troops also suffered heavily. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 6, 1891

headline: 1941: Mexico Reports New Nazi Plot

These German agents, with headquarters in Mexico City and Madrid, were said already to have split the Cabinet of President Avila Camacho into two camps. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 6, 1941

headline: How Moby Begins Every Single Morning
text: “My biggest hope for the new year is that we, collectively, stop doing things that we all know don’t work,” says Moby. “We all know which things are bad and not working, but we keep doing them anyway, which is, simply, stupid.” One thing that does work for the musician: his daily breakfast smoothie, which he’s adapted over eight years from a simple banana, kale and berry recipe. It has evolved to include specialty supplements like omega-rich DHA oil and protein-packed chia seeds; now, he says, “It’s like drinking a giant antioxidant battery every morning.” A version is available on the menu at Little Pine, the new all-day dining vegan restaurant Moby recently opened in Silver Lake, Los Angeles — though, he admits, “The rest of the Little Pine menu is a little less virtuous.”

That I remembered his face, but not the fact that he was missing both arms and a leg at the groin, caught me totally off guard.

headline: Gerard and Kelly to Perform at Schindler House  and Glass House

Beginning this weekend, the dancers and visual artists Brennan Gerard and Ryan Kelly will use two of the country’s most beloved 20th-century houses – the Schindler House, designed by Rudolph M. Schindler in West Hollywood, Calif., and the Glass House, Philip Johnson’s masterpiece in New Canaan, Conn. – as walk-in texts for a performance work focusing on what they describe as “themes of queer intimacy and domestic space within the legacies of modernist architecture.”

headline: Thai Street Food, Now at the Lucky Bee on the Lower East Side
text: The Lucky Bee Rupert Noffs and his business partner, the chef Matty Bennett, are taking a farm-to-table approach to Thai street food. It’s easy for Mr. Bennett, who was at the Fat Radish, a locavore spot. The setting, dominated by a big bar, is splashed with vibrant pink. “The pink was my idea,” said Mr. Noffs, “and I think it works.” In the front, snacks like salt-and-pepper chicken wings and oysters with nahm jim chile sauce are dispensed. The menu has crisp pork belly with palm sugar caramel and chile vinegar; grilled squid with sunchokes, coconut and shaved bottarga; and a green curry of vegetables with pickled mustard greens. The cocktail list features drinks made with honey: A dollar of each drink sold goes to the New York City Beekeepers Association. The partners hope to raise bees on the roof: 252 Broome Street (Ludlow Street), 917-262-0329, luckybeenyc.com.

headline: Deadly Snits
text: Josh Marshall has a great term for what is happening in Oregon: white privilege performance art. We have people engaging in armed insurrection over the vast oppression of being asked to pay a small fee when grazing their animals on public land; surely an important part of the story is the fact that the perpetrators know that they won’t face the consequences that would follow if, you know, some nonwhite group pulled a similar stunt — and they’re be Fox News heroes forever after.

headline: Review: Jennifer Lopez as a Conflicted Cop in ‘Shades of Blue’
text: On “Law & Order,” the show that anchored NBC for years, things were generally pretty straightforward: crime, investigation, arrest, prosecution. Nothing is straightforward on “Shades of Blue,” the network’s newest police show, which begins on Thursday. Jennifer Lopez plays a dirty Brooklyn detective on a crew full of them, and the choices that confront her and others aren’t between right and wrong, but between damage-control options.

text: Every letter, in its way, is a love letter, at least every personal one. The letters of the British novelist and philosopher Iris Murdoch contained more yearning than most. She was, to borrow the title of one of her novels, a kind of sacred and profane love machine.

headline: Help Sought to Close 18-Minute Gap in San Bernardino Inquiry
text: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — Federal investigators announced Tuesday that they had accounted for almost all the four hours between the time that a husband-and-wife terrorist team killed 14 people at a holiday party here last month and the time that they died in a bloody police shootout — all except for an 18-minute window.

headline: A Cold Remedy You Can Make at Home
text: “In retrospect, I think I was a little ahead of my time,” says Barbara Close, the founder and CEO of the healing-arts brand Naturopathica. When she opened her East Hampton store in 1995, people would stop in and “take these herbal tinctures and say, ‘Ooh, these taste bitter’ — they didn’t really understand how to use them,” she recalls. Back then, she says, the path to health was: “You get sick, you hope to get an appointment with your doctor, you get a prescription and it treats your symptoms. Now, wellness has become mainstream.” And the biggest change, according to Close, may be how we approach it: “It’s the periods in between doctor appointments that are important. What are the rituals of self-care that you can do preventatively to keep your health and vitality at its best?” She offers answers aplenty at Naturopathica Chelsea, her second brick-and-mortar location.

headline: ‘13 Hours’ Gives Benghazi Attack Cinematic Treatment

headline: With Film Supply Dwindling, a Photographer Known for Huge Polaroid Images Is Retiring
text: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — To make a good portrait, the photographer Henri Cartier-Bresson once counseled, “you have to try and put your camera between the skin of a person and his shirt.” It would be tricky for any portraitist, but especially daunting for Elsa Dorfman. Her camera is taller than she is, weighs as much as an N.F.L. linebacker and looks, from certain vantage points, like a 1970s liquor cabinet.

headline: The Hear-Nothing Gun Crowd
text: Sometimes in American politics it seems as if we are all talking past each other, that whatever one side says about an issue like, say, taxes zooms right past the other side. The current fight over gun control is not one of those moments. It is a howling storm of misrepresentation, sadly almost entirely from one side. This week’s developments fit the pattern.

headline: Michigan: Emergency Declared Over Flint’s Water
text: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan declared a state of emergency for the Flint area on Tuesday as concerns grew about the health effects of lead-tainted water there. His order, which followed emergency declarations by the city and county governments, came on the day federal officials announced an investigation of the contamination. Mr. Snyder’s administration has been criticized as slow to respond to residents’ concerns about their water. Last week, he apologized and announced staffing changes at the state agency that oversees environmental quality. Flint, which had long received water from Lake Huron provided by Detroit’s water utility, began drawing its water from the Flint River in 2014 in an effort to save money while a new pipeline was built. Residents soon complained about rashes and strange odors from the river water, but city and state officials mostly insisted that it was safe to drink. Last year, elevated levels of lead were found in children’s blood, and in October, Flint switched back to Detroit’s water system. Mr. Snyder, a Republican, said Tuesday that the emergency declaration would allow for more state resources to be used in addressing the effects of the tainted water.

headline: Judge Rules for Cosby’s Wife
text: Camille Cosby will not have to sit for a deposition Wednesday in a lawsuit filed against her husband, the entertainer Bill Cosby, a federal judge in Massachusetts ruled Tuesday, as he granted Mrs. Cosby’s request to postpone any deposition until her lawyers have a chance to appeal.

headline: Why the Government Owns So Much Land in the West

headline: This Land Is Your Land. Or Is It?
text: Since last weekend, armed men have been in control of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon. Incensed by the sentencing of local ranchers to jail time for burning public lands, the protesters want the federal government out of the land business. Their stated goal is to return the refuge to the locals so that “people can reclaim their resources.” But this raises an important question: Why does justice demand that the land and resources belong to the locals instead of the commons? What makes property private?

headline: ‘See Also’ Notations

headline: Putin’s Year in Scandals
text: GOING into 2016, Vladimir V. Putin is a very different politician from the one he was a year ago. His most significant changes have little to do with what he has done in the last 12 months. Instead they were wrought by the justice systems of two foreign countries — Britain and Spain — and a slew of Russian and Western journalists and activists. Thanks to all these disparate efforts, there has emerged a vivid, comprehensive and, most important, public picture of allegations of corruption and connections to organized crime that in the past had been the province of rumors or maverick investigations publishers wouldn’t dare to print.

headline: ­In Oregon, Myth Mixes With Anger

Yet Malheur is a place of bitterly contested human histories that remain potent today.

headline: Amid Conflict, Life and Art in Goma
text: Last July, Natalie Keyssar traveled to Goma in eastern Democratic Republic of Congo set on telling a story about the region that was different from the many narratives about its refugee population or the scars from recent wars. Instead, she spent the month among the area’s youth, letting them dictate the subject matter.

headline: Jaden Smith for Louis Vuitton: The New Man in a Skirt

headline: Retiring a U.N. Building Not Quite Fit for the World Stage
text: UNITED NATIONS — In New York, “temporary” train stations, “temporary” art installations and “temporary” sidewalk sheds can endure for a decade or more. So it is a marvel to report that an interim building will turn out to be just that.

headline: In Iowa, Ted Cruz Savors Lead Role
text: ONAWA, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas insists he does not want to be seen as the front-runner in the Iowa caucuses. “The only way I know how to run is as an underdog,” he said here after a speech on Tuesday, waving off any Joe Namath-style guarantee of victory.

headline: Morristown, N.J., Historic With a Lively Downtown

headline: An Artist Stands Before Her Fun House Mirror
text: LOS ANGELES — On a recent Friday afternoon, Genevieve Gaignard, a photographer, collagist and installation artist, was sitting on her bed in the room she rents in the Echo Park neighborhood. For the last year, Ms. Gaignard, who takes self-portraits costumed as various alter egos she imagines, then builds fictional domestic spaces for them, has lived in this nondescript, book-filled and thoroughly carpeted apartment with a professional couple in their late 20s, their chatty lime-green parrot and three cats.
