text: Mr. Raeburn presents his vision for fall 2016 men’s.

headline: The Larger, but Quieter Than Bundy, Push to Take Over Federal Land
text: DENVER — Ken Ivory, a Republican state representative from Utah, has been roaming the West with an alluring pitch to cattle ranchers, farmers and conservatives upset with how Washington controls the wide-open public spaces out here: This land is your land, he says, and not the federal government’s.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Diligent Courting of Evangelicals Pays Off in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — On Sunday, Pastor Bradley Cranston stood at his pulpit in Burlington, Iowa, and, citing Exodus 18:21 (“select out of all the people able men who fear God ... as leaders”), endorsed Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, urging his parishioners to also consider voting for him.

headline: Princess Cristina’s Tax Fraud Trial Set to Begin in Spain
text: MADRID — Princess Cristina of Spain is scheduled to appear in court on Monday, accused of tax fraud as part of a corruption case centered on money embezzled from public contracts that is bringing a member of the country’s royal family to trial for the first time.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: The awards season officially begins with the Golden Globes, hosted again by Ricky Gervais. CBS’s empowered women return in new episodes. And “Je Suis Charlie” looks back at the 2015 terrorist attack on the French satire magazine Charlie Hebdo.

text: Fall 2016 designs from Pringle of Scotland.

headline: London’s Men’s Wear Shows Revel in the Club Scene
text: LONDON — Under intermittent rain and the occasional occlusion of cement-colored skies, London Collections Men began the international fall fashion season for men’s wear on Friday, so hot on the heels of the new year, joked Dylan Jones, the editor of British GQ and the L.C.M. chairman, that “we like to think of it as a continuation of New Year’s Eve.”

headline: Nets Dismiss Hollins and Reassign King; Owner Vows to Instill ‘Winning Culture’
text: The Nets, in a midseason shake-up after years of reckless spending and trades, announced Sunday that the team had fired Coach Lionel Hollins and reassigned General Manager Billy King.

headline: Hospital Aided by Doctors Without Borders Is Bombed in Yemen
text: CAIRO — A hospital in northern Yemen supported by the medical charity Doctors Without Borders was struck by ordnance early Sunday, killing at least four people and causing several buildings to collapse, the organization said in a statement.

headline: Strong Showing for ‘The Revenant’ at Box Office
text: A savvy 20th Century Fox marketing campaign combined with the raw star power of Leonardo DiCaprio helped drive “The Revenant” to a grizzly-size $38 million in weekend ticket sales, adding sizzle to a soft box office season for prestige films.

headline: Sold on a View, New Year’s Revelers Fall to a Forgery Scheme
text: Getting into the LOL Times Square Comedy Club should not be difficult: Go to Times Square, and when a person with an LOL sign or identification badge approaches you and asks, “Hey, do you like comedy?” say yes. You’re in. Make your way to the club on Seventh Avenue and head upstairs to the windowless bar and black-box theater crowded with tables for two. Enjoy the show.

text: Sarah Burton presents fall 2016 men’s wear designs for Alexander McQueen.

headline: An Uncertain New Chapter in Sinaloa, Home State of ‘El Chapo’
text: LOS MOCHIS, Mexico — The capture of the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera stunned the world and earned President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico a much-needed round of applause. Yet here in the narcotics kingpin’s home state, Sinaloa, the news landed with a thud.

headline: Young, Mexican and Ready to Raise Their Political Voices
text: Bundled up against the cold, Janet Perez walked down Willis Avenue in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx this month, politely approaching parents waiting for their children after school.

headline: A Primer on the N.F.L. Relocating a Team to Los Angeles
text: The N.F.L. has talked about returning to the Los Angeles area almost from the moment the Raiders and the Rams left after the 1995 season. All the talk may end when the 32 owners meet Tuesday and Wednesday in Houston, where they are expected to vote on proposals that would allow one or two teams to return to the nation’s second-largest market. Here is a primer:

headline: Golden Globes 2016: Highlights and Analysis
text: Dispatches from the red carpet and backstage — and thoughts from our reporters, editors and critics watching the show.

headline: In Final State of the Union Address, Obama Aims to Set Tone for ’16 Campaign
text: WASHINGTON — For the final time, President Obama will mount the rostrum in the House chamber on Tuesday to deliver a State of the Union address. But this time, aides said, he will not bring with him a long list of proposals that will languish in Congress — after all these years, a victory of experience over hope.

text: The fall 2016 show from Dunhill.

headline: Obama’s Legacy May Hinge on Endurance of His Achievements
text: Republicans say that President Obama is too passive on foreign policy. A few Democrats see him that way when it comes to politics. The president, however, is planning an aggressive finale.

text: The latest designs from Gieves & Hawkes.

headline: Ellen Stovall, Three-Time Cancer Survivor and Advocate, Dies at 69
text: Ellen Stovall, a three-time cancer survivor and, as the president of the National Coalition for Cancer Survivorship, a prominent advocate for patients dealing with a host of problems during and after their cancer treatment, died on Tuesday in Rockville, Md. She was 69.

headline: Hillary Clinton Attacks Bernie Sanders Over Gun Control
text: Hillary Clinton pressed Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on his gun control record during her appearance on “Face the Nation” on CBS on Sunday, and brushed off “dead end” attacks from Donald J. Trump and other Republicans about Bill Clinton’s past scandals.

headline: Obama’s Guests at State of the Union Include Syrian Refugee and Mexican Immigrant
text: WASHINGTON — A Syrian refugee, a former illegal immigrant who went on to serve in the United States Army and the lead plaintiff in the Supreme Court case last year legalizing same-sex marriage will be among the official guests on Tuesday as President Obama delivers his final State of the Union address.

headline: With Ball’s Lace Facing Wrong Way, Seahawks Win by a Thread
text: MINNEAPOLIS — There is only one lace, threaded through 16 holes, on an official N.F.L. game ball. When a holder sets the ball for a kicker, the rule of thumb is “laces out” — meaning the holder should rotate the ball to put the lace on the side facing the goal posts. Something about the way that white strip meets the kicker’s foot can make the ball fly in unpredictable directions.

headline: Mohammad Javad Zarif: Saudi Arabia’s Reckless Extremism
text: THE world will soon celebrate the implementation of the landmark agreement that resolves the unnecessary, albeit dangerous, crisis over Iran’s nuclear program. All parties hoped, and continue to believe, that the resolution of the nuclear issue would enable us to focus on the serious challenge of extremism that is ravaging our region — and the world.

headline: Suspect Shot by Paris Police Tied to German Migrant House
text: PARIS — The man shot to death by the police in Paris last week as he approached a police station with a meat cleaver and fake explosives was a petty criminal who used multiple identities and who lived in a house for asylum seekers in Germany’s most populous state, the German police said on Sunday.

headline: Illumina Creating Company to Develop Early-Stage Cancer Detection Test
text: Some people see it as the holy grail in oncology — a simple blood test that can detect any kind of cancer at an early stage, when it is easiest to treat and possibly cure.

headline: Catalonia’s New Leader Vows to Continue Secessionist Drive
text: MADRID — The new leader of the regional government of Catalonia told lawmakers on Sunday that he would carry out a plan to separate the region from the rest of Spain.

headline: Yahoo’s Brain Drain Shows a Loss of Faith Inside the Company
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer, the glamorous, geeky Google executive hired to turn around Yahoo in 2012, used to inspire hope in Yahoo’s work force just by visiting the cafeteria for ice cream and mingling.

headline: Review: In Donna Uchizono’s ‘Sticky Majesty,’ Two Queens and Their Handmaidens
text: As its title suggests, the choreographer Donna Uchizono’s “Sticky Majesty” features a pronounced hierarchy. There are only five dancers, all women, divided into groups, one of two and one of three. All have solo opportunities, but it’s the two (Molly Lieber and Heather Olson) who dominate and ordain, and the three (Hadar Ahuvia, Sarah Iguchi, Meg Weeks) who are courtiers or attendants.

headline: Review: ‘Au Revoir, Pierre,’ a Celebration of Boulez
text: Organized at short notice after the death of Pierre Boulez on Tuesday, “Au Revoir, Pierre,” a tribute concert on Saturday at Le Poisson Rouge, showed off the qualities long associated with Mr. Boulez and his music: seriousness, precision, experimentation.

headline: Review: American Realness Illuminates Racial Identities With 3 Dance Works
text: “Where may I kiss you?” You don’t expect to hear that question while waiting around a theater lobby for a performance to begin, especially not from a veiled stranger. But Keyon Gaskin established a certain intimacy early on in his 40-minute solo, “its not a thing,” at Abrons Arts Center on Friday. Cloaked in black with a scarf draped over his face, Mr. Gaskin approached individual guests, inquired about their fears (“When were you afraid today?”) and offered a kiss, planted in black lipstick.

headline: Kate del Castillo, Actress Tied to ‘El Chapo,’ Set Up Sean Penn Meeting
text: MEXICO CITY — Last fall was a busy time for the Mexican television star Kate del Castillo. She became an American citizen, advertised her new tequila and appeared tirelessly to promote her new film “The 33,” a retelling of the story of the trapped Chilean miners in 2010, in which she stars alongside Antonio Banderas as his valiant wife.

headline: Review: In ‘Dog Days,’ a Family Clawing for Survival
text: It’s not surprising that “Dog Days,” the utterly bleak and musically original if heavy-handed opera by the composer-librettist team of David T. Little and Royce Vavrek, has won widespread attention since its acclaimed 2012 premiere. With its boldly eclectic score and powerful libretto, “Dog Days” tells an apocalyptic story unstintingly. The director Robert Woodruff’s gritty staging opened on Saturday at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, presented by the center and Beth Morrison Projects as part of the Prototype Festival. At the end, the courageous cast and creative team received lusty bravos from many in the hall.

headline: Review: In ‘The Last Hotel,’ a Pair Weighs Whether Someone Checks Out for Good
text: What was it that the Eagles sang about the ominous Hotel California? “You can check out any time you like, but you can never leave”?

headline: Review: Dez Mona’s ‘Sága,’ Acoustic Time Travel in a Song Cycle About Roots
text: For decades pop music has looked to global influences to enrich its sound. But a few years ago the Belgian band Dez Mona, which had previously been known for its theatrical jazz-tinged glam rock, sought inspiration from a largely uncharted continent: the distant past. On Saturday evening the group presented the fruits of that expedition, “Sága,” at National Sawdust in Williamsburg as part of this winter’s Prototype Festival. For this theatrical song cycle about roots and longing, Dez Mona teamed up with the Belgian ensemble Baroque Orchestration X, a group dedicated to performing new music on period instruments like the harpsichord, theorbo and viola da gamba. The result was an evening of unfailingly gorgeous music that felt exotic and familiar at once.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Gun Control in America
text: President Barack Obama made a push for tighter laws to curb gun deaths in America last week, announcing plans for executive actions that would increase background checks for gun buyers. He also wrote an Op-Ed in The Times addressing the politics surrounding the issue.

headline: Review: ‘A Funny Thing Happened,’ Insights into What Made the Musicals Sing
text: Only aficionados of Broadway musical history are aware that “Getting to Know You,” the classic teacher-student introductory song from “The King and I” that seems set in stone, had two earlier incarnations. Originally written for Nellie Forbush to sing in “South Pacific,” it was titled “Suddenly Lovely,” then renamed “Suddenly Lucky,” before it was dropped and later equipped with new lyrics for “The King and I.”

But this blur is particularly enjoyable, a concoction involving Hitler’s dog, a Finnish guy’s dog, Iraq and the absurdities of international relations. Oh, and musical cats.

headline: G.M. Trial, Bank Earnings and December Retail Numbers
text: General Motors on Monday will face a trial in the first of six so-called “bellwether” cases in 2016 over deadly defective ignition switches in its vehicles. The bellwethers, frequently used in product liability litigation when many people may have similar claims, could help G.M. and lawyers for the plaintiffs work out trial strategies or help determine whether to settle. The first case going to trial involves Robert Scheuer, who was injured when his 2003 Saturn Ion crashed into a tree in May 2014. Of the six bellwethers, three were picked by lawyers for the plaintiffs and three by the defense. —Danielle Ivory

headline: The Obama Boom
text: Do you remember the “Bush boom”? Probably not. Anyway, the administration of George W. Bush began its tenure with a recession, followed by an extended “jobless recovery.” By the summer of 2003, however, the economy began adding jobs again. The pace of job creation wasn’t anything special by historical standards, but conservatives insisted that the job gains after that trough represented a huge triumph, a vindication of the Bush tax cuts.

headline: Governors Get Smarter on Medicaid
text: Republican and Democratic governors in several states that have refused to expand their Medicaid programs are now seeking to do so, but will need approval from Republican-dominated legislatures. Even if they are not moved by humanitarian concerns to improve health care for their poorest citizens, recalcitrant legislators should at least see the folly of rejecting extremely generous matching funds. The federal government will pay 100 percent of the cost for newly eligible enrollees in 2016 and 95 percent in 2017, phasing down to 90 percent in 2020 and subsequent years.

headline: When Philosophy Lost Its Way
text: The history of Western philosophy can be presented in a number of ways. It can be told in terms of periods — ancient, medieval and modern. We can divide it into rival traditions (empiricism versus rationalism, analytic versus Continental), or into various core areas (metaphysics, epistemology, ethics). It can also, of course, be viewed through the critical lens of gender or racial exclusion, as a discipline almost entirely fashioned for and by white European men.

headline: ‘The Expatriates,’ by Janice Y. K. Lee
text: A female, funny Henry James in Asia, Janice Y. K. Lee is vividly good on the subject of Americans abroad. “The Expatriates,” her second novel, is set like her first, “The Piano Teacher,” in Hong Kong, and the two books taken together are a rich education in an almost century of cruelty, exploitation, deep pockets and good parties in the city — a setting that becomes a complicated character in its own right. In her new book, Lee observes an affluent community of contemporary Westerners, but more specifically, those who “crossed over into that other country of motherhood,” another foreign land requiring expatriation.

headline: ‘The Cosmopolites: The Coming of the Global Citizen,’ by Atossa Araxia Abrahamian
text: In 2008 the United Arab Emirates came up with a novel solution to their bidoon “problem” — the presence of thousands of stateless persons within their territories. Most bidoon descend from families who resided there long before the creation of the U.A.E.; many were from nomadic tribes and simply failed to register as nationals at the time. Yet they have been denied citizenship. That status would give them access to the myriad benefits accorded full members of this wealthy oil state — from free health care and education, to a guaranteed income, subsidized utilities, a marriage bonus, land and an interest-free house loan. Instead, they are categorized as illegal immigrants.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Arguments Over Requiring Union Members to Pay Dues

headline: New York Today: Every Dog Has Its Train
text: Updated 8:43 a.m.

headline: Your Monday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Senators Return From Holiday With 2016 Elections Fresh on Their Minds
text: The Senate returns to Washington on Monday, opening a 2016 in which Republicans will move cautiously on the legislative front to try to protect their endangered incumbents and their Senate majority.

headline: Marco Rubio Continues a General Election Approach to Primaries
text: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida will be taking a detour from the campaign trail this week to visit somewhere he is not seen very often these days: the Capitol.

headline: Silence Is the Enemy for Doctors Who Have Depression
text: In my first year of training as a doctor, I knew something was wrong with me. I had trouble sleeping. I had difficulty feeling joy. I was prone to crying at inopportune times. Even worse, I had trouble connecting with patients. I felt as if I couldn’t please anyone, and I felt susceptible to feelings of despair and panic.

headline: Sotheby’s, in a Gamble, Acquires Boutique Art Advisory Firm
text: In a highly unorthodox move bound to shake up the auction world, Sotheby’s is paying up to $85 million for a boutique art advisory business run partly by a former executive at its archrival, Christie’s.

headline: Belgium’s Tax Break to Multinational Companies Is Ruled Illegal
text: BRUSSELS — The European Commission said on Monday that a corporate tax break that Belgium granted to at least 35 companies, amounting to total reductions equivalent to about $765 million, was illegal.

headline: Two Debates Set the Course for a Contentious Final Sprint
text: There are two significant presidential debates over the next seven days as the races hurtle toward the first casting of votes.

headline: Knits and Shearling Among the Trends at London Collections Men
text: LONDON — Fashion is often centered on the new: a different material, the unexpected silhouette. But by the same measure, the first commandment for any commercially viable brand is always to know thy customer. And pushing men out of their comfort zones can be particularly high risk.

headline: Man Claiming to Be American Tells CNN He’s Detained in North Korea
text: SEOUL, South Korea — A man claiming to be a naturalized American citizen told CNN that he has been held in North Korea since October on charges of spying for the South, the network reported Monday.

headline: The Fashion Crowd Considers J.W. Anderson’s Grindr Debut
text: LONDON — The news that Jonathan Anderson — a.k.a. J. W. Anderson — would live-stream his fall men’s show exclusively on Grindr, the gay social-networking app, has been the whispered, and then not-so-whispered, talk of the first days of men’s fashion week here. “Now there’s a show that would’ve looked good on Grindr,” one showgoer cracked to another about a collection that featured men in cutout trousers and one very visible pair of thong underwear.

headline: Trans-Canada Highway Remains Split After Bridge Failure
text: OTTAWA — The Trans-Canada Highway, the largest road connecting the country’s east and west, remained severed on Monday after a new bridge separated from its moorings.

headline: Shire-Baxalta Merger Will Create a Giant in Drugs for Rare Diseases
text: After a courtship of more than six months, Shire won over its fellow drug maker Baxalta on Monday in a deal valued at about $31 billion. The combination would create a giant in the treatment of rare diseases.

headline: Convoys Enter Besieged Syrian Towns to Deliver Food and Medical Aid
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The first trucks from a convoy carrying food and medical aid entered the besieged Syrian town of Madaya on Monday, only to discover harrowing scenes of desperation, including 400 people who needed immediate medical evacuation, United Nations officials said Monday night.

headline: Kymeta Raises $62 Million in Investment Led by Bill Gates
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Kymeta is a start-up focusing on using tiny satellite antennas. But the company has secured a new fund-raising round from some big backers, including Bill Gates.

headline: Popular Approval For Stronger Gun Safety, But Scant Optimism
text: In his final year in office President Obama is choosing to buck the politics of the gun in America. Though the gun lobby’s supposed power at the ballot box has never been clearly established, Democrats feared it enough to avoid the gun issue for decades, especially once they lost control of the House in 1994 after roiling opponents by enacting the stronger gun controls of the Brady law.

headline: Manchu, Former Empire’s Language, Hangs On at China’s Edge
text: QAPQAL XIBE AUTONOMOUS COUNTY, China — Loyal to the core and prized for their horsemanship, several thousand Manchu soldiers heeded the emperor’s call and, with families and livestock in tow, embarked in 1764 on a trek that took them from northeastern China to the most distant fringes of the Qing dynasty empire, the Central Asian lands now known as Xinjiang.

headline: Alabama Governor’s Use of Oil Spill Funds for Mansion Draws Criticism
text: MONTGOMERY, Ala. — In a capital where almost anything can turn contentious, there has mostly been a consensus on a matter of housekeeping for close to two decades: A rehabilitation of a ramshackle governor’s mansion on the gulf coast would be political folly.

headline: Daily Report: The Tech News Cycle is About to Ramp Up
text: Just 11 days into 2016, it has already been a busy period for tech news — and that’s about to ramp up further.

headline: Printing a Paper Backup of Your iCloud Contacts
text: Q. How can I print my iCloud contact list from the web?

headline: 1916: Draft Is Likely In Great Britain
text: LONDON — The debate on the second reading of the Military Service Bill opened in the House of Commons today [Jan. 11] with every indication that Mr. Asquith’s proposals for limited compulsory service will be adopted by a very large majority. After a meeting of the Irish Nationalists today, Mr. Redmond has announced in Parliament the withdrawal of Irish opposition to the Bill, and the Government’s only serious opponents are now a section of the Labor Party and a few Radicals. Even in regard to the attitude of organized labor, a settlement of differences seems probable.— The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 12, 1916

headline: Ringling Bros. Elephants Are Taking Early Retirement to Florida
text: The days of lumbering elephants performing under big-top tents are coming to an end sooner than planned.

headline: Thom Sweeney: Fall 2016
text: The fall 2016 men’s collection from Thom Sweeney.

headline: Trial of 2nd Baltimore Officer in Freddie Gray Case Is Delayed
text: BALTIMORE — The second and most important trial of the six Baltimore police officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray was abruptly postponed Monday amid a legal dispute over whether the state’s star witness — another officer whose own trial ended in a hung jury last month — would be forced to testify.

headline: Starboard Value Pushes Macy’s to Pursue Deals for Its Real Estate
text: A prominent activist shareholder urged Macy’s on Monday to continue pursuing potential deals for its real estate, bringing in partners to help generate cash from the retailer’s famed holdings like Herald Square in Manhattan.

headline: Drug Companies to Try a Unified Front Against Cancer
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Some leading pharmaceutical companies are joining forces in an effort to speed the testing of new types of cancer drugs that harness the body’s immune system to battle tumors.

headline: ‘I Am Drowning.’ The Voices of People With Medical Debt.
text: More than 1,200 readers wrote us to answer our question: “How have medical bills changed your life?”

headline: Burberry: Fall 2016
text: Christopher Bailey’s take on fall 2016 men’s for Burberry.

headline: The Other Side of Billionaires
text: Re “Privilege, pathology and power” (Jan. 2-3): Paul Krugman implicates all billionaires as smug, selfish, pathological and Republican. Hence they are without empathy, out of touch, and use their money and power to influence elections. What about George Soros, Eli Broad, David Geffen and Tom Steyer? Are they without gobs of money, ego or the desire to inject their own “statist” principles into elections? Have they not sworn to spend countless millions in an effort to “re-shape” America? Mr. Krugman would do better to write about both sides of the billionaires’ battle.

headline: Lessons, and Parallels, in Jeb Bush’s Failed Run for Governor
text: MIAMI — A month after President George Bush lost his 1992 re-election bid, Jeb Bush summoned two Republican pollsters here to lunch. He told them that he intended to run for governor of Florida in two years and wanted their help.

headline: Swedish Police, Accused of Cover-Up, Look Into Reports of Sex Assault at Festival
text: LONDON — The police in Sweden, responding to accusations of a cover-up, said on Monday that they were investigating why the public had not been informed about sexual assaults by men reported to be migrants at a festival in Stockholm last summer.

headline: Share Your Memories of David Bowie
text: Thousands of artists, friends and fans have turned to social media to share their memories of David Bowie, who died Sunday, two days after his 69th birthday. And on our site, readers like Nina Castro of Cincinnati remembered his music as being part of her life every day. “It was New York City, 1973. He was my soundtrack for strutting up and down 8th Street, in [Greenwich] Village.”

headline: 焦糖柠檬意面
text: Melissa Clark做了焦糖柠檬，然后把它们加入意面，并装点上了芹菜叶子。

headline: Liam Hodges: Fall 2016
text: Men’s wear designs for next fall from Liam Hodges.

headline: 8 Recipes for Right Now
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Reactions to an Innovative Study on Sexism
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: Fire at Rights Group’s Offices Was Not Arson, Israeli Investigators Say
text: JERUSALEM — A fire in the Jerusalem offices of an Israeli human rights group that monitors the treatment of Palestinians was caused by an electrical problem, and was not the result of arson, officials with Israel’s Fire and Rescue Services said Monday.

headline: Russian Shares and Ruble Fall as Oil Prices Continue to Tumble
text: MOSCOW — Russia’s main stock indexes plummeted on Monday, the first day of trading after a lengthy winter holiday here, as the drop in oil prices cast a pall over the country’s energy-dependent economy.

headline: The New Republic Is for Sale Again
text: Chris Hughes, the Facebook co-founder who bought The New Republic in 2012 and prompted a revolt among staff members and contributors  when he tried to remake it, said on Monday that he had decided to put the magazine up for sale.

headline: 1941: Germany and Italy Join Forces
text: The first joint action by German and Italian airmen in the Mediterranean was announced here today [Jan. 11] by the high commands. The combined forces, the military communiqué said, attacked units of the British fleet in the Sicilian Channel, which, between Sicily and North Africa, has been a major factor in the success of the British operations from Sidi Barrani to Tobruk, in Libya. Direct hits were scored on several warships, it was said. The attack on the British warships, the communiqué said, was made at about noon yesterday by torpedo and dive-bombing planes.  — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 12, 1941

headline: David Bowie’s Indelible Mark on Fashion
text: LONDON — News of the death of David Bowie rippled through the fashion ranks on the closing day of the men’s wear shows on Monday, bringing a somber air to the proceedings taking place under slate gray skies.

headline: Broccoli’s Saucy Side
text: Italians cook broccoli longer than we do in the United States, until it is quite a bit softer and darker than we are accustomed to. This has its advantages, because soft broccoli can be mashed with the back of a spoon, and the broken-down vegetable is very nice as a sauce with pasta.

headline: The Shirts (and Pottery) of Bruta
text: One new British line focuses on garments and ceramics.

headline: ‘Star Wars,’ and How a Force Helps the Federal Reserve
text: This is a story about “Star Wars: The Force Awakens”… and the Federal Reserve. Wait! Keep reading. Some cheap tricks are entertaining.

headline: From One New Brand, Unisex Shirts and Pottery
text: In the airy reception room of a townhouse in London’s Chelsea, Arthur Yates has arranged a rack of vibrant unisex shirts next to a display of hand-painted milk urns. The two elements are unlikely halves of the same project: Bruta, his fashion and homeware brand that launched quietly last year. “There wasn’t some master plan,” he recalls. “I was just doing them in my bedroom with help from my girlfriend. And now it’s growing into something a little bit more serious, and people are taking interest.”

headline: What the End of the Case Against Steven Cohen Means
text: General Douglas MacArthur said in his retirement speech before Congress that “old soldiers never die; they just fade away.”

headline: Video of El Chapo Raid Shows Volley of Gunfire
text: Newly released video of the morning raid that led to the arrest of Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo, shows a fierce exchange of gunfire as a team of marines stormed his hide-out.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: A Flexible Constitution
text: To the Editor:

headline: Michael B. Jordan Shrugs, and Jennifer Lopez Shimmies
text: Man, are the Golden Globes after-parties ever a gloriously sprawling corporate free-for-all. They fill the Beverly Hilton’s parking lots and stretches of open space: giant tents with indoor-outdoor carpeting, D.J.s, twinkly lights, cater waiters, security guards, updos and swag. It’s like being aboard a very strange, very expensive cruise ship.

headline: Golden Globes 2016: Surprises and a Few Oscar Hints
text: Hours before the Golden Globes began Sunday, the ceremony’s accountants waltzed across the red carpet carrying briefcases handcuffed to their wrists. The cases held the award winners’ names, and one of the accountants said to a few reporters, “I think people will be surprised.”

headline: U.S. Repatriates Saudi Held at Guantánamo Since 2002
text: WASHINGTON — On the 14th anniversary of the arrival of the first Afghanistan war detainees at the American naval base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, the military announced Monday that it had repatriated a Saudi who had been held there without trial since the prison’s earliest weeks.

headline: Donald Trump Has Commanding Lead in Latest New Hampshire Poll
text: Donald J. Trump is handily leading the field in New Hampshire in the Republican presidential race, according to a new Monmouth University poll, running far ahead of his closest competitors, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Gov. John Kasich of Ohio.

headline: Whitney Museum Acquires Major Work by Archibald Motley
text: The Whitney Museum of American Art announced that it had acquired its first work by Archibald Motley, an under-recognized 20th-century painter whose stark portraits and tumultuous dance-club scenes helped define the Chicago and Harlem Renaissances.

headline: Cuomo Won’t Face Federal Charges Over Moreland Ethics Panel
text: An inquiry by the United States attorney’s office in Manhattan into Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s interference with an anticorruption panel that he created and abruptly shut down has concluded there was not enough evidence to bring a criminal case to court against him.

headline: Progress in Jimmy Carter’s Quest to End Guinea Worm Disease
text: Only 22 cases of Guinea worm disease were reported in 2015, the Carter Center announced last week, a significant drop from the 126 cases reported in 2014.

headline: Restaurants Counter Outside Cakes With Cakeage Fees
text: Cakes are meaningful, so it is no surprise that people sometimes bring them along to a restaurant as a celebratory coda to a special meal. And it’s no surprise that restaurants don’t always like it.

headline: Golden Globes 2016: Stars Hit the Parties
text: Cate Blanchett, Katy Perry, Ricky Gervais, Madonna and Sean Penn hit the Golden Globes parties.

headline: Iowa Poll Finds Ted Cruz and Donald Trump in Tight Race
text: Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas remain locked in a tight race for the lead in Iowa less than three weeks before the state’s caucuses, according to a new poll.

headline: Golden Globes 2016: Stars Hit the Parties
text: After the Globes Globes, celebrities kept the night going at numerous after-parties. Cate Blanchett arrived at one hosted by the Weinstein Company and Netflix. See the photos.

headline: Shire Pays High Price for Baxalta
text: Shire’s merger with Baxalta looks a little expensive.

headline: For French Ski Resorts, a Scramble to Offset Snow Deficit
text: CHAMONIX, France — Bright sunshine and mostly brown slopes welcomed skiers to the Chamonix-Mont-Blanc Valley just before New Year’s Eve, a sight that hardly came as a shock.

headline: Story Approval by Drug Lord? Times Editors Discuss Rolling Stone Case
text: Updated, 3:25 p.m.

headline: Pouring a Foundation on Mars
text: If humans were to attempt to colonize Mars, transporting construction materials would be difficult and expensive. Researchers at Northwestern University have proposed an alternative, a kind of concrete that can be made with materials from Mars itself: sulfur and Martian soil. The sulfur concrete is almost as strong as conventional concrete, durable in acid and salt environments, and recyclable, the researchers say. Sulfur has been used as a bonding agent since ancient times. In the 17th century, sulfur was often used to anchor metal to stone.

headline: Nets’ Owner Takes ‘Full Responsibility’ for State of the Team
text: Many of the elements of a typical Mikhail D. Prokhorov news conference were on display on Monday: the deadpan humor, the rhetorical showboating, the stubborn optimism and the incongruous talk of N.B.A. championships.

headline: When Financial Talk Turns Personal
text: Recently, my family needed a new vehicle. I’ve always wanted a truck, and I knew we would get tons of use out of it. Could I have found a cheaper vehicle? Sure. But I knew we could afford the truck, so after lots of careful thought, we decided to buy it.

headline: Children’s Book Awards Honor Diversity
text: Matt de la Peña’s illustrated children’s book, “Last Stop on Market Street,” about a boy’s reflections during a bus ride to a soup kitchen with his grandmother, won the John Newbery Medal for the most outstanding contribution to children’s literature, a rare honor for a picture book.

headline: In Retreats, Start-Ups Find a Way to Recharge Workers’ Batteries
text: Joshua Reeves, the co-founder and chief executive at the payroll and benefits management start-up Gusto, rented a house for a week in 2013 with his roughly 10 colleagues for what he called a “workation.”

headline: Human Traffickers Found to Exploit U.S. Visas and Data-Sharing Failures
text: WASHINGTON — Human traffickers used fiancé and work visas to bring dozens of victims to the United States, exploiting a lack of data sharing between immigration offices within the Department of Homeland Security, according to the agency’s internal watchdog.

headline: How David Bowie Changed Wall Street
text: David Bowie was known for his ability to reinvent himself. But he also helped inspire a pocket of Wall Street that tries to create money out of weird things like billboard rental income, cellphone tower lease payments and literary or film libraries.

headline: Supercrown Pairs Coffee With Everything in Bushwick
text: Darleen Scherer, who founded Gorilla Coffee in Park Slope, Brooklyn, sold her interest last year and has gone on to open Supercrown Coffee Roasters, a combination cafe, retail shop and coffee roaster with a behemoth of a German roasting machine positioned in full view. The coffees include some from Indonesia, like Sulawesi, with rewarding depth and balance. And she has staked out some unusual territory in coffee drinks. There’s a decadent coffee milkshake made with Ample Hills ice cream, and once the weather warms, a Scandinavian-style blend of coffee and lemonade that may be an acquired taste. To eat, there are pastries from Brooklyn purveyors like Bien Cuit and bialys, onion and prosciutto, made by Roberta’s and topped with poached eggs: Supercrown Coffee Roasters, 8 Wilson Avenue (Flushing Avenue), Bushwick, Brooklyn, 347-295-3161; supercrown.coffee.

headline: ISIS Attack on Baghdad Mall Kills 17
text: BAGHDAD — Islamic State militants attacked a shopping mall in eastern Baghdad on Monday evening, killing at least 17 people and turning the neighborhood into an urban war zone at rush hour, with helicopters hovering overhead and snipers taking positions on nearby rooftops.

headline: Sarah Howe Wins T.S. Eliot Poetry Prize
text: LONDON — Sarah Howe, a British poet born in Hong Kong, was awarded the 2015 T.S. Eliot Prize for her debut collection “Loop of Jade” on Monday evening.

headline: Ratings Drop for Golden Globes
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Sunday night’s off-color Golden Globes, filled with bleeps and controversial jokes, did not result in better viewership.

headline: Top Suspect in Paris Attacks Had Traveled to Britain, Officials Say
text: PARIS — The man believed to be the coordinator of the Nov. 13 terrorist attacks in Paris had previously traveled undetected to Britain despite being named in an international arrest warrant for his role in a foiled plot in Belgium in early 2015, European law enforcement officials said Monday.

headline: Teenager Attacks Jewish Teacher in Marseille With a Machete
text: PARIS — A teenager attacked a Jewish teacher with a machete in the southern French city of Marseille on Monday, and afterward told the police that he had carried out the attack in the name of God and the Islamic State, according to the Marseille prosecutor.

headline: 1955-65 | The Last Decade of New York’s Old Penn Station
text: Any chance to explore the history of old Pennsylvania Station in mid-Manhattan underscores the wealth of The Times’s photo and clipping archive. We’ve come to call it the “lively morgue” for a very good reason: Its holdings, numbering in the millions (though stored under precarious conditions in the basement of an abutting office building), don’t just illuminate the past but breathe life into it. They warrant a regular feature on Tumblr.

headline: ‘Sickout’ by Detroit Teachers Closes Most Public Schools
text: Most of Detroit’s public schools closed Monday in the face of a “sickout” by teachers who protested what they called unsafe, crumbling, vermin-infested and inadequately staffed buildings, and the failure of state lawmakers to agree on a plan to rescue a system teetering on the edge of insolvency.

headline: Adele Cedes Billboard’s Singles Chart to Justin Bieber After 10 Weeks
text: Adele may still be ruling album sales, but this week she yields her reign over Billboard’s singles chart to Justin Bieber.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Men in Fur
text: Blame it on Chewbacca’s return to the big screen — or the continuing nostalgia for all things ‘70s — but fur is quite literally huge this season. Oversized, overfluffed shearlings and minks were standout pieces at the men’s shows in London this weekend, especially in collections from Katie Eary, Burberry and Coach 1941. Though intimidating on their own, paired with urban staples such as track jackets, sweatshirts and sneakers, they seemed tough rather than flashy. Here’s hoping winter 2016’s climate actually merits wearing one.

headline: Manu Ginobili Made Spurs Assistant a Believer Back in Italy
text: Trending on the Internet recently was a video of Manu Ginobili assisting on a fast-break basket, while lying down on the job.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Five Fashion Hairstylists on How to Create Casual Buns
text: “Pull your hair off your face.” In the annals of maternal admonishments, the refrain is all too common.

headline: Nailing the National Anthem: Who’s Done It Best?
text: No matter what surprises are in store in the national college football championship game on Monday night (referred to from here on out as “the Natty”), one thing is for certain: Like just about all other sporting events in this country, it will begin with a rendition of the national anthem. On Monday night, the anthem will be sung by Ciara, who is known for hits like “Goodies” and “Oh.”

headline: Index-Card Financial Advice From Readers
text: Our collection of money advice written on index cards yielded an outpouring of submissions from both New York Times readers and financial experts.

headline: When a Big Baby Isn’t So Big
text: Katy Clemens wanted to have a natural, drug-free childbirth. Then an ultrasound suggested her baby would weigh 11.5 pounds, and her doctors insisted she schedule a cesarean section.

headline: Facts & Figures: The Rise of Independents
text: Last year was the fifth in a row in which 40 percent or more Americans described themselves as political independents, according to a Gallup poll. In 2015, 42 percent of those polled said they were independents; 29 percent identified as Democrats and 26 percent as Republicans.

headline: David Bowie’s Style, Through the Years
text: The iconic singer, producer, actor and artist died Sunday at age 69. Here, some of his most idiosyncratic and indelible looks.

text: To the Editor:

headline: Diplomats Meet in Pakistan in Effort to Restart Peace Talks With Taliban
text: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Senior diplomats from Pakistan, Afghanistan, China and the United States met in Islamabad on Monday to try to lay the groundwork for a new round of peace talks with the Taliban.

headline: Pictures of the Day: London and Elsewhere
text: London and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Jan. 11, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from London, Ukraine, France and South Africa.

headline: Unhappy New Year at Broadway Box Office
text: The winter doldrums have begun on Broadway.

headline: A Personalized Diet, Better Suited to You
text: In what has come to feel like a twice-a-decade mea culpa, the federal government last week released another revision of the Dietary Guidelines for Americans, this time urging many of us to consume less sugar and less protein. The new recommendations may well influence nutrition labeling, school lunches and government assistance programs.

headline: Beyond Monty Hall
text: This week’s puzzle is twist on a stunning, counter-intuitive classic — the Monty Hall Problem, made famous by Marilyn vos Savant in her “Ask Marilyn” column in Parade Magazine. Here was the problem in its original form as sent in by a reader to Ms. vos Savant:

headline: Hillary Clinton Confronts Bernie Sanders as Polls Show Her Lead in Iowa Narrowing
text: WATERLOO, Iowa — Facing new pressure from Senator Bernie Sanders in Iowa, Hillary Clinton confronted him in direct terms on Monday, warning Iowans that if elected president, he would put their health insurance in the hands of Republican governors and raise taxes on the middle class.

headline: National Championship 2016 Highlights and Analysis
text: Alabama beat Clemson, 45-40, to win the 2016 College Football Playoff national championship game.

headline: Revolt in Governing Party Shakes Tunisian Politics
text: TUNIS — Tunisia’s main Islamist party, Ennahda, re-emerged as the dominant faction in Parliament on Monday as mass resignations from President Béji Caïd Essebsi’s secular party continued, largely to protest his son’s position as party chief.

headline: This Land Is Our Land
text: To the Editor:

headline: The Arrival of Electric Light
text: Since the early 19th century, inventors had been tinkering with various methods of using electricity to produce light. The New York Times first wrote of the technology on April 15, 1858. That day, “Our Own Correspondent” in Havana described celebrations of Holy Week that included “an electric light” cast across the harbor “revealing the name of Queen Isabel.”

headline: Chris Christie Makes Steady Rightward Shift on Guns
text: The Democratic attack ad from 2009 showed Chris Christie’s face beside a row of bullets, branding him as an ally of the National Rifle Association. A narrator warned that unlike Jon S. Corzine, a Democrat who was then New Jersey’s governor, Mr. Christie “stands with the N.R.A. and opposes banning armor-piercing rifles.”

headline: White House Increases Outreach for State of the Union
text: President Obama will make one of his final prime-time addresses to the country on Tuesday, and the White House is leaving no platform uncovered in its effort to magnify its message.

headline: Ringling Circus Elephants
text: File footage of elephants performing in the Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey circus.

headline: Review: In ‘City of Thorns,’ Ben Rawlence Tells a Refugee Camp’s Story
text: In English, Dadaab means “the rocky hard place,” a translation of such freakish metaphorical precision that Ben Rawlence, the author of “City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the World’s Largest Refugee Camp,” has the sense to use it with great restraint. Stamped on a dusty desert plain in Kenya, Dadaab — the camp of the book’s title — is home to a half million inhabitants. Most are Somalis who have fled famine or terror in their home country (sometimes both), but others come from Sudan, Rwanda, Uganda, Ethiopia. What unites them all is that they live in a state of suspension seemingly interminable and intolerable.

headline: At the Golden Globes, Earrings From Another Era
text: Several actresses chose to wear dangling earrings to last night’s Golden Globes, but the standout trend were the vintage (and vintage-inspired) pieces that brought Old Hollywood — in some cases, really old Hollywood — back to the red carpet. Kirsten Dunst chose Fred Leighton diamond pendant earrings that date from the 19th century, while Cate Blanchett matched her Givenchy fringe gown with a pair of Tiffany & Co. platinum diamond and pearl earrings from 1915. And Kate Winslet’s Neil Lane diamond earrings are a contemporary design heavily influenced by the Art Deco period.

headline: When Good Medicine Mixes With Bad
text: We like to think that bad and good medicine are easy to distinguish. A huge construct of education, licensure and regulation depends on that single, simple premise. And yet, perhaps more often than not, the good and the bad swirl together like cream poured into coffee, almost impossible to separate.

headline: Mexico’s Recapture of El Chapo
text: To the Editor:

headline: Review: ‘Shadowhunters,’ a Teenage Fantasyland Roamed by Demon Killers
text: To be a teenager is to be bored. Boredom is a natural part of development: to grow restless with the cosseted world you were raised in and thus prepare to separate from it.

headline: Peach App for the iPhone Stakes a Social Media Claim
text: The world may have plenty of social media platforms already, but a new one called Peach captured the fancy of early adopters and technology bloggers over the weekend.

headline: David Bowie’s Effect on Music Videos
text: David Bowie had an indelible effect on music videos as a storytelling method. From “John, I’m Only Dancing” in 1972 to “Lazarus” just last week, Bowie’s experimentation helped make music videos what they are.

headline: Two Teams in Search of Sports-Obsessed Brooklyn
text: We’ve watched Jackie Robinson steal home a hundred times on those old reels, and breathed all the loving poetry about the Bums of Brooklyn. It is an idyllic vision, the rainbow merger of community and sports team, an interracial Eden.

headline: Catalan Independence Bid Looms Over Spain’s Coalition Efforts
text: MADRID — If it appeared for a moment that Catalonia’s drive to secede from Spain would implode along with the political fortunes of its leader, it has not turned out that way.

headline: Head of Poland’s Governing Party Leads a Shift Rightward
text: WARSAW — Poland’s new right-wing government has moved rapidly in its first months in power to pack more sympathetic judges on to the nation’s highest court and blunt its ability to overturn new laws. It has announced plans to put the choice of the country’s top prosecutor directly in the hands of party leaders. It has granted a presidential pardon to a former security chief who has been appealing a three-year sentence for abuse of office stemming from the governing party’s last time running the country.

headline: Princess Cristina of Spain Stands Trial in Tax Fraud Case
text: MADRID — Princess Cristina became the first member of Spain’s royal family to stand trial on Monday, in a tax fraud case that has become a major embarrassment for the country’s monarchy.

headline: Panel Reasserts Mammogram Advice That Triggered Breast Cancer Debate
text: In 2009, an influential panel of medical experts ignited a nationwide uproar by suggesting that women needed fewer mammograms than had long been recommended. Instead of starting at age 40 and being screened every year, women with average risk of breast cancer could safely begin at 50 and be tested every other year, the group said, citing extensive data to support its advice. It also said that after 74, there was not enough evidence to determine whether routine mammography was worthwhile.

headline: Review: The Pianist Jenny Q Chai, Evoking Chopin Without His Work
text: The dynamic Chinese-American pianist Jenny Q Chai has gained attention for unconventional programs that combine piano pieces, live electronics and video imagery, like the one she presented on Sunday afternoon at Le Poisson Rouge, intriguingly titled “Where Is Chopin?”

headline: David Bowie, Master of the Music Video
text: Among many other things, David Bowie was a pioneer and maestro of the music video: From the start of his career, he understood the possibilities of a fledgling format, the ways in which music and image could conspire to tell a richer, more complicated story. Whether in a narrative or purely expressionist mode, he brought acute visual poetry to the screen, helping to transform the music video from an afterthought — a flat promotional tool — into its own challenging (and ever-changing) artistic medium.

headline: Review: ‘The Changeling,’ Where Murder Is the Natural Solution
text: Sensation slides into silliness in “The Changeling,” a 1622 tragedy — with generous dollops of comedy — by Thomas Middleton and William Rowley. The convoluted story grows more lurid and strained as the play hurtles toward its predictably bloody conclusion, but with a fine cast bringing sufficient heat to the panting plotlines, the Red Bull Theater and its artistic director, Jesse Berger, once again win admiration for presenting a rarely seen drama from the Jacobean era with highly caffeinated verve. (Their previous productions include Middleton’s “Women Beware Women” and “The Revenger’s Tragedy.”)

headline: Marco Rubio Takes Darker Tone, Saying American Dream ‘Is Dying’
text: SARASOTA, Fla. – Summoning a bit of Donald J. Trump’s gloom, Senator Marco Rubio on Monday told an audience here that half of young Americans believe that the American Dream is dead, a warning sign he said should rouse voters to seek a new direction in 2016.

headline: Review: Lars Jan’s ‘The Institute of Memory (TIMe)’ Is a Search for Identity
text: The “searching for my father” (or, less often, “mother”) play or film is a genre at this point, but not many of the works in it are as adventurous as “The Institute of Memory (TIMe),” Lars Jan’s multimedia personal journey, part of the Under the Radar festival. Not many delve as deeply, either. Mr. Jan goes right into the brain of his father in search of a man who always seemed a cipher.

headline: Father of Koch Brothers Helped Build Nazi Oil Refinery, Book Says
text: The father of the billionaires Charles G. and David H. Koch helped construct a major oil refinery in Nazi Germany that was personally approved by Adolf Hitler, according to a new history of the Kochs and other wealthy families.

headline: Is America Headed in the Right Direction? Readers Respond
text: As President Obama prepares to address the nation, tell us whether you think America is headed in the right or wrong direction.

headline: Review: In ‘The Holler Sessions,’ a D.J. as True Believer
text: An unkempt Kansas City disc jockey named Ray has appointed himself an altar boy at the exalted shrine of jazz, and his faith burns like a five-alarm fire. Embodied with respect and ferocity by Frank Boyd in “The Holler Sessions,” which runs through Friday at the Paradise Factory, Ray radiates a hard-core obsessiveness that’s both scary and contagious. You get the feeling that he wears sunglasses inside not to be cool, but because the light he’s seen is so bright.

headline: Review: ‘The Art of Luv (Part 1),’ a Quest for the Perfect Erotic Recipe
text: “Chair or floor?” This startling question greets you as you enter “The Art of Luv (Part 1): Elliot” at the Under the Radar Festival. Audience members have the option of sitting in seats or plopping down on the floor near the performers — pillow provided, thank goodness. You are also offered a hot hand towel, as in a Japanese restaurant. The production, from the Royal Osiris Karaoke Ensemble, combines the atmospherics of a yoga or meditation class — we are given breathing instructions — with a quirky, mostly entertaining multimedia exploration of the dynamics of erotic attraction in contemporary culture.

headline: In London, Men’s Designers Explore Change — and Tradition
text: Jonathan Anderson explored the idea of speed in his fall/winter 2016 collection — while Dunhill quietly refreshed old classics.

headline: Julian Castro Warns Latinos Would Suffer if G.O.P. Abandons Health Law
text: Julián Castro, the federal housing secretary, whom Hillary Clinton has mentioned as a potential running mate, said Monday that if Republicans “recklessly” abandoned the Affordable Care Act without replacing it with “something thoughtful,” Latinos would “suffer tremendously.”

headline: Three’s a Trend: Hoods on the Men’s Runways
text: There’s a theme emerging across the runways at London Collections: Men — and it may indicate what’s on British designers’ minds. Once banned from shopping malls across the country, hoods — or at least models wearing hoods — popped up all over the runways, evoking everything from hypochondria to surveillance paranoia.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: David Bowie, Golden Globes, Sean Penn
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New England’s Top Sports Teams Support Transgender Bill
text: BOSTON — New England’s top professional sports teams have thrown their support behind legislation that would guarantee protections for transgender individuals in public spaces in Massachusetts, advocates for that measure announced on Monday. The supporters hope the teams’ muscle could help persuade legislators that the bill has broad appeal.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: David Bowie in the Movies
text: From "The Man Who Fell to Earth" to "Labyrinth," a look back at David Bowie film roles.

headline: Cartoon: Mourning David Bowie
text: The musician leaves behind many legacies.

headline: Celebrating David Bowie, a Star Who Burned Bright to the Last
text: As fans mourned David Bowie on the streets of London, Berlin and New York on Monday, a flurry of events served as a reminder of just what an outsize — and active — presence he had remained in the worlds of music, art, fashion and performance right up to the very end of his life.

headline: Oil Prices Slide Again, and the Bottom Is Not Yet in Sight
text: The continuing collapse in commodity prices pushed oil futures still lower Monday, and analysts predicted that the slide was far from over.

headline: Police Officer Shot During Bronx Street Fight Was Hit by Colleague
text: A New York City police officer shot in the leg while responding to a melee outside a party in the South Bronx over the weekend was wounded by a fellow officer, officials said on Monday.

headline: Listening to David Bowie: A Critic’s Tour of His Musical Changes
text: David Bowie made pop of impassioned critical distance. He told a good musical story by standing outside of it and knew how to make you think about the artist’s relation to his work and the listener’s relation to the artist; he took the question of image and identity seriously. (The first song he recorded under his stage name, released in 1966, was called “Can’t Help Thinking About Me.”) In a certain way, all his songs were metafictions, even when they seemed personal, even when they were hits. Here is a handful of the best and most widely loved.

headline: Rand Paul and Carly Fiorina Are Dropped From Mainstage Republican Debate
text: The Republican debate stage will be noticeably smaller when the candidates gather in Charleston, S.C., on Thursday night for their first debate of the year.

headline: Interest in Tom Coughlin Spreads to the 49ers, and the Giants Keep Seeking His Successor
text: The Giants and Tom Coughlin continued to be in the middle of a churning and ever-changing coaching interview merry-go-round on Monday.

headline: New Pressures, and Commitments, After Fire Takes Family’s Home
text: Tajiauna Spence and three of her daughters ate dinner at a McDonald’s in Chelsea late last month. Her grandson, Styles, was the center of the group’s affections as he played with his gloves and made random demands.

headline: Where the Sidewalk Ends, Abruptly: Delivery Ramp Vexes Condo’s Residents in Lower Manhattan
text: In a library just off the lobby of 20 Pine Street, a condominium conversion a block from the New York Stock Exchange, a couple of neighbors met last week to address a problem that had been vexing them for more than a year: a ramp for FedEx’s new Lower Manhattan distribution center.

headline: A New Focus on Liquidity After a Fund’s Collapse
text: The college seminar was drawing to a close in October and Martin J. Whitman was pondering the hits and misses in his long career at the top of Third Avenue Management, one of Wall Street’s better-known value investment firms.

headline: Nothing Remains: David Bowie’s Vision of Love
text: On the title track of “Blackstar,” the David Bowie record released just a couple of days before his death on Jan. 10, Bowie sings, “I’m not a pop star.” True, he was an attractive celebrity with hit records, great hair and a vaguely gender-bending past. But for me, and for his millions of fans, he was someone who simply made life less ordinary. Indeed, Bowie’s music made me feel alive for the first time. And if that sounds like overstatement, then perhaps you don’t get what music is about and what it can do.

headline: Golden Globes Reflect a New Trajectory for TV
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Over the last decade, NBC Universal’s cable chief, Bonnie Hammer, has occasionally visited the Golden Globes under less-than-glamorous conditions: sitting in a production truck for the E! network, dressed in jeans and sneakers, with her hair pulled back. By time the network wrapped up its red carpet show and the show actually began, a limo would be summoned, a pizza ordered and Ms. Hammer’s night would be all but over.

headline: Kentucky: Notice Served on Closing of Health Site
text: Gov. Matt Bevin has formally notified the Obama administration that he plans to “wind down and cease operation” of the state’s health insurance exchange. Mr. Bevin, a newly elected Republican who opposes the Affordable Care Act, said in a letter to Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the secretary of health and human services, that he wanted Kentucky residents to start using the federal insurance exchange serving 38 other states “as soon as is practicable.” Kentucky residents will continue using the state’s exchange, called Kynect, during the open enrollment period that ends Jan. 31. Mr. Bevin’s predecessor, Steven L. Beshear, a Democrat, has said it would cost the state at least $23 million to dismantle Kynect.

headline: Grindr Sells Stake to Chinese Company
text: Grindr, the popular dating and social networking app for gay men, has found itself a match.

headline: Deal Paves Way for Vote on Casino Referendum in New Jersey
text: Gov. Chris Christie returned to the State House on Monday and announced a compromise between two Democratic legislators over their proposals for a referendum on casino gambling in North Jersey.

headline: Alliance of 2 de Blasio Critics Fosters Speculation About Mayoral Challenge
text: They stood side by side, two Democratic leaders deploring the plague of gun violence. But the event, a news conference on the steps of City Hall, was notable for more than its subject matter.

headline: Air Force General Says Russia Missile Defense ‘Very Serious’
text: The commander of United States Air Force operations in Europe and Africa expressed “very serious” concern Monday over what he described as big buildups of complex Russian missile defenses that increasingly threaten NATO military access to air space in parts of Europe, including one-third of the skies in Poland.

headline: The North American International Auto Show
text: Press previews for the Detroit auto show, which was first held in 1907, are Monday and Tuesday. Over 750 vehicles are expected to be on the floor of the Cobo Center.

headline: Automakers Go Electric, Even if Gas Is Cheap
text: DETROIT — While American consumers were taking advantage of low gas prices to buy trucks and sport utility vehicles in large numbers, some automakers delayed investing in slower-selling electrified vehicles.

headline: New York City’s High School Graduation Rate Tops 70%
text: As New York State officials met on Monday to consider changes to high school graduation requirements, the state announced that the graduation rate inched up last year, with New York City’s edging above 70 percent for the first time.

headline: Extradite El Chapo Guzmán
text: The last time the world’s top drug kingpin, Joaquín Guzmán Loera, was nabbed, Mexico’s top prosecutor said the government would consider extraditing him to the United States in 300 years or so, once all his criminal cases at home had been settled. Embarrassed by his escape in July — his second — Mexican officials appear to have changed their minds. Soon after he was taken into custody on Friday, the Mexican government indicated it had started extradition proceedings to send Mr. Guzmán to the United States. That is the right call.

headline: When Restless Billionaires Trip on Their Toys
text: “If you really care about an institution and want to make it strong for the ages, you don’t walk out. You roll up your sleeves, you redouble your commitment to those ideals in a changing world, and you fight.”

headline: Venezuela: Court Held Lawmakers in Contempt
text: The Supreme Court on Monday held the leaders of the National Assembly in contempt and said the Assembly’s actions could be void, setting up a conflict between the two branches of government. The dispute stems from the swearing in last week of three lawmakers by the Assembly in defiance of a ruling by the court. The opposition to President Nicolás Maduro and his United Socialist Party won a large majority in the Assembly in elections last month. But some Socialist candidates filed lawsuits challenging the results and in one of those the court responded by halting the swearing in three lawmakers. The new Assembly leaders condemned that ruling as an attempt to undermine the new majority and swore the three opposition candidates in anyway. The summary of the Monday decision posted on the court’s website said all decisions made while the three members were “incorporated” into the Assembly would be void. The Assembly has said it will push legislation this week to free a number of prisoners who lawmakers who they say are being held for political reasons and will pursue laws to reduce the influence of Mr. Maduro’s administration.

headline: El Chapo Case Draws Mexico Closer to U.S.
text: MEXICO CITY — Mexico has started letting American agents carry guns on its soil. A special Mexican unit trained by Americans has been revived after stalling because of mistrust and a sense of national pride. American agents are working with Mexican soldiers to seize guns, and the two nations just agreed on a plan to tackle the heroin epidemic.

headline: Late Reshuffling Clouds Vote on N.F.L. Moves
text: HOUSTON — With the N.F.L. hours away from convening a special two-day meeting among owners to decide on moving one or possibly two teams to Los Angeles, it seemed likely that the city would get a team, but which one and where they would play grew murkier Monday during a round of last-minute jockeying.

headline: David Bowie Allowed His Art to Deliver a Final Message
text: In the video for David Bowie’s “Lazarus,” released last week, the mythic singer and rock ’n’ roll shape-shifter, ever thin but bordering on gaunt, is blindfolded and writhing in a hospital bed. “Look up here, I’m in heaven,” he sings. “I’ve got scars that can’t be seen.” In the end, a shaking Mr. Bowie retreats backward into a darkened armoire.

headline: Balancing Terror and Reality in State of the Union Address
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama speaks to the nation in his final State of the Union address on Tuesday night, he will offer a familiar reassurance that the country is expending enormous effort to protect Americans against international terrorism.

headline: President Obama to Focus on American Potential in 2016
text: WASHINGTON — In his first State of the Union address, President Obama delivered a somber portrayal of a nation mired in a crippling economic crisis and bitter partisanship. As he prepares to deliver his seventh and final such speech on Tuesday, the financial calamity has passed but the partisanship has gotten worse.

headline: Nick Saban Builds a Legacy Under a Long Shadow
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Midway through his final session with reporters before Monday night’s College Football Playoff championship game, Alabama Coach Nick Saban was peppered with the customary questions about strategy, the Crimson Tide’s one-loss season and how it felt to be playing in yet another title game.

headline: Conflicts Keep 24 Million Children Out of School, Unicef Report Finds
text: Nearly 24 million children living in 22 countries affected by conflict are not in school, the United Nations said Monday. A report released by Unicef, the United Nations Children’s Fund, said that of roughly 109 million children of primary and secondary school age in these countries, almost one in four are not getting an education. The highest proportion was in South Sudan, where more than half the school-age children are not in school, followed by Niger, at 47 percent; Sudan, 41 percent; and Afghanistan, 40 percent. The impact of war and upheaval on childhood education is regarded as a long-term crisis by Unicef, which has frequently warned of the effects of trauma and illiteracy as children reach adulthood.

headline: As U.S. Modernizes Nuclear Weapons, ‘Smaller’ Leaves Some Uneasy
text: As North Korea dug tunnels at its nuclear test site last fall, watched by American spy satellites, the Obama administration was preparing a test of its own in the Nevada desert.

headline: Hog the Mirror
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Today, we strut the runway with Zhouqin Burnikel. Eyes up, chin down, slouch mysteriously and pout seductively. Make the audience want you. Make those high-fashion duds look great.

headline: Court Allows FanDuel and DraftKings to Operate in New York Amid Appeal
text: The two largest daily fantasy websites, FanDuel and DraftKings, were granted a stay on Monday by the Appellate Division of the New York State Supreme Court and can continue to operate in the state while they try to fend off a challenge from New York’s attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman.

headline: Protesters Rip Out Fence at Refuge in Oregon
text: PRINCETON, Ore. — The armed men who have occupied a federal wildlife refuge here escalated their defiance of the federal government on Monday, using bare hands and a Wildcat excavator stolen from the United States Fish and Wildlife Service to rip apart a barbed-wire fence erected by the government at a far end of the vast refuge.

headline: Scott Harshbarger to Investigate Abuse Cases at St. George’s School
text: Scott Harshbarger, a former attorney general of Massachusetts and former president of Common Cause, was named on Monday as the independent investigator into sexual abuse accusations spanning decades at St. George’s School, an elite prep school in Middletown, R.I.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Lawyers Seek Dismissal of Sexual Assault Charges
text: Lawyers for Bill Cosby said Monday that they were asking for the dismissal of sexual assault charges filed against him in Pennsylvania, arguing that the local district attorney’s office had promised in 2005 that Mr. Cosby would not be prosecuted.

headline: Iran Reports Removing Core From Reactor
text: WASHINGTON — Iran reported Monday that it had removed the core of its plutonium-producing nuclear reactor at Arak as part of its efforts to complete its obligations under a new international agreement, even as President Obama moved to guard the deal against action in Congress.

headline: Four Teenagers Are Charged in Brooklyn Rape Case
text: Four days after the sexual assault of an 18-year-old woman at a Brooklyn playground, prosecutors late Monday charged four teenagers with first-degree rape, officials said.

headline: Italy: American Woman Found Dead
text: Prosecutors in Florence are investigating the death of a young American woman who was found in her apartment in the center of the city over the weekend, the police said on Monday. Local news reports said the body of the woman, Ashley Ann Olsen, 35, was found in her bedroom on Saturday by her landlady and her boyfriend, Federico Fiorentini, a well-known local artist. There were reports that marks were found on Ms. Olsen’s neck, suggesting she may have been strangled. Pathologists were performing an autopsy on Monday to determine the time and cause of death.

headline: Stable Spurs Meet Turbulent Nets, and the Outcome Is Predictable
text: At his first pregame news conference since being named the Nets’ interim coach, Tony Brown found an unopened bottle of water awaiting him at the dais. He cheerily proclaimed, “It’s a great day.”

headline: Joe Girardi Opts for Aroldis Chapman Over Andrew Miller as the Yankees’ Closer
text: Aroldis Chapman, the Yankees’ recently acquired All-Star reliever, will go into spring training as the team’s closer, Manager Joe Girardi said Monday.

headline: Ad Buys Position Marco Rubio to Dominate Iowa Airwaves
text: Senator Marco Rubio and his allies will deploy a barrage of ads across Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina before the first caucus and primary contests next month, spending less money than some of his opponents yet still managing to reach more television viewers.

headline: Consumer Loan Delinquencies Edged Up in Third Quarter
text: A measure of consumer credit worsened in the third quarter, a potentially troubling sign for banks that have enjoyed a long spell of low defaults.

headline: De Blasio to Announce New System Dedicated to Addressing Gun Crime in New York City
text: Seeking to quell stubbornly persistent gun-related violence in New York City, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Tuesday will unveil a new system for handling such cases, creating a dedicated gun court in Brooklyn and a 200-officer police division focused on gun crime.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | lectern
text: lectern • \ˈlek-tərn\ • noun

headline: Rupert Murdoch, News Corp. Chief, and Jerry Hall Announce Engagement
text: Rupert Murdoch, the executive chairman of News Corporation, and the former model Jerry Hall got engaged over the weekend and announced their pending nuptials Tuesday in the classifieds of a newspaper he owns.

headline: Alabama Wins Fourth National Championship in Seven Years
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Nick Saban won his fourth national title in seven seasons on Monday night, and his fifth over all, with an Alabama team headlined by Derrick Henry, the second Tide player, after Mark Ingram Jr., to win the Heisman Trophy. The Heismans bookending Saban’s first and fourth titles since 2009 buttress the belief outside Tuscaloosa, Ala., that Saban is the beneficiary of bountiful talent.

headline: Hillary Clinton Promises Not to Be ‘Deporter in Chief’
text: Under pressure to consolidate her support among Latinos as Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont gains ground on her in Iowa, Hillary Clinton broke with the Obama administration on a key immigration provision on Monday night and promised not to be the “deporter in chief” if elected president.

headline: Richard Libertini, Actor, Dies at 82; Had Memorable Turn in ‘The In-Laws’
text: Richard Libertini, a character actor best known for his antic turn as a deranged Latin American general in the 1979 film comedy “The In-Laws,” died on Thursday at his home in Venice, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Joe Biden Says Obama Offered Financial Help During Son’s Illness
text: President Obama offered to personally give Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. money to help out when the vice president’s son became sick, Mr. Biden recalled in an interview that aired on Monday.

headline: Dalian Wanda of China Buys Legendary Entertainment for Up to $3.5 Billion
text: HONG KONG — The Dalian Wanda Group, a politically powerful property and entertainment company in China, said on Tuesday that it was buying Legendary Entertainment, one of Hollywood’s biggest movie production companies, for as much as $3.5 billion.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
text: We’ll remember David Bowie for his music, but his film roles were no less indelible. You can stream him as Andy Warhol in “Basquiat,” Pontius Pilate in “The Last Temptation of Christ” and as a space visitor in his calling card, “The Man Who Fell to Earth.” Meanwhile, President Obama delivers a State of the Union address for the last time.

headline: Statins May Help, Not Hinder, Heart Bypass Recovery
text: People who are taking statin medications and need heart bypass surgery are often told to discontinue the drugs before and after surgery because of concerns about adverse effects. But that may not be a wise idea, a new review of studies has found.

headline: Corrections: January 12, 2016
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “What seemed not too long ago intriguingly complicated, ambiguous and opaque now seems pretty clear: a man who was yearning for immortality.”

headline: The 40,000-Mile Volcano
text: Picture a volcano. Now imagine that its main vent extends in a line. Now imagine that this line is so long that it runs for more than 40,000 miles through the dark recesses of all the world’s oceans, girding the globe like the seams of a baseball.

headline: Digging Deeper Into Vivian Maier’s Past
text: This is the first report on a two-part story revealing new research reported on Vivian Maier. The second report is now published,

headline: Despite Clear Dangers, DuPont Kept Using a Toxic Chemical
text: An article in The Times Magazine on Sunday has laid bare the unconscionable decades-long efforts of the DuPont company to hide the dangers of an obscure chemical and bamboozle regulators into allowing toxic pollution to continue long after the dangers were known to the company. The article by Nathaniel Rich described how a corporate lawyer, Rob Bilott, built a devastating case against DuPont, based on the company’s own studies and internal documents. The case illustrates the urgent need for Congress to complete its efforts to reform the Toxic Substances Control Act, which has allowed tens of thousands of untested chemicals to remain on the market with little more than the manufacturer’s say-so that they are safe.

headline: Willie Horton’s Heirs
text: In Donald J. Trump’s first television ad of the 2016 campaign, released last week, a photo of Hillary Clinton and President Obama flashes across the screen, followed by stark black-and-white images of the San Bernardino, Calif., attackers, Syed Rizwan Farook and Tashfeen Malik.

headline: The Brutalism of Ted Cruz
text: In 1997, Michael Wayne Haley was arrested after stealing a calculator from Walmart. This was a crime that merited a maximum two-year prison term. But prosecutors incorrectly applied a habitual offender law. Neither the judge nor the defense lawyer caught the error and Haley was sentenced to 16 years.

headline: How to Help the Syrians Who Want to Return Home
text: IN the aftermath of terrorist attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., American support for accepting more Syrian refugees has withered. The Republican presidential hopeful Donald J. Trump has called for blocking all Muslims from entering the United States, saying we are at war with radical Islam. Other politicians, including some governors and members of Congress, now specifically label Syrian refugees a threat.

headline: ‘Making a Murderer’ Is About Justice, Not Truth
text: Durham, N.C. — THE release last month of “Making a Murderer,” a 10-part documentary from Netflix, capped a year in which popular culture’s portrayal of the criminal justice system seems to have shifted. Out with the old tropes about truth-seeking investigators and tidy resolutions; in with the disquieting, dysfunctional reality of many courtrooms and police stations.

headline: Strong Unions, Strong Democracy
text: IF the questions that came up during oral argument in Friedrichs v. California Teachers Association on Monday are any guide, the ruling bloc of conservative justices appears ready to render a decision later this year that would significantly weaken public sector labor unions.

headline: Agony and Starvation in the Syrian War
text: After haunting pictures and stories of starving civilians showed up on international news sites and social media, food and other desperately needed aid were finally allowed into the Syrian town of Madaya on Monday.
