Yet this should not be a cause for celebration or complacency. The aid convoys and their supplies offer only a respite in the slow-motion agony that is destroying Syria and its people.

headline: In India, Dispensers of Balm Travel to Death’s Door
text: A white van coursed through narrow roads along the monsoon-soaked coastline of Kerala, a state in southwestern India. Inside, Radha Upasarna, a volunteer, and two nurses looked over the roster of patients they would visit, most of whom had cancer or heart disease or were paraplegic.

headline: John Maynard Keynes: Great Economist, Terrible Currency Trader
text: If you watch a lot of business news on cable, you will inevitably see advertisements for software platforms that enable do-it-yourself currency trading.

headline: A Therapist’s Fib
text: An old New Yorker cartoon features a man suspended upside down from the ceiling, like a stalactite. A psychiatrist explains to the wife that the first objective is to convince the man that he is a stalagmite.

headline: Reflecting on Obama's Presidency
text: What have been the defining aspects of Obama's legacy as president?

headline: News Q’s | Ötzi the Iceman’s Stomach Bacteria Offers Clues on Human Migration
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Ötzi the Iceman’s Stomach Bacteria Offers Clues on Human Migration.”

headline: Philippine Supreme Court Approves Return of U.S. Troops
text: BEIJING — The United States won a significant victory on Tuesday in its efforts to counter China’s rising influence in the South China Sea, as the highest court in the Philippines cleared the way for American troops to return to the country.

headline: Istanbul Explosion Kills 10 Tourists, and ISIS Is Blamed
text: ISTANBUL — On any given day, the heart of this city’s historic district, where the monuments of three empires — Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman — collide with a mix of majesty and tranquillity, is a bustling center of tourism, one of the world’s most visited places.

headline: Block by Block | Ditmas Park
text: Leafy streets and idiosyncratic houses distinguish the Brooklyn neighborhood of Ditmas Park.

headline: Block by Block: Ditmas Park
text: Ditmas Park, Brooklyn, is the focus of the next video in our new monthly series, “Block by Block.” Watch for future installments from neighborhoods around the city.

headline: If Shonda Rhimes Can Say Yes, So Can I
text: It is the hallmark of most adults, as we lurch zombielike into middle age, increasingly to become distilled versions of ourselves. What once burgeoned or flourished now crystallizes or self-embalms. In the last year, I started doing needlepoint while drinking a gin and tonic; currently nothing holds my interest like “The Great British Baking Show” and its explications of self-saucing puddings. My friends call me Danger.

headline: David Bowie’s Fashion Legacy
text: When the news of David Bowie’s death broke this week, and emails circulated that mourned and celebrated the artist, a colleague asked what designers Mr. Bowie had most influenced. “What designer didn’t he influence?” another wrote. It’s a good question.

headline: Hillary Clinton Races to Close Enthusiasm Gap With Bernie Sanders in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — Iowa Democrats are displaying far less passion for Hillary Clinton than for Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont three weeks before the presidential caucuses, creating anxiety inside the Clinton campaign as she scrambles to energize supporters and to court wavering voters.

headline: What Musicians or Bands Mean the Most to You?
text: Has a musician ever meant more to you than as just a person who makes music? He, she or they may have become an inspiration or role model, and perhaps even become a part of your identity and how you see yourself.

headline: Sitting With Michelle Obama to Stand for State of the Union Themes
text: WASHINGTON — Each year the first lady attends the State of the Union address with about two dozen guests who capture the news of the day and exemplify the president’s message. This year’s guests, for instance, include a Syrian refugee, the lead plaintiff in the Supreme Court case last year legalizing same-sex marriage and an Air Force sergeant who helped take down a gunman on a train in France.

headline: ‘Excellent Daughters,’ by Katherine Zoepf
text: “Why are foreigners so interested in the hijab?” a devout young Syrian woman demanded after reading a newspaper article by Katherine Zoepf in which she appeared. “We spent so many months talking to you about what we think, what we believe, what is on our minds.”

headline: ‘Their Promised Land: My Grandparents in Love and War,’ by Ian Buruma
text: Bernard and Win wrote to each ­other as teenagers in love in the long-lost years when Europe committed suicide in World War I. They continued their correspondence whenever they were apart, through another world war. They wrote about how much they missed each other, about classical music and gardening and, of course, about their children.

headline: Invisible Designs
text: Bohumil Hrabal died only once — in Prague, on Feb. 3, 1997 — but there are at least two versions of the story.

headline: Face in the Crowd: Mark Ronson at Burberry
text: LONDON — When it comes to the London men’s wear shows, Burberry is widely considered the jewel in the crown and one of the few events able to lure an A-list front row. The British behemoth starts proceedings promptly, unlike a vast majority of shows, so, about 15 minutes before the lights go down, there’s often a celebrity or four standing around. Styles caught up with Mark Ronson, the D.J. and producer, in the tent in Kensington Gardens.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Istanbul, Rupert Murdoch, David Bowie
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: New York Today: A Sprinkle of Stardust
text: Updated 8:56 a.m.

headline: Of Ted Cruz’s Birth Status, Senator Claire McCaskill Says, ‘I Think It’s a Question’
text: When Senator John McCain of Arizona, the 2008 Republican nominee for president, faced questions about meeting the constitutional qualifications because of his birth in the Panama Canal Zone, one Democratic colleague rushed to end any doubt.

headline: Morning Agenda: No Bottom in Sight for Oil Prices
text: NO BOTTOM IN SIGHT FOR OIL PRICES | The collapse in commodity prices pushed oil futures even lower on Monday and analysts predicted that the slide was far from over,Jad Mouawad reports in The New York Times.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Junior Doctors’ Strike in England Disrupts Care for Thousands
text: LONDON — Hospital doctors in England staged their first strike in four decades on Tuesday, disrupting treatment for thousands of patients in the National Health Service and escalating political tensions over a publicly funded health care system so revered that it was once likened to a national religion.

headline: China Is Said to Arrest 4 Human Rights Advocates
text: HONG KONG — The Chinese police have formally arrested four human rights advocates in the last week on charges of subverting state power after detaining them for the last six months, according to one of their colleagues and rights groups.

headline: Chelsea Clinton to Campaign in New Hampshire Amid Threat From Sanders
text: The Clinton campaign has been dispatching a rotation of high-power surrogates to New Hampshire, most recently Lena Dunham and Abby Wambach.

headline: Helen Mirren Doesn’t Feel Worthy of Your Admiration
text: Helen Mirren, people. Helen. Freaking. Mirren. The Bagger has only been at this gig for a year or so, but interviewing Ms. Mirren — at length, in a TimesTalk — has far and away been one of the brightest highlights yet.

headline: Hotels Offer Perks for Four-Legged Guests
text: A dog bed and a free rawhide bone may have represented the hospitality vanguard for pet friendliness a decade ago, but now the bar has been raised, not just by hotels supplying monogrammed doggy robes and play parks, but even tour operators that welcome canine companions.

headline: For Some Atlanta Hawks, a Revved-Up Game of Uno Is Diversion No. 1
text: PHILADELPHIA — Lamar Patterson was new to the Atlanta Hawks when he discovered several teammates playing a popular card game at training camp. Patterson asked if he could join them. He thought he knew the rules.

headline: More ‘Progressive’ Than Thou
text: In these last gasping weeks before the Iowa caucuses, Hillary Clinton has settled upon a political identity, declaring herself ‘‘a progressive who likes to get things done.’’ The label reassures left-wing Democrats that she shares their values while also signaling to the party’s centrists that she is above all pragmatic. Clinton introduced the phrase in October, at the first Democratic presidential debate, where it produced whoops of joy from the live audience: Here was Clinton striking back at the supposedly pie-in-the-sky Bernie Sanders. The Clinton campaign was so enthused by the response that it printed up bumper stickers with the phrase, and in early December, Clinton repeated it in an email to Howard Dean’s grass-roots group, Democracy for America, pleading for an endorsement.

headline: Poll Watch: Obama’s Gun Policies Are Popular, but Verdict Is Mixed on Other Issues
text: President Obama’s plan to expand background checks to cover more gun sales generated wide support among Americans, but it did little to improve his overall standing with the public, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

headline: The Trials of Alice Goffman
text: Before the morning last September when I joined her at Newark Airport, I had met Alice Goffman only twice. But in the previous months, amid a widening controversy both inside and outside the academy over her research, she and I had developed a regular email correspondence, and she greeted me at the gate as if I were an old friend. A 34-year-old untenured professor of sociology at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, Goffman had just begun a year of leave at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, which she hoped she might use to escape her critics and get back to work. Now, though, she was returning to Madison for a four-day visit, to deliver a lecture and catch up with her graduate students.

headline: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’: Going Beyond the Verdict
text: More than 20 years after some 107 million people watched a Los Angeles jury announce that it had found O. J. Simpson not guilty of the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman, are television viewers ready to see it all again?

headline: Digging Deeper Into Vivian Maier’s Past
text: When she started delving into Vivian Maier’s family history, an amateur researcher had no idea that her search would become an obsession.

headline: In Final State of the Union Address, Obama May Set Aside Convention
text: President Obama will reach one of the first major milestones of his last year in office on Tuesday night when he delivers his seventh and final State of the Union address.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 5-11, 2016
text: Have you been following this week’s news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

headline: 1935: Amelia Earhart Spans Stretch of Pacific
text: On January 12, 1935, Amelia Earhart completed a solo flight across 2,300 miles of the Pacific Ocean, from Honolulu to California. Three years earlier, Earhart became the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean. Below, an excerpt from the European edition of The New York Herald on her journey in 1935:

headline: A Progressive Way to End Corporate Taxes
text: Washington — JUST about every American chief executive has the same dream: to get out from under the corporate income tax. For many, that means lobbying Congress to change the tax code. But for a growing number, it also involves increasingly creative — and successful — tricks to avoid their liability.

headline: A Lineup of Missteps
text: Here’s a sobering start to the new year: an extra long rundown of gaffes and missteps, compiled with help from colleagues and our ever-vigilant readers.

headline: Trump Says N.F.L. Is Boring; It Has Actually Never Been More Exciting
text: Six of the eight teams left standing in this N.F.L. season are pass-wacky — only Carolina and Seattle rush more than they throw. The whole league is pass-wacky; Chase Stuart of Football Perspective, writing for The Times, noted that the N.F.L. just set records for pass attempts, passing yards and passing touchdowns per game.

headline: An Enduring Coach Pulls a Timely Trick
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The biggest play of the national championship game was a surprise in the moment because it was a surprise in the much greater sweep of Alabama’s history and Coach Nick Saban’s career.

headline: The Airbnb From Hell
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Bully for Neurotoxins
text: The Wall Street Journal has a remarkable editorial titled The Carnage in Coal Country, accusing President Obama of destroying jobs through his terrible, horrible, no good regulations on coal: “According to the National Mining Association, 40,000 coal jobs have been lost in the U.S. since 2008.”

headline: Brazil’s Digital Backlash
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A São Paulo judge sent shock waves across Brazil last month with a ruling that required Brazilian telecommunications operators to block the use of the instant messaging platform WhatsApp for 48 hours. Less than 13 hours later, another São Paulo judge reversed the decision, restoring service. But in the meantime, as many as 100 million Brazilians had been seriously inconvenienced, and civil libertarians around the world looked on with dismay.

headline: Iranian Official Denies That Nuclear Reactor Was Sealed
text: TEHRAN — An Iranian nuclear official on Tuesday denied a report that technicians had removed the core of the country’s only heavy-water reactor and poured concrete into the cavity, a final step toward the completion of the historic nuclear agreement in July and the lifting of sanctions on Iran.

headline: Daily Report: One Grand Experiment Ends for a Facebook Co-Founder
text: Silicon Valley wealth can end up in unexpected places, with unusual results.

headline: You Will Not Win the Powerball Jackpot
text: Despite the dreams that felt so real, you are still not filthy rich.

headline: Why Putin Loves Trump
text: Sofia, Bulgaria — “VLADIMIR VLADIMIROVICH, is war coming?”

headline: Inside the Set of ‘Sesame Street’
text: After 45 years on the public broadcaster PBS, Big Bird, Elmo and the rest of the “Sesame Street” crew are settling into a new set as well as a new television home on the premium cable network HBO.

headline: ‘Sesame Street’ Gets New Upscale Look for HBO Premiere
text: Big Bird’s nest has moved to a tree. Elmo has moved from an apartment into a brownstone. His best friend, Abby Cadabby, loves her new community garden. And while Oscar the Grouch still makes a trash can his home, he now pops up through an underground tunnel of connecting recycling and compost bins.

headline: Bryson Tiller and Other Singers Are Bringing Hip-Hop Into R&B
text: So much of hip-hop’s history has been about absorption and conquering. No other genre in pop has made so much mulch of its enemies and its obstacles. When it came to R&B, the dominant sound of prerap black pop, hip-hop was stealthy.

headline: Picking a Windows 10 Security Package
text: Q. I’m just starting to use a Windows computer again after many years on a Mac. I want to protect myself but the number of options is overwhelming, including antivirus, anti-spyware, anti-spam, anti-malware, personal firewalls, anti-phishing, anti-Trojan and so on. Do I need all this and should I be paying for all this protection or will some of the free programs suffice?

headline: Picasso Bust at Center of Custody Battle Between Gagosian and Qatar Royal Family
text: The high-powered art dealer Larry Gagosian says he bought it. The royal family of Qatar says it bought the sculpture, too. And now they are facing off in court over who owns Picasso’s important plaster bust of his muse (and mistress) Marie-Thérèse Walter, a star of the Museum of Modern Art’s popular “Picasso Sculpture” show.

headline: A New Director for Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival
text: Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival, nestled in the Berkshire Hills of western Massachusetts, has a new leader: Pamela Tatge, who is to take over as executive director beginning April 18. Previously, the position of executive and artistic director was held by Ella Baff. Ms. Tatge is the director of the Center for the Arts at Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., where, for the past 16 years, she has organized programming in dance, music, theater and the visual arts.

headline: Alabamians Cross State Lines, Seeking a Golden Ticket
text: TALLAPOOSA, Ga. — There was not much in the world that was more important to many Alabamians in recent days than the national football championship game between the University of Alabama and Clemson.

headline: Creative Capital Awards Nearly $4.4 Million in Arts Grants
text: Artistic projects that aim to reflect broad cultural conversations about gender, gun violence and race are among those chosen for nearly $4.4 million worth of grants awarded by Creative Capital, the organization announced on Tuesday.

headline: 1916: Key Citadel May Have Fallen
text: If it is true that Mount Lovcen has gone, then a position of great importance has been lost to the Allies. This strip of Austrian territory, says the ‘‘Times,’’ contains Cattaro, with its deep inlet from the sea, the Bocche di Cattaro — a natural harbor of great value.

headline: MoveOn Site Puts Its Backing Behind Bernie Sanders
text: The liberal political group MoveOn.org threw its endorsement to Senator Bernie Sanders in the Democratic presidential contest, backing him after its officials spent months in search of an alternative to Hillary Clinton and invested $1 million in ads to draft Senator Elizabeth Warren for the race.

headline: Decoding Airline Fare Classes to Make the Most of Your Miles
text: Do you know what a Q fare is? How about an X or a Z? When you browse for flights on an airline’s website, assorted letters appear in your search results. Travelers often miss them. Or see them but don’t factor them into their decision about which flight to choose. But these letters matter. Because of them, the person to your left may receive more award miles than you, reach elite status faster than you, or change her itinerary at no cost while you pay a $200 fee — yet you’re both in the same cabin. What gives?

headline: Pakistani Soldiers Search Times Reporter’s Home
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Pakistani paramilitary soldiers searched the private home in Islamabad of a New York Times reporter on Tuesday morning without a warrant, leaving without seizing any property or making an arrest.

headline: Bernie Sanders Has Edge in Iowa and Widens New Hampshire Lead, Polls Find
text: Senator Bernie Sanders is breaking away from Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire and is edging ahead of her in Iowa, according to new polls that show him solidifying the support of Democrats ahead the first two 2016 presidential primary election contests.

headline: Revitalizing the Waterfront in Redondo Beach, Calif.
text: Redondo Beach, once a major tourist destination, no longer attracts crowds of visitors. A $250 million public-private partnership to redevelop its faded waterfront aims to change that.

headline: California Beach City Enlists Private Partner to Rejuvenate Pier
text: REDONDO BEACH, Calif. — The Redondo Beach pier juts into Santa Monica Bay, at the southern end of a string of beach cities loosely connected by a bike path and teeming with visitors.

headline: 1941: R.A.F. Bombs Turin
text: LONDON — Swooping across the Alps, British bombers dropped loads of bombs and pamphlets on Turin, in northern Italy, last night [Jan. 11] while other R.A.F. raiders attacked objectives in western Germany, including the Nazi naval base and shipyards at Wilhelmshaven and targets on or near the Dutch and Belgian coasts.

headline: 3 Philadelphia Publications Are Donated to a Nonprofit Journalism Institute
text: H.F. Lenfest, the owner of The Philadelphia Inquirer, The Philadelphia Daily News and Philly.com, announced on Tuesday that he had donated the publications to a newly formed nonprofit journalism institute.

headline: ‘Silence of the Lambs’ House Can’t Find a Buyer
text: Since it was listed for sale last summer, a century-old house made famous as the home of a serial killer in the 1991 movie “The Silence of the Lambs” has attracted plenty of curiosity, but it has mostly languished on the real estate market.

headline: Per Se
text: Fine dining from the chef Thomas Keller in Columbus Circle.

headline: At Thomas Keller’s Per Se, Slips and Stumbles
text: The lady had dropped her napkin.

headline: U.S. to Block Fungal Peril to Salamanders With Ban on Pet Imports
text: On the eve of President Obama’s final State of the Union address, his administration gave North American salamanders a chance, and conservationists a reason to cheer.

headline: Stung by Low Oil Prices, BP Will Cut 4,000 Jobs
text: LONDON — The persistent plunge in oil prices has translated into a new round of industry job cuts.

headline: Glass Beads Made in Czech Village Adorn Bodies of the World’s Tribes
text: DESNA, Czech Republic — When the January issue of National Geographic landed in his mailbox last year, Petr Pus nearly fell to the floor. There on the cover and throughout the issue were members of the Kayapo tribe, living far up the Amazon in conditions more Stone Age than information age, all of them adorned with face paint and a glittering assortment of beads.

headline: Marin Montagut’s Atelier in Normandy
text: The artist takes T around his bucolic home-away-from-home in in Saint-Luc, where he creates his Bonjour City Map-Guides series.

headline: A French Watercolorist’s Countryside Escape
text: Rarely without his navy and white marinière — or his robin’s-egg blue Vespa — the French illustrator-filmmaker-multimedia artist Marin Montagut has emerged as a darling of sorts in the Parisian cultural scene. Known first for his documentaries for the fashion paragon Inès de la Fressange, he’s earning attention today for weaving watercolors of his favorite fashionable addresses in Paris, London and New York into Bonjour City Map-Guides, a series of pocket-sized folding maps. And yet, the globetrotter produces much of his work about an hour from the City of Light in his creative home-away-from-home in Saint-Luc, Normandy — prepossessing as much for its design as for its bucolic environs.

headline: The Artist Behind Our 52 Places to Go in 2016 Cover
text: When we needed a cover illustration for our annual 52 Places to Go issue, we turned to Rafael Lopez, a celebrated illustrator. After all, our No. 1 pick this year is Mexico City, where Mr. Lopez is from and lives part-time. He’s also an extraordinary artist who’s created dynamic and colorful posters, murals and postage stamps. We were delighted with the results. To learn more, we asked Mr. Lopez a few questions about his inspiration, his life and his work. He sent his answers, which are below, edited for length and clarity, by email from San Miguel de Allende.

headline: New York Times Names New Media Columnist
text: The New York Times said on Tuesday that Jim Rutenberg, chief political correspondent for the Sunday magazine, would become its media columnist, filling a role that has been vacant since the death of David Carr about a year ago.

headline: American Ballet Theater Names Kara Medoff Barnett Executive Director
text: She started ballet lessons at 3 in North Carolina, but gave up dancing for college, then Harvard Business School and a career in the arts that eventually led her to become an executive at Lincoln Center. Now Kara Medoff Barnett is returning to her first love: She will be the next executive director of American Ballet Theater, the company announced on Tuesday.

headline: Dear Powerball Winner: Take Our Advice and Take the Annuity
text: So let us suppose, reader, that you have won a $1.5 billion Powerball jackpot. Congratulations! You have some important decisions to make, such as what ailing magazine to acquire and what congressional seat your spouse should run for. But first, you must choose whether to take the prize as an annuity paid over 30 years, or a lump-sum payment right now.

headline: At Burberry Men’s Show, a Simple Tribute to David Bowie
text: Christopher Bailey honored the late musician in his men’s fall/winter 2016 show, while newcomer Liam Hodges explored British car culture.

headline: Coachella Promoters Announce Panorama, a New Music Festival in New York
text: The promoters behind Coachella are bringing a new pop festival to New York in July, after months of behind-the-scenes lobbying and a press-release war with a homegrown competitor, Governors Ball.

headline: New Generation of Diesel Technology
text: To the Editor:

headline: Persian (or Arabian) Gulf Is Caught in the Middle of Regional Rivalries
text: What’s in a name?

headline: Get Paid to Organize Your Children’s Closets (and Yours)
text: Anyone can clean out a closet. We pull out all the clothes and apply some standard (for children, that’s little more than “does it fit?”; for adults, it ranges from “have I worn it recently?” to the organizational guru Marie Kondo’s now-famous question, “Does it bring joy?”) If an item passes, back it goes, while failures are headed for donation boxes. Typically, especially for ourselves, we hang too many things back up. When clothes are “as good as new,” or were expensive, sometimes it’s hard to persuade ourselves to give them away, even if on some level we know we don’t really want them any more.

headline: Sasha Petraske’s Legacy Lives On With Seaborne in Red Hook
text: The bar owner Sasha Petraske, a pioneer of the current cocktail revival, had a few projects in the works when he died last August at age 42, including a book and a hoped-for third iteration of his trailblazing speakeasy Milk & Honey.

headline: China Is Said to Detain Swedish Human Rights Worker
text: BEIJING — A Swedish man who worked in support of human rights groups and grass-roots legal advocates in China has been detained in Beijing on accusations of endangering state security, supporters of the man said Tuesday. They described the detention of the Swede, Peter Jesper Dahlin, as another step in the Chinese government’s drive to silence human rights defense campaigners.

headline: A Saudi Aramco I.P.O. Could Herald a Wider Sale of Assets
text: The sale of a bit of Saudi Aramco, a government-owned oil producer, could be the first in a series of spinoffs and privatizations by Riyadh.

headline: Per Se Review
text: Fine dining from the chef Thomas Keller.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Classic White Shirts
text: London is a city where, at least with respect to fashion shows, anything goes — from pants with butt cleavage to bucket headpieces. All the more reason for a classic white shirt to feel special. They’ve popped up all over the London Collections: Men fall/winter 2016 runways, in such wildly disparate shows as Wales Bonner and Rory Parnell-Mooney (where references ranged from the jazz composer Sun Ra to catholic schools, respectively). At Alexander McQueen, a simple white shirt was the perfect foil to bold prints and ornate gilets.

headline: Change the Ways of Congress?
text: To the Editor:

headline: A Museum-Style Sampling of Italian Futurism
text: A connoisseur’s love of Italian modernist painting, abstract in style and modest in scale, lies behind this compendious, museum-style exhibition, organized by the dealer Gian Enzo Sperone. It’s the sort of historical show that can take decades to pull together. And that this can be done on such a scale by a commercial gallery is surely only possible because the art in question still has a fairly limited set of of devotees and remains obtainable.

headline: Los rostros de los que resisten la crisis económica de Puerto Rico
text: Con la crisis económica de Puerto Rico muchos profesionales jóvenes se han visto obligados a buscar oportunidades en el continente americano. Joseph Rodríguez retrató a los que se han quedado en el país”.

headline: Los rostros de los que resisten la crisis económica de Puerto Rico
text: Read in English

headline: The Post Office, Under Attack
text: To the Editor:

headline: Number of Female Directors of Top Films Ticks Up, Study Says
text: The latest study on gender equality in Hollywood found that last year, women accounted for 9 percent of the directors of the 250 top-grossing domestic films. This might not sound great, but it’s an improvement over 2014, when women made up just 7 percent of directors for those films. The 2015 result put women on par with the level achieved in 1998.

headline: Taking Action in Syria
text: To the Editor:

headline: Art Made by Tempting Animals
text: At the artist Dana Sherwood’s apartment on the Upper West Side, her dog, Hera, answers the door, tail wagging. A lifelong equestrian who now competes in dressage, Sherwood is used to collaborating with animals — and connects with them on a fundamental level. “Dressage is all about understanding a horse through the feel of your body; it’s like inventing another language,” says Sherwood. “What I’m interested in lately is the difference between what we assume animals think and how they actually behave.” In her new solo show, “Crossing the Wild Line,” at Denny Gallery on the Lower East Side, Sherwood takes nature’s pulse by way of an unlikely combination of media: pastry, video and drawing.

headline: Obama Confronts Americans’ Fears in State of the Union Speech
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Tuesday set forth an ambitious vision for America’s future but conceded his own failure to heal the political divisions holding back progress, calling it a lasting disappointment of his tenure.

headline: English Doctors Share Frustrations
text: Junior doctors in London staged a strike against government plans to reform pay and work hours. They joined their colleagues across the country for the first protest in 40 years.

headline: Supreme Court Strikes Down Part of Florida Death Penalty
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court struck down an aspect of Florida’s capital punishment system on Tuesday, saying it did not give jurors a sufficient role in deciding whether defendants should be put to death.

headline: Turkish Ambassador’s View
text: To the Editor:

headline: Ad Backing Jeb Bush Calls Marco Rubio Untrustworthy on Immigration
text: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, has released its third advertisement criticizing Senator Marco Rubio, this time attacking him over immigration. The ad is called “Vane” — no doubt a deliberate homophone.

headline: Directors Guild Nominates ‘Revenant,’ ‘Spotlight’ and ‘Big Short’
text: Alejandro G. Iñárritu (“The Revenant”), Tom McCarthy (“Spotlight”), and Adam McKay (“The Big Short”) were among the feature film nominees chosen as the year’s best by the 15,000-member Directors Guild of America, whose final winners — to be announced at a ceremony on Feb. 6 — often hew closely to pictures that win an Academy Award. Since 2000, all but three Directors Guild winners (“Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,” “Brokeback Mountain” and “Gravity”) went on to claim the best picture Oscar.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Backing of Food Services Union
text: The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union will endorse Hillary Clinton on Tuesday, giving the Democratic candidate a welcome boost as polls in Iowa and New Hampshire show Senator Bernie Sanders gaining ground.

headline: Witness Recalls the Moment of Blast
text: A man who saw the explosion in Istanbul’s central district of Sultanahmet on Tuesday recounts what he saw.

headline: David Chang Opens Momofuku Nishi in Chelsea
text: Momofuku Nishi Word got out last Friday that David Chang would open his latest venture that evening at 6. A long line had formed outside the Chelsea restaurant by 5 p.m. By 6:15, plates of food were streaming to the bare wood communal tables. Mr. Chang was there, baseball cap pulled low, describing how he had originally envisioned a fast-food model but changed his mind in favor of a restaurant with a decidedly eclectic menu. It hints of Italy, but in the hands of Joshua Pinsky, the chef, the bagna cauda winks at Caesar salad, and cacio e pepe swaps out the cheese for fermented chickpeas to become ceci e pepe. There’s no shortage of noodles, and the menu is deciphered with playful footnotes. Reservations will be taken in a few weeks: 232 Eighth Avenue (West 22nd Street), 646-518-1919, nishi.momofuku.com.

headline: Shona McCarthy New Head of Edinburgh Fringe
text: Shona McCarthy, an arts leader and consultant, has been appointed chief executive of the Edinburgh Festival Fringe Society, the organization that oversees the annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the largest multi-arts festival in the world. Ms. McCarthy, who will take over in early March, assumes a post currently occupied by Kath Mainland, who has run the Society for seven years. Ms. Mainland announced in November that she was stepping down to become executive director of the Melbourne Festival.

headline: N.H.L. This Week: Ducks Try to Reclaim Edge on Kings
text: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot — or not so hot — teams and players. (All times Eastern.)

headline: Video Is Said to Show the Moments Before a Suspected Gang Rape in Brooklyn
text: A smartphone video that its owner and defense lawyers said showed a brief verbal encounter before a suspected gang rape at a Brooklyn playground emerged on Tuesday, another development in an increasingly complex inquiry that has roiled the city.

headline: Mark Morris to Choreograph a New Full-Length Work
text: The Mark Morris Dance Group has announced that Mr. Morris is to choreograph a full-length dance narrative, “Layla and Majnun,” based on a love story that has its origins in seventh-century Persia. It is to have its premiere in Berkeley, Calif., in September. The music, live as always with Mr. Morris, will involve Azerbaijani mugham, a complex combination of music and poetry, to be performed on both traditional and Western instruments by the Silk Road Ensemble with the father and daughter Azerbaijani vocalists Alim Qasimov and Fargana Qasimova.

headline: F.D.A. Nominee Clears One Hurdle, but Others Remain
text: A crucial Senate committee on Tuesday voted unanimously to approve Dr. Robert M. Califf, a cardiologist and clinical trial expert from Duke University, as the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration. Approval by the full Senate, however, is unlikely to happen soon, because Senator Lisa Murkowski of Alaska has pledged to block his candidacy over the agency’s approval of genetically engineered salmon.

headline: Readers Respond to the Lonesome Single Men of New York
text: A storm of readers’ comments — over 650 on The New York Times’s site and over 200 on The Times’s main Facebook page — followed the posting of “Meet the Bachelors Who Yearn for Something More,” an article by Sridhar Pappu on aging single men in New York.

headline: As Cuomo Acts on Homeless Problem, New York City Blames State Cuts
text: Hopping from one interview to the next, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York hit the news media circuit to convey the urgency of the surprise executive order he issued last week requiring local governments to move homeless people off the streets when the temperature goes below freezing.

headline: Putin Doesn’t Rule Out Asylum in Moscow for Syria’s Assad
text: MOSCOW — There has long been speculation about whether President Bashar al-Assad of Syria might one day join the list of cashiered dictators who call Moscow — or at least its plush, gated suburbs like Rublovka — home.

headline: Hillary Clinton Accuses Bernie Sanders of Not Standing Up to Gun Lobby
text: AMES, Iowa – With Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont taking the lead in a new Iowa caucus poll, Hillary Clinton sharply challenged his core political message on Tuesday, saying his denunciations of big-money special interests were undercut by his 2005 congressional vote for a bill granting legal immunity for gun manufacturers – a bill backed by the National Rifle Association.

headline: Reducing the Stress on Students
text: To the Editor:

headline: The David Bowie Song That Fans Are Listening to Most: ‘Heroes’
text: A chart of the songs Spotify users listened to most after David Bowie’s death.

headline: Bill Foster, Coach Who Set Duke on Winning Track, Dies at 86
text: Bill Foster, a basketball coach who specialized in reviving underperforming college teams and achieved success at a handful of programs, most notably Duke, which he guided to the national final in 1978, died on Jan. 7 in Chicago. He was 86.

headline: Republican Candidates Grapple With a Touchy Topic: Poverty
text: COLUMBIA, S.C. — On Saturday, only three weeks before voters in Iowa first get to weigh in on the presidential candidates, six Republican hopefuls gathered at a convention center here to talk about poverty. Donald Trump and Ted Cruz, the top two, weren’t there. But still, poverty?

headline: Chris Christie, in State of the State Speech, Pledges He Won’t Fade Away
text: TRENTON — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, facing emboldened Democratic opponents at home and the first sustained attacks from his rivals for the Republican presidential nomination, used his State of the State address here on Tuesday to promise lawmakers, or perhaps to warn them, that he would not fade away in the final years of his second term.

headline: How to Transform Penn Station: Move the Garden
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo entreated New Yorkers last week to “think big” again, invoking Robert Moses, New York’s take-no-prisoners planning czar of the 20th century.

headline: A.I.G. Investors Unhappy With Insurer’s Strategy, Advisory Firm Says
text: If the American International Group’s chief executive, Peter D. Hancock, was planning to essentially maintain the status quo at the insurer, he should probably expect resistance from investors.

headline: 3-Year-Old Finds Gun in Dad’s Store, and Old Story Plays Out
text: The 3-year-old was sitting on a stool behind the counter near the cash register while his father, the owner of a small convenience store in North Carolina, chatted with a customer on Sunday.

headline: ‘Bellwether’ G.M. Trial Opens Over Defect Claim
text: While acknowledging its role in failing to report a deadly defect for more than a decade, General Motors on Tuesday forcefully questioned the story of a man who was injured in a May 2014 crash and is suing the company.

headline: Volvo Makes a Comeback, With a Detour Through China
text: DETROIT — Record sales in the American auto industry have left the biggest carmakers flush with cash, which they are pouring into new models on display this week at the annual North American International Auto Show here.

headline: 45 Whales Die on Indian Shore
text: NEW DELHI — Scores of large, short-finned pilot whales washed ashore in southern India, an official said Tuesday, and 45 have died on a beach. But many others have been guided back to sea.

headline: Op-Photo: Visiting the Oregon Protesters, in Revolutionary Costume
text: A man dressed as one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence visited the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge in Oregon on January 10. The refuge is currently occupied by armed protesters led by Ammon Bundy.

headline: Man Cuddles 1,500-Pound Bear (and Lives to Share the Video)
text: After a video was posted to Facebook that showed a man attempting to cuddle with a Kodiak bear, over 11 million people had a logical response: Click.

headline: Video Review: With the S60, Volvo Adds a Sedan to Its Cross Country Line
text: VOLVO’S Cross Country line has been a hit that automakers dream of. Raising the height, adding all-wheel drive and dressing it in Fjallraven-like cladding gave their wagons the likability of s’mores.

headline: Puerto Rico Utility’s Debt Plan Still Fragile, Lawmakers Are Told
text: WASHINGTON — Puerto Rico’s troubled electric monopoly, mired in about $9 billion of debt, stands to run out of money by midsummer if its hard-won plans to restructure fall through — something that could happen this month, a top official of the utility told a congressional panel on Tuesday.

headline: Residents in Whitesboro, N.Y., Vote to Keep a Much-Criticized Village Emblem
text: The official emblems of towns and villages generally attract little attention. Often pastoral, they are generally gentle and unassuming. Not so the seal of the Village of Whitesboro, in central New York.

headline: Street Style in London
text: The looks on the streets during London Men’s Fashion Week.

headline: David Bowie (1947-2016)
text: The British legend wrote songs above all about being an outsider: an alien, a misfit, a sexual adventurer, a faraway astronaut.

headline: How The Times Prepares for Convention Coverage, and ‘Who Is Larry Doby?’
text: Walter Baranger, who participated in a convention site walk-through in Cleveland, writes about campaign coverage and surprise swag.

headline: Monte Irvin, Star Outfielder Who Lost His Prime to Racism, Dies at 96
text: Monte Irvin, the New York Giants outfielder who was one of the first outstanding black players in the major leagues and a Hall of Famer for his brilliance in the Negro leagues, where he spent most of his prime years before baseball’s color barrier was shattered, died on Monday night at his home in Houston. He was 96.

headline: Facts & Figures: Cruz’s Canadian Birth Could Matter in Iowa
text: Forty-seven percent of likely Republican caucus-goers in Iowa do not think someone born outside the United States should be able to become president, according to a new survey by Public Policy Polling. That could pose some difficulty for Ted Cruz, who was born in Canada.

headline: Review: In Fox’s ‘Second Chance,’ a Life Resurrected
text: The Frankenstein genre and the buddy cop genre may seem a long way from each other, but “Second Chance,” which begins on Wednesday night on Fox, is born of both. And it’s aptly titled. The premiere has so much going on and is so absurd that you may be tempted not to return, but give it another try. Rewards await.

headline: Review: At American Realness Festival, Mirrored Movements and a Nearly Naked Yvonne Meier
text: In Greek mythology, Panoptes was a giant with a hundred eyes. In architecture, the panopticon, a circular building designed so that everything can be seen from its center, was sometimes used for prisons. Then there’s the choreographer Jillian Peña, who, like a modern-day Panoptes, is obsessed by the notion of multiples. On Saturday afternoon, as part of the American Realness festival, Ms. Peña offered the premiere of “Panopticon,” in which one dancer serves as a mirror to the other. Unfortunately, it wasn’t the best reflection of her experiments in twinning.

headline: The Biggest Powerball Jackpot Ever: The Odds and Where the Money Goes
text: News flash: Your chances of winning the Powerball jackpot are not great — just one in 292.2 million. Still, with the next drawing scheduled for Wednesday at 10:59 p.m. Eastern time, ticket sales are going through the roof around the country.

headline: Review: ‘Museum of Memories’ Explores What’s Left of a Life Lost
text: The young man is dead, and we know this because he tells us so himself. “When I died it was my heart that stopped beating,” Markus says gently, no grievance in his tone. Death is what he wanted, at least at the time.

headline: Review: In ‘Intimacy,’ What They Did for Love
text: “What’s the most extreme thing you’ve done out of love for someone else?”

headline: Pictures of the Day: Ukraine and Elsewhere
text: Ukraine and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Iran Seizes U.S. Sailors Amid Claims of Spying
text: WASHINGTON — Iran seized two United States Navy patrol boats and 10 crew members who were described as “trespassing” on Tuesday in Iranian waters near a major naval base.

headline: Jan. 12, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Ukraine, Turkey, South Africa and India.

headline: Review: A Woman Grows Up in ‘Employee of the Year’
text: “Employee of the Year” was performed in October 2014 as part of the Crossing the Line festival. Following are excerpts from Charles Isherwood’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 17, 2014; the full text is online here. The play continues through Sunday as part of the Under the Radar festival at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, Manhattan; 212-967-7555, undertheradarfestival.com.

headline: California Rejects VW’s Diesel Recall Plan
text: Regulators in California on Tuesday formally rejected Volkswagen’s plan to fix its polluting diesel engines, underscoring their frustration with the German automaker’s ability to repair its defective vehicles.

headline: Weary of Chaos, Factions in Libya Consider Peace
text: MISURATA, Libya — Four years after Libya’s revolution, the scars of war are still visible in this city — buildings pockmarked with bullet and rocket holes, graffiti on the walls remembering fallen fighters, and a war museum where rusty ammunition spills across the sidewalk in front.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: PAC Backing Jeb Bush Counters Campaign Message With Ad Critical of Marco Rubio
text: GRINNELL, Iowa — The messages coming out of the political world of Jeb Bush could not be more different.

headline: A ‘Barbie From Outer Space’ Touches Down on a New Stage
text: After belting out the moody opening song of her new musical, “A Ride on the Irish Cream,” Erin Markey, her long hair swaying across a microphone stand in the rehearsal room, paused to give her band notes.

headline: Mats Ek, the Swedish Choreographer, Says His Goodbye Isn’t Quite a Farewell
text: PARIS — “Last dance for the choreographer Mats Ek,” France Musique declared. “Mats Ek, the great Swedish choreographer, leaves the stage after 50 years of creation,” Les Echos said. “The choreographer removes his works from the stage,” Le Figaro reported in an article headlined “Mats Ek: The Shock of Farewell.”

headline: ‘Bowie Again!’ Fashion Critic’s Notebook
text: Emails about how best to report on the formative relationship David Bowie had with the fashion industry started to swirl through the Style section (and between the Style and Culture sections) as soon as we heard news of Mr. Bowie’s death.

headline: Review: Jane Mayer’s ‘Dark Money,’ About the Koch Brothers’ Fortune and Influence
text: When Jane Mayer published her 10,000-word article about Charles and David Koch in The New Yorker in August 2010, David Koch denounced her piece in print and, as she reports in her new book, “Dark Money: The Hidden History of the Billionaires Behind the Rise of the Radical Right,” a “private investigative firm with powerful political and law enforcement connections was retained.” While there was no hard evidence on who had hired the firm, “clues leading back to the Kochs were everywhere.”

headline: Teenagers, Fire and a Video Camera. What Could Go Wrong?
text: Never underestimate the resolve — or lack of judgment — of teenage boys seeking Internet fame.

headline: Report Is Expected to Detail Corruption in World Track and Field
text: A report to be released Thursday is expected to describe bribery and corruption at the highest levels of international track and field, two months after the sport was shaken by revelations of a state-sponsored doping system in Russia that implicated athletes, coaches, trainers, doctors, laboratories and the country’s antidoping authorities.

headline: Bill Cosby’s Lawyers Say Binding Promise in 2005 Should Prevent Prosecution
text: Bill Cosby’s lawyers have made it clear in court papers that they plan to use a former district attorney who once declined to prosecute the entertainer as a critical weapon in their effort to battle sexual assault charges filed against him last month in Pennsylvania.

headline: New York City Opera Will Return, and Soon, Under Reorganization Plan
text: New York City Opera is coming back under new management.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Google Picks Former Obama Adviser to Lead Global Public Policy
text: Google, facing increased scrutiny from European regulators, has hired a former senior adviser to President Obama to lead its global public policy team.

headline: Review: ‘Teachers,’ Expanded From Web to Television
text: “Teachers,” born as a web series and now expanded by TV Land into a half-hour comedy, is convincing evidence that more can be less. The series, which begins on Wednesday night, is about six inappropriate and inept elementary school teachers, characters who were subtly sharp in webisodes of a few minutes’ duration. In 30-minute increments, they grow a bit wearying.

headline: Rebuilding of Nepali Homes Hit by Quakes Is Still Delayed, Official Says
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — The reconstruction of houses destroyed in Nepal’s devastating earthquakes last year will not begin until April, a year after the first tremors hit, the newly appointed head of Nepal’s Reconstruction Authority has said.

headline: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: David Bowie, Istanbul, Bernie Sanders
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: U.S. Restricts Movement of Salamanders, for Their Own Good
text: The Fish and Wildlife Service is barring the door against 201 species of salamanders, making it illegal to import them or move them across state lines, the agency announced on Tuesday. Scientists hope the ban will help prevent a devastating outbreak from driving native salamander species extinct.

headline: Saudi Arabia Arrests Samar Badawi, Human Rights Advocate
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia arrested a prominent human rights activist on Tuesday in what advocacy groups called the kingdom’s latest effort to clamp down on dissent.

headline: From Chicago to Broadway
text: “Aida,” “Light in the Piazza” and other musicals that played in Chicago before Broadway.

headline: Before Broadway, Musicals Make a Detour to Test the Waters in Chicago
text: CHICAGO — When the director Jerry Mitchell was looking for a place to try out a new musical about a struggling shoe company saved by a drag queen, he picked Chicago because the city was familiar (Mr. Mitchell grew up in the Midwest) and the audiences friendly (compared with New York).

headline: A New York Times/CBS News Poll on the State of the Presidential Race
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News national poll finds a significant narrowing of the race for the Democratic nomination while Donald Trump maintains his sizable lead among Republican primary voters.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
text: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Jan. 7 through 10 with 1,276 adults throughout the United States. Of those, 1,094 said they were registered to vote.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Lead Over Bernie Sanders Slipping in New Poll
text: As the first nominating contest approaches, Hillary Clinton’s commanding lead nationally in the Democratic primary has largely melted away, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

headline: At the London Men’s Shows, Sprinters and Marathoners Alike
text: LONDON — The new year has barely begun before the men’s fashion season does.

headline: State of the Union: Reasons for Optimism
text: President Obama told the nation Tuesday night what he thought is the state of the union. Republicans got to respond. Our take? Things are pretty good. We offer a few indicators that give us reason to be optimistic, though, as with most things, there are always caveats.

headline: Chelsea Clinton, Again Her Mother’s Surrogate, Takes Up the Fight Against Bernie Sanders
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Again playing the part of candidate surrogate — though with a message now tailored to young parents like herself — Chelsea Clinton spoke of motherhood Tuesday on the New Hampshire trail while also amplifying her mother’s increasing attacks on Senator Bernie Sanders.

headline: Uber Invites Developers to Build Apps for Customized Passenger Distractions
text: Uber, the huge ride-hailing service, delivers millions of rides to passengers. Now the company wants to give people something to do while they’re in the car.

headline: Louisiana’s New Governor Signs an Order to Expand Medicaid
text: BATON ROUGE, La. — On Tuesday, his second day in office, Gov. John Bel Edwards signed an executive order expanding Medicaid coverage under the Affordable Care Act, fulfilling a campaign promise that will expand health coverage to hundreds of thousands of people in one of the nation’s poorest states.

text: RECENT SALE

headline: State of the Presidential Campaign
text: Republican and Democratic primary voters give their opinions on the candidates.

headline: U.N. Relief Official Calls for ‘Immediate’ End to Blockades in Syria
text: UNITED NATIONS — The head of the United Nations’ relief efforts for Syria pleaded with all warring parties on Tuesday to lift their sieges on key towns and let aid agencies deliver food and medical care to people stuck behind front lines.

headline: New Corporate Raider Enters Picture, With Eye on a Sale of Ally
text: When the financier Saul P. Steinberg tried to take over Chemical Bank in 1969, he drew the ire of the governor of New York.

headline: Ted Cruz Suggests Donald Trump Is Taking Cues From Democrats
text: Senator Ted Cruz, facing persistent elbows from Donald J. Trump over his Canadian birth, delivered his most forceful response yet on Tuesday, knocking Mr. Trump’s “New York values,” questioning his knowledge of foreign affairs and suggesting that the billionaire developer was taking his cues from Democrats.

headline: Hillary Clinton, a Surging Rival and the Return of the ‘Magic Wand’
text: As the polls tighten in Hillary Clinton’s primary fight against Senator Bernie Sanders, her language is starting to carry echoes from a similar point in 2008, when Senator Barack Obama started surging.

headline: With Lincoln Continental Reborn, Ford Renews Push Into China
text: DETROIT — Last April, Ford Motor announced with fanfare that it would reintroduce its storied Lincoln Continental luxury sedan, with an eye on sales in the expanding Chinese market.

headline: With N.F.L. Relocation Fates in Owners’ Hands, the Games Begin
text: HOUSTON — On paper, the choices have been clear for months when it comes to the N.F.L.’s big, probably imminent return to Los Angeles.

headline: Millions Leave Native Lands, With Broad Repercussions
text: UNITED NATIONS — Humanity is on the move, but we are traipsing across the globe a bit less than you might think.

headline: Koch Executive Disputes Book’s Account of Founder’s Role in Nazi Refinery
text: A senior executive of Koch Industries sent a letter on Tuesday to the company’s employees disputing a new book about the Kochs and other conservative families, saying it significantly exaggerated the role of the company’s founder, Fred C. Koch, in constructing an important refinery for the Nazi regime in Germany.

headline: A Conversation With Moshe Shuster
text: Mr. Shuster, 71, is the founder and president of VRE Development, which does business as the Victor Group. The company, with headquarters in Wall, N.J., and an office in Manhattan, was previously known as Victor Homes. Its condominium developments in Manhattan include the Charles and the Lumiere, and its current projects include 281 Fifth Avenue and the Getty, at 239 10th Avenue.

headline: New Attack Ads Call Marco Rubio a Flip-Flopper on Immigration
text: Senator Marco Rubio is getting savaged on the topic of immigration reform, with ads from groups backing two of his rivals painting him as a flip-flopper and as overly close to President Obama and Senator Chuck Schumer.

headline: ‘Serial’ Podcast, Needing More Reporting Time, Goes Biweekly
text: At the beginning of every episode of “Serial,” the host, Sarah Koenig, opens with these words: “From This American Life and WBEZ Chicago, it’s ‘Serial,’ one story told week by week.”

headline: Maryland: Trial in Freddie Gray Death Complicated by Appeals Schedule
text: The trial of Officer Caesar R. Goodson Jr. of the Baltimore police, charged with murder in the death of Freddie Gray, encountered another scheduling obstacle Tuesday when an appeals court set March 4 for oral arguments in the appeal of another officer who is trying to avoid testifying. On Monday, the Court of Special Appeals said the Goodson trial may not go forward until it hears the appeal of the other officer, William G. Porter, whose own trial on manslaughter charges ended in a deadlocked jury last month. The state considers Officer Porter its star witness in the Goodson case, but he is trying to assert his Fifth Amendment right not to incriminate himself. The legal wrangling could alter the schedules of four other officers facing charges in the death of Mr. Gray, a 25-year-old black man who sustained a fatal spinal cord injury in police custody in April. The death set off riots in Baltimore.

headline: David Margulies, ‘Ghostbusters’ Mayor and Tony Soprano’s Lawyer, Dies at 78
text: David Margulies, a versatile character actor who performed in scores of supporting stage, film and television roles but was most conspicuous as the common-sense mayor in “Ghostbusters” and as Tony Soprano’s sleazy lawyer, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78.

headline: Florida’s Death Machine Loses Again
text: For the second time in three Supreme Court terms, the justices have struck down a Florida law that treated the Constitution as little more than a speed bump on the road to quicker and easier death sentences.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Case Involving Judgments Against Iran
text: WASHINGTON — The Iranian government has come under sharp criticism for not giving imprisoned Americans a fair and public court hearing. But on Wednesday at the Supreme Court, Iran will get just that.

headline: College Football Championship Game TV Viewership Drops 23 Percent
text: Alabama’s 45-40 victory over Clemson in the College Football Playoff championship game Monday night on ESPN drew an average of 25.7 million viewers, a 23 percent drop from the 33.4 million who watched last year, when Ohio State beat Oregon.

headline: Board for Ferguson Schools Is Accused of Racial Bias
text: ST. LOUIS — In a suburban school district that includes most of Ferguson and 10 other towns in northern St. Louis County, three of four students are black. Yet there have never been more than two black members on the seven-person school board at the same time. Does that mean the system of electing the board is racially biased?

headline: A Guardian Is Accused of Holding 2 Teenagers Captive in Queens for Years
text: She was regularly missing from her classes at Francis Lewis High School in Queens, and when she was there, teachers would catch the girl, a 16-year-old from South Korea, nodding off during lessons.

headline: Rookie’s English Needs Work, but His Game Is Thriving
text: CHICAGO — Artemi Panarin stood before his locker in the corner of the dressing room, virtually hidden from sight. Engulfed by an ever-growing semicircle of visitors, he began to fidget, searching for any possible escape route from what had become another uncomfortable interrogation.

headline: MetLife Weighs Split of Retail Business
text: The giant insurer MetLife said on Tuesday that it was exploring spinning off its retail life and annuity business in the United States because of financial pressures it is facing under regulations put in place in the wake of the financial crisis.

headline: U.N. to Help U.S. Screen Central American Migrants
text: The Obama administration is turning to the United Nations to help screen migrants fleeing violence in Central America, senior administration officials said Tuesday, and to help set up processing centers in several Latin American countries in the hopes of stemming a flood of families crossing the southern border illegally.

headline: Jersey Shore Town Deems a Seaside Pavilion a Monumental Mistake
text: HIGHLANDS, N.J. — The story of how an angular, concrete pavilion that weighs more than a fully loaded Boeing 767 jet wound up on a patch of beach here is complex enough. Getting rid of it may be even more complicated.

headline: Rams Moving to Los Angeles Area, and Chargers Could Join Them
text: HOUSTON — After more than two decades, the N.F.L. has found its way back to Los Angeles.

headline: Standing in the Way of a Community Court in Brooklyn
text: Brownsville, Brooklyn, is the capital of the flaring atrocity, the moment of horror that vanishes in the blink of an eye from the view of the city beyond.

headline: Fervor in Oregon Compound and Fear Outside It
text: PRINCETON, Ore. — Deep inside the federal wildlife compound where armed citizens have been garrisoned for more than a week, 9-year-old Zoey Justus was preparing a snack platter for the occupiers — fruit, cheese, Ritz crackers — and her parents were explaining why they had brought her to an armed insurrection.

headline: U.S. Church Puts 5 Banks From Israel on a Blacklist
text: The pension board of the United Methodist Church — one of the largest Protestant denominations in the United States, with more than seven million members — has placed five Israeli banks on a list of companies that it will not invest in for human rights reasons, the board said in a statement on Tuesday.

headline: Transcript of Obama’s 2016 State of the Union Address
text: Following is the transcript of President Obama’s State of the Union address, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: State of the Union Speech Is One Half of Nation’s Political Split Screen
text: WASHINGTON — Over the course of 48 hours, Americans will confront two starkly disparate views of Barack Obama’s America that will frame the debate over the future of the country in this election year and beyond.

headline: Cuomo Hints Speech Will Offer Ethics Reforms After Week of Grand Proposals
text: ALBANY — Since the beginning of the year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has repeatedly implored New Yorkers to “think big,” a mantra he has seemingly also applied to his own State of the State address, which in effect he has made into a weeklong event.

headline: Hillary Clinton Releases Ad Supporting Obama’s Gun Control Efforts
text: With her lead against Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont slipping in Iowa, Hillary Clinton’s campaign on Tuesday unveiled a new television ad that sought to seize on President Obama’s popularity among Democratic voters on the issue of gun control.

headline: After Disaster and Breakup, a Mother Strives for an Education
text: Marlin Hernandez sat at the front of her classes to better understand her teachers because English was not her native language. If she still struggled with words or concepts, she sought tutoring. No matter how exhausted she was, Ms. Hernandez remained dedicated to her studies.

headline: Elementary Education
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — Let’s talk about why it’s a good thing to feel free to change your mind, at least as it applies to crossword puzzle construction.

headline: My Take on Obama’s State of the Union Address
text: I was live-tweeting President Obama’s State of the Union Address tonight. For those of you not on Twitter, or dizzied by the blizzard of Obama-related tweets, here’s what I had to say. And I welcome your comments.

headline: Implant for Opioid Addicts Urged for Federal Approval
text: SILVER SPRING, Md. — A panel of medical experts recommended Tuesday that the Food and Drug Administration approve a new way of treating opioid addicts, using a slender rod implanted into the arm that delivers medicine for months at a time. Some doctors say it could help ease the national epidemic of drug overdoses.

headline: North Korea Faked Test Video, Group Says
text: SEOUL, South Korea — The video footage North Korea has broadcast of what looked like a successful submarine-launched ballistic missile was most likely faked to exaggerate the country’s advances in missile development, according to an analysis posted Tuesday by a research institute based in the United States.

headline: Protests Resume in São Paulo
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Demonstrators in Brazil’s financial capital, São Paulo, took to the streets again on Tuesday, protesting an increase in bus and transit fares amid a prolonged nationwide recession.

headline: Michael W. Davidson, a Success in Microscopes and Neckwear, Dies at 65
text: Most scientists rely on grants from the federal government and private foundations to finance their work. Michael W. Davidson turned to neckties.

headline: President Obama’s Call to America’s Better Nature
text: In his final State of the Union speech, President Obama endeavored on Tuesday to lift Americans above the miasma of a brutally negative presidential campaign to reflect on what the nation has endured and achieved since he took office in the midst of a dire recession.

headline: Knicks Top Celtics Despite an Injury
text: One of the finest stretches of play that Carmelo Anthony and Kristaps Porzingis have produced together this season crashed to a halt late in the first half on Tuesday night, when Anthony stepped on the foot of a referee and tumbled hazardously to the floor.

headline: Stanley Siegel, TV Host Who Made Career on Candor, Dies at 79
text: Stanley Siegel, an irreverent New York television talk-show host whose unscripted interviews coupled Jack Paar’s raw candor with Oscar Wilde’s credo that nothing succeeds like excess, died on Jan. 2 in Los Angeles. He was 79.

headline: Red Simpson, Who Made Trucks a Vehicle for the Bakersfield Sound, Dies at 81
text: Red Simpson, an architect of the twangy, hard-driving Bakersfield sound in country music who made a career out of truck-driving songs like the 1971 hit “I’m a Truck,” died on Jan. 8 in Bakersfield, Calif. He was 81.

headline: Mexico: Actors Who Met El Chapo Are Not Targets of Inquiry
text: The Mexican government said on Tuesday evening that it would not be investigating the actors Sean Penn or Kate del Castillo for their meeting with the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera, clarifying that it would rather be looking into the circumstances surrounding the meeting. The government had been unclear about the nature of the investigation in recent days, with some outlets reporting that the pair were under investigation for their secret meeting with Mr. Guzmán in early October.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | venerable
text: venerable • \ˈve-nər(-ə)-bəl, ˈven-rə-bəl\ • adjective

headline: National Guard to Help Flint Address Water Crisis
text: Michigan’s governor on Tuesday activated the National Guard and sought help from the Federal Emergency Management Agency to address lead-tainted drinking water in Flint.

headline: Obama Speech Points to Successes, as Would-Be Successors Look On
text: WASHINGTON — Before President Obama had uttered the first word of his final State of the Union address, the talk in the hallways of the Capitol was about who might give the next one.

headline: When the State of the Union Is Strong, but Doesn’t Feel Like It Is
text: The fact that Americans start voting in a matter of weeks loomed over President Obama’s final State of the Union address Tuesday. “I know some of you are antsy to get back to Iowa,” he cracked, as he began the speech.

headline: Analysis: Obama’s Final State of the Union
text: Jonathan Weisman of The Times analyzes key moments from the president’s last annual address to Congress.

headline: What to Watch Wednesday
text: In “Second Chance,” Fox gives a disgraced man a new lease on life in a series that deserves its own second chance, the critic Neil Genzlinger says. Sutton Foster continues to shave off the years in “Younger.” And Jerry Seinfeld cruises Los Angeles with Kathleen Madigan on Crackle.

headline: Corrections: January 13, 2016
text: NEW YORK

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “I just want them to go home, so that I can feel safe.”

headline: ISIS Claims Assault That Killed 7 Near Pakistani Consulate in Afghanistan
text: JALALABAD, Afghanistan — Islamic State militants in Afghanistan claimed their first attack on a major city on Wednesday, after an assault near the Pakistani Consulate in Jalalabad that killed at least seven members of the Afghan security forces.

headline: A Peek Into Vivian Maier’s Family Album
text: Recent research into the early life of Vivian Maier suggests a difficult childhood that was offset by the support of other women.

headline: After David Bowie’s Death, ‘Lazarus’ Holds New Meaning for Fans
text: Tuesday was an emotional night at New York Theater Workshop, as fans and artists came together to see “Lazarus,” one of David Bowie’s final creations, now in a new light.

headline: A Peek Into Vivian Maier’s Family Album
text: This is the second of two articles about research on Vivian Maier. The first was published on Lens on Tuesday.

headline: A Smarter Way to Get Guns Off the Street
text: For a mayor happy to boast about his city’s record low crime rates, Bill de Blasio has spent a lot of time lately talking about gun violence. As he should, because New York remains a dangerous and frightening city if you live in certain neighborhoods — in Brooklyn and the Bronx — still afflicted by gangs, drugs and shootings.

headline: The Age of Protest
text: If you go to The Guardian’s website these days you can find a section that is just labeled “Protest.” So now, with your morning coffee, you can get your news, weather, sports — and protests. I found stories there headlined, “Five Fresh Ideas for the Street Art Agitator in 2016,” “Muslim Woman Ejected From Donald Trump Rally After Silent Protest” and, appropriately, “We Are Living in an Age of Protest.”

headline: Where Police Violence Encounters Mental Illness
text: NEARLY 20 years ago, I was a social worker in a county jail where I first began to understand just how frequently the police deal with people with mental illnesses. Run-ins with the police were a regular occurrence for many of my clients, with officers often knowing them by name. They were overwhelmingly poor, and poor people with mental illnesses are also likely to experience homelessness and substance abuse — issues that place them at increased risk of police contact and incarceration.

headline: Teach Your Teachers Well
text: LAST month, at the urging of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, New York’s Board of Regents suspended the use of state tests to evaluate teachers. This is a wise first step, but it won’t improve our schools unless we go further and build a professionalized system of support that views teachers as learners and challenges them to improve their classroom practices.

headline: The Republican Party’s 50-State Solution
text: Since the early 1970s, the right has conducted a sustained drive to gain power and set policy in the 50 states. The left, by contrast, has been far less effective at the state-level.

headline: Poland Deviates From Democracy
text: It has been distressing these past weeks to watch Poland, long the poster child of Eastern European states that shed the Kremlin’s suffocating embrace, adopting dictatorial measures of its own, not least a right-wing, nationalistic assault on the country’s media and judiciary. The European Commission is scheduled to examine possible sanctions on Wednesday, but it is unlikely to take any, in part because Hungary and other governments sympathetic to Poland would veto them and also because they would serve only to deepen Warsaw’s hostility to the European Union.

headline: The West 80s: An Aesthetic of Its Own

She was then renting an apartment in the West 70s, with her husband, Scott, but she found something different, “something really magical,” in the 80s. To her, the area felt quiet, green, community-minded and “cozy,” she said. “We thought we were in a whole different city.”

headline: Eileen Myles Wants Men to Take a Hike
text: Many people would be surprised to hear that according to you, poetry is alive and well in America. Our national political conversation has recently seen some rather unpoetic lurches to the right. How do you make sense of that? Poetry always, always, always is a key piece of democracy. It’s like the un-Trump: The poet is the charismatic loser. You’re the fool in Shakespeare; you’re the loose cannon. As things get worse, poetry gets better, because it becomes more necessary.

headline: Below the Line: Record Producer, Movie Composer

But many of the artists working in film composition today have recorded or produced hits before. For instance, Trent Reznor, who with Nine Inch Nails made multiplatinum records, gained prestige of a different kind when he and Atticus Ross won Oscars for their score for “The Social Network” in 2011.

headline: In Exile

It was a sign of good fortune — a gift from God — so he named the land the “gift ranch,” or Parc Cadeau.

headline: ‘ABC Dream’ and ‘Awake Beautiful Child’
text: It’s true that alphabet books exist primarily to familiarize new readers with the 26 letters. But with letters the center of attention, ABC books can also be perfect vehicles for writers to play with words and for illustrators to show off their design chops — and lately, many have been gorgeous, stylish creations, more Alfa Romeo than family S.U.V. Paging through some of these thoughtfully conceived and designed books can have a calming, almost meditative, effect. Their restrained, visually pleasing qualities are like manna from heaven in an era in which many schools seem to have decided, sadly, that learning to read should be a quick-and-dirty business, done with cheap, garish books and throwaway worksheets.

headline: Yes He Did
text: These days many Americans live in an alternative political reality, in which the simplest factual assertions are met with anger and derision. When I, like many others, noted that job growth since Obamacare went into full effect has been the fastest since the 1990s — which is simply what the BLS data say — I got a barrage of mail from people claiming that I’m crazy, a liar, etc.. Similarly, but on of course a much bigger scale, a lot of what I’m seeing in reactions to the State of the Union amounts to the assertion that only an imbecile or a hack could believe Obama’s talk about the strength of the U.S. economy relative to other advanced countries — when that’s a simple fact.

headline: Stephen Karam Makes Broadway Debut With ‘The Humans’

headline: 1941: Changes to the Italian Army
text: ROME — Two months after taking command of the Italian forces in Albania, Gen. Ubaldo Soddu has been relieved of active duty at his own request, it was announced here today [Jan. 13]. Ill health, necessitating a long rest and care, was given as the reason for his retirement. All that the military command vouchsafed today concerning the fighting in Albania was that there had been normal activity of patrols and artillery and that Italian planes had machine-gunned and shelled enemy troops and columns of trucks on the march. No word has as yet reached the Italian people officially to confirm the claims of further Greek successes, which foreign broadcasts have reported. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 14, 1941

headline: ‘Hunters in the Dark,’ by Lawrence Osborne
text: I read this book in what is called an advance reader’s edition, a trade convenience generally made up of the first-pass pages from the forthcoming hardcover edition, bound in paper, with a version of the jacket art on the front and a version of the flap copy on the back. In this case, the flap copy was appropriately enticing (but when is it ever not?), and it opened by categorizing the work as “literary suspense.” Immediately the pedant in me reared its caviling head: Aren’t all novels literary, in that they’re assembled from letters and words? (From the Latin litteratura, writing composed of letters of the alphabet.) And aren’t all novels to some extent suspenseful — or else why would we ever finish one? Surely there must always be a managed momentum toward finding out what happens in the end, however slight that may be?

headline: ‘The Lovers: Afghanistan’s Romeo and Juliet,’ by Rod Nordland
text: The sentimental title of “The Lovers” suggests a hopeful tale of youthful romance, of passion and perseverance against the backdrop of a war-ravaged Afghanistan. Zakia and Ali, the journalist Rod Nordland’s Afghan Romeo and Juliet, are Tajik and Hazara, Sunni and Shia, disparate ethnicities and rived sects. They live in Bamiyan, where the Taliban destroyed two famed sandstone Buddhas in 2001. They fall in love as teenagers, exchanging flirty glances in the fields of their village, skirting elders and convention. Soon their parents find out; marriage is deemed impossible, and Zakia runs away to a shelter. The two elope but remain sentenced to a life on the run, with Ali facing criminal charges after Zakia’s family lodges a kidnapping case against him.

headline: Bringing a Grandmother’s Upstate Home to the Lower East Side
text: “What if I said, ‘I’m an old soul, it all started in 1983?’” asks Meagan Delaney, the owner of the Lower East Side boutique the Rising States, erupting into a throaty laugh. Her story does begin in the mid-’80s on Kodiak Island, Alaska; her mother, a Russian Aleut and the youngest of 13 children, hadn’t left Kodiak before meeting Delaney’s dad, a Manhattanite who moved north to deal in fishing boats. “Two of my best friends still have the postcards that I sent to them while on a trip to the city when I was 8 years old,” Delaney says. “The funniest card reads, ‘New York is so cool. They have this store called the GAP’ — Gap in capital letters. I bought a ‘Blossom’ hat (a denim hat with a massive fake flower on the front), a sweater and some leggings, and I thought I was the coolest kid alive when I went back to Kodiak.”
