text: My Sunday column argued, fairly strenuously, that mass immigration on the scale of the last two years will put more stress on the politics and culture of Germany than any prudent statesman should accept, and that the German government should do everything in its power to not only limit migration but actually restrict asylum rights and begin deportation for some of the migrants who have already arrived.

headline: Al Jazeera America to Shut Down by April
text: The cable news channel Al Jazeera America, which debuted in 2013 to great fanfare when it promised to cover American news soberly and seriously, will be shutting down by the end of April. The move was announced at a companywide meeting on Wednesday.

headline: Anatomy of a Scene | ‘The Revenant’
text: Alejandro G. Inarritu narrates a scene from “The Revenant,” featuring Leonardo DiCaprio.

headline: Alejandro G. Iñárritu Narrates a Scene From ‘The Revenant’
text: “The Revenant,” Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s bear-wrangling, Golden Globe-winning tale of survival on the American frontier, is the kind of movie where the difficulty of its execution can be seen in most every shot.

headline: Saudi Arabia Frees Samar Badawi, Human Rights Activist, After Questioning
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia released the human rights activist Samar Badawi on Wednesday, one day after advocacy groups reported that she had been arrested. Adam Coogle, a researcher for Human Rights Watch, said that Ms. Badawi was released after having been questioned in a police station and held overnight. She was not charged with a crime.

headline: End the Looting of Antiquities: A Plea for Action
text: To the Editor:

headline: Missing a Road in Russia? This May Be Why
text: MOSCOW — Corruption in Russia sometimes amounts to highway robbery, literally.

headline: ‘Hairspray’ to Be NBC’s Next Live Musical
text: NBC, which has taken viewers from the musical hills of Austria to Neverland to Oz with its live musical broadcasts, has a humbler destination in mind for 2016: Baltimore.

headline: Obama’s Final State of the Union Speech
text: To the Editor:

headline: Dec. 24, 1994: Day of Losses for Los Angeles, as Rams and Raiders Fell
text: In Anaheim, Calif., the 4-11 Rams lost to an even worse team in a meaningless N.F.L. game. At the same time, 25 miles away, the Raiders also lost, and missed out on the playoffs. All in all, a disappointing day for the home fans. Little did they know.

headline: Paul Ryan Dada
text: OK, Paul Ryan is messing with our heads, although “messing” isn’t really the word I want to use.

headline: Donald Trump’s Iowa Ground Game Seems to Be Missing a Coach
text: DES MOINES — One volunteer leader enlisted by Donald J. Trump to turn out Iowa voters has yet to knock on a single door or to make a phone call. Another is a “9/11 truther” with a website claiming that the Sept. 11 attacks were a government conspiracy. A third caucus precinct captain, who like the others attended a training session in West Des Moines last month, said the campaign’s goal of having them each enlist 25 supporters was unrealistic.

headline: App Smart | Fresh From CES
text: Among the notable apps at International CES were the video-sharing apps MeVee and VidMob and the home DJ app Edjing Scratch.

headline: Video Feature: Some Standouts at the International CES
text: LAST week, manufacturers from all over the world gathered in Las Vegas — as they do every January — for International CES, a giant electronics show where they displayed televisions, computers and weird and wonderful gadgets. Nowadays, apps are also showcased or previewed alongside the hardware.

headline: Lawrence Phillips Is Dead in Suspected Suicide in Prison
text: Lawrence Phillips, the star Nebraska running back whose N.F.L. career was derailed by his many off-field problems, died Wednesday morning in a suspected suicide, the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation said in a news release.

headline: Was He Gay, Bisexual or Bowie? Yes
text: When David Bowie died on Sunday, he  left behind legions of fans who will remember him as the godfather of glam rock and the patron saint of defiant outcasts.

headline: ‘An Election Where Angry Sells’: Readers on the ‘Brutalism’ of Ted Cruz
text: The strength of Senator Ted Cruz’s presidential campaign reflects a Republican Party that increasingly represents the extreme right, readers said in response to a column by David Brooks about Mr. Cruz’s “brutalism.”

headline: New Polish Government Faces E.U. Investigation
text: WARSAW — The European Commission said on Wednesday that it had opened a formal inquiry to determine whether Poland’s new right-wing government had violated the democratic norms of the European Union.

headline: In Fashion, Fat Is Still a Taboo
text: Rosy-cheeked and curvy, Madame de St.-Maurice smiles complacently on visitors to the 80WSE Gallery at New York University. The subject of a late-18th-century portrait by Joseph Siffred Duplessis, she flaunts multiple chins, her fleshy arms and bosom becomingly veiled in a demi-sheer frock.

headline: Making Milton Babbitt’s Legacy Less Fearsome
text: Sometime in the mid-1920s, a 10-year-old clarinetist in the Jackson Boys’ Band in Mississippi had a small epiphany. The highest notes of his solo in an opera overture were, in fact, a transposition of the opening motif of the piece.

headline: Avalanche in French Alps Leaves at Least 3 Dead
text: PARIS — An avalanche hit a group of students skiing in the French Alps on Wednesday afternoon, killing at least three people, the French authorities said.

headline: For de Blasio, Cuomo’s State of the State Address Holds More Tough News
text: With his protracted feud with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo still simmering, Mayor Bill de Blasio trekked to Albany on Wednesday, bracing for bad news for his agenda in New York City.

headline: MetLife’s Spinoff Plan Hedges Its Fight With Regulators
text: Steven A. Kandarian is hedging his bets.

headline: The Zappos Exodus Continues After a Radical Management Experiment
text: Zappos, the online shoe retailer experimenting with the radical self-management system Holacracy, is continuing to hemorrhage employees.

headline: Paul Ryan Cuts Off Iran Vote in Rebuff to Tardy Lawmakers
text: The House on Wednesday passed legislation bolstering sanctions against Iran, seeking to check President Obama’s ability to ease them without consulting Congress.

headline: Lesson Plan | Analyzing Maps to Better Understand Global Current Events and History
text: Maps tell stories about natural and human geography and geopolitics, whether by displaying the shapes of landforms and locations of cities or by highlighting global fashion trends or the routes of explorers.

headline: How David Bowie Challenged MTV on Race
text: David Bowie was always going somewhere — Africa, Japan, outer space, “the hinterland, the hinterland” (from “Red Sails”), up, down, in, out, across. One wavelet of Internet tributes paid to Mr. Bowie after his death on Sunday recalled a trip he took to a hotel room, in 1983, to pick a bone with MTV.

headline: Per Se ‘Stumbles’: Readers Respond
text: Pete Wells’s review of Per Se dropped the landmark restaurant from a four-star rating to two stars. Reader response ranged from shocked to sad, from angry to delighted. Selections from the comments are below; some have been edited for length.

headline: Ricky Jay and the Met Conjure Big Magic in Miniature
text: The magician Ricky Jay, considered by many the greatest sleight-of-hand artist alive, is also a scholar, a historian, a collector of curiosities. Master of a prose style that qualifies him as perhaps the last of the great 19th-century authors, he has written about oddities like cannonball catchers, poker-playing pigs, performing fleas and people who tame bees. But probably his most enduring interest is a fellow polymath, an 18th-century German named Matthias Buchinger.

headline: Ex-Marine Can Wear Medals He Didn’t Earn. A Court Calls It Free Speech.
text: A federal court in California has ruled that a former Marine can wear service medals he did not earn, saying that displaying them was a form of free speech.

headline: Review: HBO’s ‘Sesame Street,’ Fancy but Not Free
text: Like many an urban brownstone owner, “Sesame Street” has come into some cash, and it’s undertaken a lovely renovation.

headline: North Korea Is Newest Frontier for a Daredevil Investor
text: He searched for oil in the badlands of Somalia and fueled a stock market boom in Mongolia. He sued the world’s smallest republic, far out in the Pacific, for a chunk of what it is worth.

headline: Gear for the Next Level of Mobile Games
text: With state-of-the-art graphics, enhanced functions and multiplayer options, gaming on a tablet or smartphone is not always as simple as tap and swipe anymore. That means getting the most out of mobile games can require new equipment. Here are some noteworthy recommendations.

headline: Musical-Theater Writers Awarded Kleban Prizes
text: The lyricist, librettist and playwright Stacey Luftig and the writer and director Daniel Goldstein are the recipients of the 2016 Kleban Prize for promising musical-theater writers, the sponsors of the prize announced this week. The awards each come with $100,000.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Backing Jeb Bush Uses Conspiracy-Minded Journalist in Ad
text: Since shortly after Christmas, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, Right to Rise USA, has been criticizing Senator Marco Rubio of Florida for missing votes in the Senate. But the ad the group released delivering that message relied on a journalist who has highlighted conspiracy theories about major news events to make its case.

headline: Understanding Health Savings Accounts
text: January signals the start of different health benefits for many people, based on the coverage they chose during open enrollment. Increasingly, consumers are enrolling in health plans that work with special health savings accounts. Here is some help in understanding how to use them.

headline: Lawyer for Iran’s Central Bank Faces Skepticism at Supreme Court
text: WASHINGTON — A lawyer for Iran’s central bank faced skepticism at the Supreme Court on Wednesday as he tried to persuade the justices that his client should not have to pay nearly $2 billion to victims of terrorist attacks.

headline: VW’s Chief Meets Head of E.P.A. to Discuss Pollution Problem
text: Under pressure to devise a fix for its polluting diesel cars, the chief executive of Volkswagen, Matthias Müller, met for the first time with a senior government official in the United States to discuss the crisis that has engulfed the German carmaker since September.

headline: To Rams’ Owner, It’s Business; to St. Louis Fans, It’s Personal
text: ST. LOUIS — Enos Stanley Kroenke, a native of Missouri and the owner of the Rams, is named after two of this city’s most revered baseball figures, the hustling outfielder Enos Slaughter and the gentlemanly hitter Stan Musial.

headline: Winter White and a New Lingerie Collaboration — Flirty, a Little Naughty
text: Plus: Bras on the red carpet and the comeback of brooches.

headline: Retired Art Teacher Leaves $1.7 Million to the Detroit Institute of Arts
text: Not much more than a year ago, the Detroit Institute of Arts was in an existential crisis, its world-class collection in danger of being parceled off by its beleaguered city to help pay debts in Detroit’s federal bankruptcy.

headline: Steve King Faults Nikki Haley’s Conservatism, but Not Her Looks
text: Representative Steve King, the staunchly conservative and proudly plainspoken firebrand from Iowa, was among the handful of Republicans on Wednesday to take issue with Gov. Nikki Haley’s State of the Union response.

headline: Howard University Takes Step Toward Sale of Spectrum Rights
text: WASHINGTON — Howard University said Wednesday that it would join other broadcasters in taking part in a Federal Communications Commission auction that could entail selling the rights to the spectrum on which it broadcasts the nation’s only black-owned public television station.

headline: All the Young Bands: The Artists David Bowie Championed
text: David Bowie’s dense catalog is a rich portrait of the ways in which he subverted rock and pop norms, exalted his fellow misfits and delighted in reinvention. It’s also a testament to the power of collaboration: Throughout his career, Mr. Bowie teamed closely with writers and producers, including Tony Visconti, who has frequently worked by his side since “Space Oddity” in 1969.

headline: The Former Kiehl’s Heiress’s Luxury Line of Skin Care
text: When third-generation Kiehl’s heir Jami Morse Heidegger sold the family business to L’Oreal in 2000, she thought she was walking away from beauty for good. But the luxury of having time away ironically sucked her back in. “I had been traveling so much for work and had three young children at home at the time,” she recalls. “I wanted to take care of myself, but there wasn’t anything on the market that addressed all of my concerns. I wanted something that was anti-aging but with top-quality oils to address the dryness I felt living in California desert.” So, she enlisted her longtime chemist from Kiehl’s to help formulate several products to rejuvenate her own skin. The requirement: Create mixtures with the highest possible concentration of effective ingredients.

headline: Venerating Mao, Even Where Famine Remains a Memory
text: ZHUSHIGANG, China — Only the orange of thousands of freshly dug carrots, washed in icy water and packed for delivery by village women, brightened this fog-draped village last Friday, one day after the authorities razed a golden statue of Mao Zedong erected by local admirers that had towered over the dun fields.

headline: Stocks Slide as Worries Persist Over Global Growth
text: Hopes for a recovery in the United States stock market were dashed on Wednesday as investors’ deepening fears about the strength of the world’s largest economies drove another wave of selling.

headline: Justices Hear Case Over Puerto Rico’s Sovereignty
text: WASHINGTON — Faced with the prospect of definitively resolving the status of Puerto Rico, the Supreme Court on Wednesday explored ways in which to render a narrow decision. But a lawyer for the Obama administration was adamant that the court’s decision should be based on the fundamental ground that the commonwealth is a territory of the United States without independent sovereignty.

headline: Teenager Killed in Shooting Near Brooklyn Schools
text: An 18-year-old man was killed and a second teenager was wounded on Wednesday in a shooting on a Brooklyn street busy with students who had just been dismissed for the day from a nearby high school campus, the authorities said.

headline: Review: ‘Now I’m Fine,’ Ahamefule J. Oluo’s Take on Himself
text: Imagine if whenever anyone asked you to say a little something about yourself, you had your very own orchestra to back you up. That’s the privileged position in which Ahamefule J. Oluo finds himself in “Now I’m Fine,” the engaging musical memoir that opened on Tuesday night at the Public Theater as part of the Under the Radar festival.

headline: Hue Jackson Skips Giants Interview and Takes Browns Job
text: The Giants have been looking for a new head coach for about 10 days and were waiting to interview the Cincinnati Bengals’ offensive coordinator, Hue Jackson, before making a decision on Tom Coughlin’s replacement. Jackson was expected to meet Thursday morning with John Mara, one of the team’s owners, and Jerry Reese, the general manager.

headline: Transcript of Cuomo’s 2016 State of the State Address
text: Following is the transcript of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s State of the State address, as transcribed by the governor’s office:

headline: Hillary Clinton Ad Seconds Obama on Guns, Rebuking Bernie Sanders
text: Seizing on gun control, an issue on which she sees an opportunity to align herself with President Obama and against Senator Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton has released a new ad titled “I’m With Him.”

headline: Review: ‘Idiotsitter,’ on Comedy Central, Skewers the Rich
text: Fey and Poehler, Jacobson and Glazer (“Broad City”), Parham and St. Clair (“Playing House”), Lindhome and Micucci (“Garfunkel and Oates”). Female comedy duos — steeped in some mix of improv troupes, cabaret, web series and “Saturday Night Live” before scoring their own television shows — are establishing a small but growing beachhead in prime time. On Thursday Comedy Central throws Jillian Bell and Charlotte Newhouse (formerly of the Groundlings) unto the breach with “Idiotsitter,” a sitcom expanded from a short-form online series.

headline: Times Insider Live: Your Money Matters
text: The ins and outs of financial planning from how to pick an adviser to knowing when you’ve got enough.

headline: Officials Study Possible Tie Between Legionnaires’ Disease and Flint Water
text: Michigan health officials said Wednesday that they were investigating whether an outbreak of Legionnaires’ disease was linked to problems with the Flint city water system, which has caused a surge in lead poisoning in children.

headline: Cricket Star Kieran Powell Tosses His Bat and Picks Up a Smaller, Rounder One
text: Kieran Powell has had an enviable life as a professional cricket player. He has traveled the world playing a challenging game in balmy weather, while earning a lot of recognition and good money.

headline: Steven Boyer Puts Down the Sock Puppet and Picks Up His Life
text: We look at our hands every day. If your dominant hand is your right, as mine is, you probably look at that one a bit more. But if you happen to have a demonic sock puppet attached to your left hand, it can’t help but take up most of your attention.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Intensify Fight over Health, Guns and Costs
text: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders escalated their battle over health care and gun control on Wednesday as the race for the Democratic presidential nomination intensified.

headline: Review: In ‘Colony,’ on USA, Los Angeles Is Occupied
text: “Colony,” USA’s new sort of sci-fi, sort of geopolitical conspiracy series, gives up its secrets slowly. In truth, it hardly gives them up at all. As the hours roll by, the facts of life in the show’s near-future Los Angeles remain vague. We know that much of the city has been surrounded by a shiny metal wall hundreds of feet tall. But who put it there? What do they look like? Are they extraterrestrial? Sorry — maybe next week.

headline: Review: ‘Death of a Bachelor,’ From Panic! at the Disco
text: “Death of a Bachelor”

headline: Photos of the Day: The Netherlands and Elsewhere
text: The Netherlands and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Research Doesn’t Back a Link Between Migrants and Crime in U.S.
text: In America, as in Europe, anti-immigrant backlashes have often followed episodes in which foreigners are blamed for crimes and other problems. But statistical studies show that in the United States, at least, immigrants are far more law-abiding than natives, regardless of race, class or education.

headline: Review: ‘Rova Channeling Coltrane’ Offers More Than a Live Performance
text: “Rova Channeling Coltrane”

headline: Seven Essentials to Make (Truly) Yours This Year
text: Thanks to the startup boom, a host of companies have recently sprung up that aim to make everything from headphones to ballerina flats perfectly personal, with intuitive sites and apps that allow you to explore your own preferences in great detail. Here, seven of our favorite ways to customize your life this year — without leaving the house.

headline: Review: Lisette Oropesa Scales Down Her Voice but Not Her Presence
text: Sometimes singers who are at home on the opera stage have trouble adjusting to the intimate requirements of a song recital. Not the lovely lyric soprano Lisette Oropesa, who on Tuesday night gave a rewarding performance with the stylish pianist John Churchwell in the Park Avenue Armory’s Board of Officers Room.

headline: Review: Ches Smith’s ‘The Bell’ Plays With Listeners’ Expectations
text: The Bell

headline: Jan. 13, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from The Netherlands, Afghanistan, Israel and India.

headline: Review: At American Dance Platform, Charm and Structure Without Flight
text: American Dance Platform is a new project at the Joyce Theater. From the audience’s point of view, though, it looks much like what has been happening at the Joyce each year in the second week of January. This is APAP week (for the Association of Performing Arts Presenters), when curators and producers come shopping in New York and when a number of the city’s performance spaces showcase multiple dance companies. With American Dance Platform, as in previous years, the Joyce gives a week to eight highly varied companies, appearing in four double bills.

headline: Stella McCartney Unveils Her Pre-Fall Collection in Hollywood
text: Katy Perry, Johnny Depp and Elizabeth Olsen join fashion stars at the landmark Amoeba Music store.

headline: Inside the Golden Globes Parties: Stars Find Their Cliques
text: If Hollywood is high school, the parties surrounding Golden Globes weekend were essentially an opportunity to show who belonged to which clique.

headline: Finding the Keys for the Right Ballet Steps
text: “There are only two tempos, too fast or too slow,” Cameron Grant, the principal pianist with New York City Ballet, said with a melancholy laugh after rehearsal a few weeks ago. It was the middle of “Nutcracker” season, and that evening he was scheduled to play the celesta, the bell-like keyboard instrument that accompanies Sugarplum’s solo, in the orchestra pit. With his neat appearance and calm demeanor, Mr. Grant is a constant, quiet presence in the theater, someone relied on by dancers, ballet masters and the orchestra. And yet few outside the circle of his colleagues realize how central he and the other company pianists are to the life of the theater.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: David Bowie, N.F.L., Iran
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Danes Debate How to Handle Migrants
text: Politicians in Denmark reacted to a bill that would require refugees to help finance their stay. The proposal is the latest of several recent migrant-deterring measures taken by the country.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Clive James, Writing Toward the Twilight
text: Since 2010, when the brilliant Australian critic, poet and memoirist Clive James learned he had terminal leukemia, he’s had his afterburners flipped on. He has been on a vivifying late-career tear.

headline: Goldman Says It Supports IEX, but Raises Market Structure Issues
text: Goldman Sachs told the Securities and Exchange Commission in a letter dated Tuesday that it supported a proposed new stock exchange, but also pointed out that one exchange should not have an unfair advantage over another in its control of market data.

headline: Studio Two-Step Sometimes Defies Oscar Labels
text: Far and away the biggest head-scratcher at the Golden Globes on Sunday was how on earth “The Martian” — that rip-roaring laugh riot about a marooned astronaut’s ingenious and desperate efforts to stay alive — walked away with the top award for best comedy or musical.

headline: How Nikki Haley Was Redeemed by Donald Trump
text: It is a truth universally acknowledged that an Indian-American in possession of gubernatorial dreams must be in want of a name like Nikki or Bobby. If I had a name like that, I would not be in Brooklyn writing some online-only essay, wearing a Uniqlo hoodie. I would probably be in Jackson, Montgomery or Raleigh, wearing a red velvet robe, tweaking my State of the State address. And if my name were Nikki or Bobby, the state of the state would be pukka — sorry, strong.

headline: Fourth Annual New York Portfolio Review
text: Applications are open for the Fourth Annual New York Portfolio Review, where editors, curators, gallerists and book publishers will conduct two days of private photo critiques.

headline: Brian Bedford, Stage Actor Who Brought the Classics to Life, Dies at 80
text: Brian Bedford, the British-born actor, reared in working-class misery, who became a stellar portrayer of the princes, kings, fops and faded aristocrats of Shakespeare, Molière and Chekhov, died on Wednesday in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 80.

headline: Ted Cruz Didn’t Report Goldman Sachs Loan in a Senate Race
text: As Ted Cruz tells it, the story of how he financed his upstart campaign for the United States Senate four years ago is an endearing example of loyalty and shared sacrifice between a married couple.

headline: Republicans Lead Congress With Two Distinct Agendas
text: WASHINGTON — Speaker Paul D. Ryan has been pressing House Republicans to develop an aggressive, conservative policy blueprint that sets the contours of the presidential campaign.

headline: Chocolate Armenteros, Trumpeter in Afro-Cuban Tradition, Dies at 87
text: Chocolate Armenteros, a Cuban trumpeter who was a standard-bearer of the Afro-Cuban musical tradition for almost seven decades, died on Jan. 6 in a nursing home in Mohegan Lake, N.Y. He was 87.

headline: Bill Clinton Cites Personal Losses in Pushing Fight Against Drug Abuse
text: KEENE, N.H. — Hillary Clinton has made battling the drug epidemic a central part of her presidential campaign. But she has only briefly mentioned of her personal connection to it.

headline: Museum of Natural History’s New Dinosaur Sticks Its Head Out
text: Curators hope a casting of a 122-foot long fossil can top a dinosaur exhibit that draws big crowds.

headline: A New Dinosaur Takes Shape
text: The American Museum of Natural History unveils a new dinosaur exhibit this month. The process required careful planning and delicate handiwork.

headline: C.D.C. May Warn Pregnant Women Against Travel to Countries With Zika Virus
text: Federal health officials are debating whether to warn pregnant women against travel to Brazil and other Latin American and Caribbean countries where mosquitoes are spreading the Zika virus, which has been linked to brain damage in newborn babies.

headline: Former FIFA Vice President Arrives in Brooklyn to Face Charges
text: The 21st of 41 defendants in the United States’ sprawling corruption case focusing on world soccer was brought to Brooklyn on Wednesday to face charges.

headline: New Dinosaur Poses Question: Does This Museum Make Me Look Fat?
text: The juvenile Barosaurus had just been laid out on the floor in the American Museum of Natural History when a staff member noticed a piece of candy corn wedged in the creature’s mouth. “So that’s what killed the dinosaurs,” said Alec Madoff, a senior preparator at the museum who had wielded the saw that felled the dinosaur.

headline: Rams’ Departure Is Another Blow to St. Louis Area, and a Chance to Shift Priorities
text: ST. LOUIS — Five years ago, it was grim census data showing that the city’s population had decreased by 8 percent at a time when officials were expecting it to grow.

headline: Ailing Valeant Chief’s Return Date Is Uncertain
text: SAN FRANCISCO — It is still uncertain when J. Michael Pearson, the chief executive of the troubled drug maker Valeant Pharmaceuticals International, will return to the company, his temporary replacement told investors on Wednesday.

headline: SurveyMonkey Names New Chief, Its Second in Six Months
text: SurveyMonkey, an online polling firm shaken by the sudden death of its chief executive last year, has replaced the man who took over in the aftermath.

headline: Chilling Messages in Journal of Louisiana Theater Shooter
text: Before he opened fire at a Louisiana movie theater in July, a man with a history of mental illness filled dozens of pages with chilling references to violence and to a white man accused of killing nine black worshipers at a South Carolina church, as well as grievances against women, blacks, gay people and the news media.

headline: Bronx Science Bans Cellphones From Wi-Fi as Students Devour It
text: When the New York City Education Department lifted a long-held ban on cellphones in school buildings last year, it acquiesced to the omnipresent reality of technology in daily life.

headline: Amnesty International Reports Torture of Detainees in Tunisia
text: TUNIS — New evidence of the torture and deaths of detainees in police custody has emerged in Tunisia, indicating a rise in repression as the government has sought to crack down on terrorism, Amnesty International warned Wednesday.

headline: For Help on Camera and Off, M.L.B. Orders Interpreters for Latino Players
text: In April 2014, Michael Pineda, the Yankees pitcher, had been ejected from a game for having pine tar on his neck. Later the same night, he answered questions from more than a dozen reporters in English about the embarrassing incident.

headline: Gov. Cuomo on the State of New York
text: Gov. Andrew Cuomo laid out an ambitious policy agenda for the coming year in a State of the State address on Wednesday that blended the personal and political. He harked back to a “tough” 2015, when he lost his father, Mario, pivoting deftly to a call for 12 weeks of paid family leave. He made a powerful economic and moral case for a $15 minimum wage, and pledged multibillion-dollar investments in transportation, infrastructure and housing, and an aggressive plan to attack homelessness.

headline: Defense Secretary, in Speech to Deploying Troops, Lauds Push Against ISIS
text: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky. — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter provided an upbeat assessment on Wednesday of the Obama administration’s efforts to defeat the Islamic State and said that missions now underway by a new deployment of Special Operations forces are “generating a virtuous cycle of action” against the extremist group.

headline: Anheuser-Busch InBev Sets $46 Billion Bond Sale
text: Anheuser-Busch InBev has completed a $46 billion, seven-part bond deal to help finance its acquisition of a fellow brewing company, SABMiller, in the second-largest corporate debt offering ever in the United States, according to Thomson Reuters.

headline: Iraq and the Kurds Are Going Broke
text: Iraqi and American officials leading the military campaign against the Islamic State now have to wrestle with a challenge that has the potential to change battlefield fortunes: the slumping price of oil.

headline: El Chapo Enticed by Star Power of Mexican Actress, Not Sean Penn
text: MEXICO CITY — Joaquín Guzmán Loera, the infamous drug lord known as El Chapo, had never heard of Sean Penn.

headline: Giants Said to Promote Ben McAdoo to Head Coach
text: Two years ago, when the Giants named the little-known Ben McAdoo as their new offensive coordinator, the team co-owner John Mara, who approved the hiring, conceded that he did not know Ben McAdoo from Bob McAdoo, the 1970s-era Knicks forward.

headline: Hello, They Must Be Going
text: Bye-bye.

headline: Sylvan Barnet, Scholar, Is Dead at 89; Edited Signet Shakespeare Paperbacks
text: Sylvan Barnet, a literary scholar who introduced generations of college students to Shakespeare through the Signet Classic Shakespeare series, for which he was the general editor, died on Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 89.

headline: President May Have Exaggerated Role of Stimulus in Clean Energy, Experts Say
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama, in his final State of the Union address on Tuesday night, boldly proclaimed the successes of what he called “the single biggest investment in clean energy in our history,” the 2009 economic stimulus that pumped $80 billion into clean and renewable energy projects.

headline: Myra Carter, Dying Mother in Albee’s ‘Three Tall Women,’ Dies at 86
text: Myra Carter, an award-winning stage actress who originated the grueling role of Edward Albee’s dying nonagenarian mother in his autobiographical play “Three Tall Women,” died on Jan. 9 in Manhattan. She was 86.

headline: Los Angeles Greets Return of Rams With a Cool Eye
text: LOS ANGELES — And on the day after, the City of Angels ... went about its business.

headline: Lawrence Phillips, Volatile Football Star, Dies at 40
text: Lawrence Phillips, a gifted running back who derailed his own career — and his life — with a series of violent criminal acts off the field, died on Wednesday in a hospital near Delano, Calif., where he was in prison. He was 40.

headline: Do You Want to Be Chicago’s New Police Superintendent?
text: The application to be Chicago's new police superintendent includes eight essay questions. Among the topics: accountability, use of technology and experience with matters related to terrorism.

headline: In Chicago, a Fraught Opening Atop the Police Force
text: CHICAGO — The job requires extensive management experience, the ability to deal with “significant distrust” and skill at addressing “highly publicized issues involving use of force.” It includes an unhappy work force, an angry public and a boss who is immersed in his own battles for survival. Federal investigators have begun sniffing around.

headline: Internet Yields Uneven Dividends and May Widen Inequality, Report Says
text: UNITED NATIONS — Can the Internet save the world?

headline: Fire-Suppressing Compound
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — How much fun is this? Yesterday, I left you with a song by THE BEATLES, based on a clue about SIDE TWO of “Magical Mystery Tour,” and today the entire theme is about THE BEATLES.

headline: ‘Moonshot’ to Cure Cancer, to Be Led by Biden, Relies on Outmoded View of Disease
text: Last Friday a group of 15 cancer researchers cut short a meeting at the Food and Drug Administration. The reason: They had been invited to Vice President Joseph R. Biden’s office to discuss his “moonshot” to cure cancer.

headline: How Rams’ Move May Affect Broadcasts and Ratings
text: For a generation, Los Angeles football fans have grown accustomed to watching other cities’ teams on television. The Raiders fled back to Oakland. The Rams migrated to St. Louis.

headline: Medical Device Maker Failed to Report Infections, Senate Report Says
text: Serious infections linked to poorly cleaned medical devices called duodenoscopes, used to examine the small intestine, have been more widespread than previously known, according to a Senate report released Wednesday.

headline: Ethiopia Halts Regional Plan After Protests
text: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia — The Ethiopian government has canceled a widely promoted plan to integrate the capital, Addis Ababa, with the surrounding region after it touched off protests and violence that has killed scores of people since late last year.

headline: Defense Lawyers in Etan Patz Retrial Seek to Bar Prosecutor
text: Defense lawyers asked a judge in Manhattan on Wednesday to bar a veteran prosecutor from taking part in the coming Etan Patz murder retrial because of statements she made about the case during her unsuccessful campaign to be the district attorney for Staten Island.

headline: Newer N.F.L. Owners Show Muscle in Tug of War

headline: Tunnel Repairs Could Disrupt L Train in Coming Years

headline: A Skateboard Stunt Turns Fatal for a Former Chef
text: Richard Oates was a skilled chef with a deft touch that put him at the top of his class at culinary school — and sped him through the kitchen ranks to central positions at the New York City restaurants where he worked. But he was, perhaps, an even better father, according to friends and former colleagues, and skateboards were the vehicles by which they said he was committing his life to his two young sons.

headline: N.C.A.A. to Let Underclassmen Return to College After Trying Out for N.B.A.
text: SAN ANTONIO — College men’s basketball players who are not seniors will now be able to try out for N.B.A. teams, receive a draft grade and then decide on returning to college — a stark shift from the past, when players had to declare for the draft before the N.B.A. combine and in doing so renounce future college eligibility.

headline: As Islanders Evolve, Coach Jack Capuano Keeps a Steady Course
text: SYOSSET, N.Y. — Five years into the job, Islanders Coach Jack Capuano still straps a whistle to his left glove and uses it liberally at practice. He covers the rink like a Zamboni, rushing from one end to the other, smacking his stick on the ice to make a point.

headline: Italy: Arrest in Killing of American
text: The police in Italy have arrested a man in the death of an American woman whose body was found in her apartment in Florence last weekend, according to Italian news reports on Thursday. The man, who was not identified, was facing a charge of aggravated murder in connection with the death of the woman, Ashley Ann Olsen, 35, according to the news agency ANSA. The suspect, who was described as a 25-year-old African immigrant, was ordered detained by the prosecutor in Florence.

headline: Gov. Christie Leaves Gun Controls Behind in New Jersey
text: It’s unfortunate that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey started running away from his own record on sensible gun controls as soon as he began his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination. Shameless pandering to voters in gun-friendly states has ensued. Mr. Christie abandoned his onetime fierce support of an assault weapons ban and reversed his opposition to armor-piercing .50-caliber rifles that have no place in civilized society.

headline: Why I Will Never Vote for Donald Trump

Bush administrations and in the White House for George W. Bush as a speechwriter and adviser. I have also worked for Republican presidential campaigns, although not this time around.

headline: How You Justified 10 Lies (or Didn’t)
text: Thanks to Stone readers who submitted a response — there were more than 10,000 — to my article, “Are These 10 Lies Justified?” Judging from the number of replies, the task of determining when it is or is not acceptable to lie is obviously one that many people have faced in their own lives. Many of you gave your own examples of lies told and why you believed they were or were not justified. It was heartening to find so many people prepared to reason thoughtfully about important moral issues.

headline: In Syrian Town Cut Off From the World, Glimpses of Deprivation
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Nisrine kept teaching school for months as the siege tightened around the Syrian town of Madaya, but had to give up a few weeks ago when her students got too weak from starvation to walk to class. A local medic has been surviving on the rehydration salts he gives patients, while a business school graduate makes soup from grass for his 70-year-old father, consulting shepherds about which kinds their long-since-slaughtered flocks liked best.

headline: During Men’s Fashion, Flocks of Peacocks Descend on Florence

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Sick Days
text: Now with computers on our laps, it’s hard to be perfectly, indulgently sick in bed. With our phones right there, we are tied to the life we were living yesterday, when we weren’t yet sick in bed. It’s time to be truly sick in bed this winter — sick like in the old days, when there was ginger ale from the store and fresh magazines on the night stand. Put it on the autoresponder: I’ll reply to you next week when I’m no longer sick in bed.

headline: My Return to Nepal, in Memoriam
text: Around the third hour on the third day of trekking uphill on a rocky trail in the rain, I felt a profound appreciation for the generous tolerance of my family. We had come to the foothills of the Himalayas by way of various story lines of my life, including President Kennedy’s 1961 inaugural address and my father’s death in 2014. These events led us to Nepal, and to a walk through the clouds.

headline: Against Neutrality
text: The photograph and the words arrive simultaneously. They guarantee each other. You believe the words more because the photograph verifies them, and trust the photograph because you trust the words. Additionally, each puts further pressure on the interpretation: A war photograph can, for example, make a grim situation palatable, just as a story about a scandal can make the politician depicted look pathetic. But images, unlike words, are often presumed to be unbiased. The facticity of a photograph can conceal the craftiness of its content and selection.

headline: The Happiness Code
text: Last summer, three dozen people, mostly programmers in their 20s, gathered in a rented house in San Leandro, Calif., a sleepy suburb of San Francisco, for a lesson in ‘‘comfort-zone expansion.’’ An instructor, Michael Smith, opened the session with a brief lecture on identity, which, he observed, can seem immutable. ‘‘We think we behave in certain ways because of who we are,’’ he began. ‘‘But the opposite is also true. Experience can edit identity.’’

text: This alluring seaside town also has its charms in the winter, with specialty shops offering wares from around the world.

text: BETWEEN Tuesday’s State of the Union address and Thursday’s Republican debate, and with the primary season around the corner, this week may well mark “peak spin” for the 2016 campaign. headline: Living Under the Sword of ISIS in Syria
text: Raqqa, Syria — A FEW weeks ago, my friend Saeed tried to get his family out of Raqqa, the city in eastern Syria that since 2014 has been the de facto capital of the self-declared Islamic State. “It’s becoming very hard to get any kind of work in Raqqa,” he told me. He was depressed that he’d failed in his attempt to smuggle his family over the Turkish border to the north.

headline: Some Cars by Renault and Other Makers Fail French Air-Quality Emissions Tests
text: PARIS — The French government said on Thursday that tests on exhaust emissions of nearly two dozen cars made by Renault and other automakers had found that “several” of the cars violated the country’s air-quality standards.

headline: 1941: Japan Opens Propaganda Office
text: MEXICO CITY — Japan began to oil propaganda guns in Mexico today [Jan. 14] for immediate use in a twofold fight against United States economic penetration and against the newly announced plan of the Roosevelt administration to block Axis purchases of Mexico’s war minerals and oil. High authorities disclosed that representatives of Domei, the official Japanese news agency, have established offices in this capital for distribution of news free of charge to Mexican and other Latin-American newspapers. The United States has no propaganda agency to combat this obvious effort by Japan to influence the Americas. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 15, 1941

headline: Tate Makes Room for Louise Bourgeois in Its New Building

headline: Evictions in Walled Old City Stir Up a ‘Hornet’s Nest’
text: JERUSALEM — The Palestinian residents of the Khaldiyya Ascent, a narrow cobblestone alley in Jerusalem’s walled Old City, have for decades lived in tiny, crammed apartments with high, moldy ceilings and peeling paint. Now, at least seven of these families face eviction threats by Jewish organizations reclaiming properties they owned before Israel was established in 1948.

headline: Daily Report: Tech Earnings Season Begins With a Warning
text: The tech earnings season got off to a rocky start on Wednesday with the surprise warning from GoPro, the maker of action cameras, that its quarterly results would be lower than expected by Wall Street analysts and that it had cut about 7 percent of its work force. A top executive also departed the company.

headline: Everybody Loves a Winner. So What Happens if Trump Loses?
text: Donald Trump misses no opportunity to remind us that he’s ahead in the polls for the Republican presidential nomination. headline: ‘American Horror Story’ Season 5 Finale: The Real Lady
text: And so began the era of Iris and Liz Taylor. Our heroines have taken over the Cortez (though, didn’t The Countess leave it to Ramona at the end of the last episode?) and, flush with cash after liquidating their former employer’s art collection, do a little redecorating. There’s 400 thread-count Egyptian cotton! Complimentary champagne! Japanese toilets!

headline: The Secret Behind Italy’s Favorite New Film
text: ROME — A BALDING government clerk in his late 30s has one true love: “il posto fisso,” a job for life. He doesn’t want to compete in the labor market; he has no urge to move on. He doesn’t even want to earn more. Give him a desk, a chair and a 9-to-5 job in the “pubblica amministrazione,” and he’s happy. Clocking in late, chatting with colleagues, accepting small bribes from taxpayers (most favored: quail), a regular salary — that’s life!

headline: Guantánamo Population Drops to 93 after 10 Prisoners Go to Oman
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon on Thursday announced that it had transferred 10 lower-level Yemeni detainees from the Guantánamo Bay prison to Oman. The departure of the unusually large group of prisoners — each of whom spent about 14 years in custody — reduced the prison population to 93, the first time it has been in double digits since the Bush administration began bringing Afghanistan war prisoners to the naval base in January 2002.

headline: As Aid Reaches Syrians, U.N. Chief Says Withholding Food Is a War Crime
text: UNITED NATIONS — The head of the United Nations said on Thursday that the warring parties in Syria were committing war crimes by withholding food from civilians. He called for all sides to lift their sieges immediately and unconditionally “as a confidence-building gesture” ahead of peace talks scheduled for Jan. 25.

headline: 1966: Succession Crisis in New Delhi
text: NEW DELHI — A wide-open race developed today [Jan. 14] for the premiership of India as a cabinet dispute erupted over the four-day-old Tashkent peace agreement with neighboring Pakistan. A new air of crisis gripped the country as reports from West Pakistan revealed that two persons were killed and 12 injured yesterday in a clash between police and students in Lahore, who were protesting the ‘‘Tashkent declaration.’’ Reports said police used tear gas against the students, who carried banners demanding ‘‘Liberation of the state from Indian rule.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 15, 1966

headline: 3 Found Guilty of Aiding $20 Million London Theft

headline: Few Answers on True Owners of Art Found in Gurlitt Trove
