headline: Walmart to Close 269 Stores as Retailers Struggle
text: Walmart, whose supercenters once transformed the way Americans shop, announced on Friday that it would close a record number of stores in the United States and overseas, as it fights to hold its ground in a retail landscape under siege by the behemoth Amazon.

headline: Paperback Row
text: GHETTOSIDE: A True Story of Murder in America, by Jill Leovy. (Spiegel & Grau, $16.) As a reporter for The Los Angeles Times, Leovy witnessed firsthand the impact of America’s staggering murder rates. Focusing here on one Los Angeles case, she delves into the “plague of black homicides,” including the fraught relationship between the police and civilians and the justice system’s failure to protect black citizens. (African-American men account for nearly 40 percent of the country’s murder victims.)

headline: Editors’ Choice
text: MY NAME IS LUCY BARTON, by Elizabeth Strout. (Random House, $26.) A writer and her estranged mother attempt to reconnect during a brief visit in a Pulitzer Prize winner’s exquisite novel of careful words and vibrating silences.

headline: The Facts of Refugee Life in Fiction
text: This week, we review several books about global migration and fractured borders, including Ben Rawlence’s “City of Thorns: Nine Lives in the World’s Largest Refugee Camp.” Rawlence’s book is nonfiction, but acclaimed and popular novels of recent years have brought the issue of refugees to wider attention by placing sympathetic fictional characters in situations much (sometimes very much) like real life.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
text: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Stuff We Liked: Bikes, Baristas and Powerball
text: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshot’s newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

headline: New Yorkers Quickly Unite Against Cruz After ‘New York Values’ Comment
text: New Yorkers may be proud, ornery individuals, quick to voice their differences loudly and unabashedly.

headline: They Have Not Yet Begun To Fight
text: In last night’s Republican debate we finally got the Donald Trump vs. Ted Cruz clash everyone has been pining for — not on policy, of course, but on the crucial questions of Cruz’s Canuckishness and Trump’s “New York values.” Cruz came prepared on both exchanges, and like others I would say that he won the night, though he did disappear for longish stretches later on and took some strafing fire from Marco Rubio (very) late in the evening. But then I also agree with the observers who think Trump fundamentally had a good night as well: The Donald has learned a lot about debating since this show started, and even when placed on the defensive he was effective and disciplined — responding to Cruz on the Canadian issue with more puckishness than bluster and then pivoting smoothly to 9/11 on the “New York values” issue. And then there was this moment, when a question about Nikki Haley’s post-SOTU critique of the party’s “angriest voices” allowed Trump to deliver — pretty calmly and evenly — what was probably the line of the night, if not of his campaign: “She did say there was anger. I’m very angry because our country is being run horribly and I will gladly accept the mantle of anger.”

headline: ‘City of Thorns,’ by Ben Rawlence
text: In 2010, Ben Rawlence, then a researcher for Human Rights Watch, visited the refugee camp of Dadaab on the eastern Kenyan border, home to 300,000 people, many of whom had fled the chronic civil war in Somalia. The next year, he returned for what would be the first of seven long visits to follow the lives of nine of its inhabitants and to watch the camp grow until it became the largest refugee settlement in the world, more town than camp, with its own hospitals, cinemas and soccer teams, occupying an area the size of New Orleans. It would be good to be able to say that his story is encouraging or uplifting; but Rawlence’s “City of Thorns” is a deeply disturbing and depressing portrait of the violence, destitution, fear, sense of hopelessness and neglect in which a large number of the world’s estimated 60 million forcibly displaced people now live.

headline: Shabab Say They Overran African Union Base in Somalia, Killing Dozens
text: MOGADISHU, Somalia — The Shabab militant group said on Friday that it had overrun an African Union base in a village in southern Somalia and killed dozens of peacekeepers.

headline: George Miller on ‘Mad Max: Fury Road’ and Furiosa Tattoos
text: One of the surprise hits in the awards race has been “Mad Max: Fury Road,” which landed 10 Oscar nominations on Thursday, including best picture and best director. The film’s momentum was one of the many unexpected turns of this season: A sequel to a sequel to a sequel, “Fury Road” seemed too much a genre flick, and for a good while, Oscar watchers didn’t consider it a contender. (Shows how much we know.)

headline: Recipes for a Long Weekend
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: New Orleans Puts Poor on ‘Waiting List’ for Lawyers, Suit Alleges
text: The cash-starved public defender’s office in Baton Rouge faces “chronic underfunding,” a federal lawsuit contends, a situation that has led to poor people arrested in connection with crimes being placed on a “waiting list,” leaving them in jail without access to lawyers.

headline: The Greatest Hoax in Sports Reporting History (The Times Fell for It, Too)
text: Before reviewing one of the greatest hoaxes in sports history, let’s first meet the perpetrators: Morris Newburger, Lew Krupnick and Bink Dannenbaum.

headline: Potatoes and Pregnancy
text: A new study suggests that the more potatoes in a woman’s typical diet, the more likely she is to develop gestational diabetes, a serious complication of pregnancy.

headline: Goodbye, Golf Clubs. Hello, Hiking Boots and Kayak.
text: THEY call him “Elusive,” at least on the hiking trails. And that’s pretty much where Dave Roberts spends his time these days, crisscrossing the country by foot, by bike, even by kayak.

headline: Inside the List
text: The List Awakens: Alan Dean Foster’s movie novelization “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” goes right to the top in its first week on the hardcover fiction list. This isn’t the only best seller to spring from Disney’s reboot — an illustrated junior novelization has spent three weeks on the middle-grade hardcover list, where it’s currently No. 2, and other titles have landed on the kids’ series list and the miscellaneous list — but it is the first “Force Awakens” tie-in to hit adult hardcover. So what, besides Chewbacca’s drunken sex scene, makes this an adult book? (I’m only kidding about Chewie — sorry! — but readers curious about the mating habits of wookies can turn to The Guardian, where an Edinburgh zookeeper reports that “I would assume they would do it pretty much the same way we do it.” If you’re like me, this will have you humming Cole Porter for days.) In fact, Foster’s novelization does contain some scenes of graphic violence missing from the movie, but the most adult thing about it may be the florid vocabulary. Here’s how it describes the villain Kylo Ren, for instance: “saturnine of aspect, lithe of build, tortured of mien and troubled of eye.” Keep the children away.

headline: Many in Jakarta Seem to Shrug Off Terrorist Attack
text: JAKARTA, Indonesia — If the militants who attacked the center of this city with explosives and guns on Thursday hoped to inspire fear and attract followers, they seem to have failed. Instead, life in Jakarta, the Indonesian capital, returned to normal on Friday, with traffic jams, long lines for public transportation and hasty breakfasts at streetside food stalls.

headline: ‘Passenger,’ by Alexandra Bracken
text: In present-day New York City, a focused young woman prepares for a recital on the violin, the instrument for which she has sacrificed both her social life and a sense of closeness to her peripatetic mother. She feels the pressure of making good on her training, along with confusion about her best path to the future she desires. While not every teenager is a violin prodigy, Etta’s situation shares common themes with the lives of many driven young people, and right from the opening moments of “Passenger” there is much to like about her. When Etta’s elderly teacher, the most supportive figure in her life, becomes suddenly discouraging on the night of the recital, and Etta overhears an argument between her teacher and her mother as she is about to go onstage, the dramatic tension is ratcheted up, promising an engaging narrative about ambition and family. But this is an adventure story, the first in a new series from Alexandra Bracken, the author of the Darkest Minds books, and Bracken is only just getting started.

headline: ‘Paper Wishes,’ by Lois Sepahban
text: The psychic pain from the forced removal and detention of American citizens and residents of Japanese ancestry during World War II is still felt profoundly today. Case in point: a nationwide protest last April that blocked a scheduled auction of artifacts made in United States detention centers, led by descendants of the internees, who could not tolerate the idea that remnants of this dark chapter of their families’ history were up for sale to the highest bidder.

headline: What Are New York Values?
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas described Donald J. Trump as having “New York values” in the Republican debate on Thursday. What does that mean exactly?

headline: Taller Condos on the Upper East Side
text: After clustering around 57th Street for the last several years, super-tall condominiums, which are coveted by buyers for their views and scorned by some others for their bulk, are turning up in other neighborhoods.

headline: Junk Bonds Go Sour, but the Question Is How Sour
text: The tide has definitely turned against investors in high-yield debt, better known as junk bonds.

headline: ‘Strictly No Elephants,’ ‘Big Friends’ and More
text: What are friends for? Children answer this question in a variety of telling ways, whether by opting for the safety of a playmate who might as well be a twin or the adventure of reaching out to a polar opposite or by steering some in-between course. Four new picture books offer different views of the risks and rewards for the very young of stepping outside the primal comfort zone of home and family.

headline: ‘Conquerors: How Portugal Forged the First Global Empire,’ by Roger Crowley
text: Afonso de Albuquerque died 500 years ago, after spending a dozen years terrorizing coastal cities from Yemen to Malaysia. He enriched thousands of men and killed tens of thousands more. Despite never commanding more than a few dozen ships, he built one of the first modern intercontinental empires. And this was just the beginning: The next step, he said, was to sail up the Red Sea, destroy Mecca, Medina and the Prophet Muhammad’s body and liberate the Holy Land. Perhaps, he mused, he could destroy Islam altogether.

headline: ‘Blood and Earth,’ by Kevin Bales
text: Kevin Bales argues in “Blood and Earth” that ending “modern slavery” could make a big difference in the ­planet’s health. “If slavery were a country,” he ­asserts, “it would have the third-largest CO2 emissions on the planet.”

headline: ‘Midnight in Broad Daylight,’ by Pamela Rotner Sakamoto
text: Pamela Rotner Sakamoto’s engrossing book opens simultaneously in Los Angeles and Hiroshima on Dec. 7, 1941. In Los Angeles, a 21-year-old Japanese-­American gardener named Harry Fukuhara is mowing a lawn when his white employer steps out of her house and tells him, “Harry, Japan has attacked Pearl Harbor.” In Hiroshima, a 17-year-old high school student named Katsutoshi is about to board a train for a track meet when he hears a garbled shout behind him. During his race, Katsutoshi keeps turning over in his mind what he thought he heard. Had someone really shouted “our victorious assault on Hawaii”?

headline: ‘The Illegal,’ by Lawrence Hill
text: How do we stop them? How do we stop the dispossessed, the poor, the hungry, the terrified, from breaching our borders and overwhelming us with their need? How do we deal with those who have already managed to sneak in? And how do we distinguish between the truly desperate and the truly evil who hide (so we suspect) among them?

headline: ‘Your Heart Is a Muscle the Size of a Fist,’ by Sunil Yapa
text: With the dwindling of the anti-­globalization movement over the past decade, the 1999 World Trade Organization protests in Seattle can now look like easily mocked millennial optimism: turtles, teamsters, Wiccans, the “Free Mumia” crowd and beanie-wearing save-the-­forests types finding common cause with the victims of corporate capital and glowing with the belief in a better world. Although media coverage of what transpired over the protests’ five chaotic days in November focused on police brutality and destruction of property, in its full reality, the “Battle in Seattle” swung from hope-filled carnival to angry riot to a moment of real change — a polyvalent, ambiguous and high-stakes drama. In other words, a novelist’s dream.

headline: ‘The Blue Line,’ by Ingrid Betancourt
text: The literary style known as magic realism, incorporating fantastic elements into otherwise realistic fiction, has been deployed with much success by Latin American writers. It is also, lately, a Colombian tourism slogan. Now the Colombian politician Ingrid Betancourt, best known for a memoir describing her six years in the jungle as the hostage of ­anti-government rebels, has added her first novel to the ranks of the genre.

headline: ‘The Love of Strangers,’ by Nile Green
text: Great was the weight placed on young shoulders in the spring of 1815 when a small group of students left their home city of Tabriz in northwest Iran and set out for “Inglistan,” the land of the English. Led by the charismatic and doggedly determined Mirza Salih, they were taliban in the truest sense of the word — seekers of knowledge. Their desire for ulum-i-­jadid, or new sciences, had become a matter of national security. Wars with Russia had battered the domain of the crown prince, Abbas Mirza, for more than a century, and he was eager to protect it from further destruction. When the young men were sent to the West, their instructions were clear, if daunting: They were to learn all they could in order to drag their country into an industrialized, czar-beating era.

headline: ‘The Kindness of Enemies,’ by Leila Aboulela
text: Perhaps we only imagine that questions of allegiance, of belonging, are more urgent now than they ever were. The “war on terror” asks for a pledge of loyalty: Whose side are you on? The question seems straightforward, but as Leila Aboulela’s new novel reminds us, to ask where we come from, to choose where we belong, is not a simple matter at all.

headline: ‘The Invitation-Only Zone,’ by Robert S. Boynton
text: A 13-year-old Japanese schoolgirl ­walking home from badminton practice mysteriously disappears. So does a young couple strolling on a beach. A mother and her 19-year-old daughter also vanish on the way back from their routine grocery shopping trip. They are among at least 17 Japanese who were abducted by North Korea in the years between 1977 and 1983.

headline: Republicans Intensify Attacks After a Pitched Debate
text: The battle for the Republican nomination appeared more splintered than ever between two halves of a bitterly divided party as several candidates scrambled on Friday to consolidate the support of more moderate conservatives a day after a raucous debate.

headline: The Smartest Comments of the Republican Debate: Readers Weigh In
text: On Thursday night, we asked you who made the most intelligent comment during the Republican debate. In response, readers gave shoutouts to Donald Trump, Ben Carson, Chris Christie and Bernie Sanders. Below, some of the most popular choices for the smartest comment of the evening:

headline: You Asked, Hillary Clinton Answered
text: During a visit to the editorial board, the candidate took a moment to answer a question from a Times reader.

headline: Thoughts on a Poland in Flux: Readers Speak Out
text: There is intense debate in Poland about the direction the country is taking under its new right-wing government, a debate that has spilled over into the European Union and that has raised questions about the direction of democracy in Eastern and Central Europe more than a quarter-century after the fall of the Berlin Wall.

headline: Sean Penn Says His El Chapo Article ‘Has Failed’
text: The actor Sean Penn said he has “a terrible regret” that the capture of the Mexican drug lord known as El Chapo has distracted from his article in Rolling Stone, which he had hoped would start a national conversation about the war on drugs.

text: YOUR FATHER SENDS HIS LOVEStoriesBy Stuart Evers312 pp. Norton, $24.95.

headline: The Fashion News to Know This Week
text: And the stars look very different today

headline: Iowa’s Heartland Beyond the Campaign Trail
text: On a Monday morning in early December I drove a rental car out of Des Moines and eventually made my way down a slender country road that cut a forthright path through cattle pastures and cornfields not yet glazed by snow. My destination was Winterset, the county seat of Madison County, whose covered bridges Robert James Waller immortalized more than 20 years ago in his best seller, “The Bridges of Madison County.” Mr. Waller’s treacly love fable is not my personal favorite, but I confess to detouring at the sign for Hogback Bridge and being stirred by the lonely spectacle of that wooden sentry crouched over the North River in an unprepossessing crease of Middle America.

headline: Oh, the Places We Tell You to Go: Inside the Travel Section’s Special Issue
text: Temples of Malta. Pine forests in Dalat, Vietnam. How about a speck of volcanic rock in the South Atlantic? Itching to get out of town? Every January, The Times Travel section publishes a “Places to Go” Issue.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: ‘City of Thorns’
text: This week, Ben Rawlence discusses “City of Thorns”; Alexandra Alter has news from the literary world; Janice Y. K. Lee talks about “The Expatriates”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Ian Rankin’s ‘Even Dogs in the Wild,’ and More
text: Retirement isn’t for everyone, least of all John Rebus, the hero of Ian Rankin’s mordant police procedurals set in the shadowy underworld of Edinburgh. In EVEN DOGS IN THE WILD (Little, Brown, $26), Rebus’s unorthodox friendship with the aging crime boss “Big Ger” Cafferty allows this retired detective to attach himself to a police investigation into the murder of a former lord advocate and death threats against other high-profile citizens, including Cafferty.

headline: Choreographer Revisits Epic Sanskrit Poem
text: LONDON — From the age of 13 to 15, Akram Khan traveled the world as a performer in the director Peter Brook’s nine-hour theatrical version of the “Mahabharata.” It’s not much of a surprise then, that Mr. Khan, now 41, and well-known in his native Britain, has returned to the epic Sanskrit poem — it contains more than 90,000 couplets and hundreds of stories and myths — for a second time in his choreographic career.

headline: Big Ticket | 146 Waverly Place
text: A five-story Greek Revival townhouse in Greenwich Village sold for $23.28 million.

headline: Greenwich Village Townhouse Flipped for $23.3 Million
text: An investment partnership sold a gut-renovated early-20th-century townhouse on a prime, tree-lined street in Greenwich Village for $23,282,932.60, more than twice what it had paid for the property just over two years ago — a transaction that was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: You Asked, Hillary Clinton Answered
text: On Wednesday, we asked you to submit questions for Hillary Clinton. During her visit to the editorial board, she picked one of your questions from a hat to answer on camera. Watch her response below:

headline: F.T.C.’s Lumosity Penalty Doesn’t End Brain Training Debate
text: A few years ago, Jennifer Perrine saw a television ad for Lumosity, an online brain training program, and decided she’d give it a try.

headline: In Online Dating, ‘Sextortion’ and Scams
text: DATING websites and apps typically see a surge in activity this time of year as people who felt lonely over the holidays try to follow through on New Year’s resolutions to find someone special with whom to share their life, or maybe just someone agreeable to share their bed on a cold winter’s night.

headline: Medical Aid Sent to Starving Syrian Town of Madaya
text: GENEVA — Alarmed by starvation in the besieged Syrian town of Madaya, aid agencies sent a mobile medical clinic there on Friday and planned to increase medical support.

headline: Rams’ Move Raises Questions About Raiders and Chargers
text: On Tuesday, N.F.L. owners voted to allow the St. Louis Rams to return to Southern California and build a domed stadium in an entertainment district in Inglewood, a few miles from downtown Los Angeles.

headline: Review: ‘Billions’ Delivers a Dose of Charisma to Hedge Fund Titans
text: Men who make lots of money and growl at one another about profits and margins and winning and losing. Remember them?

headline: Take Comfort in One-Hour Winter Vegetable Soup
text: I still have the cheap food mill I bought from a vendor at a market on the Boulevard Raspail when I lived in Paris decades ago. The knob has come loose from the handle, but it still does the job. I pull it out every time I make this soup.

headline: What I Love | Andrew Livingston
text: Andrew Livingston, the majority owner of the Knickerbocker Mfg. Co., a clothing company, lives and trend-spots in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: A Fashion Entrepreneur at Home in Brooklyn
text: The first thing Andrew Livingston did when he moved into his two-bedroom apartment in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, was to furnish the guest room with a good mattress. “I needed it up and running on Day 1,” he said.

headline: Monetary Economics at the GOP Debate
text: There wasn’t much economics, or for that matter much connection with reality. But Ted Cruz delivered:

headline: Supernova Has Energy of Hundreds of Billions of Suns
text: Astronomers have discovered a giant ball of hot gas, billions of light years away, that is radiating the energy of hundreds of billions of suns. The ball may be the most powerful supernova ever seen, a study in the journal Science reports. At the center is an object about 10 miles in diameter that scientists think might be a rare type of star called a magnetar. The gas ball, 3.8 billion light years away, was spotted through the All Sky Automated Survey for Supernovae collaboration. The project, led by researchers at Ohio State University, aims to find supernovae using various small telescopes in the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.

headline: After Nuclear Test, China Resists Pressure to Curb North Korea
text: BEIJING — North Korea had detonated a nuclear bomb, and the president of China was urging caution. It was the fall of 2013, and the North’s third nuclear test in seven years, carried out several months earlier, had rattled much of the world.

headline: Chipotle Will Close Stores for Food Safety Meetings After Outbreaks
text: As Chipotle Mexican Grill tries to  recover from a series of contaminations that have caused some customers and investors to flee, it said it would shut all its stores for several hours on Feb. 8 to hold food safety meetings with employees.

headline: His Strength Sapped, Top Marathoner Ryan Hall Decides to Stop
text: REDDING, Calif. — Sprinting seven miles down a 9,000-foot mountain and then running back up to do it again may not appeal to even the most self-punishing of athletes, but Ryan Hall believes it is the kind of “experimental workout” that transformed him into the fastest American distance runner in history.

headline: Carly Fiorina Is Not Even Good at Gratuitous Insults
text: Some political candidates are great at throwing around snappy one-liners. Donald Trump has an incredible facility with sound bites. They rarely have a passing connection to reality, and often don’t even make sense, but they land well with his audiences. He knows he can just yell, “Let’s build a wall!” and his crowds will go crazy.

headline: Louvre to Start Restoring  Another Leonardo Painting
text: PARIS — The Louvre is preparing to start the restoration of Leonardo da Vinci’s “Saint John the Baptist,” a 16th-century work that has darkened over the years.

headline: Stock Market Ends Sharply Lower as Worries About Economy Surface
text: It may be time for everyone to take the markets seriously again.

headline: When Prisoners Had Ski Jumps
text: Q. I recently saw a photograph from the 1970s showing an inmate at the Dannemora state prison using a ski jump inside the prison! Can this be true?

headline: Get the Look: Luke Spiller’s Glam Rock Makeup
text: The products and steps required to recreate the Struts frontman’s on-stage beauty look.

headline: Meet the Glam Rock Frontman Channeling Freddie Mercury
text: Luke Spiller knows that the Struts are headed for big things. Already, the U.K. rock outfit has played in front of 80,000 people in Paris as the opener for the Rolling Stones. More recently, “Could Have Been Me,” the hard-charging lead single from band’s debut album, “Everybody Wants” (out March 4 via Freesolo/Interscope Records), has racked up more than 7 million plays on Spotify and has become a regular on rock radio. And Spiller, the Struts’ charismatic singer, has garnered comparisons to everyone from Tim Curry to the late Queen frontman Freddie Mercury (to whom he bears an almost eerie resemblance.) But today, he’s worried about just one thing: getting his makeup right. “Does it look all right?” he asks, looking in the mirror.

headline: Lawsuit Questions Ted Cruz’s Eligibility to Be President
text: Donald J. Trump predicted that the lawsuits against Senator Ted Cruz, doubting his constitutional eligibility to be president, would start trickling in as questions continued to percolate about the fact that he was born in Canada. As the Republican candidates gathered to debate in South Carolina on Thursday, one had already been filed.

headline: America’s Public Lands
text: To the Editor:

headline: In Losing the Rams, St. Louis Wins
text: Don’t cry for St. Louis, sports fans.

headline: Iowa on a Plate
text: The dining landscape in the state that begins the presidential nomination process.

headline: ​Another Reason to Caucus in Iowa: The Restaurants
text: LE MARS, Iowa — To get to Archie’s Waeside, the James Beard Award-winning steakhouse here that has been run by the same family for three generations, you drive past a branch of the ubiquitous Pizza Ranch chain, cross over a set of railroad tracks and inch down an unlit road toward a low-slung and scantly marked building hard by an R.V. dump.

headline: How the Rev. Michael A. Walrond Jr. Spends His Sundays
text: The Rev. Michael A. Walrond Jr., 44, the senior pastor at First Corinthian Baptist Church in Harlem, wears jeans in the pulpit, rides a motorcycle and encourages posting on Twitter during his sermons. So far it has worked. Since he arrived in 2004, First Corinthian says, church membership has grown to 9,000 from 300. In 2014, he ran (unsuccessfully) for the congressional seat long held by Representative Charles B. Rangel. Known to congregants as Pastor Mike, Mr. Walrond lives in Harlem with his wife, the Rev. LaKeesha Walrond, 44, the church’s executive pastor.

headline: Annie Leibovitz’s “Women” Opens in London
text: The photographer kicks off a 10-city world tour with an installation at the Wapping Hydraulic Power Station.

headline: Annie Leibovitz’s Classic Portraits of Women, Now in Expanded Form
text: Down rickety stairs in an old red-brick power plant in the East End of London, images from Annie Leibovitz’s 1999 “Women” project pulse on two giant screens. They alternate with more recent portraits: an image of the late L’Wren Scott lying across a chair, a tableau of New York’s female gallerists — even the Kardashian-Wests mid-selfie. From a third screen glows the Queen in formal pomp.

headline: New Donald Trump Ad Features Less Anger, Bold Goals and No Specifics
text: Donald J. Trump’s campaign on Friday released its second advertisement, a conventional 30-second clip of Mr. Trump’s Jan. 4 stump speech in Lowell, Mass.

headline: Uber Not to Blame for Rise in Manhattan Traffic Congestion, Report Says
text: After an uproar last year between Mayor Bill de Blasio and the ride-hailing app Uber over the company’s growth in New York City, the two sides reached something of a truce on Friday with the release of a very short — and very expensive — traffic report from the city.

headline: How I Got Ejected From a Donald Trump Event
text: WAUKEE, Iowa – I was late to Donald J. Trump’s unannounced visit to a Pizza Ranch on Friday, his first drop-by of this ubiquitous Iowa chain that is standard stop for candidates, but which Mr. Trump has avoided in favor of boisterous crowds in big halls.

headline: Robust 4th Quarter Couldn’t Redeem Market After an Anxious Year
text: The stock market withstood fierce punishment last year and had almost nothing to show for it. A strong fourth quarter healed some of the damage but as the year closed and 2016 began, the battering in the market began yet again.

headline: The Reach of Lead in Flint’s Water Supply
text: How the crisis developed, and which neighborhoods had the highest lead levels.

headline: Bookshelf: Back Again
text: Reissued books include “Will Spring Be Early? Or Will Spring Be Late?” and “Arthur.”

headline: Dining in Thunder Bay, Where Sustainable Meets Delectable
text: Between the elk, venison and fish harvested by the First Nations and the pork-heavy diet of the French settlers, Canadian cuisine has always been known for its protein. But the Canadian steakhouse got a modern twist in early 2015 with Uptown Cut, a chef-focused spot that brings a tasting-menu approach to a classic concept.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Terence Koh
text: The artist shares the titles he’d want most on a desert island.

headline: Bird Flu Outbreak Confirmed in Indiana
text: The Department of Agriculture confirmed on Friday that a strain of avian influenza had hit a commercial flock of turkeys in Indiana.

headline: A Last-Minute Guide to ‘Picasso Sculpture’ at MoMA
text: This “once-in-a-lifetime” exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, which brings together more than 100 Picasso works, will close on Feb. 7.

headline: A Yacht Club in Brooklyn Elects Its First Female Commodore
text: Good evening, Madam Commodore. Congratulations, Madam Commodore. What are you drinking, Madam Commodore?

headline: Alphabet Shakes Up Its Robotics Division
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google’s robotics division has been plagued by low morale and a lack of leadership since the unit’s founder left abruptly in 2014. Now Alphabet is cleaning it up.

headline: French Movie About Jihadis Won’t Be Released in Theaters
text: PARIS — From the start, the subject hit too close to home. Out of security concerns in a country still in shock after the November terrorist attacks, “Made in France,” a French film about homegrown jihadists plotting strikes on downtown Paris, will head straight to video-on-demand this month and forgo release in cinemas.

headline: Pizza, Made With a Light Hand, California Style
text: By mid-January, I often long for something brighter than the decidedly wintry vegetable offerings at the farmers’ market. I need a reminder of summer’s sweetness. And sometimes I give in to that longing. Does that mean I’m not a seasonal cook? Or is this simply a lapsed locavore’s quandary?

headline: Gains Against ISIS Bring More Deaths Elsewhere in Iraq
text: BAGHDAD — When tens of thousands of civilians escaped an Islamic State onslaught on the Iraqi city of Ramadi last year, Amir Mishaan and his three children, the youngest barely a year old, were among those who settled into makeshift lives here in the capital.

headline: When Emerging Markets Roar, Stand Your Ground
text: While most forms of investing require a leap of faith, betting on emerging-markets stock funds this year — Chinese stocks have already had double-digit declines — may feel like jumping across the Grand Canyon.

headline: ‘Super Pac’ Backing Jeb Bush Looks to Crowdfund an Ad for the Super Bowl
text: The mega-donors who helped Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, raise over $100 million aren’t exactly the typical crowdfounding type.

headline: Fund Managers Win With Tech Stalwarts and Burly Brand Names
text: Bets on the biggest purveyors of technology — companies like Amazon, Google and Microsoft — powered three of the top-performing funds of the fourth quarter.

headline: Follow Your Conscience Without Losing Your Shirt
text: Investing can sometimes seem heartless. If whatever makes money is your mantra, you may find that you have put your cash into enterprises with which you fundamentally disagree.

headline: Loose Lips Sink Careers, Even for C.E.O.s
text: Doesn’t anybody know how to shut up anymore?

headline: Signs of a Retail Rebound as Consumers Take On More Debt
text: Consumer debt is rising. How Americans handle that load and how much cash they spend will determine the fortunes of an important stock sector.

headline: For E.T.F. Traders, Lessons From the Panic
text: A selling point of exchange-traded funds over traditional mutual funds is that they can be traded at any time during a market session, but when stocks plunged as soon as trading began on Aug. 24 — that feature of E.T.F.s became a bug.

headline: Small, Private Insurers Face Increasing Scrutiny on Avoided Taxes
text: SHOULD a Phoenix-area jeweler be able to create his own private insurance company to cover his jewelry stores against possible terrorist attacks, specifically those “relating to radioactivity from a ‘dirty’ bomb or from nuclear fuel or nuclear waste”?

headline: Investing Advice That Doubles as a Bookmark
text: Mastering the basics required to put together a solid financial plan is not too hard. Getting the most out of every investment dollar is.

headline: Brownsville’s Broken Windows
text: Between Thanksgiving weekend and the first week in January, when the gang rape of an 18-year-old woman in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn was reported, the neighborhood could too easily have found confirmation that it was a place doomed to lurid violence, if its broader history hadn’t proved the claim.

headline: Review: ‘Angie Tribeca,’ Steve and Nancy Carell’s Modern-Day ‘Police Squad!’
text: TBS is debuting its new comedy “Angie Tribeca” on Sunday, with a 25-hour “Binge-a-Thon,” playing the whole 10-episode season on repeat, without commercials. This is both unnecessary and perfect.

headline: One Syrian’s Journey From Hometown Rebel to ISIS Bomber
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — IN the early years of Syria’s revolt, he filmed protests in the streets of his rebel-held neighborhood, in the historic center of the city of Homs. He chanted for dignity and freedom with a green, white and black banner, the old version of the national flag.

headline: Ronald Perelman Quits Carnegie Hall Board
text: In a quiet coda to a period of sturm und drang at Carnegie Hall, Ronald O. Perelman, the billionaire businessman, resigned from its board of trustees earlier this month, representatives of Mr. Perelman and the hall said Friday.

headline: How Oil Prices Are Falling Again, Explained in Four Charts
text: A glut of crude oil on the markets is pushing the price of oil down to levels not seen since the global financial crisis.

headline: El Chapo’s Affection for Actress Is Met With Mockery Online
text: MEXICO CITY — Affectionate cellphone messages left by the drug lord Joaquín Guzmán Loera for the actress Kate del Castillo have some in Mexico wondering if Mr. Guzmán, the former fugitive known as El Chapo, was interested in more than just a friendly interview with her.

headline: Stock Prices Sink in a Rising Ocean of Oil
text: HOUSTON — The world is awash in crude oil, with enough extra produced last year to fuel all of Britain or Thailand. And the price of oil will not stop falling until the glut shrinks.

headline: A Year Junk Bonds Lived Up to Their Name
text: Investors chasing high yields have been battling high anxiety.

headline: More Programs Set for Rubenstein Atrium
text: The David Rubenstein Atrium at Lincoln Center will roughly double its number of free performances in 2016 in a makeover that includes the introduction of new recurring programs.

headline: Farmers Markets and Food-Borne Illness
text: OVER the last two decades, more and more Americans have begun patronizing their local farmers markets. From 1994 to 2014, the number of farmers markets throughout the country increased almost fivefold. Many consumers frequent these markets because they believe that the foods they purchase there are healthier and safer than the same items sold at supermarkets, posing less risk of food-borne illness.

headline: Justices to Hear Appeal by Bob McDonnell, Ex-Governor of Virginia
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear an appeal from Bob McDonnell, the former governor of Virginia who was convicted of public corruption and faces two years in prison in a case that offers an important test of what kinds of official conduct amount to forbidden corruption.

headline: Ted Cruz Failed to Report a Second Campaign Loan in 2012
text: The Republican presidential candidate Ted Cruz, already facing scrutiny for not disclosing a Goldman Sachs loan he used for his 2012 Senate campaign, also failed to disclose a second loan, from Citibank, for the same race, according to a letter he sent Thursday to federal election officials.

text: To the Editor:
