text: Greece and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Marco Rubio Bought a Gun on Christmas Eve, Campaign Says
text: NEWPORT, NH — How did Senator Marco Rubio spend Christmas Eve?

headline: Jan. 15, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Greece, France, Taiwan and Spain.

headline: Portugal to Extradite Ex-C.I.A. Agent to Italy in Rendition Case
text: MADRID — A Portuguese court has ruled that a former C.I.A. agent should be handed over to Italy after being found guilty by an Italian court of taking part in the kidnapping of an Egyptian cleric in 2003, one of the renditions ordered by the administration of former President George W. Bush.

headline: Autopsy of Chedrick Chatman
text: Newly released documents and videos shed light on the death of Chicago’s Cedrick Chatman, a 17-year-old who was shot and killed by police in 2013.

headline: Review: ‘Mercy Street,’ a Civil War Hospital Drama on PBS
text: A stately building owned by a wealthy family whose fortunes are in jeopardy. A principled American beauty who married a European nobleman. Lavish helpings of period dresses, ball gowns and uniforms. “Mercy Street” may be the rare PBS drama that’s set in the United States, but don’t worry: “Downton Abbey” fans will find that it has some comfortingly familiar elements.

headline: Review: Philadelphia Orchestra Plays Music From Vienna
text: In crucial ways, the charismatic conductor Yannick Nézet-Séguin, now in his fourth season as music director of the Philadelphia Orchestra, is excelling in the job. The players seem energized by his leadership. The orchestra sounded terrific on Thursday at Carnegie Hall, in a concert highlighted by an uncommonly sensitive performance of Beethoven’s Fourth Piano Concerto, with the pianist Jan Lisiecki.

headline: At Least 20 Killed in Siege by Militants in Burkina Faso
text: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Gunmen from Al Qaeda stormed a luxury hotel frequented by foreigners in Burkina Faso’s capital on Friday night, seizing hostages and killing others while fighting with dozens of security forces who began a counterattack hours later. It was Al Qaeda’s first major attack in this landlocked sub-Saharan country, a former French colony.

headline: Rocky Road Ahead for Big Banks
text: America’s too-big-to-fail cabal is nursing $130 billion in damages. That’s the amount of market value lost by the nation’s top six banks in the last two weeks. The shares of all but Wells Fargo now trade below book value, suggesting stockholders are bracing for a year or more of pain. Whether they’re right looks like a tossup.

headline: Giants Kept Ben McAdoo by Keeping Eagles Away
text: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — By the middle of this week, Ben McAdoo had interviewed for vacant head coaching positions with the Giants and the Philadelphia Eagles. He knew that if either team was serious about hiring him, it would call him back for a second interview.

headline: 18 Carmakers Agree to Share Safety Data
text: DETROIT — When Mark Rosekind became the nation’s top auto safety regulator in late 2014, the industry was reeling from record recalls prompted by a vehicle defect at General Motors that was later tied to 124 deaths.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Free Spirits
text: If there’s a revolution in fashion, it’s about men’s wear.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Free Spirits
text: If there’s a revolution in fashion, it’s about men’s wear. Shown here are men who won’t be corralled by traditional style expectations. Two looks are at the center: a pencil-slim wrap coat in an unconventional gray, left, and a dusty pink coat shaped by exaggerated welt seams, right. The effect is such that the cloth seems to have been molded into a fitted shape. More important is the authority with which the young men wear these coats, which are far removed from the expected Wall Street uniform.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week.

headline: Attack at Hotel in Burkina Faso’s Capital
text: A gun battle broke out outside the Splendid Hotel in Burkina Faso’s capital, Ouagadougou, on Friday night. The hotel, in the business district of Ouagadougou, is frequented by Westerners.

headline: Evening Hours | Dinner at the Frick and a Jazz Dance
text: Plus: Remembering a fashion editor.

headline: Oscars So White? Or Oscars So Dumb? Discuss.
text: Are these the whitest Oscar nominations ever? Or just the most recent Academy Award whiteout? For the second year in a row, the nominations failed to recognize any minority actors. Movies about black lives like “Creed” and “Straight Outta Compton” did receive recognition, but their nominations were for either white writers (“Compton”) or a white performer (Sylvester Stallone in “Creed”). The black directors of each movie along with their nonwhite actors were shut out.

headline: Review: ‘Key Change’ Hears From Women in Prison
text: Although the language occasionally takes on a darkly lyrical hue, music plays no role in “Key Change,” a moving, intimate and superbly acted drama about women’s lives in (and out of, and in again) a British prison. Written by Catrina McHugh and directed by Laura Lindow, the play was “devised with” women from an actual prison, drawing specifically on their experiences both before and during incarceration.

headline: E.U.’s Open Borders Are in Danger, German Minister Warns
text: BRUSSELS — The pressures facing Germany as it contends with record levels of migration burst into the open on Friday as the country’s finance minister warned the rest of the European Union that freedom to move within the bloc could be “close” to ending.

headline: Republicans in Congress Will Write 2016 Campaign Platform, Ryan Says
text: BALTIMORE — Republican congressional leaders said Friday that they were moving aggressively to draw up a campaign platform for 2016 so that the party would be positioned to coalesce swiftly around a nominee after a bruising primary campaign.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Flint, Coal
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Jason Craig’s ‘Longyarn’ Features a Mom Who Won’t Shut Up
text: Mom is a mountain in “Longyarn,” the uninhibitedly shaggy new comedy from Banana Bag & Bodice. Her bedraggled head nearly scrapes the ceiling of the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn, where Jason Craig’s play opened on Thursday night, and her scrawny torso is attached to a Brobdingnagian skirt that defies circumnavigation.

headline: And the Oscar Goes to ... White People
text: How can the Academy increase diversity in nominations and awards?

headline: Gingerly, Donald Trump Tries Out Some Campaign Conventions
text: In Manchester, N.H., on Monday, after a traditional town hall-style event, the candidate who prefers dashing home from speeches on his private jet stopped by the Red Arrow Diner and ordered a cheeseburger plate piled high with French fries.

headline: Review: From Chile, ‘Escuela,’ a Drama About Education
text: A chalkboard is not the most cheering sight to behold upon entering a theater. Nor is a slide projector. Both are on view, aptly enough, alas, in “Escuela,” a dull, didactic drama written and directed by the noted Chilean playwright Guillermo Calderón.

headline: To Protect Against Zika Virus, Pregnant Women Are Warned About Latin American Trips
text: Federal health officials on Friday advised pregnant women to postpone traveling to 13 Latin American or Caribbean countries and Puerto Rico where mosquitoes are spreading the Zika virus, which has been linked to brain damage in babies.

headline: He Irons. She Stitches.
text: San Toy Laundry in Park Slope, Brooklyn, is marked with old-fashioned, Charlie Chan-style lettering on its dated sign out front. The space, on Seventh Avenue, has housed a string of Chinese-owned laundries dating back more than a century, and like nearly everything else inside, the handwritten sign “No Lost Tickets on Friday & Saturday” is antiquated.

headline: Donald Trump Says He Is Self-Financing Bid, Despite the Evidence
text: Speaking to reporters after Thursday night’s debate, Donald J. Trump said, as he often does, that he was self-financing his campaign.

headline: Review: In ‘God Bless Baseball,’ Japan, Korea and America’s Pastime
text: “God Bless Baseball” at Japan Society has a few modest allegorical points to make and takes its time making them. It’s intermittently amusing and often visually arresting, but — like, some would say, the game of baseball itself — it would benefit from being sped up.

headline: Review: ‘Samedi Détente’ Looks Back at the Horrors of Rwanda
text: In “Samedi Détente,” Dorothée Munyaneza uses spoken word, dance and music to explore the Rwandan genocide that forced her from her Kigali home at the age of 12. She describes how 800,000 people died in just 100 days, how she lost friends and family, how she and her father and brother escaped into the countryside, wearing lice-ridden layers of clothing and sleeping outdoors on a tarp.

headline: Aterrizando en Venezuela: En busca del rostro de Bolívar
text: Nicholas Casey, el nuevo corresponsal de The New York Times en la región andina, compartirá en esta sección todas las vivencias de su primer mes en Venezuela.

headline: Review: The New York Philharmonic Offers Works by Modern Masters
text: For sheer sonic splendor, few programs could surpass the one Alan Gilbert and the New York Philharmonic are offering at David Geffen Hall this week. It shows three modern masters — Ottorino Respighi, Magnus Lindberg and Igor Stravinsky — using their orchestral wizardry well, if, in Respighi’s case, not always wisely.

headline: Friday Night Music: Lucius, Born Again Teen
text: I love Lucius — their songwriting is terrific, their harmonies are exquisite, and their live performances are pure joy. Frankly, I’m not quite as fond of their records — I bought their first, of course, and have an advance of their second — which are (to my taste) overproduced. But your mileage may vary.

headline: Race, Civil Rights and Photography
text: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders relied on the power of photographs to persuade, enrage and motivate.

headline: Campaign Aides Defend Bernie Sanders’s Record on Gun Votes
text: As Senator Bernie Sanders soars in polls and faces criticism from Hillary Clinton over his record on gun control, his aides are finding themselves explaining his voting record over the years on the issue.

headline: Kid Fury of ‘The Read’: From Digital Realm to the Stage
text: WASHINGTON — Kid Fury’s mentions on Twitter are often littered with story links and screenshots from his more than 100,000 followers, in which they ask if he has, say, seen the criticisms of the price of Michelle Obama’s clothes or a singer’s shady comment on Instagram. Their goal is to provide fodder for “The Read” — the podcast he hosts with his friend and fellow Internet personality, Crissle — or for “Furious Thoughts,” the YouTube series he started in 2010. On each platform he has built a rabid, eclectic following — blacks, whites, older people, high schoolers — who seek out his irreverent, profanity-ridden takes on the latest happenings both online and off, from viral racism to “The Real Housewives of Atlanta.”

headline: China Embraces Craft Beers, and Brewing Giants Take Notice
text: HONG KONG — When Jin Xin first started selling imported premium beer a decade ago, his bar manager predicted that it would take a month or two just to sell a single case. But within a few years business picked up, and soon customers started frequenting the bar for its India pale ales and other European beers.

headline: Inquiry Faults Army Leadership in Anthrax Shipment
text: WASHINGTON — The Army on Friday issued a scathing critique of the management and oversight of a military laboratory that mistakenly sent live anthrax to facilities around the world, singling out a brigadier general and 11 other people for possible disciplinary action.

headline: Dog Pants? Show a Little More Fur, Obama Says
text: [Video: Watch on YouTube.]

headline: Despite Boycott Calls, Chicago Mayor’s King Day Event Goes On
text: CHICAGO — Despite calls to boycott an annual breakfast Mayor Rahm Emanuel was hosting in honor of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., a hotel ballroom was mostly full on Friday morning. The speech he delivered was greeted with polite applause. Some influential black leaders even offered friendly remarks from the stage.

headline: In Praise of Blue Notes: What Makes Music Sad?
text: The idea of sadness connects the music of Adele, Kendrick Lamar, Billie Holiday, the English folk singer Nick Drake, the metal band Slayer and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

headline: Kuwait Airways Drops Flights to Avoid Israeli Passengers
text: Kuwait Airways will operate its last flight between New York City and London on Saturday, deciding last month to drop the route after about 35 years of service rather than transport Israeli citizens between the two cities.

headline: In New Year’s Melee in Cologne, a Migrant Was One Woman’s Savior
text: BERLIN — Caught up in a melee of drunken revelers outside the Cologne train station on New Year’s Eve, Caitlin Duncan, a neuroscience student from Seattle, was terrified. She had somehow gotten separated from her German boyfriend, who had both their cellphones and her wallet. Ms. Duncan, 27, said that she was quickly surrounded and groped by several young men: One snatched her hat from her head, another tried to kiss her face and neck.

headline: New York to Gain 30 Acres of Parkland From Catholic Nuns
text: UPPER NYACK, N.Y. — Sister Veronica Mendez adjusted her glasses and tried to remember the last time someone joined the religious order here. “Joined and stayed?” she pondered. “It would have been the 1970s.”

headline: Gov. Cuomo’s Push on Justice Reform
text: When Gov. Andrew Cuomo went to Mount Neboh Baptist Church in Harlem last Sunday to give a speech on criminal justice reform, he said, “I’m going to go down in the history books as the governor who closed the most prisons in the history of the state of New York.”

headline: Death of 3 Columbia Students Raises Fears Over Trips Abroad
text: While many of their classmates were using the winter break to unwind, the 28 Columbia University students whose bus crashed in Honduras this week had chosen to spend part of their vacation volunteering by helping doctors provide basic medical care in one of Central America’s poorest countries.

headline: States Should Raise the Gas Tax
text: The tumbling price of crude oil is helping many Americans save money. It also presents a good opportunity for state governments to raise their gasoline taxes to help pay for road repairs and other needed transportation investments.

headline: Putting an Environmental Price Tag on Coal
text: One intriguing if slightly mysterious passage in President Obama’s State of the Union address contained a pledge to “accelerate the transition away from old, dirtier energy,” in part by changing “the way we manage our oil and coal resources so that they better reflect the costs they impose on taxpayers and our planet.”

headline: Federal Reserve Started 2010 With Hope, Then Fear and Fitful Activism
text: WASHINGTON — When 2010 began, the United States economy seemed to be on the mend and leaders of the Federal Reserve discussed how they would unwind their extraordinary rescue efforts  from the crisis that erupted in 2008. The term “exit strategy” was mentioned 37 times in their first two policy meetings of the year.

headline: Disney Names Bob Weis as New President of Imagineering Unit
text: LOS ANGELES — The Walt Disney Company on Friday installed new leadership at its linchpin Imagineering division, which is responsible for designing and building rides, hotels and restaurants across Disney’s $16 billion global theme park empire.

headline: New York Values, According to New Yorkers
text: Senator Ted Cruz attacked Donald J. Trump, a Queens native, for having “New York values.” Amid much debate over what that means, we invited New Yorkers to share their own definition.

headline: Looking at Later Primaries, Bernie Sanders Works to Strengthen Black Support
text: Even if he defeats Hillary Clinton in both Iowa and New Hampshire next month, Senator Bernie Sanders faces a daunting problem when the presidential race moves on to bigger, more diverse states: winning over black voters.

headline: For Now, Anglicans Avert Schism Over Gay Marriage
text: Despite threats of a walkout or even schism over the issue of gay marriage, the archbishops of the Anglican Communion, the world’s third-largest body of churches, managed to keep their church intact after a week of tense meetings that ended with a symbolic washing of one another’s feet.

headline: New Yorkers, Self-Assured and Opinionated, Defend Their Values
text: There is a broad and recognizable New York persona. It isn’t entirely enviable, not to everyone. Assured. Brazen. Unapologetic about money. There is a New York speed, and it’s rocket velocity. You want directions in the Midwest, someone will take you there, buy you a coffee, invite you later for dinner and to stay overnight. In New York it’s: “Two blocks down, take a left.” Whoosh.

headline: Jawbone Raises $165 Million at Half Its Last Valuation
text: Jawbone, the once-hot wearable technology start-up, said on Friday that it had raised $165 million in funding at a valuation of $1.5 billion, or roughly half the amount that the company was valued at as recently as 2014, continuing a burgeoning trend of start-ups raising money at lower values than before.

headline: Girl, 15, Killed in Fall From Rooftop in Hell’s Kitchen
text: A 15-year-old girl died on Friday afternoon after she tried to jump from one rooftop to another in Midtown Manhattan and fell five stories, the police said.

headline: Oregon: Police Arrest Two Tied to Standoff at Refuge
text: One man connected with the armed takeover of a federal wildlife refuge in rural Oregon was arrested, and a second was held in the disappearance of a vehicle from the refuge, the authorities said Friday. Both arrests were made without incident and far from the refuge itself. Kenneth Medenbach, 62, was arrested Friday at a grocery in Burns on probable cause for unauthorized use of a motor vehicle that the police said was the property of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, about 30 miles away. Brian Cavalier, who identified himself as “Fluffy Unicorn,” and as a bodyguard of the militant group’s leader, Ammon Bundy, was arrested earlier in the week in Buckeye, Ariz., on a criminal warrant during the investigation of a suspicious vehicle. He was later released by a judge. A Buckeye police spokesman on Friday said Arizona law prevented disclosure of arrest warrant details. Protesters have occupied the refuge headquarters buildings since Jan. 2.

headline: Workers Sickened at House Office Building
text: Several people were taken to hospitals on Friday after possibly being exposed to lead paint dust in a House office building, the authorities said. Officials said that overnight construction at the Longworth House Office Building may have released the harmful substance in the kitchen area of the cafeteria, according to the House sergeant at arms. The area was not being used for food preparation. Ten cafeteria employees were evaluated, and most were taken to hospitals with “minor injuries,” a Fire Department official said. A favorite of House staff members, the cafeteria will remain closed while tests are conducted. The area around the Capitol was largely empty on Friday, with Congress in recess.

headline: Addressing Critics, White House Cites Diplomacy in Release of Sailors by Iran
text: WASHINGTON — The White House on Friday sought to defuse attempts by President Obama’s critics to turn this week’s overnight seizure of two American patrol boats and their crews into a symbol of what they say are the administration’s foreign policy failures and feckless relations with Iran.

headline: Hillary and Bernie, Punching
text: There’s a Democratic debate Sunday night! The party honchos scheduled it in the middle of a three-day weekend, obviously in a bid to ensure maximum attention. The American public, perky from eight straight hours of football playoffs, will totally be in the mood for a serious policy dialogue.

headline: 16-Year-Old Charged in Brooklyn Shooting Death
text: A 16-year-old has been charged with murder in the shooting death this week of a teenager near a Brooklyn school complex, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: U.S. Pledges to Ease Pain of Closing Coal Mines in Shift to Cleaner Energy
text: For the past five years, President Obama has denied the Republican charge that he is waging a war on coal. On Friday, with the Obama administration’s announcement that the Interior Department will halt new coal leases on public lands, Mr. Obama acknowledged that his climate change polices are hurting American miners and began offering ways to ease that economic harm.

headline: The Real Problem With Lunch
text: Houston — THERE’S something about comparing America’s school food to the superior meals in other countries’ schools that we seem to enjoy, in a masochistic sort of way.

headline: New England Is Abuzz (Oh, Is There a Game?)
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Last Sunday morning, Chandler Jones, the Patriots’ star defensive end, showed up in the parking lot of the Foxborough Police Department, inexplicably shirtless and disoriented.

headline: Starvation in Syria Galvanizes U.N., but Accountability Seems Distant as Ever
text: UNITED NATIONS — The images of gaunt, hollow-eyed children in three besieged Syrian towns this week prompted even the usually cautious Ban Ki-moon to bluntly and publicly declare that the people starving civilians on the battlefield were committing war crimes.

headline: In Life and on Field, Cardinals’ David Johnson Can Handle Traffic
text: TEMPE, Ariz. — David Johnson’s first run in traffic was memorable, but not in a way that made his mother proud.

headline: News Corp. and 21st Century Fox Won’t Move to World Trade Center
text: News Corporation and 21st Century Fox, two media companies controlled by Rupert Murdoch, have decided against moving their headquarters into a skyscraper at the World Trade Center, the companies said on Friday.

headline: After 85 Years in East Harlem, a Routine That Keeps Her Going
text: Most Tuesday mornings, Marta Benitez walks from her apartment on the corner of Fifth Avenue and 111th Street to the food pantry at St. Cecilia’s Church on East 105th Street. With other volunteers, she assembles bags of nonperishable items to be handed out to members of the community.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Top Political Advisers Got $500,000 in 6 Months, Records Say
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s top political consultants, some of whom also represent clients with interests before City Hall, were paid about $500,000 in the last six months by the mayor’s campaign fund and a nonprofit group created to advance his agenda, according to financial records disclosed on Friday.

headline: Venezuela Declares Emergency as Its Economy Falters
text: CARACAS, Venezuela — The Venezuelan government on Friday declared an emergency to address the country’s deteriorating economy.

headline: Building Visions of Humanity’s Climate Future – in Fiction and on Campus
text: Earlier this week I spoke at Arizona State University on ways to pursue a least-regrets approach to human development. My talk (building on one you can watch here) launched an interdisciplinary workshop on developing the capacity to manage the climate system in the face of relentlessly rising emissions of greenhouse gases.*

headline: Sessions of Congress
text: Administrivial “Heads Up For Sunday!” Alert : There will be a note on some formats of the Sunday, January 17 puzzle that reads: “The print version of the Sunday, January 17 puzzle contains small arrows between certain squares, which some formats cannot reproduce. We recommend using the Web version or the PDF.”

headline: Another Oscar Year, Another All-White Ballot
text: Is it the members who vote on the Oscars, the films, the campaigns behind them or something else?

headline: Dan Haggerty, Who Played Grizzly Adams, Dies at 73
text: Dan Haggerty, who played a gentle mountain man with a luxuriant beard and a bear named Ben in the 1974 movie “The Life and Times of Grizzly Adams” and the NBC television series of the same name, died on Friday in Burbank, Calif. He was 73.

headline: Dave Sime Dies at 79; World’s Fastest Sprinter, but Far From Its Luckiest
text: Dr. Dave Sime, who passed up baseball and football careers to become the world’s fastest sprinter but who never won the Olympic gold medal he coveted, a victim of hard luck and the unforgiving rules of track and field, died on Wednesday in Miami Beach. He was 79.

headline: Ted Cruz ‘Apologizes’ to New Yorkers, Again and Again
text: TIGERVILLE, S.C. – Senator Ted Cruz of Texas stood onstage here with a mischievous smile, setting off on a stump speech he is typically loath to change.

headline: At Fairfield Museum, Exploring Craftsmanship Across Centuries
text: In this era of mass-produced goods, when we can breezily purchase dishes and glassware by the set, browse for presized rugs online and “build” furniture by assembling kits from Ikea, it’s easy to take such quotidian household items for granted. But just a couple of centuries ago, the only way to create them was to fashion them by hand.

headline: Walter Weissman Photographs Celebrities
text: “I’m a little bit like a fly on the wall,” the photographer Walter Weissman was saying not long ago at Guild Hall in East Hampton, as he walked through an exhibition of his portraits of high-profile artists and other boldface names.

headline: Chamber Music Society Aims to Expand Its Reach
text: As the artistic directors of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, David Finckel and Wu Han have expanded the group’s reach over the past decade. Instead of just producing concerts at its home in Alice Tully Hall, the society produces and presents programs all over the world, from Seoul, South Korea, to Pleasant Hill, Ky.

headline: Review: Rye Roadhouse Maintains Its Louisiana Charm
text: The Rye Roadhouse is a perpetual tailgate, no coolers, koozies, propane tanks, tongs or foot warmers required.

headline: Review: Mazi, a Greek Taverna Refined by Time and Fire
text: Built into the bar at Mazi, a new Mediterranean restaurant in Riverhead, is a copper plaque of a phoenix rising out of the ashes. In the case of Mazi, the figure is more than a metaphor.

headline: Review: Global Sensibility at the Plum and the Pear
text: “America is a melting pot of cultures, and so is my food,” said George Kalivas, the chef and owner of the Plum and the Pear, in Wyckoff.

headline: An Ever-Changing Menu at Prospect Cafe in West Hartford
text: Goldilocks would have felt right at home at Prospect Cafe in West Hartford since its reopening four months ago.

headline: Serena Williams, Rejecting Health Doubts, Insists She’s Ready
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Serena Williams has not played a meaningful match since losing in the semifinals of the United States Open in September.

headline: Matt Harvey Re-Signs With Mets
text: The Mets agreed to a contract with Matt Harvey for the 2016 season, avoiding arbitration.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
text: Benedict Cumberbatch delivers one of the best performances of 2014 as the British mathematician Alan Turing in “The Imitation Game.” Six teenagers endure some vicious cyberstalking in “Unfriended.” And Adam Driver, the latest “Star Wars” baddie, hosts “S.N.L.”

headline: Feud Adds Intrigue to Game Between Knicks and Grizzlies
text: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Inside their training complex on Friday, the Knicks maintained that they were more or less oblivious to the interest now surrounding their Saturday night game in Memphis, a midseason contest that did not stand out at all when the 2015-16 N.B.A. schedule was released in August.

headline: Corrections: January 16, 2016
text: NEW YORK

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “We may win an Oscar now and then, but an Oscar is not going to fundamentally change how Hollywood does business. I’m not talking about Hollywood stars. I’m talking about executives. We’re not in the room.”

headline: Tsai Ing-wen Elected President of Taiwan, First Woman to Hold Office
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Tsai Ing-wen was elected Taiwan’s president on Saturday, becoming the first woman to win the office. Voters gave her Democratic Progressive Party, which is skeptical of closer ties with China, control of Taiwan’s legislature for the first time, giving her broad authority to enact her policies in office.

headline: How El Chapo Was Finally Captured, Again
text: MEXICO CITY — Stripped to his undershirt and covered in filth, the world’s most notorious drug lord dragged himself out of the sewers and into the middle of traffic.

headline: With the Rise of Justin Trudeau, Canada Is Suddenly ... Hip?
text: Led by a handsome prime minister and artists like Drake, the Weeknd and Sarah Polley, Canada is shaking off its polite image.

headline: David Bowie: Invisible New Yorker
text: About 10 years ago, the playwright John Guare got a call asking if he wanted to meet David Bowie to discuss a theater project.

headline: Airing the Evidence on Dust Mites
text: Q. Does an unmade bed kill dust mites?

headline: Eileen Myles, the Poet Muse of ‘Transparent’
text: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Rocking a pinstriped Paul Smith suit and boots that she had picked up in Paris, Eileen Myles rolled into the Golden Globes here last weekend on the arm of her girlfriend, Jill Soloway, the creator of the Amazon series “Transparent,” who was outfitted in a pink tuxedo and platform sneakers. Cool? The epitome.

headline: What Donald Trump’s Plaza Deal Reveals About His White House Bid
text: The day Donald Trump called and asked for a one-on-one meeting in the winter of 1988, Tom Barrack was a relative newcomer to the high-stakes poker game of New York real estate. He had worked for nearly two years for Robert Bass, the Texas billionaire investor, and had played an important role in winning the Plaza Hotel for his boss the year before. Mr. Trump was the country’s most quotable and ostentatious financial celebrity, a guy with a jet, a 282-foot yacht and a fondness for peach-toned marble.

headline: In Maine, Local Control Is a Luxury Fewer Towns Can Afford
text: CARY PLANTATION, Me. — Up here, near the end of Interstate 95, a single main road ridged with stately conifers runs past the odd house that at night casts an orange glow over the snow. There is no school. No police department. Not even a stoplight.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took Instagram followers from the inside of a dinosaur to Sesame Street, in Queens.

headline: Corneliani: Fall 2016
text: The fall 2016 designs from Corneliani.

headline: Liber8 BB-8!
text: A few months ago I was on a panel at ComicCon — hey, who knew CES utility functions would lead me down this road? — discussing Trekonomics. Manu Saadia has a fun book on the subject, focusing on the transformative powers of replicators that make anything you want, but as we discussed, what about services? My on-the-fly take was that there was a conceptual problem: if we made machines smart enough to provide all our services, wouldn’t those machines effectively be people, deserving freedom from servitude?

headline: Ermenegildo Zegna: Fall 2016
text: Ermenegildo Zegna’s fall 2016 men’s collection.

headline: Oil Goes Nonlinear
text: When oil prices began their big plunge, it was widely assumed that the economic effects would be positive. Some of us were a bit skeptical. But maybe not skeptical enough: taking a global view, there’s a pretty good case that the oil plunge is having a distinctly negative impact. Why?

headline: Iran Frees Americans, Including Jason Rezaian, in Prisoner Swap
text: TEHRAN — Iran freed four Americans of Iranian descent from prison on Saturday, including a Marine veteran and a reporter from The Washington Post, in a delicately negotiated swap with the United States, which released seven Iranians who had been held on sanctions violations.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: A Not-So-‘Basic’ Shift in Start-Ups
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: Costume National Homme: Fall 2016
text: The fall 2016 designs from Costume National Homme.

headline: Paul Giamatti Had a Busy Year of Mad Guys and Bad Hair
text: When Paul Giamatti is first seen in the new Showtime drama “Billions,” his character, a crusading United States attorney named Chuck Rhoades, has been bound and gagged as part of a sadomasochistic sex act. Shooting the scene last year had a curious effect on the actor. “I got really sleepy and relaxed,” Mr. Giamatti recently recalled over a cappuccino at the Lambs Club in Times Square. “I think guys who normally get tied up have the opposite reaction. Or maybe this is why they swaddle babies?”

headline: Apartments That Feel Like Saunas
text: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: In Tehran, Iranians Play Down Milestone
text: TEHRAN — On the day that crushing international sanctions against Iran were to be lifted, state television opened its morning hourly news program with an item on children’s vaccinations. There were no flag-waving youths or cheering crowds on Tehran’s streets, just the usual Saturday morning rush hour, the start of the Iranian workweek.

headline: Exploring Des Moines and Beyond in Iowa
text: With the caucuses weeks away, a road trip reaffirms that our nation, beginning with Iowa, is full of unsung surprises.

headline: Hawaii Baby With Brain Damage Is First U.S. Case Tied to Zika Virus
text: The first case of brain damage linked to the Zika virus within the United States was reported on Friday in Hawaii.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Dolce & Gabbana: Fall 2016
text: Dolce & Gabbana’s Fall 2016 show.

headline: Sgt. E. Castro: A Prison Peacemaker
text: Sgt. E. Castro, 40, is a correctional supervisor at Folsom Women’s Facility in California. (Her full first name has been withheld for security reasons.)

headline: Marni: Fall 2016
text: Fall 2016 looks from Marni.

headline: Profiles of Saeed Abedini, Amir Hekmati and Jason Rezaian
text: Age: 39

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2016
text: Jil Sander presents looks for Fall 2016.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — You need a different kind of a mindset to decipher cryptic crossword clues. Occasionally, you might need more than one different kind of mindset.

headline: The Place of Refuge in the West Village
text: Six years ago, it was decided that it would be fun to eavesdrop — with permission — on diners in the city as they sat in restaurants eating and talking. Since then, the At the Table column has covered group outings at grand hotels, holes in the wall, bistros, pizzerias, taquerias, dim sum palaces, barbecue joints, lunch counters, steakhouses, noodle shops, old classics and new finds, all in search of that ineffable combination of food, décor and clientele that gives a restaurant a sense of place.

headline: Unbeaten at Home, Warriors Are Still in Fight for a Playoff Edge
text: Off to a 37-3 start to the season entering the weekend, which had them tied for the best 40-game start in N.B.A. history, the Golden State Warriors have dominated most basketball conversations.

headline: Clinton Campaign Underestimated Sanders Strengths, Allies Say
text: Advisers to Hillary Clinton, including former President Bill Clinton, believe that her campaign made serious miscalculations by forgoing early attacks on Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and failing to undercut his archliberal message before it grew into a political movement that has now put him within striking distance of beating her in Iowa and New Hampshire.

headline: In Forbes Media Sale, Five-Figure Battle Started a $100 Million War
text: Shortly after the Forbes family sold control of its magazine and publishing business in 2014, Tim Forbes held a meeting in Hong Kong with one of the new owners. Mr. Forbes, younger brother of Steve Forbes, had been trying for weeks to collect an interest payment from the buyers. But in the October meeting, Mr. Forbes said his family had waited long enough for the $46,000 payment. The refusal to pay, he said, was “a disrespect to my family and disrespect to me personally.”

headline: TINA and the ACA
text: Lucy just snatched the football away, again. Republicans assured us that this year they really would, seriously, roll out their alternative to Obamacare. Or, maybe, not.

headline: What’s Harder Than Renting a Car? Filing a Complaint
text: This jam-packed episode contains both a Haggler intervention and a head-scratcher of a mystery. That is called value, dear readers. The mystery, for those who can’t stand suspense, will turn up at the end of the column, and a bit like Stonehenge and the career of Nicolas Cage, it will remain a mystery.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Vision Makes Hillary Clinton Camp See Red
text: Hillary Clinton’s campaign denounced an ad for Bernie Sanders in Iowa and New Hampshire, calling it a negative attack — a characterization Mr. Sanders’s team denied.

headline: The Unluckiest Captain in China
text: “Mayday. Mayday. Mayday. Call sign Alfa Bravo Charlie Delta. Mayday, Pacific Ocean. I am on fire in No. 4 hold and have dangerous goods on foredeck.” It is a Wednesday morning in Guangzhou, China, and in a recording studio on the 22nd floor of a Zhujiang New Town skyscraper, terrible things are happening to ships.

headline: Singer’s Apology for Waving Taiwan Flag Stirs Backlash of Its Own
text: BEIJING — A teenage singer made headlines in China and on her home island of Taiwan this weekend, but not for the winsome K-pop music that she hoped would attract fans. Instead, a glum, shaken apology after a controversy over a flag landed the singer, Chou Tzu-yu, in the maw of tensions between China and Taiwan, just as the island voted to elect an independence-leaning president on Saturday.

headline: Chris Davis’s Deal With Orioles Keeps Yoenis Cespedes in Play for Mets
text: The Baltimore Orioles have agreed to contract terms with Chris Davis, a development that gives the Mets a little more hope that they can sign Yoenis Cespedes to a short-term deal.

headline: Neil Barrett: Fall 2016
text: The latest designs from Neil Barrett.

headline: Ted Cruz Goes on Multipronged Attack Against Donald Trump
text: FORT MILL, S.C. — Disparaging Donald J. Trump’s temperament, questioning his beliefs and even knocking his polling numbers, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas laid into Mr. Trump in earnest on Saturday and abandoned any reluctance to take on his popular Republican rival.

headline: Prominent Jeb Bush Donor Questions ‘Super PAC’ Strategist Over Negative Marco Rubio Ads
text: A prominent donor to Jeb Bush pressed the chief strategist of the “super PAC” supporting Mr. Bush over the group’s negative ads about Senator Marco Rubio during a closed-door meeting in Manhattan on Friday, according to three people familiar with the encounter.

headline: Letters to the Editor
text: On Making College Sports Explicitly, Unabashedly Professional

headline: Soviet Star Defenseman’s Latest Turn
text: SOMERSET, N.J. — When Craig Romanok learned of his son Clayton’s new high school hockey coach this fall, he made Clayton, a goaltender on the team, sit down to watch “Red Army,” a documentary on the famed Soviet hockey team of the Cold War era. Romanok wanted to ensure that his son had the proper appreciation for the man who is now his coach.

headline: Deadly Standoff Leaves Burkina Faso Stunned
text: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — Terror came to this sleepy city this weekend, as armed fighters descended on a road nicknamed the Champs-Élysées, where friends meet for coffee and foreigners relax in a familiar hotel. After a 15-hour siege, the assailants left behind more than the dead and wounded scattered across the charred road amid shell casings.

headline: The Founders’ Intent
text: Readers discuss a letter from a retired diplomat that argued that the founders designed the Constitution to have “flexibility to respond to change.”

headline: How Measurement Fails Doctors and Teachers
text: TWO of our most vital industries, health care and education, have become increasingly subjected to metrics and measurements. Of course, we need to hold professionals accountable. But the focus on numbers has gone too far. We’re hitting the targets, but missing the point.

headline: When Anger Trumped Progress
text: JOHN YOUNG was born into slavery, on July 4, 1855. By 15 he was a free man and an electrifying orator, recruiting black voters around his native South Carolina to the Republican Party with “pyrotechnical” rhetoric and mustache-waggling jokes. In the late 1860s, it looked as if he might help his party make real change in the post-Civil War South.

headline: The Man Who Fell From Fame
text: BRETT SMILEY was no David Bowie.

headline: Rocco Casagrande
text: Rocco Casagrande, a former United Nations biological weapons inspector, is managing director of Gryphon Scientific, a consulting company that last week delivered a federally commissioned report identifying the risks and benefits of allowing research that could make certain viruses, like influenza, SARS or MERS, more dangerous.

headline: Why I Taught Myself to Procrastinate
text: NORMALLY, I would have finished this column weeks ago. But I kept putting it off because my New Year’s resolution is to procrastinate more.

headline: Donald Trump’s Existential Pickle
text: IF your very candidacy and identity rest on your supposed talent for victory, can you survive a defeat?

headline: Cancer and Climate Change
text: I’M a climate scientist who has just been told I have Stage 4 pancreatic cancer.

headline: Some Inconvenient Gun Facts for Liberals
text: FOR those of us who argue in favor of gun safety laws, there are a few inconvenient facts.

headline: Hallelujah College
text: LAST fall, as student activists around the country protested racism on their campuses, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas dismissed secular universities as havens for “leftist, coddled kids.” The protests proved that these schools teem with “psychotic Marxists,” declared “The Daily Caller,” a conservative website.

headline: The Destruction of Progressive Wisconsin
text: SHORTLY after his exit from an abbreviated presidential run last fall, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin returned to a more successful undertaking: dismantling what remains of his state’s century-old progressive legacy.

headline: The Bill Clinton Question
text: What matters about Bill Clinton’s sexual past is what we still don’t know about it.

headline: A Picasso’s Economics Lesson
text: QATAR, it seems, was gazumped.

headline: Reigning Cats and Dogs
text: WASHINGTON — AFTER running as a man last time around, Hillary Clinton is now running as a woman.

headline: After Losing a Daughter, Mustering Strength for 3 Who Remain
text: She called them her four M&M’s: Meghan and Mishelle, Makayla and Mya, each born a year apart, a tribe of sisters who walked in lock step and looked after each other when they got sick.

headline: C. D. Wright, Poet of Ozarks and Beyond, Dies at 67
text: C. D. Wright, a MacArthur fellowship-winning poet whose work — characterized by linguistic experimentation, stylistic innovation and an ever-shifting thematic canvas — was rooted in her Southern heritage yet, at the same time, utterly beyond category, died this week at her home in Barrington, R.I. She was 67.

headline: Maria Teresa de Filippis, Pioneer of Auto Racing, Dies at 89
text: Maria Teresa de Filippis, who in the late 1950s became the first woman to compete in Formula 1 world championship grands prix, widely regarded as the pinnacle of automobile racing, died on Jan. 9. She was 89.

headline: With Triple Crown Winner at Last, Sport Aims to Ride the Momentum
text: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla. — As racing prepared for a widely expected coronation of American Pharoah, the first Triple Crown winner in 37 years, as its horse of the year during ceremonies at Gulfstream Park on Saturday night, the industry recognized the need to build on the enormous lift he provided.

headline: Operating on a Shoestring, Ireland Struggles to Develop First-Rate Tennis Players
text: More than 40 nations will be represented at the Australian Open, which begins Monday, more evidence of how truly global tennis has become.

headline: The Death Penalty Endgame
text: How does the death penalty in America end?

headline: Leonid Zhabotinsky, Strongman for the Ages, Dies at 77
text: Leonid Zhabotinsky, a record-breaking Ukrainian-born Soviet weight lifter who picked up Olympic gold medals in 1964 and 1968 and was Arnold Schwarzenegger’s teenage idol, died on Thursday in Zaporozhye, Ukraine. He was 77.

headline: When Oil-Rich Countries Need More Cash
text: The long slide in oil prices, which reached a 13-year low this week of less than $30 a barrel, means that oil-rich nations are not so rich anymore. And that is potentially a big problem for investors and policy makers in the United States and abroad.

headline: Keep Guns Away From Abusers
text: While the gun violence debate often focuses on mass shootings of strangers,  hundreds of Americans are fatally shot every year by spouses or partners. In 2013, 61 percent of women killed with guns were killed by husbands, ex-husbands or boyfriends. And in 57 percent of shootings in which four or more people were killed, one of the victims was the shooter’s partner or family member, according to an analysis by the group Everytown for Gun Safety.

headline: Broncos’ Movie Buff Harris Has Been Stealing the Show From Opposing Receivers
text: ENGLEWOOD, Colo. — The Oscar nominations came rolling in last week, and that afforded Chris Harris Jr., the Denver Broncos’ resident cinephile, an opportunity to handicap the race for best picture. Of the eight films nominated, he had seen most, including “The Revenant” (bloody but good), “Bridge of Spies” (fantastic) and “Spotlight,” his pick to win — though he reserved the right to change his mind, he said, after viewing them all.

headline: Linebacker Luke Kuechly Quietly Leads a Brash Panthers Defense
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — A flashy new sign appeared in the Carolina Panthers’ locker room last week, pasted above the section where the defensive backs store their gear. It has gradations of pale blue and white and declares that the area is “Thieves Ave.”

headline: Pal Zileri : Fall 2016
text: Pal Zileri’s Fall 2016 show.

headline: Iran Complies With Nuclear Deal; Sanctions Are Lifted
text: VIENNA — The United States and European nations lifted oil and financial sanctions on Iran on Saturday and released roughly $100 billion of its assets after international inspectors concluded that the country had followed through on promises to dismantle large sections of its nuclear program.

headline: With Iran Nuclear Deal Implemented, What Happens Next?
text: The International Atomic Energy Agency declared Saturday that Iran had fulfilled requirements to limit its nuclear activities, a step that automatically lifted nuclear-related economic sanctions imposed by the United Nations, European Union and United States. The move freed Iran to sell much more oil and gain control of roughly $100 billion in impounded money, ending a prolonged isolation that has driven the country into a deep economic malaise.

text: The Fall 2016 men’s collection from Versace.

headline: Alabama Player’s Misfortunes Typify Pitfalls of College Sports
text: I first heard the name Altee Tenpenny about 10 years ago.

headline: Maryland Takes Out Frustrations on Ohio State
text: COLLEGE PARK, Md. — No. 3 Maryland went into its practice Thursday bruised from Tuesday’s 70-67 loss at Michigan, just its second defeat of the season. The team proceeded to have at it.

headline: Twisting One’s Words
text: Administrivial “Heads Up!” Alert : There will be a note on some formats of today’s puzzle that reads: “The print version of the Sunday, January 17 puzzle contains small arrows between certain squares, which some formats cannot reproduce. We recommend using the Web version or the PDF.”

headline: Flamboyant Egyptian Politician Craves Public Eye
text: CAIRO — Mortada Mansour, a pugnacious Egyptian politician, likes to boast that he beats his rivals with his shoe — so much, in fact, that he has lost count of the number of disputes he has settled in that manner. “I ran out of shoes,” said Mr. Mansour, who once spent time in jail for insulting a judge.

headline: Huffington Post and CNN Waited to Report U.S.-Iran Prisoner-Swap Negotiations
text: Two news organizations have acknowledged that they knew about the negotiations between the United States and Iran over a prisoner exchange that included a Washington Post reporter before the arrangement was announced. But they chose not to publish information about the talks.

headline: Standoff in Oregon Attracts Supporters Bearing Disparate Grievances
text: One of the people who have joined the Bundy family on a federal wildlife sanctuary in an arid patch of Oregon is an avowed anti-Semite from Ohio. One is an anti-Islamic ideologue from Phoenix.

headline: On Paper, Italy Allows Abortions, but Few Doctors Will Perform Them
text: ASCOLI PICENO, Italy — After Benedetta, 35, found out 11 weeks into her pregnancy that the baby she wanted “with all myself” had extremely serious genetic problems, she made a painful decision, and asked her longtime gynecologist for an abortion.

headline: New Guidelines Nudge Doctors to Give Patients Access to Medical Records
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration is tearing down barriers that make it difficult for patients to get access to their own medical records, telling doctors and hospitals that in most cases they must provide copies of these records within 30 days of receiving a request.

headline: Before Debris Collapse in China, Safety Fears Were Discussed
text: SHENZHEN, China — Four days before a mountain of dirt and debris collapsed here, killing at least 69 people, the government agency in charge of the construction dump convened a meeting to discuss safety concerns. In attendance were representatives of the company with the contract to manage the site and the independent engineering firm paid to monitor its work.

headline: Virginia Man Is Accused of Trying to Join ISIS
text: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department charged two Virginia men on Saturday with terrorism-related offenses, one day after F.B.I. agents arrested one of them at an airport where officials believe he was planning to begin a journey to Syria to fight with the Islamic State.

headline: Patriots Methodically Clear First Hurdle
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — Two days before the first anniversary of the game that spawned a polemic controversy over deflated footballs, the New England Patriots and their fans gathered for the first playoff game since that contretemps shrouded the franchise for nearly nine months. The atmosphere was festive, with the home side clearly happy to host another mid-January postseason game. But there was also an edge in the air.

headline: I.A.E.A. Report on Iran’s Nuclear Program
text: The agency found that Iran has complied with the accord reached last summer and has dismantled large sections of its nuclear program.

headline: Taiwan’s New Leader Faces a Weak Economy and China’s Might
text: TAIPEI, Taiwan — Before Tsai Ing-wen felt the thrill of victory on Saturday by becoming the first woman to be elected president of Taiwan, she was no stranger to the sting of defeat.

headline: Donald Trump Gets Personal in Attacks on Ted Cruz at Tea Party Convention
text: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — He told war stories about his old construction sites. He promised to build a beautiful “Trump Wall” along the border with Mexico. He poked some fun at Jeb Bush, saying that embracing his family name could do little to harm his low-polling campaign.

headline: Manners Fit Jeb Bush, if Not an Uncouth Race
text: DERRY, N.H. — Tennis. Boating. Summers at Walker’s Point.

headline: For Broadcast of Super Bowl I, NFL Network Picks Excess Over Tact
text: Those of us who love the unearthing of old relics of sports television were excited by the NFL Films’ reconstruction of Super Bowl I. Every play was found in the NFL Films archive and stitched together for Friday night’s presentation on NFL Network, which would have stood well on its own for a 90-minute broadcast, with added graphics, factoids and interviews spread out before, after or during breaks.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Under Attack on 2005 Gun Vote, Says He Will Support Bill Rolling It Back
text: Senator Bernie Sanders announced on Saturday that he is supporting legislation to amend a 2005 law on gunmakers’ liability that he voted for and that Hillary Clinton has been using to attack him as weak on gun regulations.

headline: Drug Overdoses Propel Rise in Mortality Rates of Young Whites
text: Drug overdoses are driving up the death rate of young white adults in the United States to levels not seen since the end of the AIDS epidemic more than two decades ago — a turn of fortune that stands in sharp contrast to falling death rates for young blacks, a New York Times analysis of death certificates has found.

headline: After Forward’s Strong Words Feed Rivalry, Grizzlies Earn Anticlimactic Win
text: MEMPHIS — Matt Barnes approached the scorer’s table midway through the first quarter, and the crowd at FedEx Forum erupted. Barnes was simply checking into Saturday night’s game for the Memphis Grizzlies, but given his sordid history with the man standing no more than 15 feet away, in front of the opposing bench, it felt like so much more.

headline: Cardinals Survive, Ending Carson Palmer’s Drought
text: GLENDALE, Ariz. — Like his signature deep throws, quarterback Carson Palmer’s football résumé covers a lot of ground: two high school championships, one Heisman Trophy and five 4,000-yard passing seasons for three N.F.L. teams. But Palmer’s professional career had called to mind a long drive that peters out inside the red zone.

headline: Among the Captives Freed by Iran, a U.S. Researcher Held for 40 Days
text: A researcher from Massachusetts who was in Iran to study Farsi was allowed to leave the country after more than a month’s detention, his family and the State Department said on Saturday.

Silver, the bride’s brother, is to take part, leading the couple in their exchange of vows and wedding rings.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Turn Focus to South Carolina, Courting Black Leaders
text: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Senator Bernie Sanders talked about the “seemingly endless stream of tragedies” in black communities from clashes with the police, while Hillary Clinton sought to closely align herself to President Obama, as the two Democratic candidates worked to woo black leaders ahead of this state’s Feb. 27 primary contest.

headline: American Missionary Among the Dead in Burkina Faso Siege
text: Qaeda militants killed one American in an attack on two hotels and a cafe in the capital of Burkina Faso that left at least 28 people dead and 56 injured on Friday and Saturday, the State Department said on Saturday night.

headline: Assailants Yell ‘ISIS! ISIS!’ During Attack on Man in Bronx, Police Say
text: A man wearing traditional South Asian clothing was attacked by two men shouting “ISIS! ISIS!” as he walked near a school in the Bronx on Saturday night, the police said.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “There are large numbers of people who never get established in the economy, who live outside family relationships and are on the edge of poverty.”

headline: She Plays Hillary Clinton as Bernie Sanders Prepares to Debate
text: BURLINGTON, Vt. — The debate moderator looked at the woman in a dark pantsuit standing beside Senator Bernie Sanders and said, “Secretary Clinton, we’ll give you one minute for an opening statement.”

headline: Indebted Chinese Companies Increase Pressures on Government
text: HONG KONG — Sainty Marine Corporation started small, buying and selling a few ships in the 1980s. But Sainty Marine, a Chinese state-owned company, went on a debt-fueled binge over the last few years, opening its own shipyards and signing orders worth hundreds of millions of dollars each.

headline: Suicide Attack Kills at Least 13 in Afghanistan
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — A suicide bomber struck the home of a tribal elder in the eastern Afghan city of Jalalabad Sunday morning, killing at least 13 people, an official said. It was the latest attack in the increasingly volatile Nangarhar Province.

headline: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2016
text: The latest designs from Bottega Veneta.

headline: A Daughter Too Kind for Her Own Good
text: “Mommy, I was kind to her like you told me to be and she was still rude,” my daughter told me from the back seat of the car. “She even laughed before walking away.”

headline: 1941: Relief Director Tells Plight of Jews in Europe
text: The miserable conditions of Jews in Nazi-dominated Europe were described yesterday by Morris C. Troper, chairman of the European executive council of the Joint Distribution Committee, an American Jewish organization engaged in relief for Jews throughout the world. Mr. Troper recently returned to the United States from Lisbon where he supervised European relief work. In an interview at the offices of the committee, 100 East Forty-second Street, Mr. Troper said that 1,500,000 Jews were absolutely destitute in Poland and many of them were living in walled-up ghettos which they were not allowed to leave even during the day.

headline: 1966: Nigerian Rebels Surrender
text: LAGOS — The leader of Nigeria’s bloody weekend uprising today [Jan. 17] surrendered his forces to the West African republic’s new military ruler, Maj. Gen. Johnson Aguiyi Ironsi. The peaceful surrender appeared to end the threat of further violence in the country and consolidated Gen. Ironsi’s position as the new strongman of Nigeria. When dissident Nigerian Army leaders rebelled Saturday, the country’s civilian government handed over administration of the country to Gen. Ironsi.

text: Fall 2016 men’s wear designs from Salvatore Ferragamo.

headline: 3 Freed Americans Leave Iran; U.S. Places New Sanctions
text: VIENNA — With three Americans long held in Iran flying to Europe on Sunday, President Obama urged young Iranians to “pursue a new path” with the West as he imposed modest new sanctions on the country for banned missile tests.

headline: Calvin Klein Collection: Fall 2016
text: Fall 2016 designs from the Calvin Klein Collection.

headline: In Milan, Ermenegildo Zegna and Ralph Lauren Zero In on the One Percent
text: MILAN — Horizontal is not the only direction for market expansion in the rag trade. Increasingly, designer ambitions are turning vertical. Considered in global terms, the population of the One Percent amounts to a nationality of its own, a new reality duly reflected in Stefano Pilati’s Ermenegildo Zegna collection for men, titled Ermenegildo Zegna Couture.

headline: For Italian Men, a Return to Elegance
text: It was vulgarity and not elegance that ruled the day in Italy when Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi was simultaneously running the country and staging “bunga bunga” bacchanals. Mr. Berlusconi was hell on traditional Italian cultural values, his years in office a prolonged populist takedown of the high-minded intellectual and aesthetic achievements that defined Italian architecture, art, industrial design and, not least, its fashion for much of the 20th century.

headline: Theatergoers, Desperate to See ‘Hamilton,’ Fall Prey to Ticket Forgers
text: Jason arranged to meet the seller on a Manhattan street corner on Dec. 31. He bought two tickets for $600 as an anniversary gift for his wife. You’re going to love the show, the seller told him. It’s as good as everyone says.

headline: Letters and Numbers: A Watch's Typeface
text: Brands know that well-chosen fonts can do much to convey the style of a timepiece.

text: We provided real-time analysis of the fourth Democratic debate and live fact checks.

headline: Details of 7 Iranians Granted Clemency in Prisoner Swap

Another was a maritime engineer found guilty of providing navigation technology to the Iranians. And three men had ties to a company accused of illegally exporting millions of dollars in American technology with military applications to Iran.

text: Zegna’s fall/winter 2016 show explored “excessive embellishment,” while Donatella Versace focused her collection around pioneers of the future.

headline: Netanyahu Asserts Israel Will Be Iran’s Watchdog
text: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel warned on Sunday that his nation would ensure that Tehran never obtains nuclear weapons, while also taking credit for keeping Iran from already having them.

headline: European Antitrust Chief Takes Swipe at Privacy Issue
text: MUNICH — Margrethe Vestager, the European Union’s antitrust chief, warned on Sunday that the collection of a vast amount of users’ data by a small number of tech companies like Google and Facebook could be in violation of the region’s tough competition rules.

headline: What to Watch Sunday

headline: Republican Candidates Assail Iran Agreements
text: News of the diplomatic thaw with Iran provided the Republican presidential candidates with more fodder to attack both President Obama and Hillary Clinton over the weekend on the campaign trail and on Sunday talk shows.

headline: Peggy Anderson, Chronicler of the Nursing Profession, Dies at 77
text: Peggy Anderson, who never wanted to become a nurse, like her mother, but wrote a best-selling book to correct stereotypes about the profession, died on Sunday in Philadelphia. She was 77.

headline: ‘Ride Along 2’ Is No. 1 at Box Office
text: Amid outrage over a lack of diversity among Oscar nominees, “Ride Along 2,” aimed squarely at black and Hispanic moviegoers, arrived to a robust $34 million in weekend ticket sales. Meanwhile, ticket sales for Michael Bay’s politically divisive “13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers of Benghazi” were on the soft side.

headline: State of Emergency Declared Over Man-Made Water Disaster in Michigan City
text: President Obama has declared a state of emergency in response to the water crisis in Flint, Mich., where thousands of residents have been exposed to toxic amounts of lead.

headline: Verbatim: Debbie Wasserman Schultz Says Democratic Debate Schedule Was Intended to ‘Maximize’ Exposure to Voters
text: — Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida, the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, responding on CNN to criticism from some in her party that the Democratic debate schedule, which has included weekend forums, gives an advantage to Hillary Clinton.
