headline: Netflix’s Expansion Attracts Some Unexpected Customers
text: MUNICH — Just hours after Reed Hastings announced this month that Netflix, the video-streaming service that he co-founded, would become available in 190 countries, he got an unexpected surprise.

headline: David Bowie Hits No. 1 on Billboard Chart with ‘Blackstar,’ a First
text: David Bowie’s death has brought the legendary rocker a trophy he never had in life: a No. 1 album on the American chart.

headline: As Track Atones, Some Athletes Seek More Than an Apology
text: There have been many doping scandals, too many, but if allegations about the demanding and extorting of bribes to cover up test results are true, track and field’s former leader Lamine Diack and his minions and relations took the category to a new level of low by corrupting from the top.

headline: Tracy Morgan to Star in Television Pilot for FX
text: Tracy Morgan is returning to television. The actor, who suffered severe injuries in a car crash in 2014, will star in an unnamed pilot for FX. This half-hour comedy will be written by Jordan Peele (“Key & Peele”) and John Carcieri (“Eastbound & Down”).

headline: Damir Doma: Fall 2016
text: Damir Doma presents looks for Fall 2016.

headline: Zika Warning Spotlights Latin America’s Fight Against Mosquito-Borne Diseases
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — In the campaign against mosquitoes, Brazil has deployed soldiers to destroy habitats where the insects thrive. Colombia is releasing swarms of mosquitoes treated with bacteria that limit their capacity to spread disease. Mexico is testing the first vaccine against dengue fever, a mosquito-borne virus raging throughout the region.

headline: A Closer Look at Campaign Tax Promises
text: Two certainties, as Benjamin Franklin wrote, are death and taxes. Add a third: On taxes, American presidential candidates often promise more than they can deliver. And, if elected, they may pay a price.

headline: Panthers Build a Big First-Half Lead, Then Outlast the Seahawks
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — As the Carolina Panthers ran roughshod over the N.F.L. this season, finishing a league-best 15-1, questions lingered. Sure, quarterback Cam Newton was performing like a most valuable player and the team’s defense was among the league’s best, but the Panthers also had one of the easiest schedules, and they barely escaped with wins against teams like the New Orleans Saints and the Giants, who had losing records.

headline: For Now, Self-Driving Cars Still Need Humans
text: SUNNYVALE, Calif. — Car enthusiasts, after hearing industry executives discussing the self-driving technology being built into their vehicles, might be forgiven for thinking robotic cars will soon drive themselves out of auto showrooms.

headline: A Safer World, Thanks to the Iran Deal
text: This is a moment many thought would never come: Iran has delivered on its commitment under a 2015 agreement with the United States and other major powers to curb or eliminate the most dangerous elements of its nuclear program. The world is now safer for this.

headline: Education Technology Graduates From the Classroom to the Boardroom
text: Judging by the number of learning apps available to classrooms around the country, the education technology market aimed at elementary through high schools is booming.

headline: Die Hard Conservatives
text: Oh, my:

headline: Richard G. Hendrickson, Who Recorded the Weather for 85 Years, Dies at 103
text: Neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night could stay Richard G. Hendrickson from the swift completion of his appointed rounds. For 85 years, they were his appointed rounds.

headline: Satellite Tracking Rising Seas Launches Successfully
text: A satellite to measure the heights of the oceans was launched successfully on Sunday from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California.

headline: Review: In ‘Excavation Site: Martha Graham U.S.A.,’ a Bond Is Shared
text: To Michael Kliën, choreography is more than a dance on a stage, but something akin to an archaeological dig. In “Excavation Site: Martha Graham U.S.A.,” that Austrian choreographer, with the dramaturge Steve Valk, organized a one-time event as part of the Coil festival in which 24 dancers — all but one associated with the Martha Graham Dance Company — investigated their shared bond with that luminary of modern dance.

headline: Review: In ‘In Quietness,’ a High-Powered Wife Makes Sacrifices for Her Husband’s Religious Zeal
text: In Anna Moench’s promising, frustrating “In Quietness,” produced by Dutch Kills at Walkerspace, a high-flying consultant leaves her job, her friends and her urban life to follow her husband to a seminary. At the outset of the play, Max (Kate MacCluggage) is burning up the frequent-flier miles and piling up the bonuses when she arrives home to find her husband, Paul (Blake DeLong), sitting in the dark. He confesses to an affair with a woman in his weekly Bible study group, relating that an accident has now left her in the hospital, unresponsive.

headline: ‘Horizon Events,’ Inspired by the Parameters of a PS1 Gallery
text: Because Rashaun Mitchell and Silas Riener are superlative dancers, a dancegoer wants them only to appear in work worthy of them, or in choreography that’s at least remotely important. In their most recent show — the premiere performances of “Horizon Events,” on Friday through Sunday at MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens — they gave mere glimpses of what they and their five companion dancers can do.

headline: Review: With Two Star Lutenists, Boston Early Music Festival Comes to the Morgan
text: The Boston Early Music Festival traveled light for its latest concert at the Morgan Library & Museum on Friday evening, The program, “For Two Lutes,” offered just two performers playing easily portable instruments: the stellar and widely recorded lutenists Paul O’Dette (an artistic director of the festival) and Ronn McFarlane.

headline: Patriots’ Winning Philosophy: Keep the Focus on Winning
text: FOXBOROUGH, Mass. — After the Patriots’ 27-20 victory Saturday over the previously scorching Kansas City Chiefs, New England’s coach, Bill Belichick, was asked how he felt about sharing a piece of football history: The Patriots, like the Oakland Raiders from 1973 to 1977, were headed to their fifth consecutive A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Review: Rockapella Sings Nostalgic a Cappella at Feinstein’s/54 Below
text: What is it about a cappella pop groups that makes their spirit so playful? As Rockapella, an influential ensemble since the early 1990s, performed a sleek set of oldies at Feinstein’s/54 Below on Friday, the show became the musical equivalent of watching the members of a basketball team happily toss a ball around. Camaraderie and comedy go together; there’s something essentially lighthearted about human voices imitating instruments.

headline: Narrowing a Gap in the Sci-Fi Universe: One Fangirl Giving a Voice to Others
text: Ashley Eckstein, a self-described sci-fi fangirl, believes women like her are often overlooked. So several years ago she started a company to sell apparel featuring brands like Doctor Who, Star Trek and Star Wars to other fangirls. Now, believing those same women need a voice, she is expanding into publishing.

headline: Composers’ Collectives Offer Creativity and Challenges
text: The cellist Ashley Bathgate took her bow at Le Poisson Rouge last Tuesday after the premiere of “Ash,” an evening-long work inspired by Bach’s six suites for solo cello. Then she squinted into the dimmed nightclub and made the usual hand motion of a performer beckoning the composer to share in the applause.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on North Korea’s Nuclear Testing
text: The latest nuclear test by North Korea earlier this month drew swift condemnation from the United Nations Security Council.

headline: Review: ‘19-2,’ a Police Drama on Acorn TV, Is a Slow Burn
text: To watch “19-2” is to be reminded that there is more than one way to pace a police drama. This Canadian series, which becomes available on the streaming service Acorn beginning Monday, is a slow burn, and its pacing isn’t the only thing that defies expectations.

headline: At Art Students League, Air Rights and Airing Grievances
text: One can only imagine the debates that have flared up through the decades at the Art Students League, a 140-year-old nonprofit school on West 57th Street that counts Winslow Homer, Norman Rockwell, Georgia O’Keeffe and Mark Rothko among its alumni.

headline: ‘Hail, Caesar!’ Explores the World of the Hollywood ‘Fixer’
text: LOS ANGELES — “The stories begin. The stories end. But the work of Eddie Mannix will never end.”

headline: Review: In ‘The Narrow Door,’ Paul Lisicky Opens a Window on Friendship
text: Almost all of us have friends who don’t submit easily to categorization. They’re our life’s towering originals, the difficult ones who infuriate us and exhilarate us in equal measure. And if we met them in our late adolescence or early adulthood, forget it — their significance is almost indescribable. We were still jelly in those years. Quivering, impressionable. How on earth to convey their outsize influence, the overlarge hand they had in molding who we became?

headline: Moncler Gamme Bleu: Fall 2016
text: Moncler Gamme Bleu’s Fall 2016 show.

headline: Review: Cramming ‘War & Peace’ Into a Mini-Series
text: Interviewer: “I’ll be frank: You’re a bit older than most of the applicants. Start by telling me what qualifies you for the job of 21st-century TV scriptwriter.”

headline: Sublime Physical Performance
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Kathy Wienberg appears to be making her New York Times debut today, so let’s welcome her. One of the things I really liked about her puzzle is that even though I didn’t have to turn any real handsprings to solve it, it kept its theme secret from me until I got to the revealer at 49 Across. And when the penny finally dropped, I laughed out loud. That’s rare for a Monday puzzle.

headline: NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon
text: Scenes from this year’s festival.

headline: At NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon, New Faces Make Their Mark at Grooving Places
text: NYC Winter Jazzfest began in 2005 as a showcase, a way for arts presenters and music bookers to scope out artists for their coming seasons. The festival has outgrown that strict purpose, becoming a summit and a smorgasbord, a consolidation of talent from every tier of prominence. The options this year included two nights of artists from the ECM Records roster, performing in the handsome new 800-seat Tishman Auditorium at the New School: a distinctly aboveground setting, and a powerful lure for anyone in search of proven quality.

headline: Hot Sets and Warm Chilly Nights at NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon
text: One of the breakout stars of this year’s NYC Winter Jazzfest Marathon was a piano, or the combination of a piano and a room.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 18
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing includes the regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, which will be held Tuesday as the markets will be closed Monday for Martin Luther King’s Birthday. The regular four-week bill auction will be moved to Wednesday.

headline: Bernie Sanders Supporters Invoke Martin Luther King Jr.
text: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — On the eve of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, three black supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont sought to present his stances on race and the economy as the heir to the legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: 3 Americans Are Missing in Baghdad, Embassy Says
text: BAGHDAD — The American Embassy is working with the Iraqi authorities to locate three American citizens who have gone missing in the capital, an embassy spokesman said late Sunday. Their disappearance raised fears that Westerners were once again becoming targets for the myriad militias and criminal gangs that are known to kidnap foreigners for money or for political reasons.

headline: Missing Man Back in China, Confessing to Fatal Crime
text: HONG KONG — A Hong Kong publisher last seen in October outside his condominium in Thailand surfaced Sunday on Chinese television, tearfully confessing to violating his probation in a fatal drunken-driving accident and saying that he had voluntarily returned to China to face justice.

headline: An Adman’s Big Pitch: His Life’s Work
text: “I have a Hilfiger poster that Tommy’s begging for,” said George Lois, an influential Madison Avenue art director and the creative force behind scores of famous advertising campaigns.

headline: British Labour Leader Offers Compromise on Trident Program
text: LONDON — Stirring a divisive internal debate over defense, Jeremy Corbyn, the leader of Britain’s opposition Labour Party, suggested on Sunday that he might support the continued existence of the country’s Trident submarine fleet if it were sent on patrol without carrying nuclear warheads.

headline: Fourth Democratic Debate: Analysis
text: We provided real-time updates on the fourth Democratic debate, featuring Hillary Clinton, Senator Bernie Sanders and Martin O’Malley.

headline: Peyton Manning, the Broncos’ Flickering Star, Glows Just in Time
text: DENVER — It was getting late Sunday, the winds were swirling, and Peyton Manning grabbed his helmet from the bench, lunged twice from side to side and crept closer to the sideline. The Denver Broncos trailed by a point, and they had two, maybe three possessions remaining.

headline: Covering War at Home Costs a Yemeni His Life
text: SANA, Yemen — For Almigdad Mojalli, a Yemeni journalist covering the civil war in his country, the trip early Sunday to the site of a deadly airstrike was another episode in what had long since become a painful routine.

headline: In Rural Alabama, a Longtime Mistrust of Medicine Fuels a Tuberculosis Outbreak
text: MARION, Ala. — When Patricia Church, a 41-year-old warehouse worker, felt sick recently, she suspected that she had a cold. But she also feared something more deadly that has been going around this small, impoverished city: tuberculosis.

headline: Ted Marchibroda, Who Led Colts and Ravens, Dies at 84
text: Ted Marchibroda, who coached the Baltimore Colts to three consecutive N.F.L. division championships in the 1970s and later installed a high-powered no-huddle offense that helped propel the Buffalo Bills to four straight Super Bowl games, died on Saturday in Weems, Va. He was 84.

headline: Justifiable Homicides, Taken Off the Books, Alter a Murder Tally
text: It was just after 4 a.m. when an argument outside a hookah bar in Astoria, Queens, devolved into gunfire: Three shots were fired in the direction of Christopher King, a 23-year-old Long Island man in the city for a night out. The bullets missed him.

headline: Questions on Subsidies and Local Hiring Surround Syracuse Project
text: The project known as Syracuse’s Inner Harbor looked like a feast for a starving city, the harbinger of the long-awaited turnaround of upstate New York: a $342 million constellation of hotels, upscale apartments and stores along a historic canal on a swath of disused land the city had been trying to transform for decades.

headline: In 2016 Race, Local Matters Give Way to National Tone
text: In Iowa, corn is no longer king. In Florida, subsidies for the state’s powerful sugar producers are under attack. And almost all of the Republicans left in the 2016 presidential race want to abolish the Export-Import Bank, which has provided billions to one of South Carolina’s largest employers, Boeing.

headline: Who Made the Smartest Comment of the Democratic Debate?
text: Earlier this week, we asked you who made the most intelligent comment during the Republican presidential debate. Now it’s time to answer the same question for the Democrats.

headline: Here’s What You Missed in the Debate
text: The Democratic candidates faced off in South Carolina for the last debate before voting begins in Iowa.

headline: U.N.-Appointed Panel Calls for a Tax to Pay for Crises
text: UNITED NATIONS — What if the next time you buy World Cup tickets or summon an Uber ride, you found yourself paying a few cents extra to pay for winter blankets for Syrian refugees or clean water for those displaced in Darfur, Sudan?

headline: A Businessman Who Trades in Hand-Me-Downs
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — Hajji Ramazan has built a modest empire from used clothes.

headline: China’s Growth Report and Oil Company Earnings
text: European policy makers and American tech moguls are in Munich for a three-day conference that began on Sunday to debate many of the contentious issues that have caused friction between lawmakers and companies on both sides of the Atlantic, including Europe’s tough competition rules.

headline: Obama’s Goal to Wipe Out Malaria May Be a Dream Too Far
text: WASHINGTON — Two days before delivering his last State of the Union address, President Obama called one of his top advisers into the Oval Office and said he had decided to add a major pledge to the speech that his team had neither discussed nor vetted: to rid the world of malaria.

headline: Bryan Brothers Seek Return to Top of Their Game, and the Rankings
text: Throughout their record-setting doubles careers, Bob and Mike Bryan have been paragons of professionalism. But last year, they decided they were not professional enough — at least for their advancing age.

headline: Netflix’s Opaque Disruption Annoys Rivals on TV
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Tensions between Netflix and traditional television networks escalated this weekend after industry executives expressed mounting frustration over Netflix’s refusal to disclose ratings.

headline: As Knicks Slip, Kristaps Porzingis Learns He Must Add Greed to His Game
text: MEMPHIS — Kristaps Porzingis sat at his locker at FedEx Forum on Saturday night with an ice bag strapped to his right shoulder and a towel draped around his neck. His shoulder felt fine, he said, but the team would continue to be cautious.

headline: U.S. Growth and Employment Data Tell Different Stories
text: Think of it as the looking-glass economy.

headline: Atypical Pursuit of an N.H.L. Dream
text: On the ice, David Levin looks like any other teenager pursuing his dream of playing in the National Hockey League. Off the ice, his story is unlike those of any of his teammates on the Sudbury Wolves of the Ontario Hockey League.

headline: Mini Brand Fits Celebrities Into Super Bowl Ads
text: Contrary to conventional wisdom, Super Bowl commercials featuring celebrities often fail to connect with viewers. They can be highly effective, however, when viewers see the celebrities as having an authentic connection with the brand. That is the creative strategy Mini USA will employ during CBS’s telecast of Super Bowl 50 on Feb. 7.

headline: Roosevelt Hotel Honors a Promise
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Artistry and Joy, in Victory and Defeat
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Somewhere in the fourth quarter, as Seahawks quarterback Russell Wilson spun and feinted and passed over and slid under pursuing Goliaths, and the Panthers’ coaching staff curled into a fetal position, you wondered if Carolina could achieve the impossible.

headline: Marketing in the Moments, to Reach Customers Online
text: MOMENTS are having a moment in advertising. Or at least a micromoment.

headline: Bernie Sanders Releases Details on Health Plan That Would Raise Taxes but, He Argues, Save on Costs
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, under pressure from the Clinton campaign to explain how he would pay for his progressive policies, unveiled a universal healthcare plan on Sunday night that includes sweeping tax increases and a drastic tax hike for the wealthiest.

headline: Strat-O-Matic Builds Out Its Digital Game Roster
text: Before the World Series between the Kansas City Royals and the New York Mets last fall, a small number of baseball experts were confident they knew what would happen. Two Royals players, Alcides Escobar and Alex Gordon, would hit home runs in Game 1. There would be a David Wright homer in Game 3, and Matt Harvey would dominate in Game 5, giving up just four hits and a walk in the first seven innings.

headline: A Childhood Crush Comes Back Into View in New York
text: Coincidence and a bit of technological ignorance are responsible for introducing Mercedes Rodriguez to her husband.

headline: Mississippi Fights to Keep Control of Its Beleaguered Child Welfare System
text: WAVELAND, Miss. — In 2003, a tiny girl weighing little more than 20 pounds arrived at an emergency shelter here on the gulf coast, after being shuttled between five foster homes and youth shelters in three months.

headline: After Penalty, 23 Wins Recorded Only in Memory
text: The University of Missouri men’s basketball team opened its 2013-14 season at home with the standard mismatch designed to invigorate fans. On that night in early November, the Tigers scored 89 points, kept visiting Southeastern Louisiana to just 53 — and did not win.

headline: 14 Testy Months Behind U.S. Prisoner Swap With Iran
text: WASHINGTON — For a year, Obama administration officials had been meeting in secret with Iranian counterparts, seeking to free Americans imprisoned in the Islamic republic. Finally last fall, a deal for a prisoner release seemed all but sealed.

headline: Developer Reaches Settlements Over Luxury Buildings That Were Left Unfinished
text: The developer promised the building would have the kind of luxurious amenities befitting a 40-story condominium tower overlooking that citadel of capitalism, the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Parking Rules Suspended on Monday
text: Because of Martin Luther King’s Birthday, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Season 6, Episode 3 Recap: So Nice to See Him Again?
text: This recap contains spoilers for Sunday’s episode of “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Scholastic Halts Distribution of ‘A Birthday Cake for George Washington’
text: Scholastic Publishing said on Sunday that it would halt distribution of a children’s picture book about George Washington and his enslaved household cook amid an outcry over its visual depiction of the former president’s slaves as happy, smiling workers.

headline: My Take on the Democratic Presidential Debate
text: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders dueled tonight in the fourth Democratic debate, and here’s my play-by-play commentary. This isn’t in the form of a column, or even a formal blog post, but simply my collected tweets from live-tweeting. This is an experiment, a bit like my similar collection of tweets from the Republican presidential debate the other day. Conclusions at the end.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Warriors at Cavaliers
text: Every week, The New York Times will choose one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: ‘Billions’ Recap, Season 1 Premiere: Money and Sin
text: With Oscar nominations announced this week, it’s tempting to think of Showtime’s “Billions” as a natural companion to “The Big Short,” Adam McKay’s Best Picture-nominated film about the financial shenanigans that cratered the economy in 2008. After all, this is a show about a United States Attorney attempting to prosecute just the sort of hedge fund giant who made a fortune exploiting a system that McKay exposes as fraudulent. Adding to that impression is the presence of Andrew Ross Sorkin, the founding editor of DealBook for The New York Times, who created the show with the longtime screenwriting partners Brian Koppelman and David Levien (“Rounders,” “Ocean’s Thirteen”) and who brings a level of Wall Street credibility.

headline: In Democratic Debate, Hillary Clinton Challenges Bernie Sanders on Policy Shifts
text: Hillary Clinton targeted Bernie Sanders’s electoral appeal with some of her strongest language yet in a debate on Sunday night, seizing on Mr. Sanders’s recent policy shifts on universal health care and gun control to try to undercut his image as an anti-political truth teller.

headline: Transcript of the Democratic Presidential Debate
text: Following is a transcript of the Democratic debate, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

headline: New York City Announces Deal on Carriage Horses in Central Park
text: The Central Park horse carriage industry would be significantly reduced – and its horses confined to a new stable within the park – under a deal announced late Sunday by the de Blasio administration.

headline: Williams Lures Focus From Match-Fixing Report
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Monday was opening day at the Australian Open, and with Serena Williams already on court for her first official match in four months, tennis leaders filed into the tournament’s main interview room and tried to allay fears that the game has a major match-fixing problem.

headline: What to Watch Monday
text: Occupy yourself for the next four Mondays with Tolstoy’s “War & Peace,” or ride along with some Montreal cops in “19-2.” Meanwhile, David Oyelowo portrays the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in “Selma.”

headline: Charges Against Chinese Rights Lawyers Draw Foreign Criticism
text: BEIJING — The recent arrests of Chinese lawyers and their associates on subversion charges drew sharp condemnation from presidents of foreign bar associations, prominent lawyers and former judges in a letter issued on Monday. They said the charges were part of an “unprecedented crackdown” on Chinese advocates who take up contentious human rights cases.

headline: Hillary Clinton Turns, Repeatedly, to a Democrat Not on the Debate Stage: Obama
text: Hillary Clinton may have been flanked by Martin O’Malley and Senator Bernie Sanders at the presidential primary debate on Sunday night in South Carolina, but she wanted voters to see her as shoulder-to-shoulder with another Democrat: the one living in the White House.

headline: Key Moments in the 4th Democratic Debate
text: Watch the liveliest exchanges from the fourth Democratic debate, as the presidential candidates Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders and Martin O’Malley faced off in Charleston, S.C., on Sunday.

headline: Who Won the Democratic Debate? Viewers Lean Toward Bernie Sanders
text: The final Democratic presidential debate before the first states begin voting was marked by heated exchanges between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders on Wall Street regulation, guns and who would best preserve the legacy of President Obama. Many commentators from across the web thought that a more aggressive Mr. Sanders gave himself a boost by taking Mrs. Clinton on more forcefully. She scored points on his shifting positions on guns and taxes, but was not seen as dealing any decisive blows. Martin O’Malley, meanwhile, was most notable for his unsuccessful efforts to get a word in.

text: NATIONAL

headline: Heidi Nelson Cruz Discusses Her Husband, Her Career and Campaign Fund-Raising
text: In a Republican presidential field dotted with spouses who have compelling stories of their own, Heidi Nelson Cruz stands out as the one who could most easily trade places with her husband, Ted.

headline: Race, Civil Rights and Photography
text: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and other civil rights leaders relied on the power of photographs to persuade and to motivate. For many white Americans outside the South, it was easy to be unaware — or ignore outright — the segregation of the Jim Crow era.

headline: Heidi Nelson Cruz: A Political Spouse Making Sacrifices and Courting Donors
text: Heidi Nelson Cruz stepped to the lectern in a black gown, waiting for the applause to settle. She was beaming.

headline: For Martin Luther King’s Birthday, Black Leaders as Obituaries Portrayed Them
text: The New York Times culled its files for a retrospective on how black leaders including Rosa Parks, Jackie Robinson and Dr. King himself were regarded at their deaths.

headline: Weighing the Risks of Home Births
text: The debate over whether it’s safer for a healthy woman to have a baby at home or in the hospital just tilted a bit in favor of hospital deliveries. The risks in both cases are very low, but a new study suggests that the risk to babies could be higher for out-of-hospital births.
