headline: Health Reform Realities
text: Health reform is the signature achievement of the Obama presidency. It was the biggest expansion of the social safety net since Medicare was established in the 1960s. It more or less achieves a goal — access to health insurance for all Americans — that progressives have been trying to reach for three generations. And it is already producing dramatic results, with the percentage of uninsured Americans falling to record lows.

headline: Shine a Light on Secret Real Estate Deals
text: The Treasury Department announced last week that it would start demanding the identities of the people behind the shell companies that rich foreigners use to buy real estate in Manhattan and Miami-Dade County. This is a good step that should help law enforcement agencies crack down on money laundering, tax evasion and other crimes. But the program should be broadened to cover the whole country, and it must be forcefully carried out.

headline: The Gospel According to Trump
text: IT is no secret that Donald J. Trump’s ruinous rise in the Republican presidential primaries has been powered, in large part, by a naked agenda of religious division and fear-mongering — an agenda that will likely inform his speech today at Liberty University, a conservative Christian college in Lynchburg, Va.

headline: Stop China’s Market Manipulations
text: Washington — THE other day while I was crossing the street in Beijing, a car almost flattened me. Both the driver and I were outraged at the other’s ineptitude. In China, if you want to avoid being hit, you keep your head down and avoid eye contact with the oncoming driver, since looking at him would signal that you saw the car and know you should let it pass. In the United States, the opposite rule applies: Making eye contact confirms that the driver has seen you and should yield to the vulnerable pedestrian.

headline: G.O.P. and the Apocalypse
text: Last week I suffered through another dust-dry Republican debate in which a slimmed-down roster of seven candidates leveled many of the same attacks and regurgitated many of the same staid pitches.

headline: Celebrating Martin Luther King Day
text: Like most schools across the United States, we’re off today in observance of the life and legacy of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. A new edition of What’s Going On in This Picture? will be available early next Monday.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “God leads you to where he can use you the most. And it may not look exactly like you’d expect.”

headline: What Do We Owe Each Other?
text: The thousands of refugees who continue to arrive in Europe each day face barriers: not only physical barriers — walls, fences, barbed wire — but an even deeper resistance, in the nationalism and xenophobia bubbling up across the Continent.

headline: New Watches at the Salon International de la Haute Horlogerie
text: The fine watchmaking fair opens Jan. 18 in Geneva.

headline: Clydesdale Bank in Britain Could Be Valued at $3 Billion in I.P.O.
text: LONDON — National Australia Bank said on Monday that its British unit, Clydesdale Bank, could be valued at as much as 2.07 billion pounds, or about $3 billion, in an initial public offering next month as part of a spinoff.

headline: Rural Oregon’s Lost Prosperity Gives Standoff a Distressed Backdrop
text: BURNS, Ore. — One of the largest wood mills in the West once belched its steam on the edge of town, sawing ponderosa pine. Out in the woods, tree fallers like Tex Ward were proud and prosperous.

headline: What’s New in the Dietary Guidelines
text: There’s good news, and not-so-good news for some, in the new Dietary Guidelines for Americans, released Jan. 7 by the Agriculture and Health and Human Services Departments.

headline: Lawmakers Conclude Debate Over Barring Donald Trump From Britain
text: A parliamentary committee considered a petition to bar Donald Trump from entering the United Kingdom because some say he has violated the country’s laws on hate speech.

headline: 1961 | Starring Martin Luther King Jr. (and Henry Fonda)
text: The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. played many roles on the American stage: leader, orator, preacher, protester, exemplar, conscience, symbol, martyr.

headline: Animals Die in Large Numbers, and Researchers Scratch Their Heads
text: Are die-offs occurring more often?

headline: Stabbing of Israeli Woman in West Bank Suggests Shift in Violence
text: TEKOA, West Bank — In a charity store packed with used clothing on the edge of Tekoa, a Jewish settlement in the beige hills of the southern West Bank, Michal Froman, 30 and pregnant, was shopping on Monday when a Palestinian teenager walked in.

headline: In Libya, U.S. Courts Unreliable Allies to Counter ISIS
text: TRIPOLI, Libya — The American Special Operations forces expected a warm welcome when they landed at the Libyan air base where an allied militia was stationed. Instead, armed men from another militia at the base threatened to detain the commandos, forcing the Americans to evacuate.

headline: On the Stockholm Waterfront, ‘Renewing a New City’
text: The waterfront district of Hammarby Sjostad, on the southern edge of Stockholm, has been heralded as a model of sustainable urban development, a place where one can already glimpse the future of city living. And the area’s growth, coupled with the steadily rising popularity of the island of Sodermalm to its immediate north, is pulling the inhabitable boundaries — if not the heart — of Stockholm southward.

headline: What to Do in Elena Ferrante’s Naples
text: Last week, we published an article about using the Neapolitan novels of Elena Ferrante as guidebooks to Naples. “As I discovered during a visit in September,” Ann Mah wrote, “the series of books offered a unique view of this complicated city, leading me away from popular tourist sites and helping to explain the city’s social, economic and geographic divisions. To view the Naples of Ms. Ferrante is to view Naples like a native.”

headline: The Living Dead
text: The bright aseptic room smelled of Pine-Sol and bleach and overripe Camembert. A white-bearded man lay on a stainless-steel examination table, his face angled toward the skylight and the cold, cloudless morning. An investigator read from his clipboard: 61-year-old white male discharged from a Detroit hospital last night was found at home, shirtless, in a wheelchair, a .38-caliber handgun in his right hand. On his chest was a burn that appeared to be an exact match of the gun’s barrel. Carl Schmidt, the medical examiner, wiped the contact wound with a wet sponge.

headline: Blessed Are the Comedians
text: For Middle East watchers, who are accustomed to reports of shootings and explosions, learning about a banned or suppressed book might be the closest thing to receiving good news. Suppression of a book, after all, is a perverse acknowledgment that literature holds the power to subvert the status quo — and without a single shot fired. If books that imagine peace are still able to put fear in the hearts of warmongers, isn’t it a sign that there’s some hope for us?

headline: Even Talking About Reducing Drug Prices Can Reduce Drug Prices
text: Both Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton are pushing for lower prescription drug prices as part of their campaigns. Debates about whether and how to reduce drug prices aren’t new. But they rarely lead to legislative success.

headline: Barclays Completes Sale of Controlling Interest in Trust Business
text: LONDON — The British bank Barclays has completed the sale of a controlling stake in its trust business to an independent investor group led by the Nielsen and Sarikhani families for an undisclosed amount.

headline: As Freed Americans Rejoin Relatives, Mystery Surrounds One Who Stayed Put
text: TEHRAN — As relatives of American prisoners freed by Iran over the weekend reunited with them Monday at United States military facilities in Germany, most Iranian officials conspicuously avoided talking about the deal that had led to their release.

headline: Health Reform Is Hard
text: My column and Bernie Sanders’ plan crossed in the mail. But the Sanders plan in a way reinforces my point that calls for single-payer in America at this point are basically a distraction. Again, I say this as someone who favors single-payer — but it’s just not going to happen anytime soon.

headline: Emporio Armani: Fall 2016
text: Men’s wear designs for next fall from Emporio Armani.

headline: China Largely Shrugs at Shake-Up After Taiwan Elections
text: BEIJING — The election of Tsai Ing-wen as president of Taiwan was met in China on Monday with sparse and largely critical comment, suggesting both a lack of interest toward a candidate whose party’s  nativist leanings many ordinary Chinese do not understand and censorship in the news media and online forums about an outcome that the Communist Party had not wished to see.

headline: Heidi Cruz Likes Donald Trump’s ‘The Apprentice’
text: Heidi Cruz does not consider herself a television critic. A Goldman Sachs executive, wife of Senator Ted Cruz and mother of two, she says she has little time to keep up with the small screen.

headline: Finding Your Way Around GarageBand
text: Q. I am intrigued by the creative potential of the GarageBand app on the iPad, but the program is a little overwhelming for the musical novice. How does one even begin to learn it?

headline: Saying No, So You Can Say Yes When It Matters
text: I have a problem: It’s really hard for me to say no to new, exciting projects.

headline: Tarantino’s Law: The Script Dictates the Costumes
text: If there’s one necessary qualification for a costume designer on a Quentin Tarantino film, it’s knowing how to clean blood from fabrics.

headline: Mayor de Blasio, With Carriage Horse Deal, Addresses a Pledge but Gets New Troubles
text: For Mayor Bill de Blasio, it was a bare-knuckle political fight, complete with arm-twisting appeals to lawmakers and labor negotiations lasting late into the night.

headline: 1941: Typhus Vaccine Goes to Europe
text: Dr. Thomas Parran, surgeon general of the United States Public Health Service, sailed for Lisbon yesterday aboard the American Export liner Excalibur with 10,000 doses of a new typhus fever vaccine developed by the Health Service as this country’s contribution toward fighting the great post-war disease, which took 1,000,000 lives in eastern Europe after the last war. The vaccine will be left with the American Consul in Lisbon, and any nations wanting some can procure it through their ministers of public health. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 19, 1941

headline: Desperate for Slumber in Delhi, Homeless Encounter a ‘Sleep Mafia’
text: DELHI, India — When midnight approaches in Old Delhi and a thick, freezing fog settles over the city, the quilt-wallah Farukh Khan sits on his corner, watching the market for his services come to life.

headline: China Charges Dozen Officials Over Deadly Shenzhen Landslide
text: BEIJING — The Chinese authorities have charged a dozen government officials over the deadly collapse of a mountain of construction debris in the southern city of Shenzhen last month, the state-run news agency, Xinhua, reported on Monday.

headline: Noreen Corcoran, ‘Bachelor Father’ Actress, Dies at 72
text: Noreen Corcoran, who grew up before television viewers in the 1950s and ’60s as a teenager during five seasons of the sitcom “Bachelor Father,” died on Jan. 15 in Van Nuys, Calif. She was 72.

headline: Bird Brains: Smarter Than We Thought
text: Male zebra finches learn their courtship songs from their fathers. Now, a new study details the precise changes in brain circuitry that occur during that process.

headline: Desert Rats Finding Meals Less Palatable
text: Climate change may affect wood rats in the Mojave Desert in a most unusual way. A new study finds that warmer weather reduces their ability to tolerate toxins in the creosote bush, which they rely on for sustenance.

headline: Insurer Rewards Push Women Toward Mammograms
text: A 53-year-old woman on Medicaid in Washington State who has never had a mammogram elects to get one in return for a $15 gift card.

headline: 2 Police Officers Fatally Shot in Ohio and Utah, Officials Say
text: Police officers were shot to death on Sunday in Ohio and Utah, the first killings of law enforcement officers in the line of duty this year.

headline: N.F.L. Playoffs: Here Are the Remaining Four Teams’ Flaws
text: The N.F.L.’s final four seem like a formidable group. For the first time since 2004, the top four seeds have advanced to the conference championship games. Among them, they have only 12 losses, the lowest total since 2004, when the Steelers, the Falcons, the Eagles and the eventual champion Patriots had 11.

headline: Iran Set to Pump More Oil Into Market Glut
text: HOUSTON — With international sanctions lifted, the Iranian government called on its oil industry Monday to open the taps on production, a move that could add to a global glut of crude that has sent prices into a tailspin.

headline: Case Could Widen Free-Speech Gap Between Unions and Corporations
text: WASHINGTON — The Citizens United decision, which amplified the role of money in American politics, also promised something like a level playing field. Both corporations and unions, it said, could spend what they liked to support their favored candidates.

headline: 1966: Untouchables Back Gandhi
text: NEW DELHI — Mrs. Indira Gandhi today [Jan. 18] won the support of 80 Congress party members representing India’s untouchables in her bid to become India’s first woman prime minister. The result was a heavy blow to her chief opponent, Morarji Desai, former finance minister. He had been counting heavily on the support of the untouchables. Their support gave Mrs. Gandhi, 48, an apparently overwhelming lead in tomorrow’s election. Technically it is for leader of the Congress party, but since the party controls Parliament, its leader automatically becomes prime minister. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 19, 1966

headline: Missing Americans in Baghdad Taken From Apartment, Officials Say
text: BAGHDAD — Three Americans who have been missing in Iraq since Friday were probably kidnapped from a Baghdad apartment, according to security officials and local news reports. The apartment may have been the home of an Iraqi colleague who is also believed to have been abducted, the officials and reports said.

headline: 7 Recipes for a Federal Holiday
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: MSGM: Fall 2016
text: The Fall 2016 men’s collection from MSGM.

headline: Kenneth Nicholson’s Spring/Summer 2016 collection
text: The Los Angeles-based designer created his line as a response to what he feels are limited options in the field of men’s wear.

headline: A New Men’s Wear Brand, Inspired (Loosely) by the Military
text: Growing up in Houston, Kenneth Nicholson wasn’t into the competitive side of sports, so when it came time for him to choose what he wanted to play, he chose based on the uniform. “I didn’t want to play baseball, but I was really into the socks,” he says. “That was a telltale sign that I was interested in apparel.”

headline: Using Phones to Connect Children to Health Care
text: I remember the first time one of my children texted me a photo of a skin lesion. It was not a photo of my own child’s skin, but that of a college roommate’s, and the message was something like: “Hi, Mom, is this anything to worry about?”

headline: Three’s a Trend: Zig-Zag Knits
text: Men’s knitwear has experienced a much-needed jolt this season, with prominent patterns in many of the Milan fall/winter 2016 shows. At Ermenegildo Zegna, vests came in dizzying graphic prints, while at Salvatore Ferragamo, sweaters took on a more kaleidescopic effect. And, true to form, Missoni offered stripes that zigged and zagged every which way. In all, they made an especially convincing case for adventurous dressing next fall.

headline: ‘Hack the Dinos’ Helps Paleontologists
text: Kaleigh Clary, a computer science graduate student at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, drove down to offer a day of free work for the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Canali: Fall 2016
text: The latest designs from Canali.

headline: Ai Weiwei’s Le Bon Marché Installation
text: The artist’s fantastical creatures for the Paris department store were made with the help of kite makers from the Shangdon Provence in China.

headline: Detention of Jason Rezaian’s Family Nearly Scuttled Iran Prisoner Swap
text: WASHINGTON — The Iranian authorities held the wife and mother of the journalist Jason Rezaian without telephones for hours in a separate room at a Tehran airport on Sunday before finally agreeing under American pressure to let them leave along with prisoners released in an exchange with the United States.

headline: Afghan Panel Sets Election Date, Drawing Government Criticism
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan election commission said Monday that it had set an Oct. 15 date for long-delayed parliamentary and district council elections. But the announcement immediately raised fears of new political deadlock after the country’s power-sharing government denounced the plan as illegitimate.

headline: Chickens Weren’t Always Dinner for Humans
text: Chickens get no respect. Ask any chicken researcher.

headline: The Big Search to Find Out Where Dogs Come From
text: OXFORD, England — Before humans milked cows, herded goats or raised hogs, before they invented agriculture, or written language, before they had permanent homes, and most certainly before they had cats, they had dogs.

headline: Evangelicals See Donald Trump as Man of Conviction, if Not Faith
text: Buford Arning, a retired building supply executive in Statesville, N.C., went to church each week until a pinched nerve made it hard for him to leave his house. He believes in living a faith-filled life. But he does not demand piety of his preferred presidential candidate, Donald J. Trump.

headline: WhatsApp, the Internet Messenger, to Become Free
text: MUNICH — WhatsApp, the popular Internet messaging service, will soon be free.

headline: The Switch
text: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Daniel Finkel of Math for Love, a Seattle-based math education consultancy. It’s a beautifully simple puzzle with plenty of room to explore. Let’s try:

headline: Ai Weiwei Makes Fantastical Creatures — for a Paris Department Store
text: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei made an appearance in Paris this weekend for the opening of his largest exhibition in the French capital to date — staged in a department store, of all places. Weiwei, who is renowned for exhibiting outside the traditional spaces, was invited to take over the windows and the central salon of the Left Bank luxury institution, Le Bon Marché, to promote its “White Sale.”

headline: University of Cincinnati to Pay $4.85 Million to Family of Man Killed by Officer
text: WASHINGTON — The University of Cincinnati has agreed to pay $4.85 million to the family of an unarmed black man who was shot to death in July by one of its police officers, a settlement that also requires the college to provide an undergraduate education to his 12 children, create a memorial to him on campus and include his family in discussions on police reform.

headline: Amid Oscar Boycott Plans by Spike Lee and Jada Pinkett Smith, Stars Gather for King Day
text: The outcry over the nomination of 20 white actors, and no black ones, for the Academy Awards gained momentum on Monday — Martin Luther King’s Birthday — as the director Spike Lee and the actress Jada Pinkett Smith announced they would not be attending the ceremony on Feb. 28.

headline: At Milan Men’s Shows, Velvet Suits and Vibrant Metallics
text: Bottega Veneta’s fall/winter 2016 collection was a mixture of cashmere and shearlings, Missoni showed slim knit suits and Calvin Klein featured denim and shine.

headline: Ash Barty, a Rising Tennis Star, Hits Pause
text: BRISBANE, Australia — Ash Barty, one of the most talented Australian tennis players of her generation, played Serena Williams on the opening night of the Australian Open in Rod Laver Arena two years ago. Then 17, Barty had the support of the crowd, and ultimately of Williams, who offered praise after defeating her, 6-2, 6-1.

headline: Vietnam Faces Last-Minute Maneuvering for Communist Party Leadership
text: HANOI, Vietnam — Soon after becoming the American ambassador to Vietnam in 2007, Michael W. Michalak approached Nguyen Tan Dung, the country’s new prime minister, at a gala dinner and mentioned that human rights were among the American government’s highest priorities in Vietnam.

headline: With Plan for Greenpoint Hospital, Neighbors May Finally Get Their Way
text: Ahab had Moby Dick, Sisyphus his rock, the Roeblings the Brooklyn Bridge. For Jan Peterson and her neighbors in northern Brooklyn, their ceaseless struggle has been the Greenpoint Hospital.

headline: Lisa Robb Named Head of Center for Arts Education
text: The Center for Arts Education, a New York City nonprofit group, has hired a new executive director: Lisa Robb, who since 2011 has managed about $40 million in grants for the New York State Council on the Arts.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Documentary to Air on PBS
text: The hit musical “Hamilton” will be the subject of a documentary film scheduled to air on PBS this fall.

headline: The 21st Annual Critics’ Choice Awards Red Carpet
text: Alicia Vikander, Saoirse Ronan, Gina Rodriguez and more at the Critics’ Choice Awards.

headline: Global Tensions Threaten to Upstage World Economic Forum in Davos
text: PARIS — The declared mission of the World Economic Forum, which begins on Wednesday, is “improving the state of the world.” But the perennial question is whether sequestering a few thousand of the global elite in the Alpine ski resort of Davos, Switzerland, can really achieve that lofty goal.

headline: The 21st Annual Critics’ Choice Awards Red Carpet
text: The 21st Annual Critics’ Choice Awards were held at Santa Monica Airport’s Barker Hangar in California on Sunday evening. Alicia Vikander, Saoirse Ronan and Gina Rodriguez were some of the celebrities who attended the show, which was hosted by T.J. Miller.

headline: Ken Burns to Discuss Race in Jefferson Lecture
text: Race in America has been a motif throughout Ken Burns’s nearly four-decade filmmaking career, in documentaries about the Civil War, baseball, jazz and more. This May, Mr. Burns will return to that topic when he delivers the 2016 Jefferson Lecture in the Humanities.

headline: Donald Trump Quotes Scripture, Sort of, at Liberty University Speech
text: LYNCHBURG, Va. – Donald J. Trump came to the stage where Senator Ted Cruz began his presidential campaign and vowed to “protect Christianity.”

headline: It May Be Time to Resolve the Meaning of ‘Natural Born’
text: WASHINGTON — After he left Wall Street to enter politics eight years ago, Representative Jim Himes, Democrat of Connecticut, began fielding the occasional question of when he intended to run for president.

headline: Eddie George Leaps to ‘Chicago’ From the N.F.L.
text: Eddie George was in his dressing room at the Ambassador Theater on Tuesday night, a Heisman Trophy winner and former star N.F.L. running back about to step onstage for his Broadway debut in “Chicago.”

headline: Certain Foods May Lower the Risk of Erectile Dysfunction
text: A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, tea and wine may help reduce the risk for erectile dysfunction, a new study found.

headline: In Davos, Shunning Controversy in Favor of Restrained Debate
text: The invitation was sent. And then, two weeks later, revoked.

headline: At Prada, Clothes for Men (and Women) at Sea
text: Miuccia Prada’s fall/winter 2016 men’s collection — which showed yesterday in Milan — had a haunting, naval feel.

headline: Deutsche Bank to Face British Lawsuit Over High-Speed Trading
text: FRANKFURT — Deutsche Bank, already troubled by lawsuits and official investigations, faces another challenge. A group of lawyers said on Monday that they planned to sue the company in British court, accusing the bank of using high-speed trading software to profit in foreign currency markets at the expense of customers.

headline: Fendi: Fall 2016
text: Designs from Fendi’s Fall 2016 show.

headline: Ted Cruz Criticizes Donald Trump for Supporting Democrats
text: WASHINGTON, N.H. — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas knows about Ronald Reagan. Ronald Reagan is a hero of his. And Donald J. Trump, he says, is no Ronald Reagan.

headline: Renting Blankets to Sleep on Delhi’s Streets
text: Homeless laborers, who have no place to store blankets in the daytime hours, cope with freezing nights by renting blankets to catch a few hours’ rest.

headline: Noah Rubin Upsets Benoît Paire for First Win at a Major Event
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Noah Rubin said Monday was just “another day at the office.” A bit of an understatement, considering he essentially received a promotion and a raise at what was already his dream job.

headline: Two Fresh Recipes From Obicà’s New Angeleno Outpost
text: With the opening this month of Obicà Mozzarella Bar Pizza e Cucina’s newest Los Angeles outpost, Santa Monica cheese enthusiasts can enjoy Italian mozzarella with an unprecedented level of freshness. Like its sister restaurant in New York City’s Flatiron district, which opened in 2014, the restaurant receives Mozzarella di Bufala deliveries twice a week from the practiced cheesemakers of Campania, Italy — an unusually frequent delivery schedule among restaurants in both cities. While the two menus share some dishes, the Santa Monica iteration capitalizes on the diverse agriculture and aquaculture of Southern California. Sensitive to L.A.’s appetite for more holistic dining options, native avocados and citrus lighten up the heavier dishes of the Italian kitchen canon.

headline: Review: ‘Planet Primetime’ Goes Worldwide, Investigating TV’s Wilder Side
text: It may not be the most sophisticated sociology, but “Planet Primetime,” a new show on the Travel Channel, at least raises the energy level in what can be a sleepy genre. The series, which begins on Tuesday night with two episodes, looks at various countries through the filter of some of their most popular television shows, with Karla Cavalli as effervescent host and occasional guinea pig.

headline: Video: SpaceX Rocket Landing Ends in Explosion
text: The latest attempt by SpaceX to recover one of its rockets by landing it on a platform in the ocean failed in a ball of fire on Sunday.

headline: Boy’s Response to Blasphemy Charge Unnerves Many in Pakistan
text: LAHORE, Pakistan — Late one night, the imam Shabir Ahmad looked up from prayers at his mosque to see a 15-year-old boy approaching with a plate in his outstretched left hand. On it was the boy’s freshly severed right hand.

headline: Review: In Vladimir Sorokin’s ‘The Blizzard,’ a Doctor’s Long and Strange Trip
text: With his latest novel, “The Blizzard,” Vladimir Sorokin has written a small, strange story that has little to do with his current reputation as a Russian literary bad boy and everything to do with riffing on Russia’s fabled literary past. “The Blizzard” begins as a kind of Chekhovian tale about a doctor setting off in a snowstorm on a medical mission to a village. It soon evolves into a phantasmagorical allegory sprinkled with surrealistic scenes that recall Gogol’s “The Nose” and Bulgakov’s “The Master and Margarita.”

headline: Review: Europa Galante Tells the Story of a Musical Orphan in ‘Chiara’s Diary’
text: Vivaldi fanciers may know of the Ospedale Della Pietà, the orphanage in Venice where that composer spent much of his career, teaching music to young women. But for most music lovers, the Pietà undoubtedly remains an abstraction.

headline: Review: ‘Puffs’ Parodies Harry Potter’s World
text: The wizards in training don’t dare speak the evil one’s name, but the script calls him Mister Voldy. That’s a fair gauge of the teasing affection on display in “Puffs,” Matt Cox’s spirited parody of the Harry Potter universe at the Peoples Improv Theater.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton Leave Sparring Behind at a King Day Event
text: Hours after engaging in their most contentious debate to date, Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders reconvened on Monday in a less charged setting to honor the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

headline: Navy Releases Timeline of Iran’s Capture of U.S. Sailors
text: WASHINGTON — In an effort to defuse the controversy over the brief capture of 10 Navy sailors last week, the Defense Department on Monday released a timeline of events surrounding the seizure, but the account was spare on new details and left several fundamental questions unanswered.

headline: Viewership for Democratic Debate Increased to More Than 10 Million, NBC Says
text: The increasingly close race between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders is capturing the attention of the American electorate, according to NBC, which said that more than 10 million viewers tuned in to watch the Democratic presidential debate on Sunday night.

headline: Review: ‘69 positions’ Explores the Sexual Politics in Performance
text: About halfway through “69 positions,” at MoMA PS1 on Friday, the choreographer Mette Ingvartsen, naked except for socks and sneakers, addressed her audience with a personal question: “Would anyone be interested in having a multiple collective orgasm?”

headline: A Polish E.U. Leader Seeks Middle Ground in a Dispute With Poland
text: BRUSSELS — As president of the European Council — the group representing the European Union’s often-clashing 28 leaders — Donald Tusk is forever promoting a balance between national sovereignty on one hand and common values and goals on the other. On Monday, his challenge was especially personal.

headline: François Hollande Aims 2 Billion Euro Plan at France’s Economic ‘Emergency’
text: PARIS — Declaring the French economy to be in a “state of emergency,” President François Hollande announced on Monday a 2 billion euro plan to subsidize job creation and temporarily move half a million unemployed people off the welfare rolls, as record unemployment threatens his bid for re-election next year.

headline: Brioni: Fall 2016
text: Brioni’s Fall 2016 show.

headline: Carmelo Anthony Returns to Help Knicks Ward Off 76ers
text: After having missed the Knicks’ previous two games with a sprained right ankle, Carmelo Anthony went to the bench late in the third quarter on Monday afternoon. The Knicks had a comfortable lead over the Philadelphia 76ers, and Anthony thought — or at least hoped — that his workday was done.

headline: Maldives to Let Jailed Ex-President Go to Britain for Surgery
text: NEW DELHI — The authorities in the Maldives on Monday allowed the opposition leader and former president Muhammad Nasheed, who has been in prison for 11 months, to travel to Britain for an operation.

headline: Online Booking Makes Hotel Loyalty Harder to Keep
text: For the past six months, Erin Gifford, a marketing director based in Washington, has traveled for business at least once a month, mostly to Boston.

headline: Review: ‘Let Me Tell You’ Has Its New York Premiere
text: It’s not often that a performance of a challenging new piece receives the kind of ovation typically awarded star virtuosi. But that’s what happened on Sunday night at Carnegie Hall when the conductor Franz Welser-Möst led the Cleveland Orchestra in the New York premiere of the Danish composer Hans Abrahamsen’s “let me tell you.” This eerily alluring 30-minute work for soprano and orchestra was written for the remarkable Barbara Hannigan, who performed it stunningly.

headline: Wealth Inequality Rising Fast, Oxfam Says, Faulting Tax Havens
text: Just 62 people own as much wealth as the 3.5 billion people in the bottom half of the world’s income scale, the charity Oxfam reported on Monday in its annual study of inequality, which found that the gap between rich and poor has continued to widen at an alarming rate. As recently as five years ago, the fortunes of 388 billionaires were needed to reach that halfway mark.

headline: In Argentina, Rancher’s Discovery Leads to Largest Titanosaur
text: Four years ago, a rancher in the Patagonia region of Argentina came upon an old bone sticking out of his desert property near La Flecha.

headline: Seeking Ranchland in Texas, Where Wealth Is Measured in Acres
text: Jay Ellis, an investment fund founder, may be the only person in Texas who is giddy about collapsing oil prices.

headline: National Book Critics Circle Announces Award Nominees
text: Ta-Nehisi Coates, already a National Book Award winner for “Between the World and Me,” now has a chance to add a National Book Critics Circle Award for criticism to his mantel. Mr. Coates’s book, a meditation on racism in America written in the form of a letter to his son, joins works by the novelist Lauren Groff, the memoirist and critic Vivian Gornick and the poet Ada Limón among those nominated for the awards.

headline: Partisanship Barges In on John Lewis’s Dream
text: ATLANTA — In 1963, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had a dream that, to the joy of millions of African-Americans, Barack Obama redeemed by winning the presidency.

headline: Globalfest Showcases the Sounds and Traditions of World Music
text: Roots were tangled, elastic and portable at this year’s Globalfest, the annual showcase for world music that started in 2003. With 12 overlapping sets on Sunday night at Webster Hall, Globalfest included dance music, protest songs, tradition, fusion, electronics, shtick, spirituality, camp and the blues. Some of the musicians were self-conscious emissaries from their homes; others were expatriates and widely traveled citizens of a connected world. Through the years, Globalfest has demolished the stereotype of world music performers as naifs playing the only music they know. Instead, it presents tradition as a choice and a resource, affirming a heritage or giving it a personal twist.

headline: Qaeda Rampage in Burkina Faso Shakes Service Employees
text: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso — As a receptionist at the grand Laico Hotel on the edge of downtown here, Zacharia Bagagnan, an uneducated 39-year-old, has a job his friends envy.

headline: Talk to Tehran, but Talk Tough
text: Palo Alto, Calif. — THE dramatic events of this past weekend mark a potential turning point in the modern history of the Middle East. Estranged for the last three and a half decades, the American and Iranian governments are talking and working with each other once again.

headline: New York City to Get $176 Million From U.S. for Storm Protections
text: New York City may soon be one step closer to building a new flood protection system around Lower Manhattan to guard against another storm like Hurricane Sandy.

headline: 3 Dead in Murder-Suicide Near SUNY Geneseo
text: GENESEO, N.Y. — A former student at a state university in western New York fatally stabbed two current students, one of whom was his ex-girlfriend, early Sunday morning and then killed himself, law enforcement officials said on Monday.

headline: Republican National Committee Moves a February Debate to CNN From NBC
text: The Republican National Committee has canceled its partnership with NBC for a late February debate in Houston and is awarding the broadcast to CNN.

headline: U.S. Military Deaths in the Afghan War
text: The Department of Defense has identified 2,365 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

headline: In Surprise Move, Bitter Political Rivals in Lebanon Announce Deal
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Two of Lebanon’s most prominent Christian politicians — one a crucial political ally of Hezbollah, the other its longtime foe — struck a surprise agreement on Monday that could help end the standoff that has left the country without a president for nearly two years.

headline: Lucky Blue Smith and Cameron Dallas Cause a Frenzy in Milan
text: MILAN — “It’s the Rolling Stones, the Beatles and Justin Bieber rolled into one,” said Joerg Koch, the editor of 032C, a Berlin-based art and fashion magazine. He was inside Gucci’s show space in a repurposed railway switching station near this city’s perimeter, and he was referring to the mobs clamoring all over the city for the new social media stars.

headline: Uzbeks Say Inmate Due for Release Died in 2010
text: MOSCOW — The Uzbek government, lobbied by rights groups and pressured quietly by the United States to free a high-profile political prisoner, has finally revealed a secret: He died five years ago.

headline: Puerto Rico Revises Plan to Reduce Debt as Optimism Dwindles
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Four months after announcing a grueling five-year plan for reducing the island’s vast debt and reviving economic growth, Puerto Rico’s top economic officials said on Monday that they had been too optimistic and revised the plan for the worse.

headline: Freed by Iran, Matthew Trevithick Quietly Readjusts Back Home
text: HINGHAM, Mass. — The mother and stepfather of Matthew Trevithick, the American researcher who was held for 40 days in Iran before he was freed over the weekend, said Monday that Mr. Trevithick was decompressing after returning to Massachusetts on Sunday night.

headline: TV’s Self-Reflection: Ratings May Be Down, but the Choices Are Many
text: PASADENA, Calif. — Twice a year, executives, show runners and actors convene for the Television Critics Association press tour to preview shows, review bad decisions and examine the industry at large.

headline: Boots? Marco Rubio Wants to Talk Guns and Football
text: WAVERLY, Iowa — People might have gotten the wrong impression lately that Marco Rubio is some kind of pointy-toed-boot-wearing fancy-pants. Stop thinking that. Right now.

headline: As More Pay by Smartphone, Banks Scramble to Keep Up
text: Ryan Craine hates carrying cash and finds writing checks to be a headache. He doesn’t do much of either anymore — he mostly uses his smartphone to pay for things.

headline: From Thursday Night Roots, N.F.L. Revenue Grows
text: Whatever its problems, the N.F.L. possesses a wizardly skill at conjuring up new money.

headline: British Have a Go at Trump but Shy Away From a Ban
text: LONDON — They called him a “fool,” a “buffoon” and even a “wazzock” — English slang for a combination of the two.

headline: Dispute Over Opposition’s Seat at Table Threatens to Push Back Syria Peace Talks
text: UNITED NATIONS — Barely a month after the world’s most powerful countries agreed to an ambitious road map to end the five-year-old war in Syria, there is still no agreement on who, if anyone, will show up at the peace talks that are supposed to begin in Geneva next Monday.

headline: Fairfield Ponders a Future Without General Electric
text: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — As word spread last week that General Electric was moving its headquarters and some of its employees to Boston, residents of this coastal town were just beginning to absorb what it will mean for their community to lose one of the country’s largest corporations.

headline: The Knicks’ Kristaps Porzingis Is a Precious Import. Handle With Care.
text: While the Knicks narrowly avoided what would have been a most deflating defeat, there was still an inescapable lesson for them to draw from a 119-113 double-overtime victory over the lowly-yet-feisty Philadelphia 76ers on Monday at Madison Square Garden.

headline: U.S.-Iranian Swaps Pit Compassion Against Costs
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama flew to Boise, Idaho, for a speech last winter, he met privately with the wife of an Iranian-American pastor held prisoner in Iran since 2012. Freeing her husband, he promised, was one of his top priorities.

headline: Glenn Frey, Singer-Songwriter and Eagles Founding Member, Dies at 67
text: Glenn Frey, the guitarist, singer and songwriter who co-founded the Eagles, whose country-tinged, melodic rock tunes, wistful love ballads, philosophical anthems, observations of the outlaw life and testaments to the wages of decadence made it perhaps the leading American band of the 1970s, died on Monday in New York City. He was 67.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Set for a Long Slog Against Bernie Sanders
text: Facing a tougher than expected challenge from Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Hillary Clinton’s campaign is preparing for a primary fight that could stretch into late April or early May and require a sprawling field operation in states and territories from Pennsylvania to Guam.

headline: China G.D.P. Growth at Slowest Pace Since 2009, Data Shows
text: HONG KONG — China’s growth slowed further last year, adding to the troubling economic picture that is unsettling investors around the world.

headline: In China, a Reverse Migration
text: After the sudden closure of a shoe factory, a migrant worker on China’s eastern seaboard heads back to his home in the countryside. China’s shoe industry has been hit hard by the slowing economy.

headline: Classic Out-of-Office Sign
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — No, you didn’t read that incorrectly. It’s a Byron Walden puzzle. On a Tuesday.

headline: A Woman’s Mission: Teaching Her Children to Stay ‘Full of Hope’
text: In the apartment she shares with her children, Lakima Lewis likes to leave notes. They are written on sheets of ruled notebook paper in big looping handwriting, offering messages of wisdom and hope, drawn from hours spent poring over the Bible.

headline: Macedonia: Elections Scheduled, but Opposition Threatens Boycott
text: Macedonia’s governing coalition is moving forward with a European Union-brokered plan for elections in April even though the opposition has threatened to boycott the vote, which would be run by a caretaker government. Johannes Hahn, the European Union commissioner who took the leading role in the negotiations for ending the political crisis in the Balkan country, said he would have preferred a consensual solution regarding the date of the elections. Prime Minister Nikola Gruevski submitted his resignation on Friday as part of an agreement forged by Mr. Hahn. That agreement sought to end a political crisis that erupted last February over a wiretapping scandal.

headline: Alabama: More Test Positive for Tuberculosis
text: The scale of a tuberculosis outbreak in rural Perry County widened Monday when state officials said that 47 residents last week tested positive for the bacterial infection. Those people, who are suspected of having an asymptomatic infection, will receive additional health care services as the authorities try to stop an outbreak that has now sickened or infected 73 people in and near Perry County since January 2014. In Perry County, which has fewer than 10,000 residents, three people have died. State officials previously said that the outbreak, which has mostly affected African-Americans, was concentrated in the county seat of Marion, and that Marion’s tuberculosis incidence rate was worse than those recorded in many developing countries.

headline: Morocco: Belgian Linked to Leader of the Paris Attacks Is Arrested
text: Moroccan officials announced Monday that they had detained a Belgian man thought to be a close friend of one of the leaders of the attacks in Paris on Nov. 13. The man, whom Belgian and Moroccan news sources identified as Gelel Attar, is of Belgian and Moroccan background, as were most of those who participated in the attacks. Mr. Attar was sentenced in absentia at a trial last summer in Belgium to five years in prison for involvement in a terrorist network. Two of the Paris attackers were also sentenced in absentia in that trial: Abdelhamid Abaaoud, who helped organize the attacks, and Chakib Akrouh, one of the attackers.

headline: George Jonas, Whose Book Was the Basis of the Film ‘Munich,’ Dies at 80
text: George Jonas, a prominent Canadian newspaper columnist whose controversial book about Israeli counterterrorists was the basis of the 2005 film “Munich,” directed by Steven Spielberg, died on Jan. 10 in Toronto. He was 80.

headline: Unmuzzling Himself, Ted Cruz Tells Voters to ‘Doubt the Credibility’ of Donald Trump
text: WHITEFIELD, N.H. — A week ago, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas would not lay a glove on Donald J. Trump.

headline: Tennis’s Watchdog Seems to Operate in the Dark
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Roger Federer wants names, and, frankly, so do all of us after the start of the Australian Open was dominated by discussion of match-fixing and betting patterns instead of match-winning and baseline patterns.

headline: Justin Upton Is Said to Agree on Deal With Tigers
text: One slugging outfielder reached an agreement on a nine-figure contract on Monday night. But it was Justin Upton, not Yoenis Cespedes, who found a new home.

headline: Fox Sports Ousts Greg Norman
text: Greg Norman is out as the lead golf analyst at Fox Sports after only one year with the network, a notably brief tenure for a well-known athlete-turned-analyst. Fox hired Norman, a novice at sportscasting, after it acquired the rights to the United States Open from the United States Golf Association. Norman’s inexperience was evident, as was that of Fox.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | ratiocination
text: ratiocination • \ra-she-ˌo-sə-ˈna-shən, -ˌnä-\ • noun

headline: 中国的返乡潮
text: 工作的鞋厂突然倒闭后，一位农民工从中国沿海城市返回位于四川农村的家乡。中国的鞋业在经济放缓的过程中遭到重击。

headline: Ted Cruz ‘Super PAC’ Invests Additional $2.5 Million in Advertising
text: A “super PAC” backing Senator Ted Cruz of Texas in the Republican presidential race has invested an additional $2.5 million in television ad reservations in Iowa and South Carolina as the contest hurtles toward the first votes.

headline: Thousands Turn Out on King Day to Hear Bernie Sanders Speak in Alabama
text: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Thousands of people packed into an auditorium here on Monday night for a Martin Luther King Day rally held by Senator Bernie Sanders that at times felt like a boisterous football game.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It’s not just a question of the first two states, or the first four states. We’re going to keep going into the map as long as it takes.”

headline: Corrections: January 19, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: His Factory Job Gone, a Chinese Migrant Worker Returns Home
text: Liu Lang, a Chinese migrant worker, left his rural hometown in Sichuan Province two decades ago to work in the factories of the southern province of Guangdong, China’s manufacturing powerhouse. Now, he is moving back.

headline: Breaking Things on the Path to Breakthroughs, from Rocket Stages to Balsa Bridges
text: I hope science and engineering students everywhere are pondering Elon Musk’s Instagram and Twitter flow from Sunday, when his SpaceX company successfully launched the valuable Jason-3 satellite for American and European space and science agencies but lost the first rocket stage as it landed, as planned, on a floating “drone ship.”

headline: Greenland’s Endless (for Now) Landscape
text: The seemingly endless and frozen landscapes around Greenland’s indigenous villages are vanishing and with them, a way of life.

headline: Greenland’s Endless (for Now) Landscape
text: Greenland is frequently in the news these days, its melting icebergs and receding sea ice a bellwether for climate change. But when the Finnish photographer Tiina Itkonen first visited the massive Arctic island in 1995, no one spoke of such things. Instead, she was fascinated by the indigenous Inuit and Inughuit cultures, and the impossible hues of an endless landscape. She was so intoxicated by the colors that she gave up shooting in black-and-white.

headline: Nigerians at the Mall
text: To the Editor:

headline: Real Estate Transparency
text: To the Editor:

headline: Time for a Republican Conspiracy!
text: Members of the Republican governing class are like cowering freshmen at halftime of a high school football game. Some are part of the Surrender Caucus, sitting sullenly on their stools resigned to the likelihood that their team is going to get crushed. Some are thinking of jumping ship to the Trump campaign with an alacrity that would make rats admire and applaud.

headline: Sale of The New Republic
text: To the Editor:

headline: More Autonomy for Principals
text: To the Editor:

headline: If the Supreme Court Rules Against Unions
text: To the Editor:

headline: Deregulating Corporate America
text: If you think Congress is hopelessly divided on party lines on every issue, think again. When it comes to regulating — more precisely, deregulating — corporate America, Republicans and Democrats are all too eager to find common ground.

headline: Just Saying Yes to the Politics of Drugs
text: EARLIER this month, former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida opened up on a subject he had once chided reporters for asking about: his daughter, Noelle, who, he said, “was addicted to drugs.”

headline: Taking Risks to Fight Climate Change
text: To the Editor:

headline: Proof That a Price on Carbon Works
text: Lawmakers who oppose taking action to lower greenhouse gas emissions by putting a price on carbon often argue that doing so would hurt businesses and consumers. But the energy policies adopted by some American states and Canadian provinces demonstrate that those arguments are simply unfounded.

headline: Fueling Homophobia in Russia
text: A vaguely written “gay propaganda” law passed in 2013 created a toxic environment for gay men and lesbians in Russia. Now, some lawmakers want to further denigrate and stigmatize gay people. A new bill scheduled for debate on Friday in the lower house of Parliament would allow the authorities to impose fines and even jail time for public displays of affection between people of the same sex.

headline: Protect Female Farmworkers
text: Oakland, Calif. — ACROSS the country, some 400,000 women, mostly immigrants, work in agriculture, toiling in fields, nurseries and packing plants. Such work is backbreaking and low-paying. But for many of these women, it is also a nightmare of sexual violence.

headline: You Are Stronger Than You (and Your Therapist) Think
text: I’m a psychiatrist who has spent most of the past 30 years treating patients with moderate to severe mental illness. But I’ve also administered care for the Massachusetts Department of Mental Health, Harvard Medical School and several insurance companies, and so I’m often asked for advice by colleagues who feel their patients need more help than an insurer is willing to pay for. In addition to offering technical advice, I often become, in essence, the therapists’ therapist, at least in terms of their treatment choices. And sometimes those interactions are as intense as therapy itself.

headline: Reducing Unnecessary C-Section Births
text: You are about to give birth. Pregnancy has gone smoothly. The birth seems as if it will, too. It’s one baby, in the right position, full term, and you’ve never had a cesarean section — in other words, you’re at low risk for complications.

headline: The Best Missions for a Moonshot
text: Even if hopes for a "victory" against cancer are unrealistic, how can government best be used to reduce its threat and lethalness?

headline: Underestimating Cruz and Trump: A Post-Mortem
text: Several journalists have taken to using the turnover of a new year as a time to look back on what they got wrong in the previous year. It’s a good idea. Journalists are supposed to analyze what’s happening in the world, and there is no way to do so with perfect foresight. But when we are surprised, we owe it to readers to be honest and reflective about why.

headline: Why 2016 Is Different From All Other Recent Elections
text: The 2016 Republican primary began as many Republican presidential campaigns do, with a few unexpected names atop the polls. In recent cycles, the names have included Herman Cain, Rick Santorum and Pat Buchanan. This year, they’ve been Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and Ben Carson.

headline: Chinese Students and U.S. Universities Connect Through a Third Party
text: BEIJING — Zhao Yang, 18, a high school student in Beijing, looked upset as she emerged from a room equipped with a video camera.

headline: News Q’s | ‘A Rare Chance to Pursue a New Path’ for U.S. and Iran
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “3 Freed Americans Leave Iran; U.S. Places New Sanctions.”

headline: Ellie Goulding Shares Her Beauty Routine
text: The English singer and songwriter Ellie Goulding, 29, is clearly hitting her stride. Her third album, “Delirium,” was hailed as the iTunes top pop album of 2015, while the hit single “Love Me Like You Do” earned a Golden Globe nomination (it was on the “Fifty Shades of Grey” soundtrack) and two Grammy nominations — her first. Aside from her music, Ms. Goulding has been collaborating with MAC Cosmetics on a makeup collection, which is in stores now. Below, she shares her beauty regimen for on and off the stage.

headline: Week of Attacks, Scores of Civilian Deaths and a Question: Why Them?
text: A family of Canadian volunteers dedicated to alleviating poverty in Africa. A group of intrepid German retirees on a tour of Turkey and the Middle East. An Iraqi who had gone to Baghdad seeking refuge from the jihadist violence of his hometown. A Canadian audiologist who had fallen in love with Indonesia.

headline: China’s Fading Factories Weigh on an Already Slowing Economy
text: DONGGUAN, China — Walking around an abandoned furniture factory, Fang Minghua pointed out the workshops where several hundred employees once toiled, transforming sheets of raw wood into TV stands or wardrobes for the aspiring middle class in China and other emerging economies.

headline: Film Shows Clinton Aide’s Own Struggle With Anthony Weiner Scandal
text: In May 2013, Huma Abedin and Anthony D. Weiner allowed filmmakers full access to his mayoral campaign with the hopes that the result would document a spectacular political comeback, with Mr. Weiner being sworn in as mayor of New York having emerged from a scandal centered on explicit texting that forced him to resign from Congress.

headline: Student Question | Under What Conditions Do You Do Your Best Work?
text: I do my best work under pressure.

headline: Chris Christie Offers a Key to Marital Success: Fight in a Walk-In Closet
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and his wife, Mary Pat, underwent marriage counseling to wrestle with what he called “really challenging times” in their relationship. They waited seven years to have children to ensure they “definitely liked each other.” And to this day they retreat to a walk-in closet to loudly argue away from their children’s earshot, according to a new book.

headline: ‘Why the Right Went Wrong’ and ‘Too Dumb to Fail’
text: “May you live in interesting times” is said to be a Chinese curse. The same kind of curse may apply to people who support interesting parties. There is no doubt that the Republicans are more interesting than the Democrats at the moment — their rhetoric is more incendiary, their divisions more profound, their behavior more outlandish. But the very antics that encourage people to tune in to the presidential debates also discourage them from pulling the voting lever: Hillary Clinton’s chances of winning the White House in November seem to be getting higher largely because she is a safe pair of hands.

headline: Explosion, Said to Be Suicide Bombing, Kills 8 in Northwest Pakistan
text: PESHAWAR, Pakistan — An explosion, said to be a suicide bombing, at a militia checkpoint just outside this Pakistani city killed eight people and wounded at least 11 on Tuesday morning, a senior official of the Khyber tribal region said.

headline: ‘Dark Money,’ by Jane Mayer
text: Nineteen eighty was a year of hope for conservatives in America, but it was a hope diminished by decades of consistent failure at the grass roots. Republicans hadn’t controlled either chamber of Congress, or a majority in state legislatures, for a quarter-century. Most governors were Democrats, as had been true since 1970. Not only was the Republican Party overmatched at winning elections, but those with the strongest ideological convictions — “movement conservatives,” as they liked to call themselves — were a faint voice even within Republican ranks.

headline: Q. and A.: Bei Ling on the Missing Hong Kong Booksellers
text: The disappearance of five Hong Kong booksellers in recent months has attracted international attention and raised concerns that civil liberties the city retained after its return to Chinese rule in 1997 under the so-called one country, two systems formula might be under threat. That the five men were all connected to Mighty Current Media, a publisher of exposés on Communist Party leaders, has led to suspicions that the Chinese authorities might have played a role.

headline: Twitter Experiences Worldwide Disruptions
text: Twitter experienced global disruptions on Tuesday that prevented many of its 300 million users from staying connected or from logging on to the social network in the first place.

headline: DSquared2: Fall 2016
text: The Fall 2016 men’s collection from DSquared2.

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Morning Agenda: Restrained Debate and Global Tensions at Davos
text: RESTRAINED DEBATE AND GLOBAL TENSIONS AT DAVOS | The World Economic Forum revoked the invitation it sent to Ri Su-Yong, North Korea’s foreign minister, after the country’s fourth nuclear test in January. One of its board members, Philipp Rösler, explained that the test meant “there would be no opportunity for an international, global dialogue in the spirit of the World Economic Forum.”

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Bernie Sanders, Glenn Frey, Tennis

headline: Microsoft Acquires Minecraft App for Schools
text: SEATTLE — When Microsoft acquired the creator of the game Minecraft in 2014, the giant software company instantly got a cachet bump with children, picking up a blockbuster game app for a generation that didn’t depend on its products the way their parents did.

headline: Nikki Haley’s State of the Union Response Sours Tea Party Voters’ Mood
text: It has been almost a week since Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina suggested in a State of the Union response that her fellow Republicans dial down their anger. For Tea Party activists in her state, the advice has served only to frustrate them further.

headline: New York Today: Hold Your Horses
text: Updated 8:55 a.m.

headline: Seven Years Later, Verdasco Comes Through Against Nadal
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was a moment that not every loser would have chosen to revisit: a marathon versus Rafael Nadal in 2009 that could have put Fernando Verdasco in the final of the Australian Open.

headline: Ted Cruz, on New Hampshire Bus Tour, Makes a Brief Effort in Spanish
text: PLYMOUTH, N.H. — At virtually every campaign stop, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas tells the tale of his father’s exodus from Cuba. He is less likely to speak the country’s official language.

headline: Jeb Bush to Speak at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York
text: From almost the first day he entered the 2016 race, Jeb Bush has cast himself as the cerebral, wonky adult in a room full of colorful, bombastic Republican candidates.

headline: Bernie Sanders Hits the Road to Try to Solidify His Iowa Ground Game
text: With just two weeks until the Iowa caucuses, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont is hitting the road and stepping on the gas.

headline: Getting in Shape This Year? Hotels Offer Deals to Help You.
text: Making a new year’s resolution to get healthy is easy. Sticking to that goal as the months go by? Not so much. Next month, a number of hotels are trying to help keep their guests motivated by introducing long-term fitness initiatives and packages.

headline: New York Hotels Make a Green Pledge
text: Seventeen notable New York City hotels have committed to getting greener.

headline: Rachel Bloom’s Twisted Comedy
text: Quietly and without much notice, last fall the CW network aired what was most likely broadcast television’s first-ever depiction of anal waxing. The scene, on the show “Crazy Ex-Girlfriend,” was not explicit, yet neither was it ambiguous. A young woman in her bathroom, wearing a short robe, leans forward and then reaches toward her backside with a wax strip in her hand. There is the sound of something ripping, a scream and then a cut to the spattering of blood on the side of the tub, like a shot from a slasher flick in which all the horror is implied.

headline: Donald Trump Heads to Iowa, Where Fight With Ted Cruz Is Out in the Open
text: Donald J. Trump returns to Iowa on Tuesday amid a deepening faith-focused feud with Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

headline: Investment in Internet Start-Ups Appears to Slow in China
text: HONG KONG — China’s Internet companies, in recent years, have been the shining stars of growth, with Alibaba and Tencent rivaling in size some of their most formidable global competitors.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 12-18, 2016
text: Have you been following this week’s news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

headline: Bank of America’s Profit Tops Expectations
text: Bank of America, which has struggled to maintain consistent earnings growth, on Tuesday reported a better-than-expected profit in the fourth quarter, but the bank’s results showed signs of strain from soured energy loans.

headline: Is the Writer’s Only Responsibility to His Art?
text: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. Faulkner said, “The writer’s only responsibility is to his art.” This week, Zoë Heller and Francine Prose discuss the obligations of artists.

headline: Lazard Hires Managing Director to Bolster Restructuring Business
text: As energy companies continue to struggle with the sharp drop in oil prices, Lazard is beefing up its restructuring business by hiring a new managing director: Ken Ziman of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.

headline: Here’s Someone You Never Heard of. Read On.
text: It may seem churlish to speak ill of strangers. And I’m sympathetic to reporters’ efforts to humanize their news stories with vivid examples and memorable characters.

headline: Why Green Bay Should Have Chosen Boldness
text: Green Bay lost to Arizona in overtime without getting a possession, marking the second consecutive season in which the Packers have taken a playoff game to the fifth quarter and then lost without touching the ball. But don’t blame the N.F.L. overtime format for Green Bay’s woes — blame the conservative tactics of Coach Mike McCarthy.

headline: Morgan Stanley Posts Profit as It Charts a New Course
text: Morgan Stanley swung from a loss to a better-than-expected profit in the fourth quarter compared to a year ago — at the same time that it announced a new strategic plan for improving profitability even more.

headline: Ayatollah Khamenei Warns Iran’s Government Against U.S. ‘Deceptions’
text: TEHRAN — Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, cautiously welcomed on Tuesday the completion of the nuclear deal and the lifting of economic sanctions last weekend, while at the same time dashing any expectations that the event marked the beginning of a détente with the United States.

headline: Giorgio Armani: Fall 2016
text: Giorgio Armani’s Fall 2016 men’s wear collection.

headline: Point72, Steven Cohen’s Firm, Reopens Office in London
text: LONDON — Steven A. Cohen, the billionaire investor, has returned to London, less than three years after his former firm, SAC Capital Advisors, closed its office in London amid an insider trading investigation by authorities in the United States.

headline: 1916: France Welcomes Hostages
text: Paris gave an enthusiastic welcome yesterday evening to the ten French hostages, mayors and prominent residents in the invaded departments taken prisoners early in the war, upon their arrival at the Gare de Lyon at 7.25. A great crowd assembled outside the station and the platform was lined with friends and relatives and many deputies and government officials. As the train steamed into the station, the crowd raised a great cry of ‘‘Vive la France!’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 20, 1916

headline: Caitlyn Jenner to Publish a Memoir About Her Transformation
text: Caitlyn Jenner — the reality TV star and prominent transgender activist — will publish a memoir about her highly public transformation from the Olympic track star and motivational speaker Bruce Jenner into a glamorous transgender woman, Caitlyn Marie Jenner.

headline: On Peering at an Elevator Inspector’s Initials
text: Dear Diary:

headline: U.N. Quantifies the Suffering in an Iraq Divided and Under Attack
text: BAGHDAD — It was weeks ago that Iraqi and United States officials declared the city of Ramadi liberated from the Islamic State, yet the fighting has dragged on in some neighborhoods. As Iraqi commandos advance slowly, house to house and under American air cover, hundreds of civilians are still fleeing the violence, many of them malnourished.

headline: The Conductor Andrew Litton, Finding a Different Tempo
text: Midway through his first rehearsal as music director of the New York City Ballet Orchestra, the conductor Andrew Litton did something audacious. He asked the musicians to change how they played a score that they must hold some kind of record for performing: Tchaikovsky’s “The Nutcracker,” which they have presented dozens of times each year for decades.

headline: Josef Frank: Celebrating the Anti-Design Designer
text: VIENNA — Toward the end of his life, the Austrian designer Josef Frank made dozens of meticulously detailed paintings of houses. Each was in a recognizably Modernist style, usually in a rural setting, with an elegant garden and large windows carefully positioned to capture the daylight.

headline: Viacom in Cross Hairs of Activist Investor
text: To Eric Jackson, an activist investor with SpringOwl Asset Management, Viacom appears to be a textbook-style target.

headline: Can Iran Change?
text: Riyadh, Saudi Arabia — THE world is watching Iran for signs of change, hoping it will evolve from a rogue revolutionary state into a respectable member of the international community. But Iran, rather than confronting the isolation it has created for itself, opts to obscure its dangerous sectarian and expansionist policies, as well as its support for terrorism, by leveling unsubstantiated charges against the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

headline: For Now, Bernie Sanders’s Health Plan Is More of a Tax Plan
text: If you read the news articles over the weekend about Senator Bernie Sanders’s new single-payer health reform plan, you might have thought you were reading about tax policy, not health care.

headline: Bette Midler Coming to Broadway in ‘Hello, Dolly!’
text: Hello, Bette!

headline: Davos Takes a Fresh Look at Emerging Markets
text: Ever since emerging markets became a major asset class in the early 1990s, a parade of potentates, policy makers and corporate chieftains have flocked to the stylish village of Davos in the Swiss Alps in the hope of becoming the latest global meme.

headline: Leila Alaoui, Photographer Wounded in Burkina Faso Siege, Dies at 33
text: Leila Alaoui, a French-Moroccan photographer whose hauntingly beautiful photographs explored themes of migration, cultural identity and displacement, died on Monday night from injuries sustained during a terrorist attack in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso. She was 33.

headline: Who’s Taking On Ethics in Albany? Not the Ethics Panels
text: ALBANY — On this, the leaders in New York’s Capitol can all agree: Something must be done about ethics. Reforms must be passed, the public trust once again earned.

headline: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Obama Immigration Actions
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said Tuesday that it would consider a legal challenge to President Obama’s overhaul of the nation’s immigration rules, agreeing to examine the reach of presidential power as it decides the fate of one of his most far-reaching executive actions.

headline: Daily Report: Ed Tech Start-Ups Face New Challenges
text: If numbers alone told the story, you would think these were boom times for education technology start-ups.

headline: Dick Costolo, Former Twitter C.E.O., Embarks on Next Chapter
text: In the six and a half years that Dick Costolo led Twitter’s executive ranks, he helped grow the company from a few hundred employees to a few thousand. Seven months after leaving Twitter, Mr. Costolo is going small again.

headline: Sticking With Windows 7
text: Q. Is it true that Windows 10 will be a mandatory upgrade for Windows 7 and Windows 8 users this year? I have been getting the “invitation” to upgrade my Windows 7 computer for months, but have been avoiding it because I like my current system.

headline: Weakened at Bernie’s
text: With the release of Bernie Sanders’ health plan — or actually, health “plan” — the Democratic primary is coming into much better focus. Sanders is still a long shot for the nomination, but is a serious enough contender that he deserves some real scrutiny. And it’s important to be aware that there are bigger problems with his candidacy than lack of political realism.

headline: Univision Buys a Stake in The Onion to Reach Millennials
text: The Spanish-language media giant Univision Communications announced Tuesday that it had acquired a large stake in The Onion, the comedy and satirical digital media group, as part of the company’s efforts to extend its digital reach and strengthen its portfolio of comedy outlets.

headline: 1941: Nazi Raiders Reported Active
text: MANILA, P.I. — Ninety-eight Filipino survivors of German raids on shipping in the Pacific arrived here today on the Japanese ship Kamo Maru and reported that at least twelve Nazi raiders were operating in those waters. They said that Germans on board the ships on which they had been imprisoned said that twelve more vessels were being outfitted in Japanese ports for raiding purposes. Survivors of three British ships sunk by Nazi raiders in December, the Filipinos told of having come into contact with three German raiders, including the 10,000-ton Narvik, which they said was known as the ‘‘Black Ship,’’ painted black from stem to stern and bearing no insignia to show its nationality. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 20, 1941

headline: British Fashion Council/Vogue Fund Names 2016 Award Finalists
text: LONDON — In the evermore volatile retail climate for small fashion brands and behemoths alike, the importance of winning industry prizes has become paramount to fledgling designers. Few outside the business are aware of how even household names can teeter on the edge of bankruptcy, or how putting on a catwalk show in a bid to catch industry attention can take a heavy toll on finances in a brand’s early years.

headline: East Coast Snowstorm Expected to Hit This Weekend
text: Days after a snowfall on the East Coast, any hope of a return to 60-degree winter was officially dashed on Tuesday as meteorologists warned that the season’s first significant winter storm could be fast approaching.

headline: Appeals-Court-on-Insider-Trading
text: The court affirmed the convictions of an executive at Foundry Networks for tipping about the impending acquisition of the company.

headline: Chocolate by the Book
text: Georg Bernardini, a German chocolate expert, has evaluated chocolates from more than 500 companies worldwide and shares the results, A to Z, in a comprehensive tome that has been translated from German into English and is now available in the United States. He is forthright, referring to the chocolate from one company as having an “annoying” taste, and admits to disliking chocolate that contains vanilla. Among the more compelling features is a rundown of what should be listed on the labels of good dark, milk and white chocolate. He also describes the levels of processing, from serious bean to bar (he is not particularly a fan of Mast Brothers) to simple repackaging, and tells you what each company does: “Chocolate – The Reference Standard” by Georg Bernardini (Georg Bernardini, $60), thechocolatetester.com.

headline: At New Digital Lenders, Math Rules
text: Miguel Jimenez, a 20-year-old amateur musician in Appleton, Wis., had his eye on a classic Rickenbacker bass guitar last year. He searched the Internet and found Reverb, an online marketplace for musical instruments, which had the bass guitar he wanted. But the price tag was $1,600.

headline: Is It Better to Die in America or in England?
text: WE frequently hear complaints about how people near the end of life are treated in America. Patients are attached to tubes and machines and subjected to too many invasive procedures. Death occurs too frequently in the hospital, rather than at home, where the dying can be surrounded by loved ones. And it is way too expensive. Each year, the care of dying seniors consumes over 25 percent of Medicare expenditures.

headline: Twins and Grandparents Killed in Maryland Fire
text: Twin toddlers and their grandparents died in a fire in a suburban Maryland house early on Tuesday, and investigators said they were trying to determine the cause of the blaze. The home appears to have had no smoke detectors, the authorities said.

headline: A Military Wife During Deployment Is Asked, ‘Is It Worth It?’
text: We sat around my sister’s dining room table, laughing so hard we had tears in our eyes, reliving and rehashing the events of the night before. My aunt and uncle “fishing” for each other on the dance floor. My brother’s hilarious toast to the bride and groom (my other brother). My cousin’s Russian girlfriend responding to someone’s question of “Where did he find you?” with “Amazon Prime.”

headline: Part of Sierra Leone’s History Is Being Dismantled Board by Board
text: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — On a busy roundabout in the heart of this nation’s capital stands an ancient cotton tree, marking the spot where Freetown was founded by freed slaves from North America more than 200 years ago. Walk for a few minutes toward the southeast, past the vendors who line the derelict remains of Victoria Park and through the bustling streets of the city center, and you will find at the corner of two rutted dirt roads a house that looks more suited to the American South than to a steamy West African capital.

headline: In Milan, Gucci Celebrates the Delightfully Weird
text: Alessandro Michele’s fall/winter 2016 men’s collection mixed patterns and decorative styles, for what he called an “alchemical reaction.”

headline: Activist Investor's Report on Viacom

Readers were impressed with Bernie Sanders on campaign finance, Hillary Clinton on the Affordable Care Act, Martin O’Malley on “boots on the ground,” and more. Below are some of the most popular choices for most intelligent comment of the evening:

headline: Can a Book Threaten Israel’s Jewish Identity?
text: Tel Aviv — The Israeli novelist Dorit Rabinyan has hit the jackpot: First, her latest book, “Borderlife,” became an issue of fierce debate and controversy. Then it became a symbol of liberty and progress. And then, of course, it became a best seller.

headline: Ice Cube and the Obstacles Facing ‘Compton’
text: Let’s do a throwback Tuesday to last week, a few days before the Oscar nominations were announced, unleashing a torrent of fury over the omission of black actors and films about black characters. The prospects for “Straight Outta Compton,” directed by F. Gary Gray, looked bright: many forecast it would receive a best picture nomination (it did not). Ice Cube, a producer on the film, which depicts the rise of his group, N.W.A., met with the Bagger at the Roosevelt Hotel in Hollywood. He talked about his son O’Shea Jackson Jr., who plays Cube in the film, the therapeutic value of gangsta rap, and what would be lost if “Compton” did not get a nomination. Here are excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Rudolph Giuliani to Join Greenberg Traurig Law Firm

headline: Ex-Red Army Faction Members Sought in Robbery in Germany
text: BERLIN — The German police have intensified their decades-long search for three members of the Red Army Faction, believed to be on the run since their far-left guerrilla group disbanded in 1998, after prosecutors said on Tuesday that they had linked them to at least one botched robbery last year.

headline: Anti-Abortion Groups Join Battles Over Frozen Embryos

headline: Ai Weiwei’s Latest Canvas: A Luxury Emporium in Paris
text: PARIS — On Sunday evening, Ai Weiwei — Chinese dissident artist, human rights activist and, now, European scenester — was holding court on the cosmetics floor of the Bon Marché Rive Gauche, the Paris department store. The event was the invitation-only opening of “Er Xi,” or “Child’s Play,” an exhibit of his work that fills 10 display windows and the store’s atrium through Feb. 20.

headline: New Writings by Donald Judd Coming to Light
text: The artist Donald Judd, who died in 1994, remains known for many things – his sculpture, his spare architectural interventions, his exacting and obdurate personality. During his lifetime he was also known and widely revered for his writings – criticism and essays that took the measure of many of his contemporaries and helped set the terms for Minimalism, the movement he never quite claimed as his own. But for more than two decades, Judd’s collected writings, originally published in 1975, have been extremely hard to come by, with copies sometimes trading on used book sites for hundreds of dollars.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Men’s Wear, Come Undone
text: Precise tailoring is usually the main attraction at the Milan men’s shows — but this season, a handful of designers have embraced a more undone look in their fall/winter 2016 collections. At Prada, plackets, collars and cuffs dangled from shirts and jackets, while at Gucci, Marni, Etro and Damir Doma, knits, trousers and coats came down the runway with frayed hems. And at Vivienne Westwood — certainly a patron saint of the unkempt — a patchwork sweater was cut open at the sleeves. It all makes one consider taking a pair of shears to one’s own clothes for next winter.

headline: Gun Debate at the O.K. Corral (Or Somewhere)
text: “The American people know a liar when they see one,” declared Wayne LaPierre, chief executive of the National Rifle Association, calling out President Obama for a one-on-one television debate on gun controls in a macho direct-address video that sounded more like a challenge to a duel. “Let’s see if you’re game for a fair debate,” said Mr. LaPierre. “It’s your chance to show the American people you’re not afraid to meet the NRA on neutral ground.”

headline: Rethinking College Admissions
text: Over recent years there’s been a steady escalation of concern about the admissions process at the most revered, selective American colleges. And little by little, those colleges have made tweaks.

headline: Supreme Court Will Hear a California Insider Trading Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday agreed to resolve a dispute about what prosecutors need to prove to obtain insider trading convictions. The question has divided federal appeals courts, and the justices declined to address it in October.
