headline: A Romantic Weekend for Two: Solving a Crime
text: It’s hard to imagine a more intriguing description of a weekend escape than “like being the detective in Twin Peaks,” which is how Gabe Smedresman likes to advertise his latest offering, the Headlands Gamble. Smedresman calls himself a producer of “mixed-reality entertainment” — his prior projects include the pseudo-stock-market game Pretweeting (a way to make the most of the Times Newswire API) and the Hearst Collection, “a real-life maze in which people who enter try to steal works of art without tripping laser alarms,” reported the journalist Harold Goldberg in 2013. The Headlands Gamble pulls together these key themes as the inaugural trip of First Person Travel, Smedresman’s new “immersed-narrative travel agency.”

headline: A Push for Gender Equality at the Davos World Economic Forum, and Beyond
text: As a top executive in the financial industry, Theresa Whitmarsh is accustomed to being the only woman in the room. That was the case the last two years when she attended the annual meeting of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, a conclave for the world’s most powerful leaders and tycoons.

Trump in Iowa, the former Alaska governor posted on Twitter a link to a comment from her daughter Bristol slamming Senator Ted Cruz, who holds a slim lead over Mr. Trump in the polls there.

headline: Turkish Sweets Are the Essence of a Nation

To my right, illuminated in the distance, loomed modern skyscrapers. Sea gulls swirled overhead amid emerging stars, diving for bits of bagel-like simit tossed to them from the deck.

headline: Imagination Worth the Added Price at Midtown’s La Chine

Underneath were layers of custard and hairy crab, a seasonal freshwater treat from China whose taste is a lot more seductive than its name. The rich, smooth pleasure in each spoonful almost made my head pop.

headline: In Chelsea, a Trio of Galleries Bring Cuba Stateside
text: When the U.S. loosened travel restrictions to Cuba in 2014, Havana jumped to the top of everyone’s cultural bucket list. And the New York art scene has caught the fever: A rash of exhibitions this winter are devoted to the island’s art community. A timely follow-up to last spring’s contemporary-focused “Cuba Libre!” exhibition at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, David Zwirner’s “Concrete Cuba” offers one of the first looks at the island’s pre-revolutionary art, with a comprehensive show of the sculptures and paintings of Los Diez Pintores Concretos (the Ten Concrete Painters), a group of geometrically inclined artists that operated under that collective moniker for a brief moment between 1959 to 1961. Taking up the second story of the gallery’s 20th Street tower, the historical work has a pleasingly human scale. A celebration of medium and color rather than content, the concretist compositions share more conceptual similarities with the process-based artists of today than with the abstract expressionists who were working in Europe and the U.S. at that time.

headline: New Jersey Creates Retirement Savings Plan, Modified by Christie
text: As more states explore ways to encourage workers to save for retirement, New Jersey recently decided on its own approach: The state will create a retirement plan marketplace, intended to make it easier for small businesses to select a tax-deferred savings program for employees.

headline: ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ Kills It in Final Week on Broadway

headline: The Improvised Shakespeare Company’s Couplets Off the Cuff
text: In its second show of a doubleheader on Sunday night in the East Village, the Improvised Shakespeare Company built a spot-on parody of the word-drunk sexual innuendo of Falstaff’s world, a five-man cast making up the script on the spot, piling one filthy pun atop another.

headline: Casual Italian at Lilia in Williamsburg
text: Lilia Missy Robbins, who has worked consulting gigs since leaving A Voce nearly three years ago, now has her own place to hang her toque. Hers is not the first New York restaurant to inhabit a former auto-body shop. And, as in the others, industrial elements grab the eye. But skylights and an open kitchen fitted with a wood grill and rotisserie brighten the setting for Ms. Robbins’s casual Italian, pared down to its simplest elements. Dishes include winter-vegetable bagna cauda, grilled clams with chiles and bread crumbs, whole-wheat spaghetti with smoked ricotta, and pike with salsa verde and roasted potatoes. A retail area for takeout becomes a bar in the evening: 567 Union Avenue (North 10th Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 718-576-3095, lilianewyork.com.

headline: Microsoft to Donate $1 Billion in Cloud Services to Nonprofits and Researchers
text: SEATTLE — Microsoft plans to give away $1 billion in cloud services to nonprofits and university researchers over the next three years, as the company updates its philanthropic initiatives to reflect shifts in technology.

headline: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan Apologizes in Flint Water Crisis
text: LANSING, Mich. — Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan issued a sweeping apology on Tuesday to the residents of Flint for a contaminated water supply. He pledged to promptly release his emails about the issue, and laid out more specifics than had previously been known about the state’s handling of the matter.

text: In September 2014, the organizers of the inaugural TomorrowWorld dance festival near Atlanta made a significant adjustment to the main stage lineup. Avicii, the superstar Swedish ambassador of electronic dance music, known as E.D.M., had canceled because of illness; his replacement was the lesser-known Norwegian producer-D.J. headline: Review: Eighth Blackbird Ensemble Plays Sleeping Giant’s Suite
text: Composers tend to be proprietary about their pieces. They may openly acknowledge the influence of masters, teachers and colleagues on their work, but when it’s finished, the writer claims the credit.

headline: ‘All That Jack (Cole),’ a Homage to a Forgotten Choreographer
text: If you’ve seen “Gentlemen Prefer Blondes” and “Gilda,” you’ve seen the work of the choreographer Jack Cole. And yet he’s hardly a household name, despite being one of the first to bring the energy and rhythmic attack of jazz to musical theater. Even so, Cole’s work has long languished in the archives, along with the often second-rate movies he worked on in the 1940s and ’50s. Now, in the Museum of Modern Art’s retrospective “All That Jack (Cole),” which opens on Wednesday, 18 of these films will return to the screen, many for the first time in decades.

headline: ‘Star Wars: The Force Awakens’ Receives a Cool Reception in China

headline: Review: Arturo Ripstein’s ‘Bleak Street,’ the Story of a Mexican Murder Case
text: “Bleak Street,” Arturo Ripstein’s new film, turns a lurid tabloid true-crime story into a somber, surreal, monochromatic dream. Based on a murder case that shocked Mexico in 2009, the film is less interested in sensationalism or sleuthing than in the operations of fate. When characters invoke destiny, they sometimes have happy outcomes in mind, but every gray-shadowed, elegantly grotesque frame points in the opposite direction, toward death and other sorrows.

headline: Prisoner Swap With Iran Doesn’t Necessarily Mean Iran Gets Anyone

headline: Mr. Obama’s Wise Call on a Prisoner Swap
text: It was inevitable that the prisoner exchange with Iran would be questioned as soon as it was announced — and not just by Republicans who mechanically assail anything President Obama does. The notion of making concessions to a hostile adversary to secure the release of one’s fellow citizens has always been controversial, pitting the innate longing to win their freedom against the risk that handing over money or releasing prisoners in exchange will only encourage the captors to seize more. This dilemma has bedeviled many presidents and governments through history, with no simple or single answer. In this case, President Obama did the right thing.

headline: Unequal Lives, Unequal Deaths
text: In my first year of practice in palliative medicine, I made house calls to patients in South Los Angeles. My patients all lived in neighborhoods that ranked among the city’s lowest in both income and life expectancy. In these neighborhoods, people die an average of 10 years earlier than those who live less than 10 miles away. Many of my patients felt that they had barely lived their lives when I showed up, ostensibly to help them “die with dignity.”

headline: Why Is It So Difficult for Syrian Refugees to Get Into the U.S.?
text: ‘We aren’t the kind of family that sends our daughters to work,’’ Mahmoud al-Haj Ali told me one evening this fall. He’d just returned to the family’s dingy second-floor apartment in Aurora, Ill., from the warehouse where he and his 19-year-old daughter, Sham, sorted boxes. At work, Mahmoud tried to keep her in sight. ‘‘I saw how tired she was,’’ he continued. ‘‘It’s more than she can take.’’ Sham’s English classes provided only a shaky foundation in the language, and she struggled to negotiate basic conversations. Mahmoud also spoke little English — we were sitting with an interpreter — but he could manage the essential. Mahmoud work tomorrow, Mahmoud no work tomorrow, he said in self-parody. But he, too, was tired. He rolled up his sweatpants to reveal a swollen leg. In Syria, Mahmoud, 57, who once owned a flourishing locksmith business in the Emirates, would have already retired.

headline: In Search of Japan’s Hidden Culinary Revolution
text: I was on the Shinkansen bullet train and roaring north toward the Japan Sea at 125 miles per hour when I passed through the wormhole in space-time. The wormhole was on the far end of a long, unlit tunnel. Three-quarters of an hour earlier, in the midst of a sunny winter’s day, I’d boarded the train at the loud, insanely complex and many-leveled Tokyo main station, accompanied by my friend Bob Sliwa. We were bound for the coastal town of Kanazawa, sometimes known as the hidden pearl of the Japan Sea and famed for the freshness and variety of its fish-based cuisine.

headline: ‘The Triumph of William McKinley,’ by Karl Rove
text: Writing six decades after the election of 1896 brought the retired Ohio governor William McKinley to the White House, the political scientist V. O. Key Jr. identified the Democratic defeat as “so demoralizing and so thorough that the party could make little headway in regrouping its forces until 1916.” The scale of this Republican success — a moment that ushered in a period of Republican Party ascendance that lasted until the election of Franklin Roosevelt in 1932 — draws the attention of the prominent political strategist Karl Rove, who also views McKinley’s victory over the charismatic William Jennings Bryan as pivotal. Rove is in awe, rightly so, of McKinley’s political achievement, and his richly detailed, moment-by-moment account in “The Triumph of William McKinley” brings to life the drama of an electoral contest whose outcome seemed uncertain to the candidate and his handlers until the end.

headline: David Greenberg’s ‘Republic of Spin’
text: When George Washington was president, our forebears did not wonder what spurred his occasional ghostwriter, Alexander Hamilton, to make a particular argument in the general’s 1796 farewell address. Nor did many voters in 1860 try to deconstruct why Abraham Lincoln’s propagandists chose to present him as a backwoods rail-splitter, which he had not been for a very long time, instead of the well-heeled corporate lawyer he had, thanks to hard work and talent, become.

headline: When Your Child’s Friend Is in Crisis
text: It’s not unusual for teenagers to need adult guidance on caring for their friends who have problems. Though teens are often characterized as being persistently self-centered, or for girls in particular, mean, anyone who spends a lot of time with adolescents can tell you that those stereotypes aren’t fair. Teenagers are devoted to their friends and, more often than not, they will sacrifice their time and comfort to buoy a friend who is sinking.

headline: How the ‘Perfect Storm’ Became the Perfect Cop-Out
text: When a grand jury decided late last month not to indict the two police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Tamir Rice, the 12-year-old whose killing outside a Cleveland recreation center became a cause célèbre of the Black Lives Matter movement, the task of announcing the verdict fell to the Cuyahoga County prosecutor Timothy J. McGinty. McGinty, who is in the midst of a heated Democratic primary race, appeared decidedly unhappy to be handling the case. When he presented himself to the TV cameras on Dec. 28, he shifted from foot to foot and often looked fixedly at his prepared statement. He said he told Rice’s mother that what happened to her son was ‘‘undeniably tragic.’’ Nevertheless, he went on, ‘‘Given this perfect storm of human error, mistakes and miscommunication by all involved that day, the evidence did not indicate criminal conduct by police.’’

headline: Should I Help My Sister End Her Life?
text: I have a 50-year-old sibling with multiple medical conditions (uncontrolled epilepsy, a stroke that left her physically and mentally impaired, paranoid schizophrenia, to name a few) that have left her isolated and miserable. My 80-plus-year-old parents are her caretakers. She has the very best doctors, social workers and therapists — but none can give her a fulfilling life. She calls me crying every night, often threatening to commit suicide, a threat she has tried to make good on dozens of times. I’m struggling to know if I should stop talking her out of suicide and instead give her options for a death with dignity. If she were dying of a terminal illness, the discussion could be more frank. But what of these chronic conditions with no end in sight? Name Withheld

headline: Why Are Corporations Hoarding Trillions?
text: There is an economic mystery I’ve been struggling to understand for quite some time, and I’m not the only one who’s confused: Among financial experts, it is often referred to as a conundrum, a paradox, a puzzle. The mystery is as follows: Collectively, American businesses currently have $1.9 trillion in cash, just sitting around. Not only is this state of affairs unparalleled in economic history, but we don’t even have much data to compare it with, because corporations have traditionally been borrowers, not savers. The notion that a corporation would hold on to so much of its profit seems economically absurd, especially now, when it is probably earning only about 2 percent interest by parking that money in United States Treasury bonds. These companies would be better off investing in anything — a product, a service, a corporate acquisition — that would make them more than 2 cents of profit on the dollar, a razor-thin margin by corporate standards. And yet they choose to keep the cash.

headline: 1941: First 3-Term U.S. President
text: WASHINGTON — President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the first Chief Executive in the history of the United States to be inaugurated for a third term in office, was sworn into office on the Capitol’s veranda at noon today [Jan. 20] and delivered a sixteen-minute inaugural address in which he made plain his belief that the fate of the United States is inextricably tied up with the outcome of the war now raging in Europe. “In the face of great perils never before encountered,’’ the President said, ‘‘our strong purpose is to protect and to perpetuate the integrity of democracy.’’ ‘‘We do not retreat,’’ he said. ‘‘We are not content to stand still.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 21, 1941

In “Elektra,” her latest dance-and-song adventure, which has its United States premiere at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, she mines Greek drama to retell the tale of Sophocles’ Elektra. Her brazen approach to performance, which mixes text, pop songs and vigorous movement, is rarely gentle. “I need to feel like I’m being heard, and I need to know that you’re with me,” she said. “How can I wake you up without looking you in the eyes or touching you?”

headline: Denmark’s New Front in Debate Over Immigrants: Children’s Lunches
text: LONDON — It is being called the “meatball war.”

headline: The Hottest Year on Record
text: Globally, 2015 was the warmest year in recorded history.

headline: 2015 Was Hottest Year in Historical Record, Scientists Say
text: Scientists reported Wednesday that 2015 was the hottest year in the historical record by far, breaking a mark set only the year before — a burst of heat that has continued into the new year and is roiling weather patterns all over the world.

headline: HPV Vaccination Rates Highest Among Hispanic Girls in Poorer Areas
text: Teenage girls living in poorer neighborhoods are more likely to be vaccinated against human papillomavirus, or HPV, than those who live in richer areas, researchers report. HPV is the cause of almost all cases of cervical cancer and some cases of other cancers.

headline: Share Your Thoughts on Recent Terrorist Attacks and Memories of Victims
text: Did you know someone who was injured or killed? Share with us your reflections and feelings as well as memories of those you knew whose path crossed in harm’s way.

headline: Big Snowstorm Forecast Sends a Shiver Up the East Coast
text: New York and New England could be spared the brunt of a snowstorm that meteorologists say is likely to reach the mid-Atlantic Northeast states beginning Friday, but residents of the Washington, D.C., area might not be so lucky.

headline: ‘The Magicians,’ Based on Lev Grossman’s Fantasy Trilogy, on Syfy
text: “The Magicians” — the first novel in Lev Grossman’s fantasy trilogy, and the foundation for the Syfy spinoff starting Monday, Jan. 25, at 9 p.m. — has been simplistically described as “Harry Potter for grown-ups,” if Harry were a clinically depressed Ivy Leaguer unable to confront life without his meds. That sums up Quentin Coldwater (Jason Ralph), who, when first we meet him, has checked out of a hospital and sought refuge with one of the five Narnia-like “Fillory and Further” books that have captivated him since childhood.

headline: 2016 Grammy Awards Performers Include Adele and Kendrick Lamar
text: Adele, Kendrick Lamar, the Weeknd and Little Big Town will be among the performers at the 58th annual Grammy Awards ceremony on Feb. 15, the show’s organizers announced on Wednesday morning.

headline: Sondra Radvanovsky, the Tudor Queen in ‘Maria Stuarda’ at the Met
text: Fresh from her riveting portrayal of King Henry’s ill-fated queen in “Anna Bolena,” an interpretation notable for her coloratura technique and emotive power, the soprano Sondra Radvanovsky turns her attention to “Maria Stuarda,” the second work in Donizetti’s Tudor trilogy. Based on a Friedrich Schiller play that explores the rivalry between Elizabeth I and Mary, Queen of Scots, played by Ms. Radvanovsky, the opera meshes fact and fiction and includes a confrontation in which Mary calls Elizabeth a “vile bastard.”

headline: Watanabe Will Return to ‘King and I’ on Broadway
text: The line of succession for Broadway’s Siamese throne is long this season.

headline: In ‘Quicksand,’ an Opera-Novel Takes a Mysterious Form
text: In general, dances in operas are tacked on: divertissements unrelated to the story. In the premiere of “Quicksand,” an opera-novel told in the form of a mystery by the composer Robert Ashley (who died in 2014), the choreographer Steve Paxton abides by that approach; his movement may color the text, but it doesn’t describe it. He’s keeping the choreography, in his words, “low-key.” Mr. Ashley met Mr. Paxton in the 1960s, and though they worked together, “Quicksand” — a merging of music, light and dance — is considered their only major collaboration.

headline: How the N.B.A. 3-Point Shot Went From Gimmick to Game Changer
text: Larry Bird and Magic Johnson were rookies. Bill Walton’s move to the Clippers — the San Diego Clippers — was making headlines. Some N.B.A. finals games were still being broadcast on tape delay. And the league tried something new: a 3-point shot.

headline: How to Cook Salmon
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: In Pakistan, a Final Push to Wipe Out Polio
text: KARACHI — With nearly all of the rest of the world on the brink of being free of polio, the disease’s persistence in Pakistan has long challenged health experts both inside and outside the country. Last year, the 51 cases of wild poliovirus reported here represented the bulk of all 70 cases reported throughout the world.

headline: G-Eazy, ASAP Ferg and Nef the Pharoah at Terminal 5
text: Vallejo, Calif., is a small city with an outsize hip-hop footprint. For almost three decades, it’s been home to signature stylists like E-40 and Mac Dre, clever rappers who sound different from each other, and from everyone else, too. That’s a lot of history hanging over Nef the Pharoah, the city’s latest prospect, who in November released a bouncy self-titled EP (on Sick Wid It, E-40’s label). He’s a liquid, witty rapper, but not quite as kinetic as his elders — his nasal, lethargically casual vocal presence recalls a young Snoop Dogg.

headline: Ninth Planet May Exist Beyond Pluto, Scientists Report
text: There might be a ninth planet in the solar system after all, and it is not Pluto.

headline: Apps to Manage Passwords So They Are Harder to Crack Than ‘Password’
text: IT became official again this week: We are awful at passwords.

headline: ‘The Eccentrics’ Reveals Offbeat Modes of Being at SculptureCenter
text: In Russia, “eccentric” is a word for circus performer, a figure seen by the writer Walter Benjamin as an avatar of creative deviance. Following Benjamin’s lead, the SculptureCenter curator, Ruba Katrib, has organized “The Eccentrics,” a circuslike exhibition of artworks and performances by an international roster of eight artists that promises to reveal novel, offbeat and liberating modes of being. It opens on Sunday, Jan. 24, in Long Island City, Queens.

headline: 1966: College Students Face Draft
text: WASHINGTON — College students will be drafted beginning next fall unless peace comes in Vietnam, the director of the Selective Service system announced last night [Jan 19]. Lt. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey’s grim statement directly affects the 2.2 million students now holding college deferments. Under present Selective Service policies, college students are merely required to be doing satisfactory work while enrolled full-time at a properly accredited college or university to escape the draft. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 21, 1966

headline: As Supreme Court Clerk, Ted Cruz Made Death Penalty His Cause
text: The memos of Supreme Court clerks evaluating death row petitions usually consist of a brief review of the facts and then a dispassionate legal analysis as to whether the court should hear the case.

headline: A Ninth Planet Once Again?
text: An animation explains the case for the presence of a ninth planet-size object deep in the solar system, beyond the orbit of Neptune.

headline: Kenya Rattled as Shabab Turns Sights on Somalia Military Targets
text: NAIROBI, Kenya — The attackers burst into the Kenyan military base in Somalia before dawn, blasting through the gate with a truckload of explosives.

headline: New Albums From Aoife O’Donovan, Aruán Ortiz Trio, Dr. Lonnie Smith and Others
text: IN THE MAGIC HOUR

headline: Pope Asks Davos Elite to Remember the Poor
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — The power brokers assembled here discuss the marvels and potential of what ever-new software and robots can bring in terms of efficiency and productivity, but the Vatican has issued a more sobering message.

headline: Snipping Apart Dollar Bills, for Art’s Sake
text: The artist Yuken Teruya has sliced and diced Prada shopping bags, McDonald’s sacks, toilet-paper rolls and the front page of The New York Times into lush landscapes; for his upcoming solo exhibition at Pippy Houldsworth Gallery in London, he adds to this running list. Teruya took his X-Acto knives to vintage Monopoly boards, currency and cards, leaves that he collected in autumn and rolled-up wads of American dollar bills, citing an interest in the intersection of nature and value, “in all of its abstract levels.”

headline: With Vigor and Momentum, Donald Trump Urges Iowans to Caucus
text: NORWALK, Iowa — Donald J. Trump basked in the glow of his Sarah Palin endorsement on Wednesday, proclaiming that her support, combined with criticism of Senator Ted Cruz from Iowa’s Republican governor, was a turning point for him in the state ahead of the caucuses.

headline: In Palau, Taking the Bait to Swim With Jellyfish
text: Given the opportunity, who wouldn’t jump into a lake packed with millions of jellyfish — if, of course, you knew they could not sting you?

headline: Lupita Nyong’o and Other Stars Join Oscar Protest
text: Spike Lee clarified his position regarding this year’s all-white Oscar nominees in the acting categories, telling ABC on Wednesday that he never called for a boycott of the ceremony on Feb. 28, and that he and his wife would instead catch a Knicks game that night.

headline: CrossFit Promoter Accused of Defrauding Investors Reaches Plea Deal
text: Joshua B. Newman, a New York entrepreneur charged last year with defrauding investors in several CrossFit training ventures, has reached a plea deal with federal prosecutors in New Jersey.

headline: An Insider Trading Case Heads to the Supreme Court
text: The Justice Department got its wish on Tuesday, at least in a backhanded way, when the Supreme Court unexpectedly granted review of an insider trading conviction.

headline: App Smart | Day Trackers
text: A selection of apps, including Reporter, Instant and Sleep Cycle, that help you log your daily activities.

headline: Video Feature: ‘Quantified Self’ Apps to Help Track Habits and Identify Patterns
text: THIS year, I’m trying to keep better track of my life. That includes tallying how much I exercise, how often I use my phone and how well I sleep. To do all of that, I’ve turned to a trend called “quantified self,” which is essentially using technology to monitor many daily activities. Not surprisingly, I’m relying on a bunch of apps for this.

headline: Chasing Votes for Hillary Clinton Among Iowa’s Undecided and Indifferent
text: NEWTON, Iowa — On the coldest day of winter so far, Cindy Pollard skittered up icy walkways in her white nurse’s sneakers, trying to persuade undecided, indifferent and sometimes hostile voters to caucus for Hillary Clinton.

headline: Squabbles Persist Over Who Should Be at Syria Peace Talks
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The top diplomats from Russia and the United States met in Zurich on Wednesday to reconcile problems threatening to postpone or even scuttle international talks to end the Syria war that are scheduled for next week.

headline: Against Some Scientific Disclosure
text: To the Editor:

headline: Stocks Are Potential Bright Side to Lower Wall St. Compensation
text: It’s bonus day at Goldman Sachs. It also happens to be the day that the Wall Street company reports earnings for the final quarter of 2015.

headline: Supreme Court Ruling Bolsters Ability to Build Class Actions
text: WASHINGTON — In a victory for class-action plaintiffs, the Supreme Court on Wednesday ruled by a 6-to-3 vote that courts may not dismiss lawsuits simply because a defendant has offered to give the lead plaintiff everything he sought. A contrary decision would have allowed companies accused of minor but mass wrongdoing to pick off plaintiffs one by one, frustrating their ability to band together to sue over their claims.

headline: The Fashion Blogger Behind We Wore What
text: Name Danielle Bernstein

headline: Inside the Louise Bourgeois House
text: The recessed, cluttered Chelsea townhouse where this artist lived for decades will soon open for visitors.

headline: A Look Inside the Louise Bourgeois House, Just How She Left It
text: Unlike Paris, where the homes and studios of Auguste Rodin, Eugene Delacroix and Gustave Moreau are on the standard tourist itinerary, New York has a paucity of artist’s house museums. Painters and sculptors in Manhattan have typically inhabited lofts, and when they move on, others take over the spaces. One of the few examples is 101 Spring Street, the Donald Judd house in SoHo, which is open by reservation for tours. A pristine cast-iron building, with sunny rooms that accommodate beautifully installed Minimalist art and Judd-designed furniture, it stands as a shiny, bright masculine yang. At long last, it has its corresponding yin: the recessed, cluttered Chelsea townhouse that was occupied by Louise Bourgeois.

headline: Marco Rubio ‘Super PAC’ Portrays Ted Cruz as Fickle
text: The “super PAC” supporting Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has turned its sights on Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, releasing two ads with companion websites attacking him, including this one, titled “Calculated.”

headline: Lessons From Vermont
text: Sarah Kliff has a very helpful account of Vermont’s attempt to create a state-level single-payer health care system, and why it failed. It’s a bit like the old joke about the farmer, asked for directions, who says “Well, I wouldn’t start from here.”

headline: How to Make Sense of Plummeting Global Markets
text: If you look only at the global economy, and what leading forecasters think it will do in 2016, things look to be in a reasonably solid state. The world economy will grow 3.4 percent this year, economists at the International Monetary Fund projected this week, up from 3.1 percent in 2015. Private sector forecasters mostly have similar expectations.

headline: Guide for Refugees in Germany Mocked as How Not to Instruct Foreigners
text: Faced with the task of integrating hundreds of thousands of newcomers into German society, government agencies, private foundations and the state broadcast network have all been looking for ways to explain the country’s history and traditions to refugees in easily understandable public information campaigns.

headline: Gawker Media Plans to Sell Minority Stake to Investment Company
text: Gawker Media plans to sell a minority stake to the investment company Columbus Nova Technology Partners, a move its founder, Nick Denton, said was driven by the need for funding for growth initiatives, and to bolster itself for a continuing lawsuit brought by Terry Bollea, the wrestler known as Hulk Hogan.

headline: Restore Democracy in Poland
text: To the Editor:

headline: Track Palin, Son of Sarah Palin, Is Arrested on Charges of Punching Girlfriend
text: Track Palin, the eldest child of former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska, was arrested and charged in a domestic violence case in which his girlfriend said he punched her in the head and threatened to fire a rifle, court and police documents said.

headline: Retire the Carriage Horses
text: To the Editor:

headline: Supreme Court Rules Against Kansas Inmates in Death Penalty Case
text: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday against three Kansas inmates whose death sentences had been vacated by the state’s Supreme Court.

headline: Eugenie Bouchard Exits Knowing a Full Comeback Will Take Time
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — In a brief career with a craggy trajectory, Eugenie Bouchard is again on the way up, despite a second-round loss Wednesday night at the Australian Open.

headline: Breaking the Taboo on the Use of Nuclear Arms
text: To the Editor:

headline: Israel Arrests 5 on Suspicion of Planning Attack for Hezbollah
text: JERUSALEM — Israeli security forces have arrested five Palestinian men the authorities said were planning an attack organized and funded by Hezbollah, Israel announced on Wednesday.

headline: Prehistoric Massacre Hints at War Among Hunter-Gatherers
text: The scene was a lagoon on the shore of Lake Turkana in Kenya. The time about 10,000 years ago. One group of hunter-gatherers attacked and slaughtered another, leaving the dead with crushed skulls, embedded arrow or spear points, and other devastating wounds.

headline: Are You Ready for the Cold? Really Ready?
text: Punishing temperatures won’t seem so bad with cozy accessories on hand.

headline: Few Foreign Visitors to U.S. Overstay Visa, Federal Report Says
text: WASHINGTON — A little more than 1 percent of the nearly 45 million foreign visitors to the United States overstayed their work or tourist visas last year, according to a long-awaited report by the Department of Homeland Security.

headline: George Weidenfeld, British Publisher of ‘Lolita’ and London Fixture, Dies at 96
text: LONDON — George Weidenfeld, who fled the Nazi annexation of his native Austria to achieve renown in the salons of postwar London as a publisher, networker and friend of the powerful, died here on Wednesday. He was 96.

headline: Gunmen Attack Bacha Khan University in Pakistan
text: At least 20 people were killed when militants attacked a campus in northwestern Pakistan on Wednesday.

headline: Bill Clinton Warns of ‘Gridlock’ Under Bernie Sanders’s Health Care Plan
text: Bill Clinton acknowledged he was in Senator Bernie Sanders’s backyard as he took the stage Wednesday in New Hampshire.

headline: Congress Calls Martin Shkreli to Testify on Rapid Rises in Drug Pricing
text: Martin Shkreli loves to talk.

headline: Valentino: Fall 2016
text: Fall 2016 designs from Pierpaolo Piccioli and Maria Grazia Chiuri.

headline: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Seeks to Curb Payouts to Bankers Who Go to Washington
text: Big Wall Street banks are pushing back at an attempt by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to ban an executive perk that rewards executives who leave their posts for jobs in the government.

headline: Nike’s Invitation to Climb a Skateboard, and Dover Street Market’s Reopening
text: Escape the cold at Nike SB Garage, a pop-up indoor skate space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where you can hit the decks and try out the pro skateboarder Ishod Wair’s new shoe, the Nike Dunk Low Pro Ishod Wair ($95), which offers a retro-cool silhouette with a flexible rubber outsole for enhanced grippy traction. Sign up at nike.com/events-registration/series for open skate sessions this weekend. At 646 Lorimer Street.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Serbia and Elsewhere
text: Serbia and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Jan. 20, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Serbia, Afghanistan, Pakistan and India.

headline: U.S. Plans Coalition Meeting on Fight Against ISIS
text: PARIS — The United States will convene a meeting next month of defense ministers from 27 countries participating in the fight against the Islamic State to discuss how each member of the coalition could contribute more to defeating the extremist group, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter announced on Wednesday.

headline: Rajat Gupta to Finish Insider Trading Sentence at His Home
text: During Rajat Gupta’s heyday as a globe-trotting management consultant, one of the highlights of January was the World Economic Forum’s annual gathering of global business titans in Davos, Switzerland.

headline: As Water Problems Grew, Officials Belittled Complaints From Flint
text: LANSING, Mich. — A top aide to Michigan’s governor referred to people raising questions about the quality of Flint’s water as an “anti-everything group.” Other critics were accused of turning complaints about water into a “political football.” And worrisome findings about lead by a concerned pediatrician were dismissed as “data,” in quotes.

headline: Senate Blocks Bill on Tougher Refugee Screening
text: WASHINGTON — A bill that would have greatly tightened screening procedures on refugees from Syria and Iraq failed on a procedural vote in the Senate on Wednesday, saving President Obama from another vexing veto scenario on an issue that has divided the country.

headline: Next Installment of ‘Star Wars’ Pushed Back to End of 2017
text: Walt Disney Studios on Wednesday created a large disturbance in Hollywood’s release calendar, delaying the next installment in the “Star Wars” series from May 2017 to December of that year – on a date that Steven Spielberg and Warner Bros. had already staked out for their “Ready Player One.”

headline: Bob Dole Warns of ‘Cataclysmic’ Losses With Ted Cruz, and Says Donald Trump Would Do Better
text: Bob Dole, the former Kansas senator and 1996 Republican presidential nominee, has never been fond of Senator Ted Cruz of Texas. But in an interview Wednesday, Mr. Dole said that the party would suffer “cataclysmic” and “wholesale losses” if Mr. Cruz were the nominee, and that Donald J. Trump would fare better.

headline: Spread of Zika Virus Prompts Travel Advisories
text: Travel warnings about the Zika virus, especially for pregnant women, are very much in the news now, but the germ was discovered more than a half century ago, and you may have already visited places where it flourishes.

headline: Haider Ackermann: Fall 2016
text: Haider Ackermann’s fall 2016 men’s collection.

headline: Castleton Festival to Go on Hiatus
text: The Castleton Festival, which the conductor Lorin Maazel founded in 2009 on his estate in rural Virginia, announced this week that it is canceling most of this summer’s offerings in what festival officials described as a “temporary hiatus” brought on by financial difficulties.

headline: Sending the Trisha Brown Legacy Back Into the World
text: Once upon a time, a choreographer made dances, and extraordinary ones at that. Her works, full of wit and rigor, unfolded on rooftops and rafts and even on the sides of buildings as well as in lofts and galleries, and later on proscenium stages. And then she couldn’t make them anymore.

headline: Five Tips for Curing Winter Skin, From a Cult Facialist
text: The cult facialist Kristina Holey, whose holistic approach to skincare favors healthy habits (eating well, exercising, sleeping) over a medicine cabinet full of topical antidotes, might be the beauty industry’s worst nightmare. Her modus operandi — that there is no universal rule for the skin, and each person requires a unique regimen — rejects the idea of any products touted as a quick fix cure-all. Yet it is this long-term strategy towards skincare that has seen Holey become San Francisco’s most sought-after facialist (she opened her own skincare center in June), with clients also clamoring to see her in Los Angeles and New York, where she works out of the West Village boutique Calliope.

headline: Early-Music Ensembles: Praised as Pure, but Seeking More
text: When the female vocal quartet Anonymous 4 retired last month, it left behind a discography spanning a thousand years of music. But the core of its repertory was medieval music in which, in plainchant passages, the four women’s voices seemed to melt together into one silky, unison line.

headline: Smart Guns and Shifty Politics As Governor Christie Runs for President
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey has been softening his past record on gun controls with each visit to gun friendly states as he vies for the Republican presidential nomination. As rival candidates on the gun lobby’s A-list questioned his devotion to the cause, Mr. Christie reversed his previous support for an assault weapons ban — a position he strongly voiced in his earliest days of politicking for New Jersey office. In another reversal, he vetoed a ban that would have kept the controversial, armor-piercing .50-caliber rifle out of the hands of civilians.

headline: Lesson Plan | Teaching ‘Star Wars’ With The New York Times
text: Are your students “Star Wars” fanatics? Are you?

headline: Review: ‘Dark Net’ Explores the Digital Age’s Toll on Us
text: The scariness of the digital age has been the peg for a number of newsmagazine segments and docu-series, many of them not going, conceptually, much beyond “Can you believe what some people are using the Internet for these days?” “Dark Net,” an eight-part series that begins on Thursday night on Showtime, goes further, using examples of unsettling digital phenomena to ponder larger questions, like whether and how the digital age might be changing us as a species.

headline: Review: ‘London Spy’ Follows an Unlikely Investigator With Love on His Mind
text: It’s hard not to care about a character played by Ben Whishaw, an actor whose nimble intensity has enlivened roles from Richard II, in “The Hollow Crown” cycle, to Q in the Bond movies. But during BBC America’s “London Spy,” a five-episode mini-series (beginning on Thursday) that’s a loopy mix of love story and conspiracy thriller, you may find yourself managing it for long stretches.

headline: Review: On ‘Mad Dogs,’ an Amazon Series, Male Bellicosity Rules
text: “American men, you love to fight,” a supporting female character observes in the very male dark-comic thriller “Mad Dogs,” whose 10-episode first season debuts Friday on Amazon Prime.

headline: Dover Street Market’s (Almost) Overnight Transformation
text: Twice annually, Dover Street Market undergoes what it calls a “New Beginning” — in which elaborate visual displays and new brands are installed, with select departments strikingly reconfigured. Here is how it happens.

headline: Review: Jeremy Pelt’s ‘#Jiveculture,’ Exuding Chemistry
text: “#Jiveculture”

headline: Review: Tortoise Revisits Its Elusive Identity on ‘The Catastrophist’
text: “The Catastrophist”

headline: Russian Strikes in Syria Have Stabilized Assad, Top U.S. General Says
text: BRUSSELS — Russia’s campaign of airstrikes against opponents of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria has stabilized Mr. Assad’s government, America’s top general said Wednesday. That has probably given Mr. Assad a stronger hand to play next week, when negotiations toward a political solution to the conflict will begin in Geneva, American officials said.

headline: New York City Is Set to Adopt New Approach on Policing Minor Offenses
text: New York City is poised to reshape how it treats many so-called quality-of-life offenses, softening its stance toward low-level infractions like public urination and drinking alcohol in public by steering those cases away from the criminal court system.

headline: Did Obama Overstep His Authority on Immigration?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Free Help for Tax Returns
text: Taxpayers have several options for getting free help to prepare and send their income tax return during this year’s filing season, which began on Tuesday.

headline: Review: On ‘Malibu’ Anderson .Paak Takes In All That His Surroundings Offer
text: “Malibu”

headline: Overview of Flint’s Water Crisis
text: Months after the city of Flint, Mich., switched from a Detroit water supply to one from the Flint River, contaminants have sickened people. Residents have filed lawsuits, and the governor has apologized.

headline: In Canada, the 8-Dollar Cauliflower Shows the Pain of Falling Oil Prices
text: OTTAWA — Steamed, sautéed or stir-fried, cauliflower is standard fare on many dinner tables. In Canada, it is a luxury.

headline: Animal Deaths Down and Adoptions Up Amid Reforms at New York Shelters
text: For a place often associated with confinement, suffering and death, the city animal shelter in Manhattan was a pretty happy spot last Friday afternoon, at least in the backyard.

headline: 5 Accused of Stealing Drug Secrets From GlaxoSmithKline
text: Federal prosecutors in Philadelphia said on Wednesday that they had indicted five people, including two research scientists, on charges of stealing trade secrets about drugs to treat cancer and other diseases from GlaxoSmithKline, the British drug giant.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Sarah Palin on Her Son’s Arrest
text: At a Trump rally on Wednesday, Sarah Palin discussed her son Track’s recent arrest on domestic violence charges.

headline: David H. Koch Leaves Natural History Museum Board
text: David H. Koch, a philanthropist who has given millions of dollars to the American Museum of Natural History in New York but whose businesses in energy and other industries have drawn criticism from climate scientists and environmental groups, has left the museum’s board after serving on it for 23 years.

headline: Raf Simons: Fall 2016
text: The fall 2016 designs from Raf Simons, who resigned as Dior’s creative director in October.

headline: Deutsche Bank Announces $7 Billion Yearly Loss as Legal Issues Weigh on Results
text: FRANKFURT — In a surprise earnings announcement, Deutsche Bank on Wednesday evening reported a huge yearly loss of 6.7 billion euros ($7.3 billion) as the cost of past wrongdoing continued to weigh on its earnings.

headline: Bette Midler, Glowin’, Crowin’, Goin’ Strong and Ready for ‘Hello, Dolly!’
text: Bette Midler has never seen “Hello, Dolly!” onstage.

headline: N.Y.C.F.C.’s Patrick Vieira Acknowledges ‘Long Learning Process’
text: For the previous 11 hours, Patrick Vieira had been asked questions. But at the final stop of his daylong media marathon, which included a news conference and a dozen or so interviews, he was the one asking the questions.

headline: Review: ‘The Yid,’ Paul Goldberg’s First Novel, Taunts Stalin
text: Paul Goldberg’s provocatively titled first novel, “The Yid,” is set in the Soviet Union and begins in late February 1953, just as staggering change is about to occur. Only a small part of what the book describes is a matter of record: Joseph Stalin died on March 5 at his dacha just outside Moscow. He spent enough of his final hours unattended to give a vindictive alternative historian some wiggle room.

headline: The Sundance Film Festival Trains Its Sights on the Gun Debate
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Gun violence can be an awkward subject at the Sundance Film Festival. Over the years, the event has helped popularize — some would say glamorize — extreme gun imagery in movies; Quentin Tarantino was incubated and hatched here.

headline: Review: New York City Ballet’s Winter Season Blends Movement and Music
text: In ballet, sight meets sound. When the alchemy is right, this often trivial art takes off into the stratosphere. On Tuesday, New York City Ballet, the world’s foremost specialist in this music-movement fusion, opened its six-week winter season at the David H. Koch Theater with welcome new aspects of aural accompaniment inside the auditorium (the new music director, Andrew Litton, was conducting a program of American scores, admirably) and new aspects of design around the theater’s other spaces (Marcel Dzama redecorated the main upstairs foyer with ostentatious triviality).

headline: Review: Tackling Bach, Debussy and Prokofiev at Spectrum
text: More important than the question of whether Bach should be played on historical or contemporary instruments is the general approach performers bring. The music always needs a buoyant touch and rhythmic vitality, elements missing from a heavy-handed interpretation of Bach’s Sonata for Viola da Gamba and Harpsichord in G (BMW 1027) by the pianist Taka Kigawa and the cellist Eric Edberg on Tuesday evening. The duo performed on modern instruments at Spectrum, a cozy, book-lined space on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

headline: On the Milan Runway, Assembled Fragments and Disconnected Thoughts
text: MILAN — When models start quoting Baudrillard, the creative director at Gucci name-checks Walter Benjamin and Miuccia Prada makes prints depicting Freud in a wrestling match, you know the world is upside down.

headline: Philanthropist Donates to Smithsonian’s African-American Museum
text: The businessman and philanthropist David M. Rubenstein is donating $10 million to the Smithsonian’s National Museum of African American History and Culture, the Smithsonian announced Wednesday.

headline: Flint Water Crisis: Emails Released by Gov. Rick Snyder
text: Michigan's governor released hundreds of pages of emails regarding Flint's lead-contaminated water supply.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Davos Participants Seek Out ‘Stardust’ Moments
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — At the World Economic Forum here, heads of state, billionaire investors and corporate chiefs meet to discuss the state of politics and regulation, and tackle the biggest challenges facing societies globally. This year, they are sending warning signals about the state of the markets.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Sarah Palin, Pakistan, Flint
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Be a French Girl. Or Just Look Like One.
text: “The fog comes on little cat feet,” Carl Sandburg wrote in a 1916 poem, and he might have been talking about Kate Moss slinking around London for the last two decades in her trusty black ballet flats. The shoe itself has a feline cast — it rounds the foot into a pawlike shape — but there’s also something feline about the women, like Ms. Moss, who have popularized ballet flats over the years.

headline: Happy Hour Without the Booze
text: On a recent rainy afternoon over veggie burgers at NeueHouse, the co-working space in the Flatiron district, three Vedic meditators were discussing drink options for a new kind of happy hour they were organizing.

headline: Where Wearable Technology Ends Up (Hint: Not Your Wrist)
text: The junk drawer in my home used to look just like yours, filled with loose change, batteries and birthday candles. But over the last year, a new category of junk has started to accumulate there: wearable devices.

headline: ‘Races of Mankind’ Sculptures, Long Exiled, Return to Display at Chicago’s Field Museum
text: CHICAGO — For decades, the bronzes created by the artist Malvina Hoffman for the Field Museum’s “Races of Mankind” exhibit have had a ghostly afterlife at the institution. Hailed at their unveiling in 1933 as “the finest racial portraiture the world has yet seen” and viewed by millions of visitors, the sculptures were banished to storage in 1969, embarrassing relics of discredited ideas about human difference.

headline: The Many Lives of Limelight
text: “It’s Harry Chapin going into Cat Stevens into the Beatles into James Taylor into Bob Marley, and then around 10, 11 o’clock, Jay Z and Guns n’ Roses escalating the whole vibe,” Stratis Morfogen said on a recent evening.

headline: Treasury Secretary Visits Puerto Rico and Urges Fast Action
text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — On his first official visit to the commonwealth, the Treasury secretary, Jacob J. Lew, said the financial crisis on the island was deepening and he urged Congress to act quickly to give the government the power it needs to restructure all of its debt.

headline: Obama Relaxes Rules for Striking ISIS in Afghanistan
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama has made it easier for the military to get approval for strikes in Afghanistan targeting militias that have sworn allegiance to the Islamic State, according to several government officials.

headline: Crumbling, Destitute Schools Threaten Detroit’s Recovery
text: DETROIT — In Kathy Aaron’s decrepit public school, the heat fills the air with a moldy, rancid odor. Cockroaches, some three inches long, scuttle about until they are squashed by a student who volunteers for the task. Water drips from a leaky roof onto the gymnasium floor.

headline: To Fight ‘Superbugs,’ Drug Makers Call for Incentives to Develop Antibiotics
text: More than 80 pharmaceutical and diagnostic companies from around the world are calling for new economic models to spur development of badly needed new antibiotics and to fight the rising global threat of drug-resistant “superbugs.”

headline: How New York's Shelters Keep Animals Alive
text: The euthanasia rate for animals at three city shelters has plummeted to 13 percent, from more than 60 percent in 2003.

headline: My Sarah Palin Romance
text: As a political journalist, you never forget the first time you stop just covering a politician and start identifying with her. The first time you wed your high-minded vision of what politics should be to a real candidate’s perishable breath.

headline: Ex-Rikers Guard Sentenced to Jail in Attack on Inmate Causing Vision Loss
text: A former New York City correction officer was sentenced to 90 days in jail on Wednesday for beating a Rikers Island inmate, who sustained a broken nose and lost vision in one eye.

headline: Panel Backs Janet DiFiore for New York Chief Judge; Senate Puts Off Vote
text: ALBANY — Everything seemed primed on Wednesday for the Court of Appeals, the state’s highest court, to receive its new chief judge. There were words of praise for the nominee, Janet DiFiore, and a unanimous vote of approval from the State Senate Judiciary Committee.

headline: California Said to Target Exxon in Climate Inquiry
text: California’s attorney general is investigating Exxon Mobil on whether the company lied to the public and shareholders about the risks of climate change, and whether the company’s statements over the years constitute violations of securities laws and other statutes.

headline: Officials Object to Plan to Turn Hart Island Burial Site Over to Parks Dept.
text: It was a vision to beguile many New Yorkers: an all-but-forgotten island in Long Island Sound that a noisy city would transform into its most tranquil park. And there was a concurrent vision for the families of the dead long buried there, on Hart Island: a cemetery now run like a prison would become a place to freely mourn.

headline: Pay Cuts for Top Leaders at Viacom
text: Viacom cut the annual pay for its executive chairman, Sumner M. Redstone, by 85 percent during the 2015 fiscal year, the company disclosed on Wednesday, in the face of growing questions about whether Mr. Redstone, an ailing 92-year-old, should continue in his role at the company.

headline: U.S. Drops Bombs Not Just on ISIS, but on Its Cash, Too
text: WASHINGTON — With sanctions, blacklists and other measures doing little to financially break the Islamic State, the United States has turned to a far simpler tactic to empty the group’s coffers: It is literally blowing them up.

headline: Colleagues Express Disbelief Over Arrest of Doctor With Picture-Perfect Life
text: Dr. David H. Newman seemed to have it all: an impressive post in emergency medicine at Mount Sinai Hospital, a prominent and growing public presence as an expert in health care reform, a wife who is a doctor, two young sons, and a gracious home in the New Jersey suburbs.

headline: Jack Dorsey Juggles Twitter and Square, Both Caught in Downdraft
text: It is not shaping up as a happy new year for Jack Dorsey and his two companies.

headline: A Queens Nun With a Talent for Begging
text: To some of the workers at the Hunts Point Produce Market in the Bronx, it is a familiar sight: a nun or two darting around the concrete loading docks every Wednesday. Sister Elisabeth Anne, 76, has been making the weekly trip to the large industrial market for more than 35 years to pick up food for the older adults at the residence where she lives and works.

headline: Wilkes Bashford, Clothier to Affluent San Franciscans, Dies at 82
text: Wilkes Bashford, a clothier whose eponymous emporium is famous for having dressed affluent, elegance-conscious San Franciscans for the last half-century, died on Saturday at his home in San Francisco. He was 82.

headline: Efforts to Drop Charges Against Cosby Are Meritless, Prosecutor Says
text: A Pennsylvania prosecutor on Wednesday hit back at efforts by lawyers for Bill Cosby to have the criminal charges against Mr. Cosby dismissed, describing their claim that a former district attorney made a promise not to prosecute the entertainer a decade ago as meritless.

headline: Big 5 Teams Celebrate Milestone With Throwback Doubleheader at Palestra
text: PHILADELPHIA — More than 50 years later, the memory remains as clear as ever for Don DiJulia. He will never forget Feb. 20, 1965, when a men’s college basketball game between St. Joseph’s and Villanova was interrupted after the police received a call at halftime saying a bomb had been planted in the stands.

headline: Two Sides of Ted Cruz: Tort Reformer and Personal Injury Lawyer
text: Ted Cruz says his uncompromising purity as a conservative crusader helped propel him to the top of the Republican presidential field. But his history suggests that when the cameras are off, a different Mr. Cruz emerges.

headline: Ettore Scola, Italian Film Director of Satire and Farce, Dies at 84
text: Ettore Scola, a Golden Globe winner and five-time Oscar nominee who was considered among the great directors and screenwriters of Italian cinema, died on Tuesday in Rome. He was 84.

headline: Buffalo Adds Woman to Coaching Staff
text: The Buffalo Bills hired the first full-time female coach in the N.F.L. on Wednesday when Kathryn Smith was appointed their special teams quality control coach.

headline: Michel Tournier, French Novelist Who Fused Myth and Philosophy, Dies at 91
text: Michel Tournier, a French novelist who blended myth and philosophy in prizewinning novels that revisited “Robinson Crusoe,” Goethe’s elf king and the biblical tale of the Three Magi, died on Monday at his home in Choisel, near Paris. He was 91.

headline: Republicans Unseat Mississippi Democrat Who Drew Winning Straw After Race Ended in Tie
text: ATLANTA — First, the re-election bid of State Representative Blaine Eaton II of Mississippi ended in a statistically improbable tie. Then — bizarrely, but in keeping with Mississippi statute — the outcome was decided by a drawing of straws, which he won.

headline: 2 Lawyers Leaving Paul, Weiss to Form Boutique Firm
text: Two prominent lawyers at Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison are breaking away and forming their own litigation boutique with lawyers from other firms.

headline: Film Academy, Under Fire, Is Expected to Take Steps to Improve Oscar Diversity
text: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is expected to announce as early as next week measures aimed at making its Oscar choices more diverse, people briefed on the matter said Wednesday.

headline: Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Is Closing to Become a Ballroom
text: The famed Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Manhattan will close its doors in the coming weeks, and reopen next year as an event space that caters to galas and corporate functions, the building’s owner said on Wednesday.

headline: Trial Explores Whether Towns Discriminate Against Nonmembers of Polygamous Sect
text: PHOENIX — When an unfamiliar car drives into the small neighboring towns of Colorado City, Ariz., and Hildale, Utah, private security agents working for the polygamist sect that dominates the towns ask the local marshals, who act as the police for both towns, to run the license plates to see who is passing through, federal prosecutors said.

headline: Executive in U.N. Corruption Case Pleads Guilty
text: A Chinese-born executive accused of helping to funnel more than $800,000 to a top United Nations official pleaded guilty to bribery on Wednesday, the second guilty plea in a week in the government’s continuing investigation of corruption at the United Nations.

headline: Misnomer on Skates: John Scott, N.H.L. All-Star, Is Neither in N.H.L. Nor a Star
text: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. — The captain of the Pacific Division team for the N.H.L. All-Star Game skated onto the ice of a less-than-half-full minor league arena on Wednesday, wearing a St. John’s IceCaps jersey. The game against the Bridgeport Sound Tigers was just another stop on his wacky road to becoming an N.H.L. All-Star.

headline: Hillary Clinton Dismisses Bernie Sanders’s Criticism of Groups Backing Her
text: BURLINGTON, Iowa — Hillary Clinton on Wednesday defended Planned Parenthood, the Human Rights Campaign and other Democratic-leaning organizations and labor unions that have endorsed her candidacy and that her main opponent, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, has deemed part of the “establishment.”

headline: Among N.F.L. Coaches, a Lack of Diversity Trickles Up
text: The usual scramble of firing and hiring N.F.L. coaches displayed perhaps a touch more impatience this year: Some coaches were dismissed even before the season ended.

headline: Donald Trump Is Forcing Ted Cruz to Rewrite His Playbook
text: WHITEFIELD, N.H. — Ted Cruz did not have to say a cross word about Scott Walker. Rick Perry and Bobby Jindal faded on their own. And when Ben Carson briefly rocketed to the top of the Iowa polls, Mr. Cruz and his team stayed cool, confident that the neurosurgeon’s support would wither.

headline: Filing Alleges Bias at Success Academy Network Against Students With Disabilities
text: Parents of 13 current and former students of Success Academy filed a complaint with the Office of Civil Rights with the federal Education Department on Wednesday, accusing the charter school network of discriminating against students with disabilities by denying them accommodations and in some cases pushing them out.

headline: Central African Republic: Hunger Threatens Population, U.N. Warns
text: Nearly 2.5 million people in the Central African Republic — half the population — are now facing hunger, double the figure from a year ago, the main food aid agency of the United Nations said Wednesday. The agency, the World Food Program, attributed the increase to years of conflict and insecurity that have kept people from tending their fields and livestock, exacerbated by a poor harvest. “This is not the run-of-the-mill emergency,” Guy Adoua, the agency’s deputy director for the country, said in a statement. “People are left with nothing.” The agency called for an emergency cash infusion of $41 million from donor countries to deal with the crisis.

headline: Attorney General Seeks Funding for Tighter Gun Rules
text: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans warned on Wednesday that they would fight President Obama’s attempts to impose tougher gun restrictions in the wake of the San Bernardino shooting, and they accused him of doing an “end run” around the Second Amendment.

headline: Massacre Came as Pakistan University Honored a Hero of Nonviolence
text: The university attacked by the Pakistani Taliban on Wednesday was named for a towering figure in Pakistani history — a nonviolent Pashtun activist who became known as the “Frontier Gandhi” for his advocacy of nonviolent resistance to British colonial rule.

headline: Review: ‘Our Mother’s Brief Affair,’ a Play About Unmoored Lives
text: Every mother is Greta Garbo to her children, at least upon occasion. The woman you were closest to in the world, the one who weaned and wiped you, could suddenly seem so ravishingly remote it was scary. What was really on her mind those nights she tucked you into bed, deliciously lipsticked and perfumed for an evening out?

headline: Amtrak Says New York Region’s Rail Projects Could Cost Up to $23.9 Billion
text: Amtrak officials on Wednesday provided the most detailed public account yet for the projected costs of building a new Hudson River rail tunnel and improving other critical parts of the rail infrastructure in the New York region.

headline: Off-the-Record Discussion
text: THURSDAY PUZZLE — I’ve watched every episode of “L.A. Law” and selected parts of “Perry Mason” on YouTube, so I consider myself to be somewhat of a legal expert. This expertise came in handy today as I tried to solve David Phillips’s crossword about SIDEBARS, because I was able to recognize that, from a totally legal and professional point of view, a SIDEBAR is one of the most efficient ways to inject drama into an otherwise mundane court proceeding, second only to pounding one’s fist on the table and shouting “Objection, Your Honor!” At least on television.

headline: Bernie Sanders Says He Would Defend U.S. ‘Responsibly’
text: Income inequality and greedy billionaires are neither seen nor heard from in Senator Bernie Sanders’s sober-minded new foreign policy ad, “Defend This Nation.”

headline: De Blasio Backer, Convicted of Sexual Abuse, Fails to Show Up for Jail Sentence
text: One of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s leading supporters in New York’s Orthodox Jewish community failed to appear in court this week to begin a 15-day sentence on a previously undisclosed conviction for misdemeanor sexual abuse, and a warrant has been issued for his arrest.

headline: With a New Child, Laying Claim to the Comforts of Home
text: Kayla Medina’s apartment in Harlem, where she lives with her infant son, Kayden, is simple and small. He crawls around their living room floor, his interest shifting among his toys. He will turn 1 in April; Ms. Medina turned 21 this month.

headline: Scarsdale Woman Is Stabbed to Death in Her Home
text: SCARSDALE, N.Y. — A 58-year-old woman was fatally stabbed on Wednesday inside her home in this Westchester County village, the authorities said. A man who also lived in the home, possibly the woman’s husband, was detained by the police, officials said.

headline: Mets Add Antonio Bastardo to Bullpen
text: It was not a splashy move, but the Mets made a ripple in the free-agent waters on Wednesday. They reached an agreement with Antonio Bastardo, a left-handed reliever, on a two-year, $12 million contract.

headline: As Amir Hekmati Sat in an Iranian Prison, Michigan Supporters Kept His Name in the News
text: FLINT, Mich. — After four and a half years in an Iranian prison, Amir Hekmati will return to a community where people he never knew fought to make sure the world knew his name.

headline: Cavaliers, Coming Off a Drubbing, Dish Out Punishment Against the Nets
text: The N.B.A. regular-season schedule presents many challenging markers for every team from October to April, including difficult games on consecutive nights, cross-continental trips and fierce division rivalry games.

headline: Porzingis, Lured by Pump Fake, Learns Lesson as Knicks Prevail
text: It was late on Wednesday night, much later than usual, when Derek Fisher’s postgame news conference finally wound down.

headline: Asian Markets Follow U.S. Stocks Downward
text: HONG KONG — Markets in Asia sank on Thursday, as traders surrendered to the fears that had sent shares tumbling in Japan, Europe and the United States the previous day.

headline: Centenarians Proliferate, and Live Longer
text: WASHINGTON — Move over, millennials. The centenarians are coming.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | brocade
text: brocade • \bro-ˈkad\ • noun and verb

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “The whole system is warming up, relentlessly.”

headline: What to Watch Thursday
text: A man investigates his undercover lover in “London Spy,” BBC America’s latest espionage mini-series. Glenn Frey recounts his time soaring in “History of the Eagles.” And Zach Galifianakis tries to elevate clowning to an art in “Baskets.”

headline: ‘The X-Files’: David Duchovny and Gillian Anderson Return to the Paranormal Beat
text: NORTH VANCOUVER, British Columbia — There they were in the midst of what looked like a spooky old-growth forest (Princess Park, actually, mere blocks from upscale suburban homes here), surrounded by clumps of moss, overgrown ferns and gigantic Douglas firs, looking for clues of yet another allegedly paranormal crime, the kind they used to solve almost every week. They addressed each other, as they always had, by only their last names.

headline: Who Is Leading the South Carolina Polls
text: A look at the latest results for Iowa and New Hampshire, and how this year compares to previous election seasons.

headline: Corrections: January 21, 2016
text: NATIONAL

headline: European Central Bank Says It’s Ready for New Stimulus — but Not Yet
text: FRANKFURT — The European Central Bank’s president, Mario Draghi, issued a stronger-than-expected signal on Thursday that his policy team could step up its stimulus program as early as March in response to stubbornly low inflation and turbulence in the financial markets.

headline: Among North Africa’s Berbers
text: Ferhat Bouda has made it his mission to document his people, the Berbers, whose culture and language have been suppressed over the centuries.

headline: 미래의 창업가 키우는 데 힘 쏟는 미국 대학들
text: 휴스턴 — 1891년에 작성된 라이스대학 헌장을 보면 문학과 과학, 예술을 창달하기 위해 학교를 세웠다고 쓰여 있다. 요즘 라이스대학을 보면 차세대 마크 저커버그를 키워내는 데도 그만큼 많은 힘을 쏟고 있는 것 같다.

headline: Putin ‘Probably Approved’ Litvinenko Poisoning, British Inquiry Says
text: LONDON — In the dank, dark days of November 2006, as Alexander V. Litvinenko, a former K.G.B. officer turned foe of the Kremlin, lay dying in a London hospital, he and his associates composed a deathbed missive to President Vladimir V. Putin.

headline: Self-Driving Cars May Get Here Before We’re Ready
text: SOMETIME in the future — although no one quite knows when — your morning commute may look something like this: Open an app, summon a car and wait for the arrival of a driverless vehicle that will whisk you to work like a ghost chauffeur.

headline: The Republican Establishment Is Losing at Its Own Game
text: A little more than a month ago, Ted Cruz tweeted: “The Establishment’s only hope: Trump & me in a cage match.”

headline: Among North Africa’s Berbers
text: The first day Ferhat Bouda picked up a camera, he found his calling.

headline: Palin, Trump, Cruz and Corn
text: Sarah Palin is really falling apart.

headline: Kentucky’s Bizarre Attack on Health Reform
text: Gov. Matt Bevin of Kentucky is dismantling the state’s highly successful exchange on which people buy private health insurance policies or enroll in Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. His shortsighted and pointless show of defiance against the Obama administration’s health care reforms could harm thousands of people in Kentucky, who may fall between the cracks as the state shifts their coverage from its own exchange, known as Kynect, to the federally run exchange at HealthCare.gov.

headline: The Poisoning of Flint’s Water
text: In November, I was the guest speaker at the American Civil Liberties Union of Michigan’s annual dinner. Before I spoke, the group called to the stage a longtime investigative journalist who had done tremendous work bringing the Flint water crisis to light. His name was Curt Guyette. He, in turn, recognized the scientists, doctors, politician, lawyers and activists who had helped in that quest.

headline: Scalia’s Putsch at the Supreme Court
text: IN his vitriolic dissent last June from the Supreme Court’s same-sex marriage decision, Justice Antonin Scalia accused the majority of having carried out a “judicial putsch.” Justice Scalia should know. He and his four conservative colleagues were then in the process of executing one themselves.

headline: An Important Win in the Supreme Court for Class Actions
text: On Wednesday, the Supreme Court gave an important victory to regular Americans, ruling that companies may not avoid class-action lawsuits by offering to buy off the individual plaintiffs before they can establish a class of similarly harmed people.

headline: America the Unfair?
text: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders don’t agree on much. Nor do the Black Lives Matter movement, the Occupy Wall Street protests and the armed ranchers who seized public lands in Oregon. But in the insurgent presidential campaigns and in social activism across the spectrum, a common thread is people angry at the way this country is no longer working for many ordinary citizens.

headline: Republicans Ignore a Poisoned City
text: EVER since I became a conservative as a teenager growing up in the city of Flint, Mich., I’ve heard again and again from Republican leaders about their commitment to minorities and the poor. Even today, we are told that conservative solutions exist for persistent poverty, for joblessness, for the masses of people, like those in my hometown, who live lives of quiet despair. House Speaker Paul Ryan has been especially eloquent on this point. If only Republicans would get a chance to prove it.

headline: Does Iran Remain a Threat?
text: Despite the accord that reduced its ability to build nuclear weapons, is it still a threat to safety and stability of the region?

headline: Barclays to Scale Back Asia Businesses as Part of Overhaul
text: LONDON — Barclays plans to scale back its operations in Asia, end its physical presence in several countries and eliminate what could be hundreds of jobs in the latest reshaping of its investment bank under a new chief executive, James E. Staley.

headline: News Q’s | 2015 Was Hottest Year in Recorded History, Scientists Say
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “2015 Was Hottest Year in Recorded History, Scientists Say.”

headline: VW Admits Cheating in the U.S., but Not in Europe
text: LONDON — Volkswagen is staking out an aggressive response to its emissions-testing crisis in Europe, where most of the affected vehicles were sold, by essentially saying: We didn’t cheat here.

headline: Viewing Los Angeles Through a Creole Lens
text: The pulse of the train on the tracks sets a rhythm as its passenger cars seem to skim over Lake Pontchartrain in New Orleans. These six miles of nothing but sky above and water below are the gateway into the city by rail. Next come the cemeteries at the edge of New Orleans, and all of a sudden, a day and a half of travel ends at the Amtrak terminal in the business district. I had just completed the first leg of my cross-country journeyby sleeper train, starting in New York, and was beginning the second: a foray into the cultural ties between the Crescent City and California.

headline: In Jersey City, a Room of Her Own
text: Nastasya Tsultsumova arrived in the United States as an exchange student at age 15, spending a high school year in Tulsa, Okla.

headline: Introducing Modern Love: The Podcast
text: Dear readers (and listeners),

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Paid Speeches to Wall Street Animate Her Opponents
text: Nine months after leaving the Obama administration, Hillary Clinton sat on a stage under the life-size model of a blue whale that hangs in the American Museum of Natural History.

headline: Student Question | What Role Does Hip-Hop Play in Your Life?
text: How important is hip-hop to you? How has it helped you understand the world and yourself?

headline: ‘Let the People Rule,’ by Geoffrey Cowan
text: The 1912 presidential contest was the first in which many of the delegates to a party convention were nominated directly by voters in primaries rather than by party insiders in a number of states. Thirteen states held Republican primaries, and Theodore Roosevelt won nine of them. “The right of the people to rule,” he said at Carnegie Hall, is “the great fundamental issue now before the Republican Party.”

headline: Full Report of the Litvinenko Inquiry
text: Findings by Robert Owen, a retired High Court judge in Britain, present the most damning official link between the death of Alexander V. Litvinenko in 2006 and the highest levels of the Kremlin.

headline: Verdasco, Like Others, Finds Defeating Nadal Doesn’t Guarantee Success
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — With Rafael Nadal’s dominance flickering with increasing frequency at major tournaments, more players have won a moment in the spotlight over the past four years by beating him. But each time, the glow quickly dims.

headline: Acupuncture Offers No Benefits Over Placebo for Hot Flashes of Menopause
text: Acupuncture is no more effective for menopausal hot flashes than a sham version of the procedure, a randomized trial has found.

headline: The Right Way to Stretch Before Exercise
text: For generations, gym students were taught to stretch before working out or playing games. Then the practice fell out of favor: Studies seemed to show that such ‘‘static’’ stretching (holding a pose for anywhere from a few seconds to several minutes) temporarily reduces muscular power, weakens athletic performance and increases the risk of injury. So most fitness experts currently advise against static stretches before exercise. But now a comprehensive new review of decades’ worth of research indicates that they might not be such a bad idea after all.
