text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Thursday Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.

headline: Morning Agenda: Asia Markets Succumb to Jitters
text: ASIA MARKETS SUCCUMB TO JITTERS | Markets in Asia sank on Thursday, as traders surrendered to the fears that had sent shares tumbling the previous day, Amie Tsang reports in DealBook.Investor concerns over growth in China and oil prices drove global markets lower on Wednesday, pushing London and Japan into a bear market.

headline: Pravue Cafe and Albanian Grill
text: A restaurant in Ridgewood, Queens, serving Albanian comfort food.

headline: At Pravue Cafe, Albanian Home Cooking in Queens
text: The fries at Pravue Cafe and Albanian Grill taste as if they have taken a tumble in a perfect bowl of ramen and have somehow still emerged crisp. First fried, then baked, they arrive slightly sticky with a truffle glaze and pecorino Romano gone lax in the oven. But the verve comes from Vegeta, a synthesis of salt, sugar, spice and dehydrated vegetables engineered a half-century ago in Yugoslavia.

headline: New York Today: Making It Official
text: Updated 9:23 a.m.

headline: Arts Program Will Commemorate Battle of the Somme
text: LONDON — The Syrian National Orchestra for Arabic Music and Damon Albarn, the artists Yinka Shonibare and Imran Qureshi, and the composer David Lang are among those commissioned to create work for “14-18 NOW,” an eight-month-long arts program that will commemorate the 100th anniversary of the Battle of the Somme.

headline: Poll Watch: What to Make of the ‘Sanders Surge’
text: As Senator Bernie Sanders appears to gain momentum in his race for the Democratic presidential nomination, the breadth and depth of his support remain uncertain.

headline: Ways to Be Free
text: When you grew up in an unmapped, unwired world and find yourself in this one — observing the panic when GPS fails or the extent of online status anxiety — you can’t help wondering if somewhere along the way freedom got lost.

headline: Pearson, Ex-Owner of Financial Times, to Shed 4,000 Jobs
text: Pearson, the troubled British publisher, said on Thursday that it would eliminate 4,000 jobs worldwide as part of a continuing restructuring by the former owner of The Financial Times and The Economist to shift its focus primarily to its international education business.

headline: Rockefeller Foundation to Take Food-Waste Fight to Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — The World Economic Forum suffers from no shortage of lofty goals — its theme two years ago was no less than “reshaping the world” — and the gathering of global power players still lends itself to high-minded ideals.

headline: John Kasich Embraces His Back Story in Congress
text: With Congress so unpopular, most Republican presidential candidates are intent on bashing the institution and its members. Not so with Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, who served 18 years in the House before leaving in 2001 and evidently has fond memories of his Capitol Hill years.

headline: Bob Odenkirk Thinks Other Comedians Are Lousy Critics
text: When you played the lawyer Saul Goodman on ‘‘Breaking Bad,’’ your opinion of him was pretty low. Was there a particular moment or episode when your sense of him as a character shifted? Episode 1, Season 1 of ‘‘Better Call Saul.’’

headline: A Cassoulet Worth the Effort
text: Cooking is not always about simplicity and ease. Sometimes, particularly when it’s cold outside and the dark comes early, what you want in the kitchen is a project, a culinary jigsaw puzzle to solve. There is no greater one than cassoulet.

headline: In the Bahamas, Scuba Diving With James Bond’s Trainer
text: “I taught Sean Connery to scuba dive,” Stuart Cove said with an impish grin. “And I’ve got to be honest: He was petrified.”

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Tech-Firm Snacks
text: Tom writes: I work for a big tech firm that offers its employees free snacks. A colleague of mine thinks it’s acceptable to conceal his favorite snacks behind other items to retrieve them later. I think this is unfair. All of us should have the chance to serendipitously discover a delicious treat.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: Sleep, ‘Dopesmoker’
text: The origin story of ‘‘Dopesmoker’’ sounds like a light-bulb joke co-written by Nancy Reagan and Sisyphus: Three California stoners decide to write a song about how much they love marijuana, but they’re so high that it takes them four years. When they finally deliver the song to their record label, the label refuses to release it. And so the band breaks up without the world hearing their wonderful heavy-metal jam about weed. Don’t do drugs. The end.

headline: Kamasi Washington’s Giant Step
text: On a late October afternoon in South Central Los Angeles, Kamasi Washington was facing what is for him an increasingly familiar problem: making a lot of big ideas fit into a single space, even one as large as the nearby Club Nokia, a rock-star-size venue where he would be performing in December. His recent triple album, ‘‘The Epic,’’ is a nearly three-hour suite for a 10-piece jazz band, backed by a 32-piece orchestra and a 20-person choir. Washington’s show promised to be a typical swirl of activity, a sprawling procession of dancers, musicians, DJs and singers unified by the magisterial sound of Washington himself, a 34-year-old tenor saxophonist who has emerged as the most-talked-about jazz musician since Wynton Marsalis arrived on the New York scene three decades ago.

headline: Let Me Tell You About My Big Baby
text: What happens when a doctor predicts the wrong birth weight?

headline: Bernie Sanders, and Simon and Garfunkel, Put Focus on Voters
text: With the help of the Simon and Garfunkel song “America,” Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has released a powerful 60-second commercial in Iowa that seeks to remind his supporters how far he, and they, have come — and to inspire them anew to caucus for him on Feb. 1.

headline: Daniel Alarcón: By the Book
text: The author of “At Night We Walk in Circles” and “City of Clowns” taught Toni Morrison to 10th graders: “Teaching a book, talking about it with young people, is the best way to fall in love with it.”

headline: Surrogates Add Grudges to Donald Trump’s Match With Ted Cruz
text: As the Republican presidential contest looks increasingly like a two-man race between Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, members of the Republican establishment are left contemplating which candidate it finds more palatable at the top of the ticket.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Ads Diverge on Road to Caucuses
text: One ad, to the humming and harmonies of the Simon and Garfunkel song “America,” shows Americans working, farming and excitedly flocking by the thousands to see Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on the campaign trail. Hope, it projects.

headline: Fire at Ritz Hotel in Paris Stuns the Fashion Crowd
text: PARIS — Something like shock swept through members of the fashion crowd arriving here for the fall men’s wear shows last week when they learned of a fire at the Ritz hotel.

headline: Draft of Inquiry Report on Jimmy Savile Cites Flaws in BBC Culture
text: LONDON — A culture of deference to “untouchable stars,” an “above the law” attitude among members of management and a climate of fear at the BBC allowed Jimmy Savile, the disgraced British television personality, to carry out sexual assaults on children for decades, according to a leaked draft of an inquiry published on Thursday.

headline: Gun Control Groups Say Bernie Sanders Is the Wrong Candidate to Support
text: A centrist organization and two other groups devoted to gun control are denouncing supporters of Senator Bernie Sanders who have been arguing that he has a “strong record against gun violence,” the latest salvo between backers of the Vermont senator and Hillary Clinton on the topic of firearms.

headline: ‘Grease: Live’ Prepares for the Small Screen
text: BURBANK, Calif. — Thomas Kail, the celebrated director of “Hamilton” on Broadway, strode across the Warner Bros. back lot here earlier this month and broke into a verbal tap dance. “Well, hmm, let’s see,” he started to say in response to an impolite query from the person walking next to him (me). “I think that there is always a learning curve. Going first, second, third isn’t easy.”

headline: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Why Use an Old Photo?
text: A reader, Alyssa Pack, wondered about the use of a 14-year-old photograph to accompany a recent news story about a bombing in Jakarta. She called it disappointing and potentially misleading to readers. Ms. Pack added: “There are several photos from the most recent attack, so I do not understand the purpose of using the one from 2002.”

headline: Russian Economy Stumbles as Stocks and Oil Prices Fall
text: The turmoil in global stock markets and the plunge in oil prices are shaking Russia’s economy, already wobbly from being cut off from Western finance by sanctions.

headline: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday — Driving Mr. Dole
text: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican presidential nominee in 1996, at a campaign rally in Amana, Iowa, in September of that year.

headline: ‘Cats’ Will Return to Broadway This Summer
text: “Cats,” one of the most successful musicals of all time, is returning to Broadway this summer.

headline: ‘Night Vale’ Creators to Start New Podcast Platform
text: The world of “Welcome to Night Vale,” the popular fiction podcast made up of dispatches from a surreal Southwestern town, is getting bigger.

headline: Another Win for a Player Getting in Touch With Her Japanese Roots
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Naomi Osaka liked to think she had a universal appeal to the crowd that watched her 6-4, 6-4 win over 18th-seeded Elina Svitolina at the Australian Open on Thursday afternoon.

headline: A Toast to a 100-Year-Old Spy Catcher
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Bracing for a Blizzard, From the Deep South to the Northeast
text: WASHINGTON — At a grocery store on H Street, not far from the Capitol, the shelves were nearly picked clean of water bottles by Thursday afternoon. Lawmakers, fearful of the coming blizzard, scurried to catch early flights out of town. And the region’s mass transit system took the rare step of announcing it would shut down for the weekend.

headline: 10 Sundance Movies With Heat
text: A look at select films screening at the Sundance Film Festival.

headline: Airbnb Takes Its Case to U.S. Mayors Conference
text: WASHINGTON — Chris Lehane, Airbnb’s head of global policy, appeared on Thursday before hundreds of American mayors with an enticing pitch: Team up with us to collect millions of dollars in taxes for you.

headline: Rick Owens: Fall 2016
text: Fall 2016 looks from Rick Owens.

headline: 1891: King Kalakaua Is Embalmed
text: The body of the late King Kalakaua was embalmed at San Francisco last night, and to-day the remains were placed in a metal casket hermetically sealed, and conveyed to the mortuary chapel in Trinity Church, where they will be guarded by United States soldiers. The remains will not lie in state, and will not be exhibited to the public. At one o’clock on Thursday afternoon funeral services will be held at Trinity Church. King Kalakaua’s body will be taken from San Francisco by Rear-Admiral Brown to Honolulu in the United States cruiser Charleston. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 22, 1891

headline: Republicans Take Aim at Marco Rubio With Negative Ads
text: Senator Marco Rubio, who is placing only as high as third in most state and national polls, has been the target of more attack ads than any other candidate — more than $20 million worth since the first week in December, a huge sum that may help explain why the Florida senator is struggling to gain ground on his rivals for the Republican nomination.

headline: Catholic Church’s Hold on Schools at Issue in Changing Ireland
text: DUBLIN — The Roman Catholic Church has lost the battles over divorce, contraception and gay marriage in Ireland. But it still wields what some parents call the “baptism barrier”: influencing admission to public schools.

headline: In Britain, New Creative-Business Website Draws Support
text: LONDON — The fashion folk were arriving in Paris for the men’s wear shows, and Prime Minister David Cameron was at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland. But the lights were still burning Wednesday night at 10 Downing Street for a gathering of Britain’s design talent and to toast the introduction of Creative Entrepreneurs, a website intended to help what it calls “creative people” become successful.

headline: Daily Report: Mr. Dorsey’s Companies Go on a Wild Stock Market Ride
text: It isn’t easy being a paper billionaire.

headline: Editing a Gmail Inbox Trip Bundle
text: Q. I generally like the way Gmail Inbox collects all the messages related to travel, and groups them together so I have my flight information, hotel and rental car under one heading on my Android phone. However, I noticed that for a coming trip, the collected information has me listed in the completely wrong hotel. I don’t know how this happened, but can I get rid of the incorrect information in the Trips grouping?

headline: Evidence of Burial Ground Is Discovered in East Harlem
text: For nearly a decade, keepers of Harlem’s historical flame have insisted — in the face of official skepticism — that a significant antebellum landmark lay beneath an enormous bus depot near the Harlem River.

headline: Kolor: Fall 2016
text: Kolor presents looks for fall 2016.

headline: Kelly Zutrau of the Band Wet Has Plenty to Say
text: The band Wet is obsessed with endings. “I think we better quit while we’re ahead,” the songwriter and singer Kelly Zutrau announces on the single “You’re the Best.” But this is only the beginning of the road for this moody New York and Massachusetts electro-R&B trio. After building buzz last year with a barrage of immaculate singles and appearing on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon,” the band will release its debut album, “Don’t You,” on Friday, Jan. 29, on Columbia Records. It will also tour the United States and Europe, with stops at the Bowery Ballroom on Jan. 28 and Rough Trade in Brooklyn on Jan. 29; unannounced major festival dates are looming on the horizon.

headline: ‘The Body of an American’ Visits Battle Zones of the Field and the Heart
text: One body you won’t see in the seats for “The Body of an American,” Dan O’Brien’s play at the Cherry Lane Theater starting Feb. 10, is its main subject and inspiration, the Canadian war reporter and photographer Paul Watson. Not because Mr. Watson, 57, is dead or incapacitated — he has cooperated happily with Mr. O’Brien’s requests for documents and recordings from his work and life, and he participates willingly in post-show talk-backs when he can.

headline: Lincoln Center Festival Announces Summer Season
text: The Lincoln Center Festival announced Thursday that its summer lineup would include the familiar and the new, including Noh theater, Shakespeare, music by Steve Reich, ballet, and, for the third time, appearances by Goran Bregovic, a Balkan musician and composer, and his Wedding and Funeral Orchestra.

headline: Snowy Gridlock in Washington
text: Slick streets caused problems for drivers and pedestrians in Washington on Wednesday as snowfall paralyzed traffic in the evening.

headline: Winter Storm Aftermath: Live Updates
text: The Northeast is recovering from a severe weekend snowstorm. The latest updates.

headline: Lleyton Hewitt Ends Aptly: Sprinting, Cursing, With a Few Tears
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was finally time to go for Lleyton Hewitt, and although it might have been time to go rather sooner, who could begrudge him this?

headline: Assessing the Road to the Syrian Peace Talks
text: UNITED NATIONS — Diplomats have been working nonstop this week to set the groundwork for Syrian peace talks that were scheduled to, but will not, begin on Monday in Geneva. On Wednesday, Secretary of State John Kerry and Russia’s foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, met in Zurich to discuss the matter, but the meeting broke up inconclusively. On Thursday, Mr. Kerry said that the talks would take place soon, delayed by a day or two, but that the rivals would not sit in the same room. It was a stark measure of the gulf between them.

headline: Brooklyn Rider Gets a New Cellist
text: One-fourth of the innovative string quartet Brooklyn Rider will soon change: Eric Jacobsen, its cellist, plans to leave to concentrate on conducting, the group said on Thursday. He will be replaced by Michael Nicolas, a classmate of his at the Juilliard School who has played with other groups dedicated to new music, including the International Contemporary Ensemble

headline: Ted Cruz Mines Donald Trump’s Twitter Feed for Policy Shifts
text: Senator Ted Cruz, who is scrambling to come up with ways to fend off sustained attacks from Donald J. Trump on his policies and personality, has been digging around in the archives of Mr. Trump’s Twitter feed.

headline: As Jeb Bush Struggles, Some Allies Blame His ‘Super PAC’
text: When Jeb Bush and his allies began helping the “super PAC” supporting him raise more than $100 million last year, his bid for the Republican nomination seemed like a safe bet. But as Mr. Bush’s campaign continues to lag, his backers are increasingly turning their frustrations over his floundering candidacy on the group, Right to Rise, and its inability to influence the race.

headline: Activists, Journalists and Celebrities: China’s Televised Confessions
text: A look at some men and women whose confessions of crimes were aired on Chinese state television in recent years.

headline: At Lemaire, Tailoring With a Sense of Ease
text: The fall/winter 2016 men’s show drew inspiration from portraits of craftsmen and workers in the early 1900s.

headline: Review: ‘Youngblood,’ an Urgent Novel About the Iraq War
text: Matt Gallagher’s 2010 memoir, “Kaboom: Embracing the Suck in a Savage Little War,” grew out of a popular blog he wrote while stationed in Iraq for 15 months, beginning in 2007. By turns thoughtful and irreverent and darkly funny, that book possessed an electric immediacy — a you-are-there sense of what it was like to be a grunt in the hot desert sands outside Baghdad, hunting for I.E.D.’s and bomb factories, negotiating with local sheikhs and frightened civilians, and grappling with the absurdities of military bureaucracy.

headline: At Raf Simons, Americana With a Dark Side
text: For his first men’s show since exiting Dior, the designer was inspired by “Twin Peaks” and “The Breakfast Club.”

headline: China Uses Foreigners’ Televised Confessions to Serve Its Own Ends
text: BEIJING — For seven years, the young Swedish man had directed a nongovernmental organization in Beijing that offered legal aid to Chinese citizens in trouble. Now he was a captive of China’s legal system, forced in police detention to speak on video about his so-called crimes.

headline: 1941: U.S. Lifts Embargo on Russia
text: WASHINGTON — In a surprise move late tonight [Jan. 21], the State Department announced the lifting of President Roosevelt’s ‘‘moral embargo’’ against the Soviet Union by which American manufacturers were prevailed upon not to ship airplanes, aeronautical equipment and materials essential to airplane manufacture to nations resorting to unrestricted aerial warfare against civilian populations. There is a catch remaining, however, in the fact that, although the ‘‘moral embargo’’ has been lifted against Russia, all the articles covered by the embargo are now subject to the export license system. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 22, 1941

headline: Below the Line: Designing ‘The Martian’
text: The secret to building a believable-looking Mars on screen? Rocks, plenty of rocks.

headline: Works Sighted: Ursula Le Guin on the Oregon Occupation
text: Ursula Le Guin, the author of the famous “Earthsea” series and a longtime Oregon resident, was displeased with The Oregonian’s coverage of the armed occupation of the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge. In a letter to the editor of the paper, she wrote:

headline: Donald Trump or Ted Cruz? Republicans Argue Over Who Is Greater Threat
text: WASHINGTON — With Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz battling for the Republican nomination, two powerful factions of their party are now clashing over the question: Which man is more dangerous?

headline: Kevin Spacey an Unusual Davos Suspect
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — President Obama may not be here at the World Economic Forum, shaking hands with fellow dignitaries as the snow flurries swirl. But another American president — albeit a fictional one — has been a talk of the town this week.

headline: Key Findings From the Litvinenko Report
text: A summary of the report by Robert Owen, a retired High Court judge in Britain, on the killing of Alexander V. Litvinenko.

headline: Video Review: Chevy Volt Impresses With Tech, Design and Driving Pleasure
text: THE concept of the first Chevrolet Volt was simple — drive 40 miles or so on battery power alone and then continue the journey with a gas-powered generator. In short, driving to Duluth could be a drop-of-the-hat decision. From Anchorage.

headline: Iggy Pop and Josh Homme Team Up for ‘Post Pop Depression’
text: LOS ANGELES — “Now that you’re all greased up, how about ‘Lust for Life’?” Iggy Pop said in a voice that was part Midwestern twang, part grizzled prospector to his new band as they rehearsed at a North Hollywood studio. Although it was Mr. Pop’s first time singing with the group, which had been preparing on its own, the mood shifted quickly from tension to elation. After each song, Josh Homme of Queens of the Stone Age, who assembled the musicians, asked Mr. Pop if he wanted to wrap up, but Mr. Pop kept calling for more: first new songs and then oldies from “The Idiot” and “Lust for Life,” his two late-1970s collaborations with David Bowie. Mr. Pop, 68, wore a dark, patterned shirt, baggy black pants and sandals. He had started the rehearsal seated, conserving his energy, but by the end he was strutting.

headline: Kent State Professor Investigated for Possible Ties to ISIS
text: An associate professor at Kent State University in Ohio is under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation over possible involvement with the Islamic State.

headline: How Much Should a University Have to Reveal About a Sexual-Assault Case?
text: Five years ago, the United States Department of Education got serious about addressing campus rape. In a 19-page “Dear Colleague” letter that was sent to almost every American college and university, the department reminded institutions of their obligation, under the federal law known as Title IX, to protect students from sexual violence. Universities that failed to take “prompt and effective steps” to investigate and adjudicate allegations of sexual assault, the letter warned, risked losing millions of dollars in federal funding. Most institutions took heed and adopted the policies laid out by the department.

headline: Dresses Our Brides Have Worn
text: A selection of wedding day looks from brides recently featured in our announcements.

headline: Guantánamo Detainee Refuses Offer of Release After 14 Years in Prison
text: WASHINGTON — Three Guantánamo detainees were slated to leave the American prison in Cuba this week after about 14 years in captivity. But early Wednesday morning, only two were willing to board the plane.

headline: Sarah Palin’s Facebook Fans Say Backing Donald Trump Is Disingenuous
text: Sarah Palin made her return to national politics this week with a rousing endorsement of Donald Trump, praising the billionaire developer for his penchant for “going rogue” and lashing out at Republicans who say he is not sufficiently conservative.

headline: High-Rise Living Linked to Lower Survival After Cardiac Arrest
text: The higher the floor you live on, the lower your chance of surviving a cardiac arrest, according to a new study.

headline: ‘Dear Yeti’ and ‘The Thing About Yetis’
text: When I was growing up, the Yeti — who back then went by the more formal and forbidding name “abominable snowman” — was a creature capable of stirring up serious fear. Like the Loch Ness monster, this gigantic people-eating being actually existed, we children knew. There were, predictably, adult doubters. That made the question of whether he was merely mythical a topic every curious child had to investigate. My own research resulted in a habit of mind I’ve carried with me all these years, swinging between a creeping horror at all the unsettling supernatural realities most adults are too thick-headed to even acknowledge, and that feeling that comes after a good debunking — a mixture of emotional comfort, intellectual pleasure and condescending pity aimed at the still benighted myth-believers.

headline: Lydia R. Diamond’s ‘Smart People’ Begins Previews at Second Stage
text: Lydia R. Diamond, whose “Stick Fly” was seen on Broadway in 2011, dives again into thorny territory in “Smart People,” which begins previews Tuesday, Jan. 26, at Second Stage Theater. Set just before President Obama’s first election, the play explores the romantic interactions and careers of four racially diverse characters, all with ties to Harvard University.

headline: Platonic, Until Death Do Us Part
text: Please check out the newly launched Modern Love: The Podcast.

headline: The Beauty Parlors of Bangladesh
text: Dhaka, Bangladesh — EVERY winter, I return here to my hometown, and every year, I feel a little shabbier. This time, when I was meeting a few old school friends at a neighborhood cafe, I finally understood why: the blow-dry. Everyone else had one. Everyone else had gone to the beauty parlor, and I hadn’t.

headline: Building the Future in Israel
text: JERUSALEM — Dizengoff Street in Tel Aviv is always bustling. Youngsters, families and tourists fill its shops, cafes and bars. On Jan. 1, this boulevard became the site of another terrorist attack on Israelis. First, two young men were gunned down in a bar; then, as he fled the scene, the terrorist killed a taxi driver. Several others were injured.

headline: Former Academy President Says Film Industry Needs More Diversity
text: LOS ANGELES — A former president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Thursday suggested in an unusual open letter to the entertainment industry that calls for an Oscar boycott be superseded by a broad effort to hire “African-Americans, Hispanics, Asians, women, LGBTs, the disabled and all under-represented groups.”

headline: A Pinot Noir From Argentina That Stands Out in a Sea of Malbecs
text: MAINQUÉ, Argentina — The flat, dry Río Negro Valley on the northern end of Patagonia won’t strike anybody as a glamorous wine region. For one thing, apple and pear orchards, along with platoons of poplar trees, far outnumber grapevines. For another, the restaurants, hotels and the usual camp followers of the winemaking life are nowhere to be found.

headline: Dov Charney Argues in Court for His Return to American Apparel
text: Dov Charney, the colorful ousted founder of American Apparel, made a last-ditch effort to wrest back control of the company on Thursday, accusing former partners of stealing away his multimillion-dollar empire and declaring that his new alliance with investors was the only way to save it.

headline: Marco Rubio, After Hitting Chris Christie, Is Suddenly All Too Glad to Go at Jeb Bush
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. – Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has directed much of his fire on the campaign trail in recent weeks at Gov. Chris Christie, using town halls in this state and in Iowa to unfurl a long list of the New Jersey governor’s deviations from conservative orthodoxy.

headline: How Symantec Let Bad Math Lead to a Shaky Deal
text: If Benjamin Disraeli had been an investor, he might have been credited with saying “Lies, damned lies and M.&A. math” instead.

text: When you learned about genes in high school, chances are it went something like this:

headline: Hsin Wang’s “De-Selfing” Series
text: The photographer uses faceless subjects and vivid symbolic props to capture the melancholy of heartbreak.

headline: Haunting, Beautiful Images That Capture the Melancholy of Heartbreak
text: After ending a serious relationship six years ago, the photographer Hsin Wang was left questioning not just the partnership but also herself: What did she do wrong? What could she have done differently? What was wrong with her?

headline: Lindsey Graham Says Nominating Donald Trump or Ted Cruz Would Be ‘Death’ of the Party
text: Unleashing perhaps the sharpest Republican criticism of the party’s top presidential contenders, some Senate Republicans on Thursday said they doubted whether Senator Ted Cruz of Texas could win the general election.

headline: Italy’s Famed Palio Horsemen Decline Royal Invitation
text: ROME — When Her Majesty calls, the commoners hasten? Not necessarily.

text: How far would you go to follow your moral beliefs if they conflicted with the laws of the state?

headline: Claire Danes Joins Cast of ‘Dry Powder’ Off Broadway
text: Claire Danes, taking a break from battling America’s enemies and her own demons in “Homeland,” will return to the New York stage this March in “Dry Powder,” a new play about the excesses of the American economy. She and Hank Azaria will join John Krasinski, whose casting had already been announced, in the comic drama written by Sarah Burgess.

headline: LeBron James Is So Luminous, Yet So Trapped by the Public’s Glare
text: With each locational move, celebrated or decried, the baggage has become a heavier burden. Glass has covered more and more of LeBron James’s basketball house.

headline: Jeb Bush’s Brother, Quiet So Far, Could Re-emerge In February
text: NASHUA, N.H. — To W., or not to W., that is the question.

headline: Cuomo Picks Maria Vullo as State’s Top Financial Watchdog
text: After a monthslong delay, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday named a new top financial regulator for New York State, nominating Maria T. Vullo, a prominent litigator with ties to his administration.

headline: ‘Nice Try!’ Is Not Enough
text: Among the most-uttered phrases of my generation of parents have to be these: “Great effort!” “Nice try!” “I can tell you worked so hard!”

headline: Parents in Tow, Finding a Charming and Cheap Corner of Panama
text: The first Panamanian I met promptly handed me a baby.

headline: A Public Health Crisis: ‘The People of Flint Deserved Better’
text: To the Editor:

headline: De Blasio Presents $82.1 Billion Budget
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio presented his proposed budget for New York City on Thursday mostly devoid of new broad liberal initiatives that have been the hallmark of his tenure, underscoring a recognition that the city may be headed for an economic downturn.

headline: Vibrant Lives of Afghan TV Crew, Erased in a Taliban Bombing
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — One was a young graphic designer planning a wedding. Another was an editor who made documentaries in his free time and dreamed of winning an Oscar. A third employee, whose child died of an illness last year, often posted pictures of his surviving child on Facebook in hopes of a brighter future.

headline: The Republicans’ Downward Spiral
text: To the Editor:

headline: Saul Leiter’s Fashion and Documentary Work
text: The photographer is the subject of a new retrospective, which opens tomorrow in London.

headline: A Prolific New York Photographer Comes Back Into Focus
text: “You could almost say he had a lifetime of being continually rediscovered,” says Margit Erb, the director of the Saul Leiter Foundation. Leiter, who died in 2013, just shy of his 90th birthday — had a varied seven-decade career, and gained his most significant recognition in the last years of his life, with the 2006 publication of his book “Early Color.” “I think his rise back to fame was because people just couldn’t help stumbling over and over him, and realizing that the world needed to know him,” Erb says.

headline: Zika Virus May be Linked to Surge in Rare Syndrome in Brazil
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — A mosquito-borne virus that has been linked to severe brain damage in infants may be causing another serious health crisis as well, Brazilian officials and doctors warn: hundreds of cases of a rare syndrome in which patients can be almost completely paralyzed for weeks.

headline: The Past Haunts Oxford Debate Over Rhodes Statue
text: LONDON — High above a main thoroughfare in the city of Oxford, in an alcove framed by twirly columns, a statue of Cecil John Rhodes, the archimperialist who shaped Britain’s empire and the destiny of its far-flung subjects in Africa, peers down inscrutably on the people below. If you weren’t looking for it, you might miss it.

headline: Marco Rubio Steps Up Attacks On Ted Cruz, Calling Him a Flip-Flopper
text: BROOKLINE, N.H. – Senator Marco Rubio declared Thursday that his Senate colleague Ted Cruz “is not who he says he is,” challenging Mr. Cruz’s sincerity and calling him a flip-flopper.

headline: Nepal Police Fire on Madhesi Protesters, Killing at Least 3
text: KATHMANDU, Nepal — The police fired on ethnic Madhesi protesters in eastern Nepal on Thursday, killing at least three of them in the latest flare-up of political tensions over Nepal’s Constitution.

headline: Is a Single-Payer Health Insurance Program Feasible?
text: To the Editor:

headline: Database Tracks ‘Tigers and Flies’ Caught in Xi Jinping’s Corruption Crackdown
text: Two days after taking control of the world’s most powerful political party in November 2012, Xi Jinping warned his fellow Chinese Communist Party members that their six decades of rule was in jeopardy because of what he saw as endemic corruption eating away at the party’s authority and effectiveness.

headline: Saoirse Ronan’s Red-Carpet Looks
text: At events, Ms. Ronan displays both mature silhouettes and whimsical touches.

headline: Fired Police Chief and 2 Others Sue, Charging Racial Bias in Maryland
text: WASHINGTON — A fired black police chief and two black officers on Maryland’s Eastern Shore filed a civil rights lawsuit in federal court in Baltimore on Thursday, alleging the kind of Jim Crow-era racial discrimination that “most Americans would have believed unthinkable in the second decade of the 21st century.”

headline: Saoirse Ronan of ‘Brooklyn’ Masters Minis and Mixed Prints
text: The Irish-American actress Saoirse Ronan received her first Oscar nomination at age 13, and now, at a positively ancient 21, she’s having another breakout year.

headline: Pete Wells’s Most Read Restaurant Reviews
text: Some of the restaurant reviews that have provided the most feedback.

headline: Where Virtual Reality Takes Us
text: Groundbreaking films selected from the Sundance Film Festival explore a range of topics and new approaches to nonfiction, 3D storytelling.

headline: De Blasio Vows Better Coordination as New York Prepares for Snowstorm
text: One year ago, as New York braced for what many experts said would be one of the worst winter storms ever to hit the city, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo decided to shut down the subway system for the first time in its 110-year history because of the threat of snow.

headline: Review: ‘Aferim!’ Traverses an Unforgiving Romania in the 1800s
text: Do you need another reason to be mad about the Oscar nominations? Well here’s one, expressed as tradition demands in the form of a hashtag: #WhataboutAferim! “Aferim!” — the title translates more or less as “Attaboy!” — is Radu Jude’s sublime new feature, a funny and brutal costume drama with a potent contemporary kick. Officially submitted for consideration as Romania’s official entry in the best foreign-language film sweepstakes, it was omitted from the final list of five nominees.

headline: Cow Is Captured by the Police After Running Loose in Queens
text: The cow in Queens was confused but determined.

headline: Mustafa Koc, Leader of Turkish Conglomerate, Dies at 55
text: ISTANBUL — Mustafa Koc, a prominent Turkish businessman who succeeded his father and grandfather in running one of the world’s largest conglomerates, Koc Holding, died here on Thursday. He was 55.

headline: Hillary Clinton Knocks Bernie Sanders on Iran
text: INDIANOLA, Iowa — With Senator Bernie Sanders’s domestic message of tackling income inequality giving him momentum here, Hillary Clinton sought Thursday to shift the conversation to foreign policy, portraying her rival as inexperienced and ill-equipped to address the firestorms erupting in the Middle East.

headline: Husband of Scarsdale Doctor Is Charged in Her Fatal Stabbing
text: SCARSDALE, N.Y. — Robin Goldman was a doctor who made a career caring for children, and a teacher who showed young doctors how to do the same. But her own children said it was her role as mother that she seemed to covet most.

headline: Yohji Yamamoto: Fall 2016
text: Yohji Yamamoto’s fall 2016 show.

headline: Pacino Leads ‘China Doll’ to Broadway Profitability
text: “China Doll,” a critically panned but commercially successful new David Mamet play starring Al Pacino, has recouped its $3.7 million investment costs.

headline: Review: ‘Prescription Thugs,’ a Confessional Documentary on Substance Abuse
text: Even before a “do as I say, not as I do” twist costs it all credibility, “Prescription Thugs” is a not very good documentary about a very important subject.

headline: Rate of Birth Defect of Abdominal Wall Increasing, C.D.C. Says
text: A serious birth defect is appearing in maternity wards with increasing frequency, and experts do not know why, federal researchers reported on Thursday.

headline: Review: Vanessa Williams, Strong and Steady, Without Taking Chances
text: Vanessa Williams operates in so many arenas, it has always been difficult to figure out who she really is — beyond being an attractive, disciplined, highly competent singer and actor who seems equally comfortable in front of a camera, in a recording studio and on the stage. In her 90-minute concert on Wednesday evening at the Appel Room, which opened Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series, the persona she projected was a hard-working, self-possessed entertainer with a clear perspective on her show business lineage.

headline: Marc-André Hamelin Gradually Ups the Ante at Carnegie Hall
text: In a delightfully perverse bit of programming, the esteemed pianist Marc-André Hamelin opened his Carnegie Hall recital on Wednesday evening, after a hero’s welcome from the audience, with Mozart’s unassuming Sonata in C (K. 545) — in the composer’s words, “a little piano sonata for beginners.”

headline: U.S. Tightens Visa Rules for Some European Visitors
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Thursday announced changes to a visa-waiver program that would make it harder for travelers to enter the United States from Europe if they had dual citizenship from Iran, Iraq, Sudan or Syria, or had visited one of those countries in the last five years.

headline: N.F.L. Playoffs: How the Four Conference Championship Teams Match Up
text: 3:05 p.m. Eastern, CBS. Line: Patriots by 3.

headline: Review: Wet Ink Ensemble Pays Tribute to Anthony Braxton
text: A marching tune that dissolves into frenzy, a big-band jamboree with an ethereal voice hovering over it: The dense, wild, yet artfully controlled tribute to Anthony Braxton at National Sawdust on Wednesday evening bore a striking resemblance to his dense, wild, yet artfully controlled music.

headline: Frank Lloyd Wright House in Los Angeles Will Be Auctioned
text: A 1,200-square-foot house that Frank Lloyd Wright designed to perch on a Los Angeles hillside will be auctioned next month, with most of its contents sold separately.

headline: Review: ‘Martyrs,’ a Slashing Remake, Centers on Two Friends
text: For those who care deeply about the provenance of their entertainment (and I am sometimes among them), the filmmaking brothers Kevin and Michael Goetz describe their new project, “Martyrs,” as a “reimagining” of Pascal Laugier’s 2008 original of the same name. Without seeing the earlier movie, I can’t comment; but after enduring this one, I can only wonder why the brothers would cop to any creative input at all.

headline: This Time, Cheaper Oil Does Little for the U.S. Economy
text: WASHINGTON — It has been a truism of the American economy for decades: When oil prices rise, the economy suffers; when they fall, growth improves.

headline: 36 Hours in Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic
text: More than simply a base for the beaches, this energetic city combines a vibrant night life with graceful, centuries-old buildings.

headline: The Italian Artist Enrico Baj at Luxembourg & Dayan
text: “Enrico Baj” at Luxembourg & Dayan is a hoot and an eye-opener. Surveying about 16 years of works in several modes, the exhibition reintroduces the Italian artist Enrico Baj (1924-2003) to New York after an absence of three or four decades. This townhouse gallery is overflowing with his works, which confirms quite emphatically that there is more to postwar Italian art than the relatively pure abstraction of artists like Lucio Fontana, Piero Manzoni and Alberto Burri.

headline: Elisabeth Moss and Boyd Holbrook’s Sundance Tips and Truths
text: Among the most anticipated titles in competition at the 2016 Sundance Film Festival, kicking off today and running through Jan. 31 in Park City, Utah, is “The Free World,” an atmospheric drama from first-time filmmaker Jason Lew. The film stars Boyd Holbrook as a man wrongfully imprisoned for a grisly crime he didn’t commit who, upon his release, meets an equally scarred woman (played by Elisabeth Moss of “Mad Men”) who again turns his life upside down. The two actors and friends are no strangers to Sundance — Holbrook first attended in 2011 with the drama “Higher Ground,” directed by Vera Farmiga, and Moss made her first trip in 2013 for the Sundance Channel series “Top of the Lake.” Here, they share a few things they’ve learned along the way.

headline: Ann Veronica Janssens Casts Strong Beams at Bortolami
text: In this exhibition, the artist’s first solo show in America, six works display Ms. Janssens’s gift for manipulating light and texture.

headline: Freeport-McMoRan Battles the Oil Slump
text: For a look at the damage that the plunging price of commodities — especially oil — is inflicting on the global economy, consider the plight of the venerable Freeport-McMoRan.

headline: Here’s How an Artist Plays the Stock Market
text: In her first Manhattan solo exhibition, Sarah Meyohas inventively recycles the genre of the artist performing live in a gallery. Wearing her own elegant design of a businesswoman’s suit, with gold pinstripes on sheer gray fabric, Ms. Meyohas sits at a chic, all-glass desk in the middle of 303 Gallery. Hanging on the gallery walls around her are 10 blank white canvases.

headline: Walking the Walk in Hamilton’s Old Stomping Grounds
text: Jimmy Napoli is not throwing away his shot.

headline: Dana DeGiulio and Molly Zuckerman-Hartung Make an Emphatic Statement in ‘Queen’
text: Two painters, long based in Chicago, have moved to New York, and “Queen,” their joint exhibition at Lyles & King, is a dramatic statement signaling their arrival. This is Dana DeGiulio’s first show in New York; Molly Zuckerman-Hartung, who was  in the last Whitney Biennial, had a solo here in 2011. For both, however, this is a notable group of works.

headline: A Step Toward Measuring California’s Water
text: One of the biggest problems facing California during its drought has been its failure to accurately measure water use, especially by farms. New regulations adopted by the state’s water board on Tuesday are a big step toward a solution.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump Open Up Strong Leads in Iowa, Poll Shows
text: Senator Bernie Sanders and Donald J. Trump have opened up solid leads in Iowa less than two weeks before the state’s caucuses kick off the 2016 presidential nominating contests, according to a poll released Thursday.

headline: And You Thought You Loved Broadway
text: Stories and photos from some of the several thousand enthusiasts set to attend the first BroadwayCon in New York.

headline: Money Grows on Anniversary Trees
text: My daughter surprised my husband and me with an awesome 25th anniversary party. On her invitation, she asked guests to give money toward our second honeymoon instead of gifts. All gave generously. We know our daughter meant well, but we are so embarrassed. My husband wants me to return the money with notes of apology. But my friend says, “Why steal people’s joy in giving?” I don’t know what to do.

headline: Review: ‘Tosca,’ From NYCO Renaissance, Puts a Grand Ambition to the Test
text: Seldom has so much ridden on a single production of Puccini’s “Tosca.” After months of legal wrangling over the fate of the New York City Opera, which filed for bankruptcy protection in late 2013, a group called NYCO Renaissance won approval for its plan to reorganize the company. It began the effort Wednesday night with the opening of a six-performance run of “Tosca” at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center.

headline: Dries Van Noten: Fall 2016
text: The fall 2016 men’s collection from Dries Van Noten.

headline: Brady vs. Manning
text: On Sunday in Denver, Tom Brady and Peyton Manning will face off in the N.F.L. playoffs for the fifth and possibly final time. Here’s a look at their previous postseason meetings.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Big, Baggy Pants
text: Volume has been a big theme at the men’s shows this season, with several collections featuring oversize silhouettes and exaggerated proportions. Big fur coats popped up in London, and already throughout the first two days of Paris Fashion Week, designers including Y/Project and Raf Simons have shown extra-large knits and coats with long, trailing sleeves. But perhaps the most practical interpretation of volume is evident in slouchy pants — which this season have been cut wide through the legs. At Rick Owens, the baggy style (complete with cargo pockets) resembled that of a ’90s raver. Christophe Lemaire deftly balanced his creased-front trousers with tailored coats, while Dries Van Noten paired a double-breasted blazer with generous trousers. And at Gosha Rubchinskiy, sweatpants — worn high, à la Al Bundy — came with a tucked in T-shirt and military shirt. Finally, we may just see the demise of the bare ankle in 2016.

headline: Ted Cruz Goes Local in Latest South Carolina Ad
text: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is appealing to potential voters in South Carolina’s Midlands region in a new advertisement called, simply, “Midlands.”

headline: Britax Car Seats Recalled After Handle Breaks
text: Britax Child Safety is recalling about 71,000 child car seats in the United States because the carrying handle may break, allowing the infant carrier to be dropped, the company reported on Thursday in a regulatory filing.

headline: Review: Dark Suspicions in Jumps and Gestures in ‘The Winter’s Tale’
text: WASHINGTON — Christopher Wheeldon’s “The Winter’s Tale” — the first ballet to dramatize that Shakespeare play — achieves an extraordinary amount. Movingly, over three acts, it takes us on a great arc of emotion and experience, capturing the play’s themes of death and regeneration, hostility and reconciliation. When it takes liberties with aspects of the story, it does so persuasively. Its five leading roles — three for women, two for men — are marvelously distinct, while never seeming like copies of other roles in the repertory.

headline: Events That Led to Flint’s Water Crisis
text: Timeline of the critical moments leading to the public health emergency.

headline: Review: David Parsons Shares the Stage at Joyce Theater
text: This season, David Parsons shares the wealth — or, at least, the stage of the Joyce Theater — by including dances by two former company members: “Train” (2008), by Robert Battle, now the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater — a percussive jolt of a dance, powered by raw, manic athleticism; and the world premiere of “Almah,” by Katarzyna Skarpetowska, a subtle look at her Polish roots.

headline: New Biggest Prime Number = 2 to the 74 Mil ... Uh, It’s Big
text: The largest known prime number, newly discovered, is almost five million digits longer than the previous record-holder.

headline: A Multitude of Fans, With a High Regard for Broadway
text: THE intense global and commercial nature of contemporary pop culture fandom is catching up with Broadway, and with it comes people like the 19-year-old Helen Fredstam, who arrived from Sweden this week to meet face to face with those who share her passion.

headline: U.S. Presses for Haiti Runoff Vote Amid Fears of Violence and Fraud
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — After spending more than $33 million on a widely discredited election in Haiti, the United States has been pressing the country’s leaders to go ahead with a presidential runoff election this Sunday, despite a growing chorus of warnings that the vote could lead to an explosion of violence.

headline: Comedy Listings for Jan. 22-28
text: For news about comedy, including critical commentary: nytimes.com/arts. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Theater Listings for Jan. 22-28
text: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Alexander Litvinenko and the Banality of Evil in Putin’s Russia
text: Today, a retired British High Court judge named Robert Owen published a 328-page report on the 2006 death in London of Alexander Litvinenko, a former agent of Russia’s Federal Security Service, the F.S.B. Nine years after Litvinenko went bald and wasted away in a London hospital bed, from poisoning with a rare radioactive isotope, Owen’s report found that there was “strong circumstantial evidence of Russian state responsibility” and that the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, and the head of the F.S.B. likely sanctioned the murder.

headline: At the Outsider Art Fair, the Creative Impulse Is in Its Raw Glory
text: Now in its 24th year, the fair features works by familiar names like Henry Darger as well as lesser-known artists.

headline: Court Rejects a Bid to Block Coal Plant Regulations
text: In a significant victory for President Obama, a federal appeals panel on Thursday rejected an effort by 27 states and dozens of corporations and industry groups to block the administration’s signature regulation on emissions from coal-fired power plants while a lawsuit moves through the courts.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Bernie Sanders, Alexander Litvinenko, Flint
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: 139 Years Ago: American Museum of Natural History Opens Its Permanent Home
text: The titanosaur that clomped into the American Museum of Natural History last week has big footprints to fill, and not just those of the Barosaurus it booted.

headline: Movie Listings for Jan. 22-28
text: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Jamie Dimon’s Compensation at JPMorgan Chase Rises 35%, to $27 Million
text: JPMorgan Chase paid Jamie Dimon, its chairman and chief executive, 35 percent more in 2015 than the previous year’s compensation package, which was only narrowly approved by shareholders.
