headline: Rape by Strangers
text: Late last year, a Brooklyn judge sentenced a 26-year-old man, Dexter Bell, to a minimum prison term of 100 years for raping four women in the course of one week during the spring of 2013. In each instance, Mr. Bell had approached his victim in late afternoon or early evening, briefly initiating conversation before dragging her into an alleyway or stairwell and waging his assault. The B12 bus route between Crown Heights and Canarsie was a preferred corridor for his predations; his youngest victim was 15.

headline: An American Designer Takes Cerruti Back to Its Roots
text: PARIS — It was both a new beginning and a return to the past for the designer Jason Basmajian, who presented his first collection for Cerruti 1881 on a dark, rainy Friday afternoon in a showroom off the Place Vendôme. “At least it’s not snowing,” said one of the attendees as he shook the rain from his expensive-looking blazer, a reference to the snowstorm working its way up the East Coast that many of the Americans here for men’s fashion week seem to be obsessing over.

headline: Some Charges Against Former Penn State Officials Thrown Out
text: A Pennsylvania appeals court on Friday threw out some of the more serious criminal charges against three high-ranking former Penn State administrators whose handling of the Jerry Sandusky child molestation scandal continues to be a flash point for the state’s flagship university.

headline: How Cynthia Rowley, Fashion Designer, Spends Her Sundays
text: To judge from the society pages, the fashion designer Cynthia Rowley and her husband, Bill Powers, seem to be out on the town six days a week. But on the seventh day, the couple downshifts (slightly) into the rhythms of family life. Which is to say, “We do extreme activities,” said Ms. Rowley, 57, for whom family means her husband, a 48-year-old writer and art dealer, and two school-age daughters, Kit and Gigi. If your idea of unwinding is racing go-karts or singing Iggy Pop songs, then let them be your relaxation counselors. If not, try to hang on until the rocket returns to home base, a house in the West Village.

headline: Sundance Officially Sidesteps Oscar Controversy, but Its Opening Film Doesn’t
text: PARK CITY, Utah — The Sundance Film Festival, which has long championed diversity, both behind cameras and in front of them, did its best on Thursday, the festival’s opening day, to stick to its knitting and avoid getting drawn into the #OscarsSoWhite controversy.

headline: Pentagon Chief on Turkey, ISIS and Asia
text: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Friday, Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said that he wanted to see Turkey do more in the fight against the Islamic State. He also discussed peace in Asia.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Is One Victory From Downhill Skiing Record
text: CORTINA D’AMPEZZO, Italy — Elite female ski racers, coaches and technicians sip cappuccino on the sun-drenched deck of the Rifugio Duca d’Aosta lodge while gazing in awe at the Schuss, the most harrowing section of Cortina’s Olympia delle Tofane downhill course.

headline: Chris Christie to Return to New Jersey to Prepare for Snowstorm
text: Residents of New Jersey who have been missing Gov. Chris Christie during his presidential bid now know what it takes to bring him home: the threat of a big snow.

headline: Workhorses
text: The photographer Julie McGuire captured images of the carriage horses of New York City. A mayoral proposal under consideration could significantly change the industry.

headline: Central Park Carriage Horses, Steady as They Go
text: After Mayor Bill de Blasio announced a plan this week to reduce the size of the Victorian-era carriage-horse industry and relocate carriage horses to Central Park, virtually the only parties involved not heard from were the horses themselves. As ever, they maintained a dignified silence amid the hubbub.

headline: Takata Airbag Flaw Linked to 10th Death; 5 Million More Vehicles Recalled
text: Federal safety regulators on Friday said that a man had died in late December when an airbag made by Takata exploded in the vehicle he was driving.

headline: Talking Media With The Times’s New Media Columnist, Jim Rutenberg
text: The Times has a new media columnist. Jim Rutenberg, who has been the chief political correspondent for The Times Magazine, will fill a role that has been empty since the death of David Carr last Feburary.

headline: C.D.C. Issues Travel Alert for 8 More Locations Over Zika Virus
text: Federal health officials on Friday added eight destinations to the list of those to which pregnant women should not travel in order to avoid infection with the Zika virus, which has been linked to brain damage in newborns.

headline: What Donald Trump’s Retweets Reveal
text: Donald Trump’s Twitter account has long been famous for its creative spelling and less creative insults. Now it’s rapidly building a reputation for something else: endorsing the work of bigots.

headline: Popcast: Tropical House Movement
text: Ben Ratliff and Michaelangelo Matos discuss the genre.

headline: Mexican Politician Is Freed From Jail but Must Stay in Spain
text: MEXICO CITY — Humberto Moreira, the Mexican politician who was arrested last week in Madrid on suspicion of laundering money, was released from jail on Friday but must remain in Spain and surrender his passport, a judge from Spain’s National Court ruled.

headline: Academy Board Endorses Changes to Increase Diversity in Oscar Nominees and Itself
text: LOS ANGELES — Confronting a fierce protest over a second straight year of all-white Oscar acting nominations, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said on Friday that it would make radical changes to its voting requirements, recruiting process and governing structure, with an aim toward increasing the diversity of its membership.

headline: The Bartender Bob Quiz
text: Mr. Bozic, the legendary Fanelli’s bartender, was known for his outlandish exploits, usually self-reported. They couldn’t possibly all be true. Or could they?

headline: After Last Call: A Bartender Trades SoHo for Serbia to Reclaim His Mansion
text: If you’ve heard of Bartender Bob Bozic, then you’ve heard the stories.

headline: Givenchy: Fall 2016
text: Givenchy’s fall 2016 men’s collection.

headline: Robo-Advisers for Investors Are Not One-Size-Fits-All
text: Since the last major stock market plunge, back in 2008 and 2009, a new type of investment adviser has arrived on the scene.

headline: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley Cut Chiefs’ Pay
text: Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley have both cut the pay packages of their chief executives after a year when Wall Street was challenged by increased regulation and market turmoil.

headline: U.S. and Allies Weigh Military Action Against ISIS in Libya
text: WASHINGTON — Worried about a growing threat from the Islamic State in Libya, the United States and its allies are increasing reconnaissance flights and intelligence collecting there and preparing for possible airstrikes and commando raids, senior American policy makers, commanders and intelligence officials said this week.

headline: Popcast: The Rise of Tropical House
text: -Listen to this week’s podcast| Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

headline: Presidential Candidates, Silent on Presidential Power
text: DONALD J. TRUMP has declared that as president, he would bring back waterboarding “and more” as options for interrogating terrorism suspects. But anti-torture laws forbid that. Does he believe the Constitution would empower him, as commander in chief, to override those limits?

headline: After Six Years, Marianne Boesky to Close Uptown ‘Experiment’
text: When Marianne Boesky opens an exhibition on Tuesday that pairs works by Donald Moffett with a series of pieces by the Arte Povera artist Pino Pascali, it will be the final show in her space on East 64th Street.

headline: Why the Surge in Merger Litigation Fizzled
text: The takeover litigation boom has ended.

headline: Interview: The Directors Behind a Mapplethorpe Documentary
text: PARK CITY, Utah — They got their start in New York in the 1980s, when they performed in nightclubs as a rock disco group called the Fabulous Pop Tarts. They directed “Party Monster,” the 2003 film about Michael Alig, club kid turned murderer. They produce “RuPaul’s DragRace.”

headline: Haiti Postpones Presidential Runoff as Violence Rises
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — A runoff election to choose the next president of Haiti was delayed on Friday, less than 48 hours before it was to take place, as protesters who expected a rigged outcome began to block roads and burn voting centers.

headline: Review: Chelsea Handler Chats Up Racism, Marriage and More
text: If you let someone with a talk-show background make documentaries, what you get, apparently, are talk-show-like documentaries — ones that ramble and lack focus and are more akin to visiting with a topic than to making a point about it.

headline: Kansas Court of Appeals Voids Restrictive 2015 Abortion Law
text: In a split decision, the Kansas Court of Appeals on Friday held that the state Constitution, like the federal one, protected a woman’s right to an abortion and affirmed a lower court order blocking enforcement of a restrictive 2015 law.

headline: U.S. May Put Forces at Iraqi Bases in Effort to Retake Mosul
text: PARIS — American commanders are considering whether to establish a presence at Iraqi military outposts and bases north of Baghdad ahead of a looming fight against Islamic State militants in Mosul, defense officials said Friday.

headline: At Dries Van Noten, Psychedelic Cues Meet Military Tailoring
text: The designer was inspired by the graphic designer Wes Wilson’s ’60s posters, synonymous with the peace movement of the time.

headline: New Suspect in Paris Attacks Is Detained, Belgian Officials Say
text: PARIS — The Belgian prosecutor’s office announced on Friday that it had detained a new suspect in the attacks in Paris and had released one who had been previously detained. But it said it would still require the man who was released to appear before a judge and limit his activities.

headline: True Scandal of Deflategate Lies in the N.F.L.’s Behavior
text: John Leonard is a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who roots for the Philadelphia Eagles, listens to sports talk radio when he is exercising, and teaches a course called Measurement and Instrumentation. When the Deflategate story broke after last year’s A.F.C. championship game between the New England Patriots and the Indianapolis Colts, he found himself fixated on it, yearning to dig into it from a scientific point of view.

headline: Gainsbourg and Birkin, Fearless on Film at Lincoln Center
text: “Charlotte?”

headline: The Timeshare Hard Sell Comes Roaring Back
text: For more than 25 years, Mary Ann Gutierrez, 77, has spent several weeks a year at on the southern shore of Lake Tahoe, Calif., often playing host to her children and grandchildren at one of two timeshare units she owns.

headline: What We’re Reading
text: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Opposing Factions Take to Facebook in Oregon Wildlife Refuge Dispute
text: PRINCETON, Ore. — As more people beg the armed antigovernment protesters who took over the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge here three weeks ago to go home, the protesters this week embarked on a new quest: a search for allies.

headline: Cavaliers, No. 1 in the East, Fire Coach David Blatt
text: The Cleveland Cavaliers own the best record in the Eastern Conference and are one season removed from appearing in the finals, but no jobs are ever safe in the coaching profession. The Cavaliers made that clear on Friday afternoon by firing Coach David Blatt in an organizational shake-up three weeks before the All-Star break.

headline: Snow Starts to Spread Across the Country
text: As the East Coast prepared for a major winter storm, many parts of the United States were already being blanketed by snow.

headline: On Set Videos
text: Behind the scenes of T Magazine’s photo shoots with some of the biggest names in entertainment, fashion, design — and photography.

headline: Evening Hours | Honoring Young Opera Stars and Celebrating the Winter Antiques Show
text: Plus: Storefront Academy Harlem’s reception and a party for conservationists.

headline: T’s Fashion Videos
text: With on-camera interviews, behind-the-scenes footage and exclusive access to fashion designers and insiders, T Magazine explores the vast world of fashion.

headline: With Calm and Experience, John Kasich Connects in New Hampshire
text: WOLFEBORO, N.H. — At a Rotary Club meeting in Laconia, N.H., on Thursday, a woman confided that she feared whether the United States would be safe for her children and grandchildren, citing dangers like the Islamic State.

headline: At Louis Vuitton, an Ode to Paris for Fall 2016
text: The designer Kim Jones celebrated the City of Light with his fall/winter 2016 collection for the French fashion house. Many models wore berets.

headline: Four Killed in Saskatchewan School Shooting
text: OTTAWA — Four people were killed and an unknown number were injured in a school shooting in a small town in northern Saskatchewan on Friday, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police said.

headline: Donald Trump Blasts Ted Cruz Using the Senator’s Own Words
text: Fighting neck-and-neck in the Iowa polls with Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, Donald J. Trump has gone negative, with a 60-second advertisement assailing Mr. Cruz over a hot-button issue with conservatives in Iowa: immigration.

headline: ‘Art From the Holocaust’: The Beauty and Brutality in Forbidden Works
text: BERLIN — When Nelly Toll was 8 years old, during World War II, she rewrote the Cinderella fairy tale with a feminist twist. Instead of Prince Charming, a powerful princess invited Cinderella to live in her castle and enjoy a pianist performing in a sun-drenched room.

headline: Berluti: Fall 2016
text: Berluti presents men’s wear looks for next fall.

headline: Abortion Opponents Rally in Washington
text: Anti-abortion activists took part in a March for Life event near the National Mall on the anniversary of the decision in Roe v. Wade.

headline: Review: John Epperson Steps Out, Leaving the Diva at Home
text: One thing we’ve learned from the Superman myth is that the Man of Steel has a mild-mannered alter ego, Clark Kent, who few suspect has any connection to that heroic crusader. A similar relationship exists between the drag actor, singer and pianist John Epperson and his brilliant, brassy creation Lypsinka, one of the greatest creatures to emerge from the New York club scene.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Spotted
text: The cat family doesn’t change its colorsbut the fashion world is in a playful mood with one of its most popular patterns: the leopard print. It’s intriguing to see all the variations of black and gray, some of them with an overlay of subtle color. One wearer highlighted her coat with creative details, such as a gold-bronze envelope bag; a necklace that blended with the coat, and a color cast of pale pink and aqua; and leopard-print fingerless gloves. Perhaps surprisingly, this fashion lover works in investment banking; her personal style of dress is her hobby.

headline: Review: ‘Elektra’ Runs Wild, With Ann Liv Young
text: It’s hard to imagine Ann Liv Young and company doing what they did on Wednesday night more than once, let alone eight times, the length of their run at New York Live Arts in Chelsea. The brutal rawness and immediacy that we’ve come to expect from Ms. Young, a divisive performer and choreographer, reaches new heights — or newly disturbing depths — in her “Elektra,” which had its United States premiere alongside its even rowdier companion piece, “Elektra Cabaret.”

headline: Review: ‘The Book of Disquiet,’ Opera as One Man, With Films
text: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — O.K., opera lovers, try this one on for size: No one sings live. The only two vocal numbers are rendered on film by a Portuguese fado singer. The lone figure onstage, apart from the small orchestra, speaks throughout. The drama is all internal and mostly philosophical.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Academy Awards, Donald Trump, N.F.L.
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Photos of the Day: Serbia and Elsewhere
text: Serbia and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Review: ‘A Ride on the Irish Cream,’ Erin Markey’s Tale of an Odd Affair
text: “Huh?”

headline: Jan. 22, 2016 — Photos of the Day
text: Photos from Serbia, Ukraine, India and the United States.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘Dirty Grandpa’ Features Robert De Niro on the Prowl
text: Dan Mazer’s crude, mindless “Dirty Grandpa” is like watching a friend’s mediocre improv troupe do an extended spring-break sketch. And your friend just happens to be Robert De Niro.

headline: Review: Daniel Wohl’s ‘Holographic’ Is Performed for the First Time
text: Unsurprisingly, in a digital age, multimedia performances have become pervasive at both uptown and downtown spaces. While contemporary works are most often accompanied by visuals, the standard repertory is not immune: A coming series at the 92nd Street Y will offer multimedia takes on Beethoven violin sonatas, among other pieces.

headline: Review: ‘The Boy,’ in Which a Doll May be Alive, or the Heroine May Be Mad
text: A creepy doll and a creepy house are the main ingredients of “The Boy,” a small-cast horror movie that spends a lot of time building itself into a psychological thriller, only to veer in a more literal direction at the end. It still has enough scary moments to satisfy horror fans, but you’re left wondering whether it might have been more disturbing had it stayed on its original path.

headline: Review: Keanu Reeves Undertakes an Investigation in ‘Exposed’
text: “Exposed,” starring Keanu Reeves, opened on Friday in the 23rd of 25 theaters in a New York City multiplex, with little fanfare and no screenings for critics.

headline: Julien Duvivier, a Gallic Auteur at Home, and Jacques Feyder, One Abroad
text: Perennially ripe for rediscovery, Julien Duvivier (1896-1967) was a prolific if uneven filmmaker with a five-decade career that included a short stint in Hollywood and encompassed a variety of genres.

headline: Philips Halts Sale of Controlling Stake in LED Business
text: Philips, the Dutch electronics giant, said on Friday that it had terminated an agreement to sell a controlling stake in its automotive and LED components business because of regulatory concerns raised in the United States. A group led by GO Scale Capital, an investment fund sponsored by GSR Ventures of China and Oak Investment Partners, agreed in March to acquire an 80.1 percent stake in the Philips unit, called Lumileds, for as much as $2.9 billion. Philips combined the lighting and LED components operations into a stand-alone company in 2014. Philips said in October that the closing of the deal was “uncertain” after the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, an interagency body that includes representatives from the Treasury and Justice Departments, raised “unforeseen concerns” about the deal. GO Scale Capital has offices in Beijing, Hong Kong and California. It has said that its goal is to “scale up its investments in China for global markets.”

headline: Fears About China’s Economy Fester at Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — At the World Economic Forum here, chief executives and investors are blaming China for a slump in global markets.

headline: Steven Moffat Leaving ‘Doctor Who’ in 2017
text: After six seasons of overseeing the exploits of a centuries-old alien adventurer, Steven Moffat plans to move on to other parts of the space-time continuum.

headline: Anger in Michigan Over Appointing Emergency Managers
text: LANSING, Mich. — In the spring of 2013, Detroit was groaning under the weight of its troubles. It had accumulated billions in debt, was riddled with crime and had seen much of its affluent tax base disappear. A former mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, was convicted of racketeering and fraud.

headline: Storage of Records of Background Checks Shifted After Last Year’s Security Breach
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Friday said that the Defense Department would take over the storage of records from federal background checks, part of an overhaul prompted by a colossal cybersecurity breach at the Office of Personnel Management.

headline: In Case of Blizzard, Do Nothing
text: In the winter of 1985 my hometown, Buffalo, was engulfed in a blizzard — not an uncommon occurrence for the region, which is justly famed for epic snows. But this was a big one, and the city’s blustery Irish-American mayor, Jimmy Griffin, was at pains to persuade people to stop trying to go about their business as conditions deteriorated. He urged Buffalonians to “relax, stay inside and grab a six-pack,” which must be the best advice any elected official ever gave the public in an emergency situation.

headline: On The Road (Personal and Trivial)
text: Just a note on radio silence: I’ve been traveling — back home yesterday, and then basically fleeing the New York area, moving up a family-related car trip so as not to get trapped by snow. Destination safely reached, but bandwidth very limited, so no posts, musical or otherwise, today.

headline: Community Gardens Imperiled by New York’s Affordable Housing Plans
text: Apart from a colorful hand-painted sign, there is little to suggest that the Mandela Community Garden in Harlem, a lot piled with pieces of pavement and bounded by graffitied walls and a chain-link fence, is a garden at all. The volunteers who pulled up the concrete had made plans for the spring, however: to pepper the dirt with wildflower seeds, make sculptures from the rubble and turn the lot into a verdant little oasis.

headline: Google Pays Britain $185 Million to Settle Back Taxes
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Google on Friday agreed to pay 130 million pounds, or about $185 million in back taxes to Britain, making it the latest United States technology company to settle claims that it does not pay its fair share of taxes in Europe.

headline: Judge Orders Medical Examination of Sumner Redstone
text: A California judge has ordered the ailing 92-year-old media mogul Sumner M. Redstone to undergo a medical examination, a major development in the continuing legal battle over his mental competence.

headline: 2 Women Hurt in Robbery at Hotel Near J.F.K. Airport
text: A woman who had traveled to New York with her daughter was shot and her daughter injured after they were robbed outside a hotel near Kennedy International Airport, the authorities said on Friday.

headline: Their Boss Stays on the Sideline, but Obama Aides Tilt to Clinton
text: WASHINGTON — The two leading Democratic contenders for president are competing to wrap President Obama in a tight embrace. He is hugging only one of them back.

headline: Biking Through a Snowstorm in Washington
text: Follow the Times video journalist A. J. Chavar as he takes a bike ride to the Capitol as a blizzard took hold of Washington on Friday.

headline: Mosquito-Borne Zika Virus Found in 3 New York State Patients
text: State health officials said on Friday that three people in New York State, including one from Queens, tested positive for Zika, a mosquito-borne virus that has prompted concern as it has spread rapidly, mostly in Latin America and the Caribbean.

headline: The Oscars and Hollywood’s Race Problem
text: WHEN we talk about diversity, or the lack thereof, we refer to it as “a problem.” This or that industry, organization or group has a gender problem or a race problem or some other kind of diversity-related problem. We identify the problem and discuss it, exhaustively, often contentiously, because the problem is significant, pervasive, and for those of us who are most affected, the problem is personal.

headline: Sarah Palin, This Is What PTSD Is Really Like
text: AS a veteran, I want politicians and public figures to try and understand what military deployment is like, and to relate to my experiences. But I’m not sure I want Sarah Palin weighing in.

headline: UConn Undaunted by Uneven Start (It’s Not March Yet)
text: STORRS, Conn. — In the $40 million basketball practice center at UConn, there are subtle and more obvious reminders of the Huskies’ most recent men’s basketball glory: a giant banner commemorating the 2014 national championship team, and the folding chairs scattered throughout the gym taken from that year’s Final Four.

headline: Who Needs Assassins When You’ve Got Hackers?
text: Moscow — A BRITISH inquiry announced this week that Alexander V. Litvinenko, a Russian security officer turned defector who died in a London hospital of polonium poisoning in 2006, was “probably” murdered on the instructions of President Vladimir V. Putin. That’s little surprise. For more than eight years the world has suspected that the Kremlin was behind the assassination. (Just as surely, Mr. Putin has denied his responsibility. His spokesman Dmitri Peskov denounced the inquiry as a “quasi investigation” and an expression of the “elegant British sense of humor.”)

headline: Clues Emerge on Robert Levinson, C.I.A. Consultant Who Vanished in Iran
text: When the United States and Iran swapped prisoners last week, nothing was said to resolve the mystery about another captive: Robert A. Levinson, a Central Intelligence Agency consultant who disappeared in Iran in 2007.

headline: Academy Members Respond to Swift Changes for Board
text: The reaction to the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences saying on Friday that it was taking steps to double the number of female and minority members by 2020 was varied.

headline: France Plans a New Keyboard to Shift Control to Typists
text: PARIS — Bad spelling? Incorrect grammar? It’s all in the keyboard.

headline: ‘Boxer’ Sells for $785,000 at Christie’s
text: Looks like a knock-out.

headline: The Fading Two-State Solution
text: Given the brittle relations between the Obama administration and Israel, even truth-telling can ignite a firestorm. That happened this week when Daniel Shapiro, Washington’s ambassador in Tel Aviv, delivered a speech that drew unfair rebukes from Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, and his right-wing government.

headline: A Waiting List for Justice in New Orleans
text: On Wednesday, the New Orleans police arrested Deonca Kennedy after her 3-year-old grandson was killed by a bullet fired from a gun under her pillow as the two slept.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ in the Age of Truthers
text: To watch “The X-Files” in 2016 is a strange thing. The original television show was so much a child of the peaceful ’90s that it’s easy to forget it actually limped along until 2002. Its best seasons aired after the Gulf War and before 9/11, and took place in a version of the United States where the government apparently had so few terrestrial problems to deal with that its highest priority was keeping its citizens in the dark about aliens.

headline: Ted Cruz Condemns Donald Trump for His Use of Eminent Domain
text: Attacked first in a Donald J. Trump ad, Senator Ted Cruz swiftly responded on Friday with a commercial assailing Mr. Trump over his real estate background.

headline: Coming to Terms with Donald
text: Americans of all races, creeds and political persuasions are united today in the realization that, good grief, Donald Trump actually could become the Republican presidential nominee.

headline: Success Academy Founder Defends Schools Against Charges of Bias
text: Eva S. Moskowitz defended her Success Academy charter schools on Friday, two days after a group of parents filed a federal complaint accusing the network of discriminating against students with disabilities.

headline: Mythological Subject for Leonardo, Correggio and Rubens
text: Administrivial Important PRINT solving Alert! Due to a production error, there is a clue missing at 58 Down in the Sunday, January 24 crossword puzzle in the Magazine. Apologies in advance for the “spoiler,” but that clue should be “Follower of upsilon.”

headline: Spain’s Acting Prime Minister Declines Invitation to Form Government
text: MADRID — Spain’s acting prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, on Friday turned down an invitation by King Felipe VI to try to form a new government, prolonging the country’s political deadlock after inconclusive elections in December.

headline: Lois Weisberg, Chicago’s Cultural Connector, Dies at 90
text: Lois Weisberg, a whirlwind of civic enthusiasm whose decades of shepherding public arts projects to fruition deepened the cultural life and reputation of Chicago, died on Jan. 13 at her home in Miami. She was 90.

headline: Clarence Reid, Singer and Songwriter Also Known as Blowfly, Dies at 76
text: Clarence Reid, a soul singer, songwriter and producer who under the alias Blowfly was a proto-rap innovator and a leading light of American outsider music, thanks to decades of parody songs, sexual and scatological in nature, died on Jan. 17 in hospice care in Lauderdale Lakes, Fla. He was 76.

headline: Death of Man in Brooklyn Fire Is Called a Homicide
text: The death of a man discovered inside a burning apartment in Brooklyn on Friday morning has been ruled a homicide by the police, who said his throat was slashed and his body was covered with stab wounds.

headline: Knicks Lose Their Cool, and a Game Slips Away
text: The Knicks watched Clippers center DeAndre Jordan put together a highlight reel for two and a half quarters before tempers finally boiled over.

headline: Flood of Support After Bronx Councilman James Vacca Reveals on Twitter He Is Gay
text: James Vacca, a city councilman from the Bronx, had a message on Friday for his constituents — and the sundry users of the Internet: He is an out and proud gay man.

headline: In Surprise, Mets Agree to a Deal With Cespedes
text: The Mets had spent the entire off-season leaving the strong impression that they did not expect the right-handed-hitting slugger Yoenis Cespedes to be with the team in 2016.

headline: Review: At Communal Kitchen, a Local Harvest Through All Seasons
text: If you live on the east side of the Tappan Zee Bridge and head west to Nyack — which draws diners with its lively restaurant row — you’re in for a show: The construction of the new bridge, alongside the existing span, features one of the world’s largest floating cranes, lit up like a Zipper ride on a midway. Called the Left Coast Lifter, the crane can hoist the equivalent of 12 Statues of Liberty.

headline: Review: Laurel & Sage in Montclair Takes a Global Approach
text: Talk about tough acts to follow: Laurel & Sage opened last March at the address of the widely lauded restaurant CulinAriane, which closed in 2014 when its owners decamped to Verona.

headline: Review: Da Legna, a Pizza Contender’s Secret Weapon in New Haven
text: Some might say that the very act of opening a pizzeria in New Haven — the pizza capital (to locals, at least) of New England — takes serious audacia. This is, after all, the same town where hallowed institutions like Sally’s Apizza, Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana and Modern Apizza have for decades vied for the most critical raves and fervently devoted fans.

headline: Cespedes Deal Proves Mets May Know a Thing or Two
text: We have seen the Mets rebuild. It worked. They are the reigning National League champions. They have done some things right.

headline: Two Teenagers Charged in Hate Crime Attack Against Muslim Man in the Bronx
text: Two teenage boys were arrested on Friday and charged with assaulting a Muslim man in the Bronx last week while shouting “Isis! Isis!,” the police said.

headline: Two Mets Reach Deals
text: The Mets reached agreements with Lucas Duda and Jenrry Mejia, avoiding arbitration with both of them, a person in baseball said. Duda, a first baseman who has hit 57 home runs over the past two seasons, could be called upon to provide much of the power in the team’s lineup in 2016. Mejia, a relief pitcher, missed most of the 2015 season because of two suspensions after he tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs. The Mets will not have to pay him until his suspension ends midway through the season.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
text: Like a thruway pileup, Saturday is ripe for bottlenecking — whether the antics of the “Entourage” guys or the rise and fall of some R&B legends. Meanwhile, the comedians Whitney Cummings and Chelsea Handler assume the warrior position in the battle of the sexes.

headline: Review: Venetian Warmth at Bacaro Italian Tavern
text: “This is my kind of restaurant: warm and friendly, with good food, large portions and moderate prices,” said one of my dining companions about Bacaro Italian Tavern in Massapequa Park, which opened in November.

headline: Senior Care Facilities With World-Class Art
text: Artworks by Robert Rauschenberg, Ellsworth Kelly, Marc Chagall and Alex Katz adorn the walls. There is a fabric and paper collage by Romare Bearden, and a drawing by Diego Rivera. A corridor is lined with 10 silk-screened portraits by Andy Warhol and a few of William Wegman’s photolithographs of his bedecked Weimaraner dogs.

headline: Review: Passions Ignite in ‘Lives of Reason’ at Two River Theater
text: It is likely that Robert Rechnitz and Kenneth Stunkel enjoyed some chuckles while collaborating on “Lives of Reason,” their play being presented in a world premiere at Two River Theater in Red Bank.

headline: Review: At Hartford Stage, Friendship Forged Through Somalia War
text: The current Hartford Stage production depicts two men — one of them representing the playwright — talking mostly by email, with some bare-bones dramatization of a few of their stories.

headline: The Art of Maxfield Parrish
text: For much of the first half of the 20th century, a quarter of American homes were decorated with art by Maxfield Parrish, said Judy Goffman Cutler and her husband, Laurence S. Cutler. They are the curators of “Maxfield Parrish: Paintings and Prints From the National Museum of American Illustration,” an exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art in Roslyn Harbor.

headline: Corrections: January 23, 2016
text: NEW YORK

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “We are watching all this with alarm. It is clear that the government lacks the necessary resources to give us a normal life.”

headline: Talks to Restructure Puerto Rico Power Company’s Debt Collapse
text: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico — Negotiations to restructure roughly $9 billion of the debt of Puerto Rico’s power company collapsed late Friday, according to a statement from a group of creditors involved in the talks.

headline: In an Ancient Tomb, a Hierarchy of the Dead
text: A 6,000-year-old tomb in Northern Spain provides valuable information about an ancient Neolithic community, according to a new study in the journal PLOS One. The tomb holds the remains of 47 individuals, laid to rest in several layers. Individuals in the bottom tomb were closely related, and family members were buried side-by-side, DNA analysis suggests. In layers above, however, the bodies appear to be missing skeletal parts, including skulls. The bones were manipulated, possibly for ritualistic purposes. . The analysis also showed that the community relied on cereals and other plant-based food for sustenance.

headline: The Cult of Marie Kondo
text: On Wednesday evening, the tidy and the would-be tidy sat very still on the fourth floor of the Barnes & Noble bookstore at Union Square in Manhattan, craning to hear the soft voice of Marie Kondo, the Japanese author of “The Life-Changing Magic of Tidying Up,” as she demonstrated her folding technique on ever more complex garments. She was balletic and masterly. When done, Ms. Kondo received a standing ovation.

headline: Review: ‘Remaking the American Patient’
text: Does any modern American doctor or patient get through a day without thinking wistfully of simpler times? The process of providing or securing even basic health care is so endlessly complicated now, so perilous and frustrating, so entrepreneurial and expensive. Everything was so much easier in the old days. Just beam us back, someone, please.

headline: The New Side Job for Actors and Artists in Los Angeles: Driving
text: LOS ANGELES — When Lauren McKnight, 27, isn’t appearing on television shows for VH1 and ABC, she’s driving a black Scion xA, picking up Hollywood executives on their way to the airport.

headline: Alice Walker and Colm Toibin, and Their Trail of Words
text: One of the special pleasures of movies and plays based on great novels is the way they lead us back to their literary roots. Playing the images and emotions from stage or screen against the ones in our head while reading the original creates a doubled experience.

headline: Palestinian Girl With Knife Killed by Israeli Guard, Police Say
text: JERUSALEM — A 13-year-old Palestinian girl was fatally shot by an Israeli security guard at the entrance to a West Bank settlement on Saturday after she ran at him with a knife, according to the Israeli police.

headline: The Week on Instagram
text: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from the campaign trail to the aptly named Jellyfish Lake.

headline: As Frustrations With Mexico’s Government Rise, So Do Lynchings
text: AJALPAN, Mexico — The lynching began around 7:20 p.m., not long after the brothers had finished conducting their final interviews on tortilla consumption.

headline: Major Cities Grind to a Halt and Face Days of Digging Out Snow
text: Making up for a remarkably mild winter, the first major snowstorm of the season charged up the East Coast on Saturday, a blizzard propelled by tropical-storm-force winds that brought much of the Northeast to a standstill and left more than two feet of snow in New York City, where Mayor Bill de Blasio called it “very likely one of the worst snowstorms in our history.”

headline: ‘A Little Variety': We Welcome Your Comments
text: A LITTLE VARIETY — We’re trying something new — a weekly place to gather and discuss the “A Little Variety” puzzles that publish online on Thursdays and appear in the Sunday Magazine. You are welcome to talk about the puzzles in the comments section.

headline: Wonks and Minions
text: One of the differences between right and left in America is that the progressive infrastructure includes a contingent of genuine wonks — commentators on policy who really do make models and crunch numbers, and sometimes come up with answers that aren’t fully predictable from their politics. The list includes Ezra Klein, Jonathan Cohn, Jonathan Chait, Mike Konczal, myself some of the time, and others. Right now the wonk brigade has been weighing in on Bernie Sanders, and is in general not too impressed on either financial reform or health care.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: The Chatter on Messaging Apps
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: An App Helps Teachers Track Student Attendance
text: Over the years, Etta Covington, a science teacher at Wadleigh Secondary School for the Performing and Visual Arts in Harlem, has seen her share of students who routinely show up late to class, cut classes or skip school altogether.

headline: Bloomberg, Sensing an Opening, Revisits a Potential White House Run
text: Michael R. Bloomberg has instructed advisers to draw up plans for a potential independent campaign in this year’s presidential race. His advisers and associates said he was galled by Donald J. Trump’s dominance of the Republican field, and troubled by Hillary Clinton’s stumbles and the rise of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on the Democratic side.

text: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Bangladeshi authorities have filed terrorism charges against 14 Bangladeshi construction workers deported from Singapore on suspicion of involvement with Islamic militant networks.

text: Cordy Williamson, 74, is a senior vegetation manager at Duke Energy Corporation in Florence, S.C.

headline: S.E.C. Is Criticized for Lax Enforcement of Climate Risk Disclosure
text: As recently as 2011, shares in Peabody Energy, the world’s biggest private sector coal company, traded at the equivalent of $1,000. Today, they hover around $4 each. Over that time, investors who held the stock lost millions.

headline: U.S. Student’s Detention by North Korea Was a Surprise, Tour Group Says
text: HONG KONG — An American student who is being detained by North Korea did nothing obvious during a five-day trip to the country that would have angered the authorities, a member of his tour group said Saturday.

text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: U.S. Relies Heavily on Saudi Money to Support Syrian Rebels
text: WASHINGTON — When President Obama secretly authorized the Central Intelligence Agency to begin arming Syria’s embattled rebels in 2013, the spy agency knew it would have a willing partner to help pay for the covert operation. It was the same partner the C.I.A. has relied on for decades for money and discretion in far-off conflicts: the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia.

headline: Variety Puzzle: A Thoughtful Acrostic
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — Think carefully before you answer this question: What is the difference between the mind and the brain? You might not believe that there is a difference and, for some, the answer delves into spirituality. But for me, the brain is the THREE-POUND MASS OF JELLY inside our human skulls, and the mind is the consciousness that enables us to both CONTEMPLATE INFINITY and decide what we want to have for lunch. It makes us who we are individually, and it separates us from other species.

headline: Letters to the Editor

headline: Shoveling Snow Through the Decades
text: The snow itself has remained the same but the methods for clearing it have evolved over the last century.

headline: Federer Is Aging Gracefully, but Australian Ken Rosewall Set the Standard
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Marvel at Roger Federer, who last year reached the Wimbledon final at age 33 and the United States Open final at age 34.

headline: The Hairy Face of a Most Unlikely Winning Streak
text: VALENCIA, Spain — Five or 10 or 20 years from now, when all those who care about the basketball team here talk about the gloriously unexpected winning streak that began in October, stretched until mid-January and covered 28 games in six countries, they will talk about the upset in Madrid that started it all. Or the late comeback in Germany. Or maybe the overtime game against Bilbao.

headline: How To Make Donald Trump President
text: Step 1: Democrats nominate Bernie Sanders. I don’t think Sanders is unelectable, but when you look at polling, remember that Hillary Clinton’s numbers reflect her standing after more than two decades of constant character assassination, whereas Republicans haven’t even begun to go after him.

headline: Levels, Rates, and Sweden
text: I’ve been unhappily surprised by a lot of what has gone on within the economics profession since the 2008 crisis. But one of the most depressing things, in a way, has been the extent to which well-known economists seem confused about the difference between levels and rates of change. Unfortunately, you see this all the time — for example, in the constant assertions that because some country posted a year of pretty good growth after several years of austerity, this proves that austerity doesn’t actually depress the economy.

headline: A Streaky Hitter, a Poor Center Fielder and an Appealing Signing
text: At the height of the mania that surrounded outfielder Yoenis Cespedes after his trade to the Mets last season, some people talked of a $200 million contract in his future and debated whether he should be considered for the National League’s Most Valuable Player Award despite having played in the league for just two months.

headline: Status of Airports, Trains and Other Services in the New York Area
text: What is open and closed as the New York region copes with its first big snowstorm of 2016.

headline: Suspect, 19, Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of Brooklyn Teenager
text: Police officials on Saturday announced the arrest of a man wanted for the stabbing death of a teenager in Brooklyn last week that investigators now believe was the culmination of a quarrel over an exchange of text messages.

headline: Boban Marjanovic Is Entering Fans’ Hearts, if Not the Spurs’ Lineup
text: SAN ANTONIO — The Bobinator is a cartoon figure created by a friend of Boban Marjanovic’s back in Serbia. The Bobinator’s green skin matches the Incredible Hulk’s, but his face and left arm — which is metallic and culminates not in a hand but in a hook that grabs a basketball — is a reference to his primary inspiration.

headline: David Stoliar, Survivor of World War II Disaster, Dies at 91
text: (The death of David Stoliar, in 2014, received little attention outside Oregon, where he lived. The New York Times, which had prepared an obituary, learned of his death on Friday.)

text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — As he waited for a team, any team, to call him, Robert McClain grew to love the jogging trails around Buford, Ga. He ran daily, always on his own, unless you count Melo, his 6-year-old German shepherd.

headline: Danger May Lurk in Denver for New England Patriots

headline: One Republican Candidate Wouldn’t Mind Seeing Michael Bloomberg in the Race
text: NASHUA, N.H. — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio offered welcoming words to Michael R. Bloomberg on Saturday, suggesting that an independent run by the former New York City mayor could have a positive effect on the presidential race.

headline: A Canadian Threat to Alaskan Fishing
text: Sitka, Alaska — FROM fall through spring, the fleet of commercial fishing boats here in the panhandle of Alaska stalk winter king salmon. In the mornings prisms of ice sparkle beneath the sodium lights of the docks, where I live on a World War II tugboat with my wife and 8-month-old daughter. This winter I’ve been out a few times fishing on the I Gotta, catching pristine wild salmon, torpedoes of muscle. But the work is slow, five fish a day, and my skipper recently traveled down to Reno, Nev., for knee surgery.

headline: A Colleague Drank My Breast Milk and Other Wall Street Tales
text: I STILL think about a female job applicant I interviewed more than a decade ago, when I was a managing director at Bear Stearns and she was fresh from the Wharton School of Business.

headline: Stranded in the Snow, Travelers Camp in Cars and Make Do
text: Sabrina Swidergal was among hundreds of Catholic high school and college students returning from an anti-abortion rally in Washington who started their weekend stranded on the Pennsylvania Turnpike.

headline: Is Warfare in Our Bones?
text: The discovery of what looks like the aftermath of a brutal clash between two groups of prehistoric hunter-gatherers on the shore of an African lake is certain to stir up a debate about human nature that goes all the way back to Adam and Eve.

headline: Home vs. Hospital Births
text: Readers discuss the risks and benefits of both settings and suggest ways to improve care.

headline: The Way to Stop Trump
text: THIS is, of course, a pointless column. The Republican presidential race is over, as you may have heard. Donald Trump has the nomination wrapped up — in the most luxurious, velveteen packaging you’ve ever seen. You’ve seen his polling lead: It’s yuge. You’ve watched his rallies: They’re even yuger. You’ve heard from the insiders, the panjandrums, the grand poo-bahs: He’s a man they can do business with; Bob Dole guarantees it. You’ve heard from Sarah Palin, and when has her political judgment ever failed?

headline: Facts, Fairness, and the Election­
text: When you’re Donald Trump, bashing The New York Times must always seem like a good idea.

headline: U.N. Can Seal the Peace in Colombia
text: The government of Colombia and the country’s largest guerrilla group have made an unusual joint request to the United Nations Security Council. Nearing the final stages of an armistice negotiation, the two sides asked the Council to set up a mission of international experts to oversee a critical part of the proposed agreement: disarming the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, a Marxist-inspired insurgency.

headline: Sarah Palin Saves Feminism
text: WASHINGTON — IT’S a tough call to figure out which place is more benighted: Hollywood or Saudi Arabia.

headline: Tom Lutz
text: Tom Lutz is editor in chief of The Los Angeles Review of Books.

headline: Fix Flint’s Water System, Now
text: The conditions on the ground in Flint still do not seem to have sunk in at the Michigan statehouse. Thousands of residents are still relying on trucked-in water, as if they were in a war-zone refugee camp, while worrying that their children may suffer developmental and other health problems from a water system poisoned by lead. Gov. Rick Snyder has been busy apologizing, but the tiny steps he is taking to repair the damage shrink beside the urgency of the problem.

headline: Can Shame Be Useful?
text: MODERN American culture is down on shame — it is, we are told, a damaging, useless emotion that we should neither feel ourselves nor make others feel. This is particularly the case when it comes to drug and alcohol addiction. The nation’s drug czar, Michael Botticelli, has led a well-intentioned campaign to eradicate feelings of shame in addicted people by, in part, likening addiction to cancer, a disease outside of people’s control.

headline: Our Insane Addiction to Polls
text: REMEMBER the poll last week that had Bernie Sanders ahead of Hillary Clinton in New Hampshire by three points?

headline: Did the Man I Sentenced to 18 Years Deserve It?
text: IN 2006, I sentenced a man to 18 years in prison. I have been wrestling with that decision ever since.

headline: Race, History and Baptist Reconciliation
text: WITH the protests in Ferguson, Mo., the Black Lives Matter movement and the massacre of black churchgoers in Charleston, S.C., on their minds, the presidents of the nation’s two major Baptist groups — one predominantly white, one predominantly black — decided it was time for a bold gesture. The Southern Baptist Convention, founded by slaveholders and their supporters before the Civil War, is now the nation’s second-largest Christian denomination after the Roman Catholic Church. Black Baptists formed their own churches and in 1880 founded what eventually became the National Baptist Convention, U.S.A.

headline: No Split Between Simon and Garfunkel Over Bernie Sanders’s Use of Their Song

text: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Negotiations to restructure roughly $9 billion of the debt of Puerto Rico’s power company collapsed late Friday, raising the prospect of the biggest default yet in Puerto Rico’s deepening debt crisis.

headline: Negative Words for Negative Ads From Bush-Aligned ‘Super PAC’
text: BOW, N.H. — Some of Jeb Bush’s major donors have been worried about the negative tone that Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Mr. Bush, has taken in criticizing his Republican rivals. They aren’t the only ones concerned.

headline: #Blizzard2016 on Instagram
text: From Alabama to New York, people ventured out in the snow and shared it with the world on social media.

headline: ‘Hillarycare’ Failed, but Hillary Clinton Reminds Voters She Tried
text: After weeks of criticizing Bernie Sanders’s plan for a single-payer “Medicare for all” health care system as budget busting and unrealistic, Hillary Clinton over the past few days has a new message for voters: Universal health care was her idea first.

headline: The Y Embarks on Its First National Advertising Campaign
text: The Y.M.C.A. — or the Y as it is now known — has existed for more than 160 years and has never felt the need to advertise. After all, even without the help of the ubiquitous song from the Village People, most people know what the Y is.

text: When the team bus lurched to a halt around 9:15 p.m. Friday, Brian Baudinet, the player development coach of the Duquesne men’s basketball team, assumed that an accident on the Pennsylvania Turnpike had caused the disruption.

headline: For Many Workers, Staying Home Is Not an Option During Blizzard
text: There were the workers who boarded a Manhattan-bound subway train before sunrise in boots and denim shirts, looking for a place to sit between the men sprawled out and sleeping on the benches who had no other place to spend the night.

text: Fall 2016 men’s wear designs from Hermés.

headline: Health Scare Eclipses Action on Courts; Bottom of Draw Offers Path for Azarenka
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Ana Ivanovic was leading her third-round match against Madison Keys, 6-4, 1-0, on Saturday night at the Australian Open when a disturbance in her player’s box caught her eye. Nigel Sears, 58, had collapsed on a staircase inside Rod Laver Arena.

headline: Milos Raonic Wins Match While Grieving for Victims of a Shooting in Canada
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Milos Raonic’s compatriots at Melbourne Park chanted his name and waved Canadian flags and handmade signs decorated with the country’s symbol, the maple leaf. If Raonic won his third-round match against Viktor Troicki, he decided, he would return the nationalistic show of support.

headline: U.S. Prisoner Who Stayed in Iran Was F.B.I. Consultant, Expatriate News Service Says
text: An American prisoner recently freed by Iran, but about whom little is known, is a former California-based carpet seller and F.B.I. consultant, a news service run by expatriate Iranian journalists reported on Saturday. It said Iranian officials might have believed the man had links to the case of Robert A. Levinson, an American who went missing in Iran nearly nine years ago.

headline: Crackdown by Egypt Draws Attention to an Anniversary It Aimed to Avoid
text: CAIRO — The normally invasive Egyptian authorities had long left Studio Emad Eddin alone, seeing no threat from a performance space that houses rehearsal studios and offers classes in set design and drama.

headline: Afghan Officials, Voicing Security Fears on Facebook, Are Fired for Their Trouble
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — As the fate of Helmand Province hung in the balance last month during a withering Taliban offensive, the province’s deputy governor, Mohammad Jan Rasoolyar, found his urgent pleas for help from the central government going unheeded. So he did what millions of other people do every day: He ranted on Facebook.

headline: Initial Turn
text: Administrivial Important PRINT solving Alert! Due to a production error, the print version of the Sunday, Jan. 24 crossword puzzle in the Magazine is missing the clue at 58 Down. That clue should be “Follower of upsilon.”

headline: Iraqi Leader Asks U.S. for Help to Train Police Forces, Officials Say

headline: Donald Trump Would ‘Love’ to See Michael Bloomberg Run

headline: La Loche, the Canadian Town Where 4 Were Killed, Has a Bleak History
text: OTTAWA — Sudden deaths in La Loche, Saskatchewan, where shootings at two locations left four people dead and seven wounded on Friday, are an all too familiar event. But before Friday, suicide was the main cause of such deaths.

text: PELLA, Iowa – The Des Moines Register, the largest newspaper in Iowa, announced Saturday night that it had endorsed Senator Marco Rubio in the Republican race and Hillary Clinton in the Democratic race.

headline: El Salvador Advises Against Pregnancy Until 2018 in Answer to Zika Fears
text: SAN SALVADOR — Reacting to the rapid spread of the Zika virus in Latin America and the Caribbean, health officials in El Salvador are urging women not to get pregnant until 2018 in an effort to halt a surge of birth defects that are suspected to stem from the mosquito-borne disease.

headline: In Support of Ted Cruz, Glenn Beck Slams Donald Trump
text: ANKENY, Iowa — Such is the state of the 2016 election that the following, apparently, needs to be said: “I have no intention of shooting anybody in this campaign,” Ted Cruz told reporters here on Saturday, with a now-official attack dog at his side.

headline: In Surprise Showing, Iowa’s Senior Senator Appears at Donald Trump Rally

headline: At Givenchy, Riccardo Tisci Celebrates the Freedom of Dress
text: For a second season, the designer showed women’s couture looks during the men’s wear presentation. A cobra motif snaked through all the designs.

headline: When the Water Turned Brown
text: FLINT, Mich. — Standing at a microphone in September holding up a baby bottle, Dr. Mona Hanna-Attisha, a local pediatrician, said she was deeply worried about the water. The number of Flint children with elevated levels of lead in their blood had risen alarmingly since the city changed its water supply the previous year, her analysis showed.

headline: The Big Four in Saudi Arabia’s Government
text: Brief background information on the most powerful figures in the kingdom, and how they stand in the sometimes complicated order of succession.

headline: Gas Leak in Los Angeles Has Residents Looking Warily Toward Flint
text: LOS ANGELES — Health officials have tested the air and deemed it safe. Yes, the awful smell from a huge natural gas leak near the Porter Ranch neighborhood may cause vomiting, nosebleeds and other short-term symptoms, they say, but they have assured residents that it does not pose long-term health risks.

headline: Donald Trump Says Megyn Kelly Should Skip Debate; Fox Says She’ll Be There
text: Since Megyn Kelly’s pointed question to Donald J. Trump about his treatment of women in the first Republican debate, he has been attacking her regularly, through Tweets and on the campaign trail.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Fans Embrace Tune of ‘America’ in Ad Free of Attacks
text: For a blissful minute, the cacophony of political ads on Iowa television sets vanishes altogether. No speeches, no slurs, only the warm harmonies of Simon and Garfunkel singing “America” can be heard, as down-to-earth Iowa landscapes and scenes of daily life accompany the famous song, in a new ad from Senator Bernie Sanders with the same title.

headline: Bernie Sanders Courts Elusive Voters: Young Iowans
text: UNDERWOOD, Iowa — With the Iowa caucuses just over a week away, the Bernie Sanders youth brigade is on the move.

headline: A Day of Endorsements for Presidential Candidates in Iowa
text: PELLA, Iowa — After nonstop candidate traffic in Iowa for a full year, the gun was sounded on the final lap before the Feb. 1 caucuses, as the leading candidates in both parties crisscrossed the snowy plains and the state’s largest newspaper announced its endorsements.

headline: In Return to Iowa, Bernie Sanders Picks Up Where He Left Off on Wall Street and Clinton
text: MAQUOKETA, Iowa — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont tied himself to Barack Obama and Hillary Clinton to Wall Street as he returned to Iowa on Saturday for a weekend tour through the state.

headline: Knicks Show Little but Midseason Malaise in Loss to Hornets
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — When Carmelo Anthony warmed up before the Knicks played the Charlotte Hornets on Saturday, something, he said, felt off. He couldn’t make the ball do the things he typically can. He couldn’t sink baskets with the ease that he normally does.

headline: Stephanie Schneider, Matthew Schwartz

Gail Prudenti, a former chief administrative judge of New York State, officiated. The couple celebrated their marriage the following day at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in Manhattan, where David Gilman, a retired judge who is now a judicial hearing officer in the Bronx, led the couple in their wedding vows.

Atkinson and Dr. Peter L. Atkinson of Ilkley, England. The Rev. Anthony Nye, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in London.

Greenberg and Gary A. Greenberg of Ambler, Pa. Rabbi Yisrael Pinson officiated at 501 Union, an events space in Brooklyn.

headline: Julia Groeblacher and Daniel Castillo: They’ll Always Have Baghdad
text: Julia Michaela Groeblacher, the daughter of Michaela M. Groeblacher of Lindsborg, Kan., and the late Johann H. Groeblacher, was married in Washington Jan. 20 to Marine Gunnery Sgt. Daniel Lee Castillo, the son of Dahlia S. Castillo and Francisco A. Castillo of South Padre Island, Tex. Gary Shaw, a friend of the couple who received authorization from the District of Columbia to preside, officiated in a Federal-style house in Georgetown that’s part of the L’Enfant Trust.

headline: Elise Chang, Alastair Kusack
