text: Isabel Ann Solmonson, a daughter of Leslie Morgan Solmonson and Steven J. Solmonson of New York, was married Jan. 23 to Elliot Burt Cohen, the son of Paula T. Cohen and Albert E. Cohen of Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Michael Resnick officiated at the Flagler Museum in Palm Beach, Fla.

headline: Margaret Howe, Sergio Vera Gutiérrez
text: Margaret Saltonstall Howe and Sergio Oscar Alejandro Vera Gutiérrez were married Jan. 23 at the Sulgrave Club in Washington. John H. Bayly Jr., a senior judge on the Superior Court of Washington, officiated.

headline: Hena Daniels, Andrew Doba
text: Hena Nadia Daniels and Andrew Ronald Doba were married Jan. 23 at the Society Room of Hartford, an event space in Hartford. Gov. Dannel P. Malloy, a friend of the groom, officiated.

headline: Corrections: January 24, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It’s not worth it. It’s coming down as fast as we clear it away.”

headline: Maria Sharapova Looks to End 17-Match Losing Streak Against Serena Williams
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Sven Groeneveld was camped out in the media seats in Rod Laver Arena on Sunday, shifting his experienced gaze from his smartphone to Serena Williams, who was thumping winner after winner down below.

headline: Novak Djokovic, Despite 100 Unforced Errors, Advances to Australian Open Quarterfinals
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The bottom line on Sunday at the Australian Open was that Novak Djokovic prevailed over Gilles Simon, 6-3, 6-7 (1), 6-4, 4-6, 6-3, to reach his 27th consecutive Grand Slam quarterfinal.

headline: Looking for Signs That Apple’s Runaway Growth Is Waning
text: SAN FRANCISCO — Investors have long relied on Apple to deliver one crucial attribute: growth. Now they are beginning to wonder whether Apple’s days as a growth stock are coming to an end.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Blizzard, Bloomberg, N.F.L.
text: Here are the week’s top stories.

headline: Loving a Grandpa Right Down to His Toes
text: It was early November when my youngest daughter, Sarah, asked her grandfather, “Hey Pop, have you ever had your toenails painted?”

headline: Lanvin: Fall 2016
text: Lanvin’s vision for fall 2016 men’s wear.

headline: After East Coast Blizzard, the Cleanup and the Workweek Begin
text: Bounded by mountains of snow and slush-covered roads and sidewalks, millions of people along the Eastern Seaboard slogged to work on Monday morning, one day after one of the biggest blizzards ever recorded swept through the region, dumping more than two feet of snow in many cities.

headline: Drone Lobbying Heats Up on Capitol Hill
text: WASHINGTON — The last time Congress weighed in on rules for nonmilitary drones, in 2012, the flying machines were hardly a hit with consumers. And companies said little about using them for commercial purposes.

headline: 1941: Minister Says British Gains Aided Palestine
text: WASHINGTON — Declaring that British victories in Egypt and Libya have thrust the danger of attack upon Palestine by the Axis powers ‘‘well into the background,’’ Neville Montagu Butler, newly appointed Minister to the United States from Great Britain, said in a message today [Jan. 24] to Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, national chairman of the United Palestine Appeal, that Palestine can look forward to a bright future if American Jews do their utmost in support of Britain and the program of rebuilding the Jewish national home in Palestine.

headline: For Those With ‘Hamilton’ Tickets, a Storm of Disappointment
text: Don and Naiema Frieson flew up from northwest Arkansas, treasuring the “Hamilton” tickets they had bought for $1,500, eager to experience the musical they had heard so much about. Jessica Pride came in from San Diego, excited to see the show with her husband, who bought a pair of tickets for $1,450 as a Christmas gift. And Tamiko Brooks traveled from Los Angeles, the event an expensive birthday present from her husband.

headline: Marriage, Poverty and the Political Divide
text: There remains some argument among lawmakers over which Americans should be able to marry, but nearly everyone agrees that marriage itself offers stability and economic benefits to couples and to society at large.

headline: The Snowstorm Is Over, but Travel Delays Aren’t
text: The snow may have stopped falling but the blizzard that brought travel in the Northeast to a standstill is still wreaking havoc on transportation and tourism. Here is how it is affecting your trip.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Where Addiction Treatment Programs Are Taking Shape
text: These law enforcement agencies are offering addicts referrals to treatment programs, either in lieu of arrest, as in Gloucester, Mass., or through direct outreach, according to the Police Assisted Addiction and Recovery Initiative:

headline: Massachusetts Chief’s Tack in Drug War: Steer Addicts to Rehab, Not Jail
text: CANTON, Ohio — Leonard Campanello, the police chief of Gloucester, Mass., took the microphone here in mid-December and opened with his usual warm-up line: I’m from Gloucester, he said in his heavy Boston accent. “That’s spelled ‘G-l-o-s-t-a-h.’”

headline: The East Coast, Coated by a Winter Blast
text: Near-record amounts of snow accumulated in places along the East Coast, leaving cities and residents with huge piles to clear on Sunday.

headline: Candidates React to Bloomberg With Dismissals and Differences
text: Senator Marco Rubio dismissed Michael R. Bloomberg as “just a private citizen who owns a big company.” Hillary Clinton said she would “relieve” Mr. Bloomberg of any need to enter the presidential race. Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey was uncharacteristically charitable, calling Mr. Bloomberg “a good mayor” of New York City.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says Senator Charles Grassley Wants ‘to Defeat Me’
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa – Hillary Clinton on Sunday accused Charles E. Grassley, the senior Republican senator from Iowa, of trying to undermine her presidential campaign by leaking negative information about her tenure as secretary of state. She also criticized him for showing up at an Iowa rally for Donald J. Trump on Saturday “for the simple reason to defeat me.”

headline: Men’s Fashion Week: Hermès and Sacai in Pictures
text: A photo diary of the Hermès and Sacai fall/winter 2016 collections, which were presented yesterday in Paris.

headline: Patriots vs. Broncos: Who Has the Edge?
text: 3:05 p.m. Eastern, CBS. Line: Patriots by 3.

headline: Chris Christie Attacks Marco Rubio Over Blizzard Remark
text: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey angrily scolded Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Sunday for his sarcastic remark about the blizzard that crippled much of the Northeast this weekend, calling the comment a sign of his “immaturity” and inexperience.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: Mulder and Scully are back, and if their chemistry in the newfangled iteration of “The X-Files” isn’t immediately evident, sit tight, because the mini-series gets better, says the New York Times critic James Poniewozik. The snowbound can brush up by streaming the original shows. Not in the mood? Check out “Amy,” Asif Kapadia’s Oscar-nominated documentary about the troubled chanteuse Amy Winehouse.

headline: N.F.L. Playoffs: How the Arizona Cardinals and Carolina Panthers Match Up
text: 6:40 p.m., Fox. Line: Panthers by 3.

headline: Republicans Risk Repeating Mistake on Hispanic Vote
text: Three years ago, high-level Republicans declared that after losing the popular vote in five of the past six presidential elections, the party needed to appeal more to Latinos to win the White House. Immigration was a threshold issue.

headline: 1966: Indira Gandhi Becomes Prime Minister
text: NEW DELHI — Mrs. Indira Gandhi was sworn in today [Jan. 24] as India’s third prime minister and the first woman to lead the nation’s millions. The 48-year-old daughter of India’s first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, took the brief oath before turbaned President Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan in the same room where he administered the same oath 19 months earlier to Lal Bahadur Shastri. Fifteen other cabinet ministers were sworn in at the same time by Mr. Radhakrishnan, including Gulzarilal Nanda, home minister; Y. B. Chavan, defense; Chidambaram Subramaniam, food; and the Untouchables leader, Jagjivan Ram, labor and employment.

headline: Broncos 20, Patriots 18: A.F.C. Championship Highlights
text: Peyton Manning and the Denver Broncos knocked off Tom Brady and the defending champion New England Patriots in the A.F.C. Championship. Highlights and analysis.

headline: Umit Benan: Fall 2016
text: Umit Benan’s fall 2016 men’s wear collection.

headline: At Sundance, a Focus on Fetishes and Flatulence
text: PARK CITY, Utah — It will be hard to beat “Swiss Army Man,” a comedic drama centered on an extremely flatulent, sexually aroused corpse, as the most warped entry at this year’s Sundance Film Festival here.

headline: ‘The Revenant’ Tops the Box Office
text: With theaters in major cities like New York, Washington and Philadelphia closed on Saturday because of a severe winter storm, new wide-release films — all with terrible reviews — arrived to modest box-office results.

headline: Manhunt for Three Escaped Inmates in Southern California
text: SANTA ANA, Calif. — A manhunt spanning Southern California was underway Sunday for three inmates described as “very dangerous” who escaped from a maximum-security jail in Orange County, using tools to cut through steel bars and then rappelling from the jail’s roof with makeshift ropes made of linens.

headline: Chris Christie Warns New Hampshire Against Voting for Donald Trump
text: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey warned primary voters in New Hampshire that their ballots must be more than “an expression of anger,” and that picking Donald J. Trump as their candidate could hand the White House to Hillary Clinton.

headline: Panthers vs. Cardinals: N.F.C. Championship Highlights
text: Cam Newton and the Carolina Panthers advance to Super Bowl 50 after dominating the Arizona Cardinals, 49-15, in the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Studio in a School Expands Arts Education Nationwide
text: Studio in a School, a New York City nonprofit that enlists professional artists to teach visual arts to public school students, is expanding its mission and scope by creating a Studio Institute to bring its program to the rest of the country.“These are programs that can be replicated,” said Agnes Gund, the organization’s founder and chairwoman. “They have substance, they work for children in schools that don’t have many opportunities. Art is the first thing that’s cut.”

headline: Thom Browne: Fall 2016
text: See what Thom Browne dreamt up for fall 2016 men’s.

headline: Europe’s Top Digital-Privacy Watchdog Zeros In on U.S. Tech Giants
text: PARIS — The latest standoff between Europe and American tech companies runs through a quiet street just north of the Louvre Museum, past chic cafes and part of the French national library, to the ornate office of Isabelle Falque-Pierrotin.

headline: As Jack Dorsey Tries to Reshape Twitter, Revolving Door Takes Another Spin
text: Jack Dorsey began his tenure last year as Twitter’s chief executive with layoffs and a string of new personnel appointments. It turned out those moves were just a prelude.

headline: ISIS Video Appears to Show Paris Assailants Earlier in Syria and Iraq
text: PARIS — The Islamic State released a video on Sunday apparently showing footage of the men who carried out the November attacks in Paris while they were in Syria and Iraq, where they are pictured carrying out executions, including beheadings.

headline: Italy Divided Over Effort to Legalize Civil Unions for Gays
text: ROME — Six years ago, Andrea Rubera married his partner in Canada, where the couple later became parents of three young children. But when they returned to their native Italy, a transformation occurred. Mr. Rubera suddenly became a single man, and his legally recognized husband in Canada became his single male roommate in Italy. Italian law also divided custody of their children.

headline: Making a Haute Couture Look: Atelier Versace
text: On the above image, we take a closer look at the making of this spring 2016 Atelier Versace haute couture look.

headline: Review: In Pairing of ‘Pagliacci’ and ‘Cavalleria Rusticana,’ One Rises Above the Other
text: Of course the audience at the Metropolitan Opera on Thursday clapped at the end of “Vesti la giubba,” a pivotal moment in Leoncavallo’s “Pagliacci.” As the cuckolded and heartbroken clown Canio, the tenor Roberto Alagna had invested the aria with self-destructive despair, pushing his muscular voice close to the breaking point. But when applause broke out, he turned with a start and fixed the crowd with a look of blank horror.

headline: Review: ‘The Velveteen Rabbit’ Is a Tribute to the Less Flashy Toy
text: Do you remember the toy you most adored? A blanket? A doll? Some shabby bit of plush and stuffing? Unicorn Theater’s “The Velveteen Rabbit,” a stage adaptation of Margery Williams’s beloved 1922 picture book at the New Victory Theater, pays sweet and occasionally sorrowful tribute to every plaything loved, gnawed and hugged into tatters.

headline: Carson Palmer’s Memorable Season Ends With a Forgettable Night
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Heading into Sunday’s N.F.C. championship game, Arizona’s Carson Palmer had been the forgotten man of the playoffs.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Jan. 25
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Donald Trump Hears a Lesson in Humility at Church
text: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump is not usually a candidate who invokes the words of evangelical voters. But on Sunday, he went to church in eastern Iowa, where he studied “humility,” he later told attendees at a rally.

headline: Versace: Couture
text: Donatella Versace’s vision for couture 2016.

headline: Tech Giants’ Earnings, the Fed Meets and a Deadline on a Data-Sharing Deal
text: This week’s quarterly earnings announcements will include results from three of the technology sector’s most important companies: Apple, Microsoft and Amazon. Investors on Tuesday will try to divine from Apple’s numbers just how quickly the company’s growth is decelerating. Their focus will be on iPhone sales. On Thursday, Microsoft and Amazon investors will want to see strong growth in both companies’ computing services businesses. Although Microsoft is an important software maker and Amazon is one the world’s most successful e-commerce businesses, those companies also run two of the largest cloud services companies, selling remote computing services and information storage. —Katie Benner

headline: Match-Fixing Suspicions Raised at Australian Open After Site Stops Bets on Match
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — A major sports gambling website suspended betting on Sunday for a mixed doubles match at the Australian Open, raising suspicions of match fixing at one of the world’s most prestigious tennis tournaments.

headline: Review: Loudon Wainwright III Offers Tart Folk-Song Sentiments at Appel Room
text: How did it happen? All at once, it seems, the enfant terrible of yesteryear is a grand older man. Or in the language of Loudon Wainwright III, the singer-songwriter who was mislabeled a “new Bob Dylan” four decades ago, he has become the graying “patriarch” of a distinguished folk music clan.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Taiwan’s New President, Tsai Ing-wen
text: Voters gave Tsai Ing-wen and her Democratic Progressive Party, which is skeptical of a closer relationship with China, control of Taiwan’s legislature for the first time.

headline: Winter Wonderland in Manhattan’s Heart
text: Snowflakes started falling at Central Park on Friday night, forming a smooth white blanket that by Sunday would wrap the area in the pristine quiet of winter.

headline: Review: ‘The Magicians,’ on Syfy, Draws Students Into a Fantasy That’s Real
text: Young magicians joining forces against a malevolent, balance-of-life-threatening adversary? Check. A picturesque, hard-to-find campus where young mages learn to harness their skills? Check. Quidditch? No, thank god.

headline: Egyptian Museum Officials Face Tribunal for Damaging King Tutankhamen’s Mask
text: CAIRO — Eight Egyptian museum officials are to face a disciplinary tribunal for their role in a botched repair job that caused lasting damage to the famed golden burial mask of King Tutankhamen, one of the country’s most prized artifacts, the country’s administrative prosecutor has said.

headline: For the Love of Broadway
text: Despite a massive storm, the show went on at the first BroadwayCon, a theater-themed fan convention in New York.

headline: BroadwayCon Carried On, Even as Broadway Went Dark
text: There were pops of “Wicked” green and “Sweeney Todd” red among the whiteout conditions in Manhattan over the weekend at the first BroadwayCon, a theater-themed fan convention that hopes to do for Broadway devotion what Comic-Con International, in San Diego, has done for superhero worship. Nearly 6,000 people from around the world, most of them young women, turned out for the three-day event at the New York Hilton Midtown, according to event organizers.

headline: Knoedler Gallery Heads to Trial in Sale of a Fake Rothko
text: No scandal in recent years has hung over the art market as heavily as the Knoedler & Company forgery case.

headline: Despite Decades of Stealth, Sticking Points Bedevil F-35 Jet
text: One of the earliest stealth weapons on record was a stone used by the young Israelite David to kill the Philistine giant Goliath. In the biblical account, David shunned the conventional armaments of his time: sword, helmet, armor. Instead, he went forth with a slingshot and a few stones, kept undetected in a pouch. As any schoolchild knows, one well-aimed fling was all it took to put Goliath down for good. The big guy never saw it coming.

headline: Review: In ‘Cure,’ Accepting the Mind’s Role in a Body’s Health
text: It’s been almost 40 years since Jeff Goldblum appeared in “Annie Hall” as an unnamed party guest who couldn’t remember his mantra. Mr. Goldblum has done very well since then; mantras, alas, have had a rougher go of it. But perhaps it’s time to ask: Must the mantra be forever impugned?

headline: Betting That Rock Is Back (Again)
text: For nearly two decades, “Now That’s What I Call Music!” has churned out what passive pop consumers want to hear — compilations of hit songs of the moment. In the United States, there have been 56 volumes, plus spinoff Latino versions, Christmas collections and more than a dozen country albums.

headline: Review: On ‘Lucifer,’ a Fox Drama, the Devil Tries to Fit In
text: Even Satanists will be reaching for the remote when …

headline: Puppy Amuser
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — Guess who got a puppy! No, not me. Ian Livengood, today’s constructor, got a puppy, her name is Josie and she’s adorable. I’m sure that, in no time at all, Josie will have Mr. Livengood and his wife properly trained to obey each and every one of her commands. Let’s congratulate him.

headline: Review: City Ballet Celebrates Balanchine and Heeds Mother Nature
text: New York City Ballet had planned to celebrate the birthday of George Balanchine as usual, with performances and demonstrations of his works. Instead, Mother Nature showed up on Saturday with the kind of enchanting yet hazardous gift common to fairy tale ballets: a waltz of the snowflakes voluminous enough to cause transit shutdowns that forced the troupe to cancel performances for the first time this century. Climatically, this may have been a climax, but for the company, it was an unfortunate interruption of the momentum built in the first week of its winter season.

headline: Pentagon Wants Psychologists to End Ban on Interrogation Role
text: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon has asked the American Psychological Association to reconsider its ban on the involvement of psychologists in national security interrogations at the Guantánamo Bay prison and other facilities.

headline: Public Divide on Police Hangs Over Brooklyn Officer’s Manslaughter Trial
text: On Thursday, the final day of jury selection in the trial of Peter Liang, the New York police officer charged with manslaughter in the shooting of an unarmed man in the stairwell of a Brooklyn housing project, a prosecutor asked jurors if they thought the charges were “heavy-handed.”

headline: Tyco International and Johnson Controls Are Said to Be Merging
text: Tyco International, the remnant of the industrial conglomerate that was marred with corporate scandal and later broken up, is in late-stage discussions to merge with Johnson Controls for as much as $20 billion, a person briefed on the discussions said on Sunday.

headline: Broncos’ Defense Bruises Tom Brady, Lifting Peyton Manning to Super Bowl
text: DENVER — His Broncos teammates came bounding through the tunnel, dispensing hugs and high-fives, and then here came Peyton Manning, shadowed by boom mikes and television cameras and mayhem.

headline: A Beloved Bronx Teacher Retires After a Conflict With His Principal
text: Tom Porton is used to drama: Since arriving at James Monroe High School as an English teacher 45 years ago, he has taught and staged plays. Outside, in the Bronx River neighborhood where the school is, there was plenty of drama in the 1980s, when AIDS and crack ravaged the area. His response then was to establish a group of peer educators who worked with Montefiore Medical Center to teach teenagers about H.I.V. prevention. His efforts earned him awards, including recognition from the City Council and the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, and led to his induction into the National Teachers Hall of Fame.

headline: Fishing for Donations, With a Coat Hanger in Hand
text: Ioannis Amanatidis — known to his customers as Johnny the Greek — would drive to his busy corner of Northern Boulevard in Bayside, Queens, in the morning with his food cart in tow. Lunch was still hours away, but every day for six or seven years, he said, an older man would be waiting when he arrived.

headline: Precipitous Rents in Ski Country Push Workers to Edges
text: BRECKENRIDGE, Colo. — On nights when she could not crash on a friend’s couch or unroll a sleeping mat on an attic floor, Chelsea Lilly tucked her silver Subaru into a supermarket parking lot or a dark spot along a mountain pass, wrapped herself in a green Army blanket and watched movies on her phone until she fell asleep.

headline: China Considers Larger Role in Afghanistan Peace Process
text: BEIJING — As a  bloody offensive by the Taliban spreads in Afghanistan and with American combat operations there officially ended, anxious Chinese leaders find themselves under pressure to take a more active role in the long-stalled peace process, according to scholars and current and former diplomats.

headline: Aboriginal Brass Band Offers Burst of Hope in a Bleak Community
text: YARRABAH, Australia — This remote stretch of coastline in north Queensland has much to offer: pristine beaches dotted with mango and palm trees, tropical breezes, an azure ocean.

headline: China Deepens Its Footprint in Iran After Lifting of Sanctions
text: ZARRINABAD, Iran — Rising from the yellowish, treeless plains so typical for central Iran stands a square labyrinth of pipes and conveyor belts, topped by a silver chimney that glitters in the summer sun.

headline: Fighting to Preserve the White Barn Theater
text: NORWALK, CONN. — Lucille Lortel, an actress and theater producer who was known as the queen of Off Broadway, staged hundreds of plays during her lifetime at her theater on Christopher Street in the West Village.

headline: In Portugal, Voters Pick Center-Right President
text: Portugal’s voters elected a veteran center-right politician and television commentator as their new president on Sunday, two months after a Socialist administration took office following inconclusive parliamentary elections.

headline: A Struggle to Quell Investor Fears Over Unsettled Emerging Markets
text: Currency turmoil in China and fears of a global slowdown have led investors to abandon emerging markets in droves, rattling the large asset management firms that have long promoted such investments in their hunt for higher returns.

headline: Southern Jersey Shore Hit With Severe Flooding by Snowstorm’s High Tides
text: The southern end of the Jersey Shore, which was largely spared by Hurricane Sandy three years ago, had the most severe flooding in the state during the weekend blizzard, as high tides sent icy water rushing into darkened homes and businesses.

headline: Second-Year Super Bowl Advertisers Face Their Own Pressures to Succeed
text: To say Alvaro Luque, the president of Avocados From Mexico, was nervous during last year’s Super Bowl would be an understatement. His company had decided to advertise during the game for the first time, and millions of dollars were at stake.

headline: Employee Wellness Programs Use Carrots and, Increasingly, Sticks
text: It may be an offer employees simply can no longer refuse.

headline: Protesters in Haiti Demand That President Quit
text: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — Volcy Assad, a Haitian political activist, stood before an enormous plume of black smoke emanating from a pile of burning tires and made it clear that the demands of protesters had changed.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Battle for Party’s Future
text: DES MOINES — The race between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders, which voters will begin deciding a week from Monday, is not just about the White House anymore. It has intensified into an epochal battle over their vastly different visions for the Democratic Party.

headline: Mother and Son, 1, Die of Carbon Monoxide Poisoning in Car During Snowstorm
text: A woman and her 1-year-old son died of carbon monoxide poisoning in Passaic, N.J., on Saturday after sitting in their parked car with the engine running, the police said.

headline: French Jews Fear a New Strain of ISIS-Inspired Anti-Semitism
text: MARSEILLE, France — It was the heavy leather-bound volume of the Torah he was carrying that shielded Benjamin Amsellem from the machete blows.

headline: Broncos’ Defense Keeps Patriots Off Rhythm
text: DENVER — New England Patriots quarterback Tom Brady was already having a day to forget by the time Denver Broncos safety Darian Stewart intercepted a pass late in the first half of the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Peyton Manning Is Primped and Primed for, Perhaps, a Final Showdown
text: DENVER — After the Denver Broncos won the A.F.C. championship game on Sunday to make it to the Super Bowl, Peyton Manning primped.

headline: Donald Trump Means Business in Iowa: Night in Motel, and a Day in Church
text: MUSCATINE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump spent the last seven months saying he wanted to win. Now he is really acting like it.

headline: Bob Bradley Climbs the Global Soccer Ladder With an Impediment: He’s American
text: LE HAVRE, France — In the conference room of a smart hotel in the center of this port city, four Frenchmen were talking loudly over one another and gesticulating toward a flip chart in front of a row of empty chairs.

headline: A Resurgent Marco Rubio Sprints to the Finish in Iowa
text: MARION, Iowa — For months, it was the biggest question nagging at the Rubio campaign here: “Where’s Marco?”

headline: Bobby Wanzer, 94, Hall of Fame Player From N.B.A.’s Early, Patient Days, Dies
text: Before the arrival of the 24-second shot clock in 1954 turned pro basketball into a fast-paced game, many a victory came from clever passing and ball-handling in the backcourt that set up good shots.

headline: Jeb Bush on the Stump Sounds Different From the TV Version
text: BERLIN, N.H. — Expectations are not always high at Jeb Bush’s campaign events, where impressions of his halting performances in debates and other TV appearances often precede him.

headline: Donald Trump Did Stay at a Holiday Inn Express on Friday Night
text: It wasn’t a Trump-branded hotel, but Donald J. Trump found the Holiday Inn Express in Sioux Center, Iowa, to be a perfectly suitable stand-in for Trump Tower or Mar-a-Lago.

headline: Shutting Down Aboveground Subway Service in New York, and Learning From Previous Missteps
text: For many New Yorkers, riding the subway is an underground experience, calling to mind dark tunnels and fluorescent-lit stations. But the blizzard over the weekend was a reminder of just how much of the system runs aboveground.

headline: Boston Globe Endorses Hillary Clinton
text: The Boston Globe, New England’s largest newspaper, has “enthusiastically” endorsed Hillary Clinton for the Democratic presidential nomination.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Clash on Issues and Vie for Votes of Iowa Women
text: NORTH LIBERTY, Iowa — From universal health care and paid family leave to college costs and the Keystone XL oil pipeline, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders challenged each other’s priorities and courted female voters on Sunday as they began the final week of their increasingly hard-fought campaign to win the Iowa caucuses next Monday.

headline: Panthers, Led by Flashy Cam Newton, Swamp Flailing Cardinals
text: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Fifteen minutes in, the party had already started: the laughing, the singing, the Dabbing, the crowing. The U2 song “Sunday Bloody Sunday” rang through the loudspeakers, and towels waved, and it continued to feel, justifiably, as if the Carolina Panthers were on the verge of another score.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Season 6, Episode 4: The Engine Purrs
text: Mary: “So! You really are a car man. I wasn’t sure how much you meant it.”

headline: Over 200 Educators in New York Receive Erroneous Scores Linked to Student Performance
text: More than 200 teachers and principals received erroneous scores from New York State on a contentious measurement that ties their performance to how well their students do on tests, according to state documents obtained by The New York Times.

headline: Return to Normalcy Will Be Halting as Mid-Atlantic Starts Digging Out
text: CHEVY CHASE, Md. — In Washington, there was a massive snowball fight in Dupont Circle, and on Capitol Hill, families went sledding. But in suburban Rosslyn, Va., Lila Hertz, 22, fell down in the snow Sunday as she struggled to find transportation to her job at a popular lunch spot two blocks from the White House. She was rescued by a passing cab — and was the only person who showed up for work.

headline: For Gadget Geek in the Oval Office, High Tech Has Its Limits
text: WASHINGTON — In this always-on, always-connected world, what good is a Fitbit with no GPS or an iPad that can’t connect to the cloud?

headline: ‘Weiner’ Directors Say Film Is About Media’s Sensationalism
text: PARK CITY, Utah — The directors of “Weiner,” which follows Anthony D. Weiner and his wife, Huma Abedin, as they navigate the public fallout from an explicit texting scandal, sought in remarks at the Sundance Film Festival on Sunday to position their documentary as less political personality study and more dissection of the news media.

headline: Woman, 59, Is Killed in Machete Attack in Bronx
text: A 59-year-old woman was fatally attacked by a man wielding a machete in the Mott Haven section of the Bronx on Sunday afternoon, the police said.

headline: Broadway Panhandler, Longtime Manhattan Cookware Retailer, to Close in Spring
text: Broadway Panhandler, a packed-to-the-rafters kitchen store that opened in Manhattan 40 years ago and is beloved by home cooks, celebrities and restaurant chefs, will close by the spring when its owner and founder, Norman Kornbleuth, retires.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 2: Part of the Firmament
text: Axelrod Hall will not be named Axelrod Hall forever. Even Bobby Axelrod understands that. His name will be there, he says, “until some guy richer than me wants it to come down.”

headline: ‘The X-Files’ Season 10 Premiere: A Crazier Mulder Than Usual
text: When I heard that “The X-Files” was coming back to TV, it was like hearing that I would see some dear old friends again. I spent every Friday night of my young adulthood with Agents Fox Mulder and Dana Scully. News of their coming six-week mini-series started me on a mega rewatch — I mainlined the original episodes in five-hour chunks.

headline: The Cigarette Smoking Man of ‘The X-Files’ Resurfaces
text: When we last saw the Cigarette Smoking Man, in “The X-Files” series finale in 2002, he was living as a guru in an old Anasazi settlement in New Mexico. Or at least he was, until a couple of black helicopters blew it and him to smithereens, seemingly ending his run as the story’s nefarious conspirator and prime concealer of whatever truths may, in fact, be out there.

headline: Updates on Schools, Subways and Commuter Rails After the Storm

headline: Alone, in a Crowd, With Gregory Crewdson
text: Gregory Crewdson’s photographs almost always project solitude and intimacy, even if his images take a team to organize. The subject of one of his images looks back at the experience.

headline: Alone, in a Crowd, With Gregory Crewdson
text: One push through a revolving door and I was in complete darkness. I walked to the right to get a sheet of resin-coated paper and then turned toward the enlarger, where I could finally rest my mind. The most sacred moments were when I could just stand there and dissolve into the test prints. There were no New York hospitals, no expectations of my father’s recovery or death. Not even the constant companion of intensive care beeping sounds, those Montefiore monitors I couldn’t get out of my head.

headline: Michigan’s Great Stink
text: In the 1850s, London, the world’s largest city, still didn’t have a sewer system. Waste simply flowed into the Thames, which was as disgusting as you might imagine. But conservatives, including the magazine The Economist and the prime minister, opposed any effort to remedy the situation. After all, such an effort would involve increased government spending and, they insisted, infringe on personal liberty and local control.

headline: New York City’s Promising Step on Criminal Justice
text: The New York City Council is poised to take what could be a step toward a fairer and smarter criminal justice system. A package of bills to be introduced on Monday seeks to resolve an old impasse over how to deter minor lawbreaking without punishing too many people unjustly.

headline: Ending the Horror of Myanmar’s Abuse of Muslims
text: The government of Myanmar’s departing president, Thein Sein, oversaw the systematic persecution of the country’s Rohingya Muslim minority — a human rights debacle that one study has described as genocide. Mr. Thein Sein also signed four bills into law last year regulating interfaith marriage, birth spacing and religious conversion that clearly targeted Myanmar’s Muslim minority.

headline: Drug Deaths Reach White America
text: Congress has historically treated drug abuse as a malady afflicting mostly poor, minority communities, best dealt with by locking people up for long periods of time. The epidemic of drug overdose deaths currently ravaging white populations in cities and towns across the country has altered this line of thinking, and forced lawmakers to acknowledge that addiction is a problem that knows no racial barriers and can be best addressed with treatment.

headline: Hillary Clinton Stumbles

headline: Convicted of Corruption, but Still Getting a Pension
text: IN New York State, both the former Assembly speaker Sheldon Silver and the former Senate majority leader Dean Skelos have recently been tried and convicted on numerous federal charges of corruption. They share another distinction: Since their trials, they have both applied for their state pensions. Sadly, they have every right to do so.

One of the best-known, and certainly the most detailed, of these works was Herman Kahn and Anthony J. Wiener’s “The Year 2000” (1967), which offered, among other things, a systematic list of technological innovations Kahn and Wiener considered “very likely in the last third of the 20th century.”

headline: 1941: Rome Concedes Loss of Tobruk

To give the people of this country some cheerier word, however, the military communique asserted that an Italian submarine had sunk the British armed merchantman Eumaeus, said to have been loaded with troops at the time, and that German airmen had dropped a large caliber bomb on an enemy heavy cruiser in the central Mediterranean. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 26, 1941

headline: Security at Paris Fashion Shows Less Strict Than Anticipated

Two months later, France is still in a state of emergency, with security barriers and increased patrols of police officers and soldiers carrying automatic weapons a common sight, even though residents say the fear that hung over the city before Christmas is less palpable now.

headline: Vincent Price’s Cookbook Lives On
text: In 1965, Vincent Price, the actor and connoisseur of art and food, wrote a cookbook with his wife, Mary, featuring recipes from restaurants in destinations including New York, California, France, Italy and England. The book became a collector’s item; now a 50th-anniversary edition has been published with the help of the Prices’ daughter, Victoria, who has written the preface. The Proust in all of us will relish the profiles of ghosts like Le Pavillon and the Forum of the Twelve Caesars in New York, the original La Pyramide in France and Bali in Amsterdam. Reproductions of menus, with prices like $3.25 for Lüchow’s Wiener schnitzel and $5.95 for roast duck at the Four Seasons (soon to be another fond memory) will give you pause. There are well-detailed, pre-food-processor recipes, including an unapologetic quiche Lorraine calling for eight egg yolks: “A Treasury of Great Recipes: 50th Anniversary Edition” (Dover, $50).

headline: 2016 Executive Power Survey Responses

headline: Supreme Court Upholds Efforts on Managing Electricity Use Through Pricing
text: The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that federal regulators may encourage electricity users like schools, hospitals and shopping centers to reduce consumption at peak times in exchange for price breaks. The regulatory approach, known as “demand response,” lowers costs for consumers and lessens the risk of system failures that can cause blackouts.

headline: Deep Manure and the Future

headline: Woody Guthrie Wrote of His Contempt for His Landlord, Donald Trump’s Father
text: More than a half-century ago, the folk singer Woody Guthrie signed a lease in an apartment complex in Brooklyn. He soon had bitter words for his landlord: Donald J. Trump’s father, Fred C. Trump.

headline: N.H.L. This Week: Jockeying Before the All-Star Game
text: With a light schedule because of the All-Star Game break, it’s time for a special Monday edition of The New York Times’s look at the week ahead in the N.H.L. (All times Eastern.)

headline: Johnson Controls and Tyco Can Take a Political Punch
text: Johnson Controls’ acquisition of Tyco International is insured against politics.

headline: An Artist’s Monograph That Tests the Limits of Language
text: “Language,” notes the filmmaker and artist Wu Tsang, “is always present in my work.” And as her first monograph, “Not in My Language” (Walther König, $50), makes clear, how we say things extends beyond simply the words we use. Intended as a companion to Tsang’s 2015 group exhibitions at the Kunsthalle Düsseldorf and the Migros Museum in Zurich, the publication surveys the artist’s prodigious output and highlights themes recurrent throughout her work. Combining stills and reproduced screenplays from six of her films — including “DAMELO TODO,” 2010, centering on the story of an El Salvadorian teenage refugee who finds sanctuary in L.A.’s transgender community, and her documentary “Wildness,” 2012, which profiles the habitués of Silver Lake’s legendary trans bar the Silver Platter and was included in the 2014 Whitney Biennial — “Not in My Language” foregrounds Tsang’s interest in communities and subcultures often relegated to the margins of society.

headline: Guardian to Slash Costs and Renew Online Focus
text: The Guardian said on Monday that it intended to cut its costs sharply in an effort to reduce its losses and break even at an operating level in three years’ time.

headline: Unprompted, John Kasich Makes Light of His Tenure at Lehman Brothers
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. – John Kasich is campaigning for president as the good-humor man, eschewing what he calls the “doom and gloom” of his rivals for the Republican nomination.

headline: As Iowa Caucuses Approach, Political Ads Swamp TV Channels
text: DES MOINES — Ted Cruz was accused of proposing a socialist tax plan. Marco Rubio was called out for supporting “amnesty” for illegal immigrants. Bernie Sanders denounced the “rigged economy,” and Jeb Bush’s campaign was called a “train wreck.”

headline: Vintage Photos of Jeanne Lanvin, Jean-Paul Gaultier, Christian Dior and More
text: Fashion flashback! To celebrate haute couture week in Paris, T visited the New York Times photo archives and unearthed historical gems of couture designers at work (and play).

headline: Michigan Attorney General Picks Investigator for Flint Water Case
text: CHICAGO — The attorney general of Michigan said Monday that a former county prosecutor would lead his office’s investigation into the water crisis in Flint, where a 2014 switch of the city’s drinking water source led to contamination and widespread health concerns.

headline: Emotional Accounts of Financial Struggle at a Bernie Sanders Event
text: IOWA FALLS, Iowa — Carrie Aldrich, 46, wept Monday as she told Senator Bernie Sanders and 200 other people about her struggles cycling though minimum-wage jobs, fighting to get disability checks for a joint disorder, and having to rely on her elderly parents for survival.

headline: Missouri Professor Who Called for ‘Some Muscle’ at Protest Is Charged
text: COLUMBIA, Mo. — A University of Missouri assistant professor who called for “some muscle” as she tried to remove journalists from a campus protest last year was charged on Monday with misdemeanor assault, court documents showed.

headline: Arguments Over North Carolina Voter ID Law Begin in Federal Court
text: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. — The bitter dispute about North Carolina’s elections laws returned to a federal courtroom here on Monday as the state’s voter identification requirement went on trial.

headline: The Bugs Sharing Your Home (Get Out a Calculator)
text: Humans share their homes with hundreds of species of flies, spiders, beetles, lice and other arthropods, a new study reports.

headline: Some Carnivores Are Better Than Others at Unlocking Dinner
text: Spotted hyenas are the animals that got Sarah Benson-Amram thinking about how smart carnivores are and in what ways.

headline: New York Officer Charged in Akai Gurley’s Fatal Shooting Goes on Trial
text: At about 11 o’clock on the night of Nov. 20, 2014, Melissa Lopez was in her kitchen in the Louis H. Pink Houses in East New York. Her partner was getting ready for his workday, which started at midnight, and her two girls were in their rooms.

headline: Review: ‘Outsiders,’ the Latest Iteration of the American Family as Criminal Enterprise
text: To the line of television shows that imagine the American family as an embattled criminal enterprise — “The Sopranos,” “Sons of Anarchy” — add “Outsiders,” a 13-episode series starting Tuesday on WGN America. Like the New Jersey wiseguys and drug-dealing California bikers in those shows, the Farrells, the moonshine-making Kentucky clan in “Outsiders,” are morally compromised but representative of traditional American values. They may engage in armed robbery, vandalism and matricide, but it’s because they really just want to be left alone.

headline: If Bloomberg Enters the Presidential Race …
text: To the Editor:

headline: Giambattista Valli: Couture
text: Giambattista Valli’s couture show.

headline: A Bird’s-Eye View After a Winter Storm
text: Drone and aerial footage show a peaceful, snow-covered Northeast after a winter storm coated parts of Pennsylvania, New York, New Jersey and several other states.

headline: Justices Expand Parole Rights for Juveniles Sentenced to Life for Murder
text: The Supreme Court on Monday ruled that its 2012 decision banning mandatory life-without-parole sentences for juvenile killers must be applied retroactively, granting a new chance at release for hundreds of inmates serving life sentences without the possibility of parole for murders they committed in their youth.

headline: ‘The Skinny,’ About Bulimia, to Debut at Sundance
text: PARK CITY, Utah — A couple of years ago, Jessie Kahnweiler was interning at Bad Robot, the movie and television company owned by J. J. Abrams. But she found herself wanting something else. Finally, all around her in Hollywood, or so it seemed, were intrepid women making boundary-pushing shows: “Girls,” “Broad City,” “Transparent.”

headline: Rock Is Back as Panic! At the Disco Tops Billboard Chart
text: It’s not often that a rock album tops the Billboard album chart, but Panic! At the Disco did it this week with its new release, “Death of a Bachelor” (Fueled by Ramen/DCD2), which sold 169,000 copies and had 17 million streams, according to Nielsen.

headline: New From Hilton: Midpriced Hotels Geared Toward Millennials
text: Hilton Worldwide has announced a new hotel brand today, Tru by Hilton, that is positioned to be the first design-forward hotel chain in the midscale category where rooms start at $80.

headline: Review: Donny McCaslin’s Quartet, Fresh Off the Release of Bowie’s ‘Blackstar’
text: Donny McCaslin dedicated an untitled new song at the Village Vanguard on Sunday night to someone he said had been a great influence in his life, “someone who recently passed away.” The song, which began in a hush, sounded faintly familiar: The brooding dignity of its melody, carried by Mr. McCaslin on tenor saxophone against a spooky stir of keyboards, bass and drums, evoked the mood of David Bowie’s last album, “Blackstar.”

headline: Palestinian Assailants Are Killed After Knife Attack on 2 Israeli Women
text: JERUSALEM — Two Palestinian assailants stabbed two Israeli women in a Jewish settlement in the occupied West Bank on Monday, wounding one of them severely, before being fatally shot by a security guard, according to the Israeli police.

headline: J. Crew Puts Its Own Spin on Classic Sunglasses Shapes
text: “Every time I see myself in a picture and I’m wearing aviators, I think ‘ugh,’” says Jenna Lyons, the president and creative director of the J. Crew Group. “They have a tendency to tilt down, so that the top of the glass lifts away from your eyebrow and the bottom hits the top of your cheek. They aren’t that flattering in photos — I know that sounds silly, but for us, it’s a big thing.”

headline: Dior’s Couture Show Has a Different Look
text: PARIS — Traditionally, the front row of the Dior couture show, which was held Monday in the gardens of the Musée Rodin, has bloomed with the radiant faces of its campaign stars and A-list Hollywood actresses. Emily Blunt, Lupita Nyong’o and Charlize Theron are just a handful of stars who have attended in recent seasons.

headline: Linking Arthritis to Old Injuries
text: Q. Why does arthritis tend to develop in joints that have experienced trauma earlier in life?

text: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: E.U. Ministers Spar as Bloc’s Promise of Free Movement Wavers
text: AMSTERDAM — European Union interior ministers clashed on Monday over how to check the flow of migrants across their countries’ borders amid growing concern that the Continent’s commitment to the free movement of people within the bloc is at risk of collapse.

headline: Facts & Figures: What Democrats and Republicans Want From Politicians
text: A recent Monmouth University poll asked respondents which caused more problems in the federal government: elected officials’ failure to compromise, or their failure to stand by their principles. Sixty-eight percent of Democrats said lack of compromise was the bigger problem, while 25 percent chose failure to stand on principle. Among Republicans, meanwhile, 54 percent said failure to stand on principle was the bigger issue, and just 36 percent picked lack of compromise.

headline: Hillary Clinton Holds Fire on Bernie Sanders, Taking Aim at Republicans
text: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — Hillary Clinton’s remarks on the campaign trail a week before the Iowa caucuses are harking back to a simpler time in her candidacy: last month.

headline: Opposition Groups in Moldova Unite to Protest New Government
text: BUCHAREST, Romania — Frustration with the political establishment is boiling over again in Moldova, where more than 15,000 people took to the streets of the capital on Sunday to vent their anger at the new government that was sworn in just last week.

headline: Where the Wild Things Aren’t: A Sendak Museum
text: RIDGEFIELD, Conn. — The characters of Maurice Sendak may live in the imaginations of children around the world, but many of those characters were born in a wooded residential neighborhood on the outskirts of this small town, in a rambling shingle house where Mr. Sendak lived and worked beginning in the early 1970s.

headline: Review: Milton Babbitt Inspires a Focus! Festival Tribute
text: Street crime, of all things, might have been what caused the brainy composer Milton Babbitt to abandon his Concerti for Violin, Orchestra and Synthesized Sound in 1976. That’s what Joel Sachs, the founding director of the New Juilliard Ensemble, suggested to the audience that nearly filled the Peter Jay Sharp Theater at the school on Friday for the opening concert of the 32nd Focus! festival, a free weeklong centennial tribute to Babbitt.

headline: In Napa Valley, Future Landscapes Are Viewed in the Past
text: NAPA, Calif. — San Francisco Bay, the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta and the watershed that feeds them make up one of the world’s largest estuary systems, a wildly varied tableau of beaches, river, creeks, grasslands and tidal marshes. Forty percent of the land in California drains into this rich ecosystem.

headline: Ted Cruz on Feud With Donald Trump: He Started It
text: MANCHESTER, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas suggested a simple explanation on Monday for his sudden antagonism toward Donald J. Trump in recent weeks: The other guy started it.

headline: Billy Donovan’s One-on-One Game Plan to Connect With Thunder Players
text: Not long after Billy Donovan became coach of the Oklahoma City Thunder last spring, he had a member of his staff reach out to the players. The team had scuffled through an injury-marred season, and most of the players had scattered for the approaching summer. Steve Novak, for example, was home in Wisconsin when he got the phone call.

text: Photos from New York, France and England

headline: As Population Ages, Where Are the Geriatricians?
text: PORTLAND, Ore. — Ruth Miles, 83, sat in a wheelchair in a small exam room, clutching a water bottle, looking frightened and uncomfortable.

headline: Jan. 25, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from the United States, France, Israel and London.

headline: Review: ‘Drunk Shakespeare,’ Where the Tipsy and the Sober Take Liberties
text: It seems inevitable that soon all performing will be done either plastered or stoned. Among the early adopters of this trend, probably no one is applying more verve to the conceit than the members of the Drunk Shakespeare Society. Here’s hoping others learn from their sloshy example.

headline: Joni Ernst, Standing Next to Marco Rubio, Is Not Endorsing Anyone
text: DES MOINES — Senator Joni Ernst of Iowa wants you to know that she is remaining neutral in next week’s caucuses.

headline: Celebrities and Their Sundance Style
text: Sundance fashion doesn’t have to be Canada Goose puffers, hats and bulky boots. Here are celebrities who are stepping out stylishly in the Utah weather.

headline: Citadel Punishes Students for Costumes Evoking the K.K.K.
text: Fourteen cadets at the Citadel in Charleston, S.C., were disciplined on Monday after several of them appeared last month in photographs wearing white pillowcases on their heads. The pillowcases evoked a likeness to the hoods worn by the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: Some Areas Hit by East Coast Blizzard Can Only Crawl Toward Recovery
text: The storm is over. But as millions of people from North Carolina to Massachusetts tried on Monday to dig out from the weekend’s massive snows, it was clear that for many of them it could still be several days before life returns to normal.

headline: Review: Young Pianists Offer Rich Duos
text: Music may not offer a better mixture of grandeur and intimacy than the piano duo. Just two people on stage, yes, but each playing this instrument of fearsome potency. In range of colors and sheer volume, the combination surely has no equal in the chamber repertory.

headline: Review: Peter Bergen’s ‘United States of Jihad’ Surveys Homegrown Terrorism
text: Since Sept. 11, 2001, Peter Bergen reports in his new timely book, 330 people in the United States have been charged with some kind of jihadist terrorist crime, and a startling four out of five of them were American citizens or legal permanent residents.

headline: Bill de Blasio Not Keen on a Bloomberg Presidential Run
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York weighed in Monday on a potential presidential run by his predecessor, Michael R. Bloomberg, saying he did not believe Americans would “turn to billionaires to solve problems created by billionaires.”

headline: 2 Abortion Foes Behind Planned Parenthood Videos Are Indicted
text: HOUSTON — A grand jury here that was investigating accusations of misconduct against Planned Parenthood has instead indicted two abortion opponents who made undercover videos of the organization.

headline: Sarah Palin, Rage Whisperer
text: DONALD J. TRUMP has made a shrewd bet. For the first time since he descended an escalator in Trump Tower last June to announce that this time, he really was running for president, he ceded control of his campaign message. He handed the Trump-bedecked podium over to Sarah Palin.

headline: Zika Virus: Two Cases Suggest It Could Be Spread Through Sex
text: Zika virus has already been linked to brain damage in babies and paralysis in adults. Now scientists are facing another ominous possibility: that on rare occasions, the virus might be transmitted through sex.

headline: A Space Station, With Surveillance Cameras for Hire
text: LONDON — The two cameras sit on the Russian part of the International Space Station. They are named Theia and Iris. And they are available to hire out for “space-based video surveillance.”

headline: Bernie Sanders Mailing in Iowa Defends His Record on Guns
text: The rah-rah atmosphere at campaign events for Senator Bernie Sanders is often punctured, if only momentarily, by a sharp question from a voter asking him to explain his record on gun regulation and his vote affording special legal protection to the gun industry.

headline: Review: ‘The Burial at Thebes,’ a Vicious but Poetic Tale Retold
text: A few things feel off in “The Burial at Thebes.” But one big thing — the script — is on, and that saves this version of “Antigone” from failure.

headline: Looks from Schai’s fall/winter 2016 collection
text: The military-inspired line is also an homage to her team.

headline: For One Designer, Inspiration That Began With Hand-Me-Downs
text: Listening to the designer Suk Chai describe a garment in thorough detail is almost like seeing it and touching it for yourself. She fine-tuned her fashion vocabulary as a child, watching items that originally belonged to her eldest brother get passed to her second-oldest brother, then to her older sister, and finally to her. “I waited for this particular tweed coat and red beret for at least six years,” says Chai, now 43, who was born in Korea and raised in Seattle. Her first non-hand-me-down came in the form of a white, crew-neck, short-sleeved, all-cotton dress with patchwork and a poofy skirt (the occasion: her second-grade piano recital). “Both outfits were special,” she remarks. “The tweed coat — I had my eye on that for a long, long time, and I loved it and knew it’d eventually be mine; but I did like having my own clothes.”

headline: New York Weddings Blanketed in White
text: Some couples were in denial about how disruptive one of the biggest blizzards in the city’s history would be.

headline: How to Build Affordable Housing in New York City
text: Hurricane Sandy was the last straw for many residents of Ocean Village, a housing project in the Rockaways. Heralded as state of the art when it opened in 1972, this beachside campus of high-rises and four-story townhouses had, over the years, taken a nose dive, the victim of bad management, crime and rot. Sandy left homes flooded, and poor tenants bereft of electricity and hot water. Residents who could, fled.

headline: As Iowa Caucuses Near, Jeb Bush Goes to Nevada
text: Iowans head to their local caucus precincts a week from Monday — and Jeb Bush on Tuesday is headed to … Elko, Nev.

headline: Budget Office Lowers Its Forecast for Obamacare Enrollment
text: When the Affordable Care Act was drafted, the Congressional Budget Office expected people to sign up quickly for new health insurance.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Personal on Christ and Her Faith
text: KNOXVILLE, Iowa — Hillary Clinton is Methodist, but she rarely talks about her faith on the campaign trail.

headline: The Best Women’s Looks — on the Men’s Runways
text: As the fall/winter 2016 men’s shows wrap up in Europe, a look back at a surprising trend: the inclusion of women’s wear.
