headline: Hillary Clinton, Battling in Iowa, Turns Warm Under Pressure
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa — At big ballroom dinners on the campaign trail, Hillary Clinton often emerges from behind a curtain to deliver a speech, then disappears again behind the folds when finished.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Consultant Gets $7 Million More to Plan Reform at Rikers Jails
text: In the latest indication of how daunting it has been to remake the troubled New York City jails, the de Blasio administration is spending an additional $7 million on an international consulting firm that it first hired in 2014 to develop a blueprint for reform.

headline: Marvin Minsky, Pioneer in Artificial Intelligence, Dies at 88
text: Marvin Minsky, who combined a scientist’s thirst for knowledge with a philosopher’s quest for truth as a pioneering explorer of artificial intelligence, work that helped inspire the creation of the personal computer and the Internet, died on Sunday night in Boston. He was 88.

headline: Seeking to End Gerrymandering’s Enduring Legacy
text: WASHINGTON — Buried less than two miles from the Capitol is the man many blame for the toxic partisanship infecting Congress today even though he died 202 years ago.

headline: Argentina Scrambles to Fight Biggest Plague of Locusts in 60 Years
text: BUENOS AIRES — Farmers and fumigators in Argentina are running out of time as they scramble to control the country’s worst plague of locusts in more than half a century, officials warned on Monday.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Backed by Image of a Bright Horizon, Lays Out His Vision
text: In Part 2 of his closing argument to Iowans, Senator Bernie Sanders lays out his vision and explicitly asks Democrats to caucus for him.

headline: Three Styling Take-Aways from Dior Couture
text: With Raf Simons gone, Dior’s spring/summer 2016 haute couture collection, which showed today in Paris, was left to studio heads Lucie Meier and Serge Ruffieux. Though Simons’s modern sensibility was certainly felt in Meier and Ruffieux’s designs, the duo introduced small styling suggestions in several looks that were entirely fresh. Here, three tricks from the show that were cool, laid back — and far more approachable than is typical for couture.

headline: Atelier Versace’s Athletic-Inspired Haute Couture Collection
text: For spring 2016, Donatella Versace celebrated strength and femininity with ergonomic lines, sporty hues and cutout silhouettes.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump Far Ahead in New Hampshire, Poll Finds
text: Senator Bernie Sanders and Donald J. Trump appear to be the candidates to beat in New Hampshire, according to a poll released Monday that showed them with commanding leads two weeks before the state’s primary.

headline: Iran Still a Leading Executioner of Minors, Report Says
text: Iran is one of the leading executioners of juvenile offenders, despite its improved legal protections for children and a pledge more than two decades ago to end the death penalty for convicts younger than 18, Amnesty International said Monday.

headline: Tumult in World Markets Damps Conviction at Davos
text: DAVOS, Switzerland — The World Economic Forum has long been a citadel for corporate chieftains and government officials to bask in their collective stature, coming together to chat about what they can do as leaders about the world’s troubles.

headline: Pope Francis, Catholics and Lutherans Will Recall Reformation
text: Nearly 500 years ago, Martin Luther nailed his 95 theses to the door of a German church, beginning the Protestant Reformation that led millions to break with the Roman Catholic Church and ushered in more than a century of conflict and war.

headline: 2 Offices Won’t Investigate New York Constitutional Amendment on Adirondack Mining
text: The offices of the New York attorney general and inspector general have declined to open investigations into the 2013 constitutional amendment that allowed a private company, NYCO Minerals, to conduct open-pit mining on state land in the Adirondack Mountains.

headline: The Supreme Court Says Again: Juveniles Are Different
text: The Supreme Court has ruled repeatedly over the last decade that it is morally and constitutionally wrong to equate offenses committed by emotionally undeveloped adolescents with crimes carried out by adults. It made this point again on Monday when it ruled that people who were sentenced to mandatory life in prison without the possibility of parole as juveniles have the right to seek parole.

headline: Comforts of a Hotel That’s Close to Home in Dangerous Weather
text: When Robert Kruszka of Virginia saw last weekend’s storm heading for the Washington area, he did not hesitate to find a place where he and his family could stay warm and comfortable — the nearby Hyatt Regency Tysons Corner Center.

headline: Quintonio LeGrier’s Three 911 Calls
text: Audio released Monday of calls placed to the Chicago police by Mr. LeGrier on Dec. 26. Mr. LeGrier was fatally shot by officers as he emerged from a home holding a baseball bat.

headline: California: Help Sought to Find Escapees
text: Two of the three inmates who escaped Friday from a maximum security jail in Orange County are believed to be members of Vietnamese gangs, and sheriff’s officials said on Monday that they believe the men could be embedded within the county’s sizable Vietnamese community. Officials identified Jonathan Tieu, 20, and Bac Duong, 43, as likely members of Vietnamese gangs, which they declined to name. Officials put out a message in Vietnamese asking for any information about the fugitives. The family of Mr. Tieu spoke to a local television station, and asked him to turn himself in. The two men and a third inmate, Hossein Nayeri, 37, have not been seen since the Friday morning head count at the Orange County Central Men’s Jail in Santa Ana. It is unclear if they had help from jail employees or contractors.

headline: Dean Skelos and His Son, Convicted on Corruption Charges, Seek New Trial
text: Lawyers for Dean G. Skelos, the former New York State Senate majority leader, and his son, who were convicted on federal corruption charges last month, filed a motion on Monday seeking a judgment of acquittal and a new trial.

headline: Climate Deal’s First Big Hurdle: The Draw of Cheap Oil
text: Barely a month after world leaders signed a sweeping agreement to reduce carbon emissions, the global commitment to renewable energy sources faces its first big test as the price of oil collapses.

headline: Yemen: Top Judge and 6 Relatives Are Killed in Airstrike
text: Airstrikes by the Saudi-led military coalition on Monday hit the home of a senior judge in Sana, Yemen’s capital, killing the judge along with six relatives, according to witnesses and medics. The judge, Yayha Alrubaid, who headed a court that dealt with national security matters and terrorism, had recently prosecuted members of Yemen’s Saudi-backed government in exile for high treason, officials said. Saudi Arabia entered Yemen’s civil war in March on the side of President Abdu Rabbu Mansour Hadi, who was driven from power by Houthi rebels last year. Coalition airstrikes have routinely hit civilian targets and killed hundreds of people, according to human rights workers. The Obama administration, which has supported the Saudi-led campaign in Yemen, issued an unusual statement on Saturday, criticizing recent airstrikes that killed a Yemeni journalist and an ambulance driver working with Doctors Without Borders, though the statement made no mention of Saudi Arabia or the coalition.

headline: So Far, Amazon and Netflix Are Sundance’s Top Buyers
text: PARK CITY, Utah — It was the independent film equivalent of a crack of thunder.

headline: Zephyr Teachout Announces Bid for New York Congressional Seat
text: ALBANY — Zephyr Teachout has a name that can be both hard to remember and, for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, probably hard to forget.

headline: El Salvador’s Advice on Zika Virus: Don’t Have Babies
text: SAN SALVADOR — When in human history has an epidemic become so alarming that a nation feels compelled to urge its people not to have children for two years?

headline: A Tidal Wave of Corporate Migrants Seeking (Tax) Shelter
text: In the fall of 2008, with General Motors and Chrysler on the precipice of bankruptcy, executives at the car parts supplier Johnson Controls flew to Washington. The company’s president testified before a Senate panel and implored lawmakers to bail out the auto industry.

headline: Upset Over Megyn Kelly, Donald Trump Says He May Skip Debate
text: With anticipation building over the final Republican debate before the Iowa caucuses next week, one candidate is contemplating skipping it: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Police Presence in Egypt Mutes Most Protests on 5th Anniversary of Uprising
text: CAIRO — The few dozen protesters seemed to emerge from nowhere, surging down a narrow street and waving a four-finger salute that identified them as likely supporters of Egypt’s outlawed Muslim Brotherhood.

headline: Libya: Parliament Rejects Cabinet Plan
text: Lawmakers in Libya’s internationally recognized Parliament overwhelmingly rejected a proposed United Nations-backed unity cabinet on Monday, dealing a blow to diplomatic efforts to swiftly reconcile the country’s splintered factions. Parliament, which sits in the eastern city of Tobruk, rejected the 32-member cabinet out of concern that it was too large and that its members had been chosen not for their competency but to satisfy various regional factions, according to Abu Bakr Buera, an influential lawmaker. Diplomats have been urging Libyan officials to bridge the divisions that emerged after the 2011 revolt against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Budget Office Sharply Cuts Health Exchange Estimate
text: WASHINGTON — The Congressional Budget Office on Monday sharply reduced its estimate of how many people would get health insurance this year through the Affordable Care Act’s public marketplaces, to 13 million, from a prior estimate of 21 million.

headline: Central African Republic: Court Invalidates Legislative Election
text: The Central African Republic’s constitutional court certified presidential election results Monday but separately scrapped results from a legislative election, citing irregularities like illegible ballots and poor training for election workers. The court’s validation sets the stage for a runoff for the presidential election that pits Anicet-Georges Dologuélé against Faustin Archange Touadera, two former prime ministers. They will face each other in a vote scheduled for no sooner than Feb. 7. Election observers said that redoing the legislative vote, which took place simultaneously with the presidential vote, would be costly. Candidates were puzzled by the court’s decision. “This is illogical,” said Lydie Nzengou, the communications officer for Karim Meckassoua, a presidential candidate. “Why would the results for the presidential vote be more credible than those of the legislative vote?”

headline: Donald Trump to New Hampshire: Give Me a Mandate
text: FARMINGTON, N.H. – Donald J. Trump asked New Hampshire voters on Monday to hand him a victory so big, so beautiful, that only one word in the political lexicon could describe it.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ Season 10, Episode 2: That’s More Like It
text: Part human, part alien siblings who can shatter glass; stolen babies; evil parents; our heroes in danger; and suits for everyone. “The X-Files” is back!

headline: Online, Egypt’s Internet Activists Mourn Their Stifled Revolt
text: As my colleague Declan Walsh reports from Cairo, a crackdown by Egypt’s security forces managed to suppress even the slightest echo of the massive street protests that began on this date in 2011 and led, 18 days later, to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Chris Christie’s Momentum Tested as Opponents Attack
text: HAMPTON FALLS, N.H. — Gov. Chris Christie has seized every chance to show voters that he is a man with true grit. In a summer of Black Lives Matter protests, he cast himself as a flinty defender of the police. He responded to the attacks in Paris and San Bernardino, Calif., by campaigning as a fearless former antiterrorism prosecutor.

headline: Libyan Lawmakers Reject U.N.-Backed Unity Government
text: CAIRO — Lawmakers in Libya’s internationally recognized Parliament overwhelmingly rejected a proposed United Nations-backed unity cabinet on Monday, dealing a blow to diplomatic efforts to swiftly reconcile the country’s splintered factions.

headline: Obama Bans Solitary Confinement of Juveniles in Federal Prisons
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Monday banned the practice of holding juveniles in solitary confinement in federal prisons, saying it could lead to “devastating, lasting psychological consequences.”

headline: Waiting in the Sky
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The world lost DAVID BOWIE, one of its most innovative musical artists, recently. More than that, we lost someone who made it acceptable to be just who you happened to be at the time: fluid, sparkly, experimental without fear, both human and alien at once. He made it easier for kids who were discovering their own styles and their own sexuality to be themselves, and we will not see his kind again. We’ve lost our Starman.

headline: Man Killed by Chicago Police Called 911 Before Being Shot
text: CHICAGO — A man who was fatally shot by the police in December as he emerged from a home with a baseball bat had called 911 seeking help from the police three times in the minutes before the shooting, but was met with curt dispatchers, according to audio of the calls made public on Monday. One of the dispatchers hung up on him when he was unwilling to elaborate on what was wrong.

headline: Red Wings Halt Islanders’ Momentum
text: Playing for only the third time in 11 days and skating in their last game before the All-Star break, the Islanders had a chance on Monday to vault into the winter break in style.

headline: Bernie Sanders a Target of Ads by Republican Donor
text: A “super PAC” founded by the former TD Ameritrade executive Joe Ricketts is spending more than $600,000 on a television ad in Iowa lashing Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont as “too liberal” in the final days of his close race against Hillary Clinton in the state’s caucuses.

headline: Trial Begins in Art Forgery Case Against Knoedler Gallery
text: Perhaps the most anticipated trial exploring the art market in recent years began Monday in United States District Court in Manhattan with a lawyer for a couple that bought a fake Rothko asserting in her opening argument that Knoedler & Company, a once-celebrated Manhattan gallery that is now defunct, had deceived its customers while selling them dozens of fake works that it said were by master artists.

headline: Suspect in Machete Killing in the Bronx Said Neighbors Spied on Him, Officials Say
text: A 26-year-old man who told the police his neighbors in a Bronx public housing complex were spying on him was charged on Monday with killing a 59-year-old woman in a machete attack outside her mother’s apartment, the authorities said.

headline: Serena Williams Rolls Past Maria Sharapova at Australian Open
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Maria Sharapova gives herself and her public plenty of time to think as she takes her now-characteristic long pause between first and second serves.

headline: Traffic Comes to a Halt, and a Kitten Is Saved
text: Stopped at a light on Ocean Parkway in Brooklyn on Monday afternoon, a block from her house in Windsor Terrace, Geraldine Cassone saw a little black kitten run in front of her car.

headline: Rangers Savor Win and a Week to Relax
text: Coach Alain Vigneault stepped briskly to a lectern two hours before his Rangers were to face the last-place Buffalo Sabres on Monday in their final game before the N.H.L. All-Star break and announced that Rick Nash had sustained only a bruised left knee Friday.

headline: Film Academy Gives Guidance on Oscar Voting Rights
text: LOS ANGELES — As its members struggled to understand new diversity-oriented rules that may cost many their Oscar voting rights, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences late Monday disclosed guidelines meant to settle at least some questions about who remains in and who may be out of Hollywood’s exclusive professional association.

headline: Miley Cyrus Joins the Cast of Woody Allen’s Amazon Series
text: For his first foray into streaming television, Woody Allen is relying on one of his tried and true formulas — casting an attention-grabbing young actress alongside himself. In this case, Miley Cyrus, the former Disney kid turned outré pop star, will appear in his coming streaming series for Amazon.

headline: Judge Upholds Gun Arrest Made by New York Officer Who Was Later Killed
text: One of the last gun-possession arrests made by a New York police officer who was killed in the line of duty last year remained intact on Monday, after a state judge denied a request by the defense to exclude the weapon from evidence.

headline: 2 People From New York Are Found Dead in Cars After Storm
text: Two people from New York were found dead in their cars on Monday, and the authorities were investigating whether their deaths were related to the weekend blizzard.

headline: Obama to Urge Easing 401(k) Rules for Small Businesses
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will propose in his 2017 budget new rules that would make it easier for small businesses to join together to form 401(k) retirement plans for their workers, even if the businesses are in different industries, administration officials said Monday.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | halting
text: halting • \ˈhȯl-tiN\ • adjective

headline: Ted Cruz Reminds Iowans That Donald Trump Called Them ‘Stupid’
text: Senator Ted Cruz is trying to antagonize Iowans against Donald J. Trump, with whom he is locked in an increasingly contentious fight, in this new ad, “New York Values.”

headline: In Iowa Forum, Democrats Promote Themes for Final Stretch to Caucuses
text: DES MOINES — Democrats made their final arguments to Iowans on Monday night, with Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont offering contrasting views about whose vision would best move the country forward.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
text: “Justified” all over again? Not so much, our critic says of “Outsiders,” which features English as a second language. Elsewhere, watch Jack Black do his panda shtick without having to buy a movie ticket. And John Quiñones brings back his shame game.

headline: Malaysia Closes Investigation Into Prime Minister Najib Razak’s Funds
text: BANGKOK — Malaysia’s attorney general said on Tuesday that he had closed an investigation into transfers of hundreds of millions of dollars into Prime Minister Najib Razak’s personal bank accounts because no laws had been broken.

headline: Editors’ Note: January 26, 2016
text: INTERNATIONAL

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “It’s not up to the government. It’s up to God.”

headline: Christie’s 2015 Sales at $7.4 Billion, a 5 Percent Drop
text: After a year that included its $170.4 million auction of Amedeo Modigliani’s “Nu Couché” in November, Christie’s on Tuesday announced total sales of $7.4 billion for 2015, down 5 percent over the previous year.

headline: Liberals Turn to Cities to Pass Laws and Spread Ideas
text: If Congress won’t focus on a new policy idea, and if state legislatures are indifferent or hostile, why not skip them both and start at the city level?

headline: Amid Bay Area Gentrification, One Man’s Three-Year Struggle
text: A chance encounter with a man trying for a new start in Oakland led to a complex, three-year tale with no easy answers.

headline: Merger of Huntington and FirstMerit to Create Banking Giant in Ohio
text: Huntington Bancshares said on Tuesday that it would buy FirstMerit Corporation in a deal worth $3.4 billion in stock and cash.

headline: Amid Bay Area Gentrification, One Man’s Three-Year Struggle
text: Amid the political and cultural fervor a half-century ago, Oakland and the Bay Area were once home to founding members of the Black Panthers, Beats and hippie movements. These days it’s attracting many white middle-class residents who bring with them rising rents and displacement. When Sam Wolson moved to Oakland, he became keenly aware that he was a part of that influx.

headline: What Voters Want
text: Imagine you’re discussing the presidential election with a group of friends who live in Iowa or New Hampshire. You ask them who they intend to vote for next month.

headline: Opening a New Front Against ISIS in Libya
text: The Pentagon is ramping up intelligence-gathering in Libya as the Obama administration draws up plans to open a third front in the war against the Islamic State. This significant escalation is being planned without a meaningful debate in Congress about the merits and risks of a military campaign that is expected to include airstrikes and raids by elite American troops.

headline: Stay Sane America, Please!
text: In January of 2017 someone will stand at the U.S. Capitol and deliver an Inaugural Address. This is roughly the place where Abraham Lincoln, Franklin Roosevelt, Dwight Eisenhower and Ronald Reagan once stood. I am going to spend every single day between now and then believing that neither Donald Trump nor Ted Cruz nor Bernie Sanders will be standing on that podium. One of them could win the election, take the oath, give the speech and be riding down Pennsylvania Avenue. I will still refuse to believe it.

headline: The Punctual Patient
text: It was two years into the treatment, and T., a retired executive, still continued to fantasize about being my ideal and favorite patient. She repeatedly attempted to please me by trying to say whatever she thought I would like to hear, despite the fact that I kept reminding her that this was her treatment, not mine.

headline: Democracy on Hold in Haiti
text: A runoff election on Sunday for president in Haiti was postponed indefinitely late last week. The decision made sense, because with protesters in the streets, violence and gunfire and the torching of electoral offices, it was clear that any vote would be marred by bloodshed and chaos.

headline: EKG Screening for College Athletes
text: LAST March, the N.C.A.A.’s chief medical officer, Brian Hainline, announced that he was going to recommend that all male college basketball players undergo an electrocardiogram, which measures the electrical activity in the heart, presumably as a requirement for being cleared to play competitively. He said his action was in response to research suggesting that the risk of sudden cardiac death in Division I basketball players was about one in 5,200 per year, much higher than previously thought.

headline: What’s Our Duty to the People Globalization Leaves Behind?
text: A FEW days ago, I visited the shiny headquarters of the Peterson Institute for International Economics on “think tank row” in Washington — basically, the locker room of the Team Globalization and Free Trade cheering squad.

headline: Reducing Preventable Harm in Hospitals
text: First of two articles.

headline: Could Bloomberg and His Millions Save Us From Ourselves?
text: Could a capable nonpartisan billionaire, like Michael Bloomberg,  fix our damaged political system needs or just give rich people more power?

headline: Chinese Stocks Fall Sharply, Leading Asian Markets Lower
text: HONG KONG — China’s stock market sank on Tuesday amid accumulating evidence of the Chinese economy’s deeply rooted troubles and as the central bank pushed huge sums of money into the banking system.

headline: News Q’s | Justices Expand Parole Rights for Juveniles Sentenced to Life for Murder
text: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Justices Expand Parole Rights for Juveniles Sentenced to Life for Murder.”

headline: Afghan Police Officer Suspected of Helping Taliban Kill 10 Comrades
text: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — Ten police officers in the southern Afghan province of Oruzgan were poisoned by a rogue colleague and shot in the head by Taliban fighters the officer was working with, the second insider attack on the police in the province in less than two weeks, officials said Tuesday.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Evangelical Gamble
text: On Nov. 13, 2013, one year after his son was elected to the United States Senate, the pastor Rafael Cruz delivered a speech at Liberty University in Lynchburg, Va. The topic — ‘‘What does the Bible say about why Christians need to be involved in the political arena?’’ — was one of his favorites, and notably appropriate for a school founded by Jerry Falwell, who also founded Moral Majority, the once-powerful political action committee. Over the course of a 30-minute speech that touched on everything from the need for school prayer to the similarities between President Obama’s Washington and Fidel Castro’s Havana, the question of why slowly gave way to the question of who. The pastor concluded by telling his audience, ‘‘God is saying to you: ‘Vote for righteous people.’ ’’

headline: In Race for FIFA President, Two Front-Runners and Many Possibilities
text: The election to select the next president of FIFA, world soccer’s governing body, is a month away. On Feb. 26, a special — the official word is extraordinary — congress of FIFA’s 209 member associations will be held in Zurich, and the successor to the now-suspended Sepp Blatter will be chosen. While some of the five official candidates have trumpeted commitments recently, plenty of speculation remains about voting support, back-room deals and campaigning tactics. Through interviews with federation officials and people connected to the candidates, all of whom spoke on the condition of anonymity, here is a look at the state of the race with a month to go:

headline: Free the Nipple?
text: The debate about exposed female nipples intensified in 2015. Many women wonder why their nipples are censored, while men’s aren’t.

headline: Student Question | How Have You Helped a Friend in a Time of Need?
text: Have you ever had friends who were going through a rough time? Maybe they had a family member who died? Or they were struggling with depression or addiction? Or maybe they just needed a helping hand after a difficult breakup or a bad situation at home?

headline: As Donald Trump and Ted Cruz Soar, G.O.P. Leaders’ Exasperation Grows
text: DES MOINES — Republican leaders are growing alarmed by the ferocious ways the party’s mainstream candidates for president are attacking one another, and they fear that time is running out for any of them to emerge as a credible alternative to Donald J. Trump or Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

headline: The Wreck of Amtrak 188
text: From 30th Street Station, the train glided northwest out of Philadelphia, tracing the arc of the freeway. Near the old Schuylkill River Bridge, it jogged right, gathering speed, bound for the New Jersey border. Had you been standing anywhere near the tracks, you would have heard Amtrak 188 before you saw it, in the hum of the rail bed and the metallic shiver of the electricity in the overhead catenary wires. And then you would have felt it, in the vibration of the earth: the combined weight of a 98-ton locomotive and seven 50-ton cars, carrying a total of 258 people, eight of them employees.

headline: Working, and Assimilating, on New York Farms
text: Twenty-three Bhutanese refugees have taken part in a state program, learning to be milkers at a state college and then getting jobs on local farms in Western New York.

headline: From Bhutan to New York’s Dairy Heartland
text: WARSAW, N.Y. — Purna Gurung and Hem Gurung stood in dung-slopped boots and rubber gloves, the heady perfume of wet cow, raw milk and manure permeating the room. They washed down the dirty stalls in the rotary milking parlor at Noblehurst Farms in western New York, some 7,500 miles from their birthplace in Bhutan.

headline: The Fight to Free the Nipple
text: On a warm fall day, members of a literary group gathered in Prospect Park to soak in the sun and snack on chocolate pretzels. Most book clubs in a park in Brooklyn wouldn’t cause much of a stir, but as the mostly female group read, men gawked and children stared. Police officers were called to the scene. The members of the Outdoor Co-ed Topless Pulp Fiction Appreciation Society are used to such attention. They are part of a larger movement called Free the Nipple, and see themselves as proponents of gender equality.

headline: Ask Well: Taking All Your Antibiotics
text: Question:

headline: Your Tuesday Morning Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know to start the day

headline: Your Tuesday Briefing: Hillary Clinton, Planned Parenthood, Novak Djokovic
text: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Giorgio Armani’s Capsule Collection, Complete With Tea
text: PARIS — What is “the new normal”? Does such a state even exist, or is the idea that something can embody both the hitherto unseen and the standard an oxymoron?

headline: New York Today: Your Local Glacier
text: Updated 9:18 a.m.

headline: Republican Says ‘Malleable’ Donald Trump Is More Electable Than a ‘Rigid’ Ted Cruz
text: While there has been a lot of hand-wringing among conservatives about the damage they fear Donald J. Trump is doing to their brand, one centrist leader among congressional Republicans sees a potential silver lining for Mr. Trump: electability.

headline: Guo Pei, Creator of Rihanna’s Met Gala Gown, Is Ready for Paris
text: PARIS — Until nine months ago, Guo Pei was a Chinese haute couturière known by millions in the East yet virtually unheard-of in the West. That all changed last May when the pop star Rihanna wore one of Ms. Guo’s designs to the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute gala in New York, after finding her work on the Internet. The look in question, a 55-pound canary-yellow fur-trimmed gown and cape, took seamstresses 50,000 hours and more than two years to make and landed on the cover of American Vogue — and Ms. Guo on the haute couture schedule in Paris.

headline: Morning Agenda: A Tidal Wave of Corporate Migrants Seeking Tax Shelters
text: A TIDAL WAVE OF CORPORATE MIGRANTS SEEKING TAX SHELTERS | Until lawmakers in Washington reform the tax code, American companies will continue their exodus in search of lower tax rates,

headline: Bank of England’s Andrew Bailey Named C.E.O. of Financial Conduct Authority
text: LONDON — The Financial Conduct Authority of Britain on Tuesday named a longtime Bank of England official to serve as its new chief executive.

headline: Seeking to Sway Iowans, Conservative Group Grades Candidates’ ‘Exceptionalism’
text: Hoping to sway undecided voters in Iowa, a conservative group has issued grades to the candidates, which it says are based on who is “the most effective and principled leader.”

headline: From Paris With Love: Valentine’s Day Packages Aim to Boost Tourism
text: Hotels in the quintessentially romantic city are offering Valentine’s Day packages and amenities to help counter the dip in tourism attributable to last November’s terrorist attacks.

headline: In Toronto Cafes, Board Games Rule
text: Even on a sunny afternoon at Snakes & Lattes Annex,  many Torontonians didn’t mind acting like kids inside. A few months ago, an elderly man traded pawn moves with a school-age girl. A cluster of millennials dug into the German-style strategy classic Carcassonne. Up front, where board games are sold, an Ottawa entrepreneur held a stack of boxes under one arm as he consulted Steve Tassie, one of the cafe’s game-teaching gurus, on what to stock in his own board-game cafe.

headline: How ‘-Phobic’ Became a Weapon in the Identity Wars
text: It started, innocently enough, at Hooters. A waitress who goes by Zola got to talking with a diner named Jessica. The two bonded over a shared romantic philosophy (each had a ‘‘sugar daddy’’ at home) and career focus (each moonlighted as an exotic dancer), and when Jessica invited Zola on a road trip to Florida to strip at some local clubs, Zola strapped in. Little did Zola know, she was hurtling toward the center of a backwater psychodrama in which she would face off against a series of pimps, johns, kidnappers, one very weepy white boy and Jessica herself, who had pulled her new friend into this nonconsensual weekend tour of the underground sex trade.

headline: Poll Watch: Terrorism and Economy Are Top Concerns for Primary Voters
text: Heading into next week’s Iowa caucuses, much has been written about which candidate voters trust, who is most electable, and who seems prepared to get things done.

headline: Donald Trump and Ted Cruz Are Nearly Side by Side in Iowa, Poll Shows
text: DES MOINES — Little daylight sits between Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas in Iowa, according to a new poll that shows the two presidential candidates essentially deadlocked less than a week before Republicans head to the caucuses.

headline: New York City’s Pension System in Danger of ‘Operational Failure,’ Report Says
text: New York City’s pension system, which encompasses $160 billion in retirement funds, is rife with problems that leave it vulnerable to an “operational failure,” according to an independent report commissioned by the city comptroller’s office.

headline: Weekly News Quiz | Jan. 19-25, 2016
text: Have you been following the past week’s news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

headline: Our Man in Iowa: Early Signs of a Big Turnout for Republicans
text: Good morning from Iowa, where premium gasoline is $1.67 a gallon at Git-n-Go, and where a warming trend has arrived, which could last through the caucuses six days from now, favoring a strong turnout.

headline: Chanel: Couture
text: Karl Lagerfeld’s designs for couture 2016.

headline: Democrats Gather to Make Final Arguments in Iowa Sprint
text: On what was perhaps the best day of Hillary Clinton’s primary campaign since October, she ended with a strong presence at a town-hall-style forum hosted by CNN, the final appearance by all three Democrats in the same place before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: A.I.G. Opts for Streamlining, Spurning Calls for a Breakup
text: At American International Group, big is still better, at least for now.

headline: Man With Knife in East Village Is Shot by Police
text: A knife-wielding man who charged at New York City police officers in the hallway of his grandmother’s East Village apartment early on Tuesday was shot and wounded by a sergeant after refusing orders to drop the weapon, police officials said.

headline: Wait. Which Party Is Imploding?
text: Gail Collins: Arthur, I’m so pleased to be conversing with you about this election. I miss my old pal David Brooks, but David’s just got too much on his plate to pick up one more project right now. And I get another Brooks! I will refrain from making any water-related jokes.

headline: Tangled Passages
text: Here’s another sampling of overstuffed or impenetrable sentences in recent stories. As we’ve noted often, such passages are an unnecessary burden for hurried readers, and often lead to grammatical trouble.

headline: 1916: Spain to Intern German Troops
text: The British successes in Cameroon are likely to be of indirect consequence to this country. In December last the Spanish Government, wishing to prevent any possible breach of Spain’s neutrality, entered into correspondence with the German, French and British Governments. Even at that time it appeared evident that the Germans would eventually be defeated in Cameroon, and Spain insisted upon a German assurance that, should the German troops be forced to take refuge in Spanish territory at Guinea, they would consent to be disarmed and interned. After lengthy negotiations, Germany reluctantly gave this assurance, with a rider to the effect that a German defeat was ‘‘impossible.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 27, 1916

headline: Netanyahu Chides Ban Ki-moon for Settlement Remarks
text: JERUSALEM — Hours after an Israeli woman who was stabbed by Palestinian assailants in a West Bank settlement died on Tuesday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel rebuked the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, who criticized Israel’s settlement activity and said it was “human nature to react to occupation.”

headline: A Retro Super Bowl, Putting Defense and Running First
text: Perhaps no N.F.L. team has reinvented itself as quickly and successfully as the Denver Broncos — from No. 1 offense headed into the 2014 Super Bowl to No. 1 defense headed into the 2016 trophy contest, from postmodern quick-snap to traditionalist ground-and-pound.

headline: Taxi Drivers and Air Traffic Controllers Go on Strike in France
text: PARIS — Taxi drivers and air traffic controllers in France went on separate but simultaneous strikes on Tuesday, blocking traffic in major cities and disrupting flights at several airports.

headline: United by African Music
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Twitter Recruits a Chief Marketing Officer From American Express
text: The reshaping of Twitter’s top ranks under Jack Dorsey continues.

headline: National Tour Is Planned for ‘Hamilton’
text: “Hamilton” is hitting the road. The Broadway musical, which has already announced that it plans to begin an open-ended run in Chicago this fall, is also planning a separate national tour next year, starting in San Francisco, moving to Los Angeles, and then on to other cities.

headline: Review: A Widow Documents Her Loss in ‘The Iceberg’
text: Tom Lubbock, the chief art critic for the English newspaper The Independent, had alert blue eyes, a big laugh and terrible teeth. He was said to be a world-class mimic. His beard, a colleague recalled, “gave him the air of a 19th-century Russian anarchist.” People liked to be around him.

headline: Ukrainian War Veterans Trade Heat of Battle for Pizza Ovens
text: KIEV, Ukraine — Out in the fields of eastern Ukraine, they fought the Russians. Now, as men in a kitchen, they are no less fearsome.

headline: To Love, and Maybe Lose, a Foster Child
text: On the day it became clear to me that my time with my foster son is likely coming to an end, the bench under me was hard. The walls surrounding me were grand and white. The ceiling above me was as high as that of a cathedral.

headline: Daily Report: Tepid Response to Twitter Shake-Up
text: If Jack Dorsey and the other leaders at Twitter thought news of a high-level shake-up would excite investors, they were wrong. On Monday, shares in Twitter fell once again, by 4.6 percent. The company’s stock has fallen more than 40 percent in the last three months.

headline: Bouchra Jarrar: Couture
text: The latest couture looks from Bouchra Jarrar.

headline: Making Music on an Android Tablet
text: Q. GarageBand looks like a fun app, but not everyone uses Apple hardware. Is there a version of the program (or something similar) for the Android tablet community that isn’t expensive and is also simple enough for normal people to use?

headline: Undoing Years of Progress in Turkey
text: ISTANBUL — Entire towns and districts are under siege. Tanks ram through narrow alleys closed off by barricades and trenches. Residents are trapped indoors for weeks because of curfews. Those who venture outside risk sniper fire. Their bodies lie on the streets for days before they can be collected. Bullets fly in through windows and buildings collapse under shelling, killing those seeking shelter at home.

headline: Strategists for Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Aim for Every Inch of Iowa
text: DES MOINES — Inside the Iowa campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, the latest polling and reports from volunteers in the field told a tantalizing tale: There were votes to be had in Mason City.

headline: 1941: Nazi Flyer Escapes Canada
text: A garrulous young German aviator with taped ears and an exuberant grin arrived in Grand Central Terminal early yesterday, eager to tell the world how he escaped from a Canadian prison train. Baron Franz von Werra found no time for conversation, however. A brusque German consular attache shouldered his way down platform 32 when the train from Ogdensburg pulled in at 6:45 a.m. and collared the twenty-six-year-old pursuit pilot as soon as he alighted. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 27, 1941

headline: U.S. Eases Restrictions on Financing Exports to Cuba
text: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced Tuesday that it was removing major impediments to contact between the United States and Cuba by lifting restrictions on American financing of exports to the island nation and relaxing limits on the shipping of an array of products, from tractors to art supplies.

headline: Nebraska Senator Raises Issue of Donald Trump’s Sexual Affairs
text: Senator Ben Sasse of Nebraska reeled off a stream of Twitter messages going after Donald J. Trump on Monday night, questioning the candidate’s flip-flopping on gun rights and health care policy, his expansive view of presidential power – and his well-publicized history of bedroom exploits.

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 9: Pride and Prejudice
text: Most network TV shows have breaks and hiatuses, but there is always so much happening in any given episode of “Jane the Virgin” that trying to remember each plot line after a few weeks away can be nearly impossible.

headline: G-Dragon in Paris, Another Appearance on Chanel’s Front Row
text: PARIS — The latest stage of the Asian invasion of the Paris couture season occurred at the Chanel show, held at the Grand Palais on Tuesday morning.

headline: The Spurs Are Great, but the Warriors Are Much, Much Better
text: The San Antonio Spurs were supposed to be the team that slowed the Golden State Warriors’ inexorable run to the N.B.A. title. The arrival of LaMarcus Aldridge, the continued transformation of Kawhi Leonard into a star, the veteran leadership of Tony Parker and Tim Duncan and the craftiness of Coach Gregg Popovich seemed to add up to a formidable challenge for the defending champions.

headline: Report on Troubled New York City Pension System
text: An independent report commissioned by the city comptroller’s office found the city’s retirement system needed additional resources, staffing and the basic tools required to understand the complicated risk embedded in its investments.

headline: El Niño Storms Put Pacifica Cliff Apartments at Risk
text: On a stretch of coast between San Francisco and Half Moon Bay, rows of apartments sit on cliffs, dangerously close to falling into the Pacific Ocean.

headline: From Movement in Ancient Art to Radical Choreographers
text: Trisha Brown and Steve Paxton

headline: When ‘Made in Israel’ Is a Human Rights Abuse
text: Just before Christmas, Ron Dermer, Israel’s ambassador to the United States, sent the White House a box of holiday gifts with a pointed political message. Inside were items (body lotion, halvah, olive oil) produced in Jewish settlements in the West Bank. Or rather, as Mr. Dermer put it in an accompanying letter, in Judea and Samaria — the term used by religious nationalists who see the settlements as no less a part of Israel than the Galilee or Tel Aviv.

headline: Inquiry in China Adds to Doubt Over Reliability of Its Economic Data
text: HONG KONG — The veracity of China’s economic data has been increasingly questioned as the slowing pace of the country’s growth has startled the world. And a new investigation into the official who oversees the numbers is unlikely to inspire confidence.

headline: Disney’s ‘Aladdin’ to Begin National Tour in 2017
text: The Broadway musical “Aladdin” has already taken its magic carpet to Europe and Asia. Now the show is ready to travel America.

headline: Panel Calls for Depression Screenings During and After Pregnancy
text: Women should be screened for depression during pregnancy and after giving birth, an influential government-appointed health panel said Tuesday, the first time it has recommended screening for maternal mental illness.

headline: Fed Fumble
text: US growth seems to have slowed sharply. Fed Kremlinologists are already wondering how the FOMC will word its next statement, so as to acknowledge the reality without sounding too panicky. But panic may be warranted; given the combination of slowing growth and a big deterioration of financial conditions, there’s growing talk that the Fed made an error in hiking rates.

headline: Crumbling Cliffs on California's Coast
text: Drone footage shows apartment buildings along Esplanade Avenue in Pacifica, Calif., that have been declared uninhabitable in the wake of the eroding coastline.

headline: Panzanella to Suit the Season
text: I’d always thought of panzanella as a summer salad made with stale bread and tomatoes.

headline: Carnegie Hall Announces Its 2016-17 Season
text: With an early-music festival exploring works from the Venetian Republic, a Bruckner symphony cycle and a celebration of Steve Reich’s 80th birthday, Carnegie Hall’s 2016-17 season, announced on Tuesday, bears the unmistakable imprint of Clive Gillinson, who survived a power struggle last year to remain artistic and executive director.

headline: Reporter’s Notebook: Navy SEAL Commander’s Suicide
text: In looking into the suicide of  a Navy SEAL team commander, Job W. Price, during a deployment in late 2012, Times reporters learned more about the stresses on elite Special Operations troops, the stigma that many have felt about seeking help for mental health issues and what the military is trying to do to change that. Christopher Drew, one of the reporters who worked on the story, discusses these issues.

headline: Venezuelan Opposition Seeks Housing Giveaway
text: Now that former President Hugo Chávez’s old adversaries have taken over Parliament, they want to give away the deeds to hundreds of thousands of homes that he built.

headline: Foes May Hate Hugo Chávez, but They Like His Political Playbook
text: CIUDAD MIRANDA, Venezuela — Twenty thousand people live in this concrete bastion built by President Hugo Chávez. He gave them the keys, and they gave him their votes.

headline: Russia Will ‘Reset’ Relations With West on Its Own Terms, Official Says
text: MOSCOW — The Russian foreign minister, Sergey V. Lavrov, said on Tuesday that while he wanted to see a “reset” of Russia’s relations with the United States, Moscow would not budge on any of the issues that put it at odds with Washington.

headline: Billie Joe Armstrong Warns of Censorship After School Cancels ‘American Idiot’
text: In what could be a scene straight from the punkish musical “American Idiot,” a Connecticut high school has canceled a planned production of the show, citing its sex, drugs and foul language.

headline: Tiny Leech Named for Amy Tan
text: Amy Tan’s novel “Saving Fish from Drowning” (2005) included a number of references to jungle leeches, such as a teasing suggestion that one character eat them as part of a mock reality show called “Darwin’s Fittest.”

headline: Passport Expiring Soon? Renew It Now, State Dept. Says
text: If you have a United States passport expiring any time in 2016, the State Department has a message for you: Renew it now.

headline: John Kasich and Chris Christie Pick Up Endorsements in New Hampshire Race
text: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, whose campaign has seen some positive signs in New Hampshire, has been endorsed by two more newspapers in the region, The Boston Globe and The Concord Monitor.

headline: Pope Francis and Hassan Rouhani of Iran Discuss Mideast Unrest
text: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis met with President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on Tuesday — the first meeting between a pope and an Iranian leader in nearly 17 years — and urged Iran to play an “important role” in finding political solutions for the various conflicts afflicting the Middle East.

headline: Depression in Mom or Dad Increases Risk of Premature Baby
text: Having a mother or father who is depressed increases the risk of preterm birth, a new study has found.

headline: Chanel and Valli: Odes to the Natural World
text: PARIS — The climate change conference held in Paris late last year represented many things — a political breakthrough, the first real global agreement on the subject, a triumphant narrative for France after the tragedy of the November attacks — but for some in fashion it was also an inspiration.

headline: At Schiaparelli, Inspiration Comes From Fine Dining
text: The house’s spring/summer 2016 haute couture show was filled with references to food — with, of course, a heavy dose of shocking pink.

headline: Super Bowl Spotlight on Santa Clara Reveals How It Has Changed
text: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Santa Clara hosting Super Bowl 50 is a miracle along the lines of the Catch. Before the 49ers moved their practice center here in 1988, it would have been hard to fathom the N.F.L. champion being crowned here, even for someone with an imagination like mine, which grew as wild as the cottontail plants along the Guadalupe River trail.

headline: Achilles Heel and Resto
text: Wine-bar fare at a restored dockworkers bar in Greenpoint, and Koren Grieveson, the former chef of Avec in Chicago, takes over at Resto in Kips Bay.

headline: Meat Matters at Achilles Heel in Greenpoint and Resto in Kips Bay
text: In its more peaceful hours, Achilles Heel, a revived waterfront bar with a painted stone facade in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, reminds me of McSorley’s Old Ale House.

headline: ‘Antibirth,’ Natasha Lyonne and Chloë Sevigny’s Sundance Reunion
text: PARK CITY, Utah — There was a time when Natasha Lyonne and Chloë Sevigny personified the Sundance circus. It was 2003, and the festival was becoming more of a celebrity party zone than a film showcase. The film that brought the two gregarious actresses to Sundance that year was even called “Party Monster.”

headline: Activist Investors May Have Met Their Match: A Down Market
text: The stock market slump has hit activist hedge funds particularly hard, raising the question of whether shareholder activism can survive a down market.

headline: ‘In a Different Key: The Story of Autism,’ by John Donvan and Caren Zucker
text: Through history, the commandment to act with empathy has been more honored in the breach than in the observance. In their new book, John Donvan and Caren Zucker chart America’s path to recognizing autism as part of the human condition, making a case that the arts as well as advocacy have been central to the process. The authors come from the world of television news — Donvan is a correspondent for ABC, and Zucker is a journalist and producer — and their book is crafted like a tightly edited news special: The prose is vivid, the tempo rapid and the perspective intimate, as if each character has been filmed with a hand-held camera. They depict history through biography, recounting the stories of individuals with autism and their families, physicians and psychologists — focusing on those who challenged traditional concepts of cognitive and behavioral debility and led the way to broader acceptance of autism.

headline: Argentina and Aramco Are Deals for Difficult Times
text: Two big deals dominated the agenda in Davos, Switzerland, last week: Argentina’s negotiations with holdout creditors and Saudi Arabia’s potential sale of a piece of its national energy leviathan, Saudi Aramco.

headline: Rapper B.o.B Insists Earth Is Flat. Take That, Neil deGrasse Tyson.
text: People at one time did not have the privilege of seeing a famous rapper debate a famous astrophysicist about whether the earth was flat. We are deprived no more.

headline: Donald Trump Receives Backing From Jerry Falwell Jr.
text: The evangelical leader Jerry Falwell Jr. endorsed Donald J. Trump for president on Tuesday, giving the Republican candidate another boost in the final days before the Iowa caucuses, in which religious voters usually play a crucial role.

headline: Switzerland to Finance Research Into Disputed Art
text: PARIS — The Swiss government announced this week that it would spend almost $2 million to finance research to help museums to track down the ownership of art that may have been illegally taken by the Nazis during World War II.

headline: Djokovic Seeks Big Four Supremacy in Semifinal With Federer
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Great and enduring rivalries have been the motor for men’s tennis in the age of the Big Four: Roger Federer, Rafael Nadal, Novak Djokovic and Andy Murray, the Ringo Starr of this supergroup.

text: The high-frequency trading takeover of the New York Stock Exchange is now essentially complete.

headline: Jonas Kaufmann Cancels Met Opera Production
text: Jonas Kaufmann, the star tenor, has canceled his performances in a highly anticipated new production of Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut” that will open at the Metropolitan Opera next month. The company said in a statement that Mr. Kaufmann was suffering from illness.

headline: Submit Questions for Nahnatchka Khan of ‘Fresh Off the Boat’
text: Nahnatchka Khan answered the questions here.

headline: Lorne Michaels, ‘Saturday Night Live’ Creator, to Be Subject of a New Biography
text: For all but a few of the 41 seasons that “Saturday Night Live” has been on the air, Lorne Michaels has been at the helm of this NBC sketch-comedy institution, helping to give national attention to stars like Tina Fey, Bill Murray, Tracy Morgan and Jimmy Fallon. Now a new book will tell the story of Mr. Michaels’s life and a trailblazing comedy career spanning nearly half a century.

headline: Danish Law Requires Asylum Seekers to Hand Over Valuables
text: LONDON — Denmark passed a law on Tuesday requiring newly arrived asylum seekers to hand over valuables, including jewelry and gold, to help pay for their stay in the country. The move underscored an anti-immigration backlash that has prompted several European countries to seek ways to discourage migrants from entering.

headline: Poké, a Hawaiian Specialty, Emerges in Chelsea
text: Wisefish Poké Not that restaurants are any more reliable than finance, but Drew Crane and Bryan Cowan have fled the world of money management to bring their passion for poké (poh-kay), the Hawaiian specialty they encountered in the islands, to New York. “We love poké and saw that it has exploded on the West Coast,” Mr. Crane said. “We want to make it acceptable here.” (Actually, New York now has a number of poké options.) The dish is simple: raw fish, often tuna, diced in a bowl with rice, garnishes and dressings. And it is well suited to “fast casual” dining; bowls, in three sizes, are assembled at a counter according to set combinations or the customer’s choice of ingredients: 263 West 19th Street, 212-367-7653, wisefishpoke.com.

headline: Sundance Roars for a Black Film, and Fox Searchlight Bids $17 Million
text: PARK CITY, Utah — With the outcry over an all-white field of acting nominees for the coming Academy Awards, and the shutout of several films focused on black characters from the best picture race, Hollywood has come under extreme pressure in recent weeks to find more prestige-minded movies with diverse casts.

headline: Tennis Announces Review of Anticorruption Efforts
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Tennis officials on Wednesday announced an independent review into their sport’s anticorruption program, including its internal integrity unit.

headline: How to Get Five Planets Into a Single Photograph
text: Greg Hogan, an amateur astronomer from Kathleen, Ga., woke up at 5:30 a.m. on Sunday with two of his sons and went to a nearby wilderness area known as Oaky Woods to capture this image of five planets as they danced across the dawn sky. The rare celestial performance is set to repeat every morning until late February, creating stellar photo ops for early morning risers.

headline: Don’t Distract Me
text: In 1893, Grover Cleveland’s doctor peered into the president’s mouth and discovered a tumor. He deemed it a “bad-looking tenant” and recommended immediate surgical removal. I’m reminded of this every time I spot my iPhone on my desk or bedside table, or hurtling around in my purse. The iPhone is a bad tenant: It makes disturbing noises, it keeps me up at night, it devours my attention, it costs me dearly. It should be banished from my life, yet I do not have the courage to evict it.

headline: Abe Vigoda, of ‘Godfather’ and ‘Barney Miller,’ Dies at 94
text: Abe Vigoda, the sad-faced actor who emerged from a workmanlike stage career to find belated fame in the 1970s as the earnest mobster Tessio in “The Godfather” and the dyspeptic Detective Phil Fish on the hit sitcom “Barney Miller,” died on Tuesday morning in Woodland Park, N.J. He was 94, having outlived by about 34 years an erroneous report of his death that made him a cult figure.

headline: Sheriff Joe Arpaio to Endorse Donald Trump in Iowa
text: Joe Arpaio, the hard-line anti-immigration sheriff from Maricopa County, Ariz., will appear with Donald J. Trump in Iowa on Tuesday and endorse his candidacy, according to Mr. Trump’s campaign.

headline: Obama Meets With the Emir of Qatar
text: President Obama hosted the emir of Qatar, Sheikh Tamim bin Hamad al-Thani, on Tuesday, and both said they were committed to defeating the Islamic State and other terrorist organizations.

headline: Donald Trump Assails Iowa Religious Leader
text: As word spread that Donald J. Trump had picked up the endorsement of the evangelical leader Jerry Falwell Jr., Mr. Trump took to Twitter to attack a leading Christian conservative supporter of his main rival, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

headline: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston Acquires Frida Kahlo Work
text: The Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, announced Tuesday that it had acquired its first painting by Frida Kahlo, the Mexican modernist whose unsettlingly beautiful works are few and far between in American public collections. “Dos Mujeres (Salvadora y Herminia),” from 1928, depicts two Mexican women, maids whom Kahlo had known since childhood, set against dense tropical foliage.

text: As a child in the Bronx, Jon Gray used to entertain himself by reading “The Joy of Cooking.” On nights when his family ventured out to a restaurant, he took charge.

text: The couture 2016 collection from Giorgio Armani Privé.

headline: Undercover Planned Parenthood Video
text: Video from the Center for Medical Progress, an anti-abortion group, purported to show Planned Parenthood officials trying to illegally profit from the sale of fetal tissue. A leader and another employee of the anti-abortion group were indicted.

headline: Daniel Doctoroff Takes His Business to Hudson Yards
text: Daniel L. Doctoroff, the powerful former deputy mayor who pushed to add glittering offices and apartments to industrial areas in New York, giving much of the skyline its current look, is moving to a neighborhood of his making.

headline: Meredith Is Said to Be Set to End Media General Deal
text: The Nexstar Broadcasting Group may finally get the deal with Media General it has been trying to consummate for six months.

headline: Christie Announces Plan for State Control of Atlantic City’s Finances
text: ATLANTIC CITY — The elected officials of this struggling seaside gambling resort will yield control of the city’s finances to the state government in a deal announced on Tuesday by Gov. Chris Christie that is intended to stave off bankruptcy.

headline: Making a Haute Couture Look: Dior
text: Yesterday’s spring/summer 2016 haute couture show marked Dior’s first show since the departure of Raf Simons — and the first designed by the house’s studio heads, Lucie Meier and Serge Ruffieux. In the show notes, they described the collection’s shapes: “Volumes are freestyle, the Bar jacket changes appearance depending on whether it is worn closed or loose; the shoulder is sensual, bare.” On the above image, we take a closer look at the making of one Dior haute couture look.

headline: Fox News to Donald Trump: Megyn Kelly Stays as Debate Moderator
text: As Donald J. Trump continues to criticize Megyn Kelly before the Republican presidential debate on Thursday, Fox News is showing no signs of giving the candidate an inch in his request to remove Ms. Kelly from the debate moderating panel.

headline: 'X-Files' Ratings Stay Strong
text: Fox’s revival of “The X-Files” has come crashing out of the gates with some big ratings. For its premiere Sunday night, it drew 16.2 million viewers, following Fox’s broadcast of the NFC Championship Game. On Monday night, the second episode attracted an audience of 9.7 million viewers. It also drew a 3.2 rating in the 18-to-49 year old demographic important to advertisers, which was the highest rating in that bracket on network television for the night.

headline: Regulators to Return $21.5 Million to Hedge Fund Shut After Raid
text: A little more than five years after federal agents raided the offices of Level Global Investors, securities regulators are returning $21.5 million in settlement money that the hedge fund paid to resolve an insider trading investigation.

headline: In ‘The Piano Lesson,’ a Family Fight Over an Heirloom Rooted in Slavery
text: You already know their words will be wonderful. But pay attention, too, to the actors’ eyes. They offer a kind of punctuation that conjures still more magic in an already outstanding production of “The Piano Lesson,” at the McCarter Theater Center in Princeton.

headline: Marco Rubio Tries Distancing Himself From Elites He Hopes to Lead
text: OSKALOOSA, Iowa – Senator Marco Rubio of Florida is fond of telling voters hungry for a political outsider that he is not the candidate with the most endorsements from leading Republicans. He doesn’t mention that he has the second most, behind only Jeb Bush.

headline: 3 Democrats May Debate Next Week in New Hampshire
text: The Democratic presidential candidates may gather one more time in New Hampshire for a televised debate days before voters head to the polls there.

headline: Hillary Clinton Attends Cities Conference
text: Hillary Rodham Clinton participated in a conference on U.S. cities in Washington on Monday, saying that cities are driving prosperity despite the persistence of wealth gaps.

headline: The Dollar Keeps Rising, for Good or Evil
text: Just the other day I got an email in which Ron Paul, libertarian icon, former member of Congress from Texas and father of the Republican presidential candidate Rand Paul, eagerly proclaimed that his “final prediction of a dollar collapse is about to become reality.”

headline: Brazil Will Deploy Troops to Spread Awareness of Zika Virus
text: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s government has decided to deploy 220,000 troops for a day next month to spread awareness about the Zika virus, which has been linked to severe birth defects in thousands of infants.

headline: Chris Christie Apologizes to One Critic — but Only One
text: Gov. Chris Christie apologized Tuesday for having labeled a New Jersey mayor as “crazy” after the mayor suggested that flooding from last weekend’s blizzard was worse than during Hurricane Sandy.

headline: At Dior, a (Surprise) Matte Red Lip
text: There wasn’t a single red lip on Christian Dior’s spring 2016 couture runway — which was presented yesterday in Paris — until well into the show. After a sea of models with nude lips, the makeup director Peter Philips sent out the vibrant beauty look, which was inspired by the house’s founder. “Christian Dior had this idea: Halfway through the show when people were getting bored, he’d do a surprise — and quite often it was a red dress that suddenly came out of nowhere,” Philips said, referring to what has come to be known as the “coup de Trafalgar.” He lined a handful of models’ lips with a Dior lip pencil in Rouge Royale before painting them with Diorific lipstick in Fabuleuse. To get the same soft edges, another classic trick: gently blot.

headline: Short Answers to Hard Questions About Postpartum Depression
text: Answers to questions about depression screening and maternal mental illness, following new recommendations saying that women should be screened for depression during pregnancy and after childbirth.

headline: Judge Approves Settlement in Head Injuries Suit Against N.C.A.A.
text: A federal judge granted initial approval of a settlement Tuesday between the N.C.A.A. and a group of athletes who sued the association over its handling of head injuries. The agreement, which still needs N.C.A.A. approval, does not contain cash settlements for the plaintiffs in the proposed class-action suit, but mandates a new national protocol for head injuries sustained by players.

headline: Japanese End Drought in Sumo Wrestling, Their National Sport
text: In Tokyo on Sunday, the sumo wrestler Kotoshogiku won the first of the year’s six top-level tournaments. The result was big news because of his nationality: Japanese.

headline: Apple Says Sales of iPhones Have Slowed
text: SAN FRANCISCO — The iPhone fueled Apple’s ascendance into the world’s most valuable company. But even iPhone sales have their limits.

headline: Dangers for Female Prison Guards
text: An investigative video shows that female correctional officers around the country face many threats in the workplace, including at the hands of their co-workers.

headline: Harassment and Attacks From Fellow Officers in U.S. Prisons
text: In America’s hidden world of prisons and jails, officers are unarmed and outnumbered by inmates: Their peers are their only protection.

headline: Jan. 26, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
text: Photos from Israel, Indonesia, Paris and South Africa.

headline: Sri Lanka Destroys Illegal Elephant Tusks
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — A group of saffron-robed monks chanted as officials crushed more than 300 elephant tusks in a seaside ceremony on Tuesday, as the new government of President Maithripala Sirisena sought to differentiate itself from its predecessor by sending a powerful message of intolerance for elephant poaching.

headline: Familiar Faces Lend Star Power to Video Game Voices
text: To “Star Wars” fans he has been the face of one of the most beloved characters in film, Luke Skywalker. To video-game players, though, Mark Hamill is the unmistakable voice of the Joker in Batman: Arkham Asylum and its sequels.

headline: Face in the Crowd: Iggy Azalea at Armani
text: The Australian rapper Iggy Azalea, known for her singles including “Fancy” and “Goddess,” held court in the front row of the Armani Privé show in Paris Tuesday next to the actresses Charlotte Rampling and Juliette Binoche.

headline: Touring the Ruins of St. Peter’s Seminary in Scotland
text: A night tour of one of Scotland’s most famous modern ruins, St. Peter’s Seminary, above, will open the country’s first Festival of Architecture. For the ticketed event, called Hinterland, held March 18 to 27, audiences will walk through woodlands to explore the derelict buildings, backed by moving light installations and a specially commissioned recorded choral work performed by St. Salvator’s Chapel Choir of the University of St. Andrews. Built 50 years ago, the structure was heralded as a modernist masterpiece of glass and concrete, but fell into disrepair after being deconsecrated in 1980. A planned restoration will transform it into an arts facility.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Makes New York City’s Fiscal Case to a Wary Legislature
text: ALBANY — Mayor Bill de Blasio arrived here on Tuesday with a substantial wish list for the State Legislature, urging lawmakers to deliver money for several of New York City’s needs, including public housing, infrastructure and health care.

headline: MoMA Trims Back Some Features of Its Planned Renovation
text: Gone is the “Art Bay,” with a glass garage-like door that would have allowed visitors to enter galleries straight from the street.

headline: The Panettone That Big Chefs Can’t Get Enough of
text: It’s beginning to look a lot like — Valentine’s Day? Barely a month after launching his virtual luxury bakery From Roy with two Christmas panettones — one scented with candied orange and raisins, the other a less traditional chocolate-streaked loaf — the pastry chef Roy Shvartzapel has unveiled a third in honor of the holiday at his workshop in Los Gatos, Calif. The news is cause for celebration among Shvartzapel’s discerning devotees — many of the country’s most respected chefs among them. His domed wonders are unworldly in their featherweight texture: the tender crumb dissolves on your tongue, almost like cotton candy, were cotton candy spun from butter. They seem paradoxically rich and ethereal at the same time.

headline: Migrant Influx in Germany Raises Fears of Anti-Semitism
text: BERLIN — These days, all talk here is of the ramifications of taking in more than one million asylum seekers who arrived over the past year.

headline: Octo Telematics, Whose Technology Monitors Driving, Prepares I.P.O.
text: In a market that has scared off potential initial public offerings of stock, one company whose purpose is to manage risk is taking steps toward a market debut.

headline: A Pair of Cousins Who Make Furniture, and Sometimes Partner With Daft Punk
text: The cousins Cédric and Nicolas Hervet first partnered on a construction project as teenagers; their fathers, who are brothers, both had workshops filled with machinery that the boys used in an attempt to recreate the hoverboard they’d seen in “Back to the Future II.” “We took the entire thing seriously, sketching and welding an aluminum box that was filled with helium,” Nicolas says. “Our grandfather ran over the prototype with his car. Of course, in the end, it didn’t work anyway.”

headline: Egyptian Satirist Threatened for Giving Police Condom Balloons
text: An Egyptian comedian who works as a correspondent for a popular satirical television program could be in legal trouble for handing balloons made of inflated condoms to police officers in Tahrir Square on Monday, the fifth anniversary of the uprising against former President Hosni Mubarak.

headline: Bernie Sanders Won’t Attack Hillary Clinton, but He’ll Point Out Her Ties to Wall Street
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont reiterated his commitment Tuesday to not personally attack Hillary Clinton but said that he would continue to point out her ties to big commercial banks.

headline: Slush Puddles, the Scourge of New York Walkers
text: THE day after it stopped snowing in New York City last weekend, I took my daughter sledding in Prospect Park. Despite the near record blizzard, things were, remarkably, back to normal in my part of Brooklyn — thanks to stalwart efforts by city employees. The streets were plowed and salted to glistening blackness. The subway arrived seconds after we did. On Prospect Park’s circular drive, cyclists serenely spun past.

headline: A Woman on the $10 Bill, and Everyone Has 2 Cents to Put In
text: WASHINGTON — If Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew was not aware that Americans have strong opinions about what, and who, is in their wallets, he certainly is now.

headline: Florida Beachgoers Cling to a Right to Make the Sand Their Driveway
text: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — On sunny weekends, when busy schedules yield to bygone notions of leisure, Greg Gimbert and his 9-year-old son jump into a silver sport utility vehicle packed with a pop-up canopy, a cooler, chairs, surfboards and boogie boards and drive a short distance to the beach, where Mr. Gimbert parks on the sand and sets up his gear.

headline: With Punch, Blake Griffin Breaks Hand and Will Miss Time
text: Blake Griffin of the Los Angeles Clippers was involved in a physical altercation Saturday in Toronto that left him with a broken right hand, which could keep him out of action for a month or more.

headline: Grandson of Ayatollah Khomeini Is Excluded From Election Panel
text: TEHRAN — A grandson of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the first supreme leader of the Islamic Republic of Iran, has been barred from helping to choose the next one, according to a family member’s posts on Instagram.

headline: The Street Meets Luxury at Hermès, Berluti and Dior Homme
text: PARIS — More than half of the 48 looks Véronique Nichanian showed for her fall 2016 Hermès men’s wear collection — staged against the inky-blue night sky of Paris as seen through the glass-walled Maison de la Radio — were worn with sneakers in Hermès orange. The high-end trainers are a new introduction at the luxury leather-goods house founded as a saddlery to the French carriage trade.

headline: At Giambattista Valli, a Garden of Earthly Delights
text: For his spring/summer 2016 haute couture presentation, the designer took inspiration from the gardens of Paris.

headline: Vindication for Planned Parenthood
text: One after the other, investigations of Planned Parenthood prompted by hidden-camera videos released last summer have found no evidence of wrongdoing. On Monday, a grand jury in Harris County, Tex., went a step further. Though it was convened to investigate Planned Parenthood, it indicted two members of the group that made the videos instead.

text: Mr. Margules, 56, is the founder, president and chief executive of Margules Properties, a New York-based company that specializes in residential rental buildings, many of which are rent-stabilized or rent-controlled walk-ups. He founded the company in 1992.

headline: Lead in Ohio Villages’ Water Went Uncurbed for Months, State Says
text: Lead contamination in tap water went unchecked for months in a cluster of Ohio villages, state officials said Tuesday, as a local official waited too long to raise an alarm, caused more delays with shoddy paperwork, failed to do required testing and might have even falsified documents on water quality.

headline: Some Officers Bristle at Recall of Military Equipment
text: PONTIAC, Mich. — On the day a heavily armed couple fatally shot 14 people and wounded more than 20 others in San Bernardino, Calif., last month, Michael J. Bouchard, a sheriff here in the Detroit area, got an order to return his department’s 14-ton armored personnel carrier to the federal government.

headline: Hillary Clinton on Nominating Obama to the Supreme Court: ‘Great Idea’
text: DECORAH, Iowa – Hillary Clinton is sometimes asked what kind of people she would want to put on the Supreme Court – but not who. During a campaign event here in northeast Iowa on Tuesday, one attendee had a nominee in mind: President Obama. Would she name him?

headline: Former Morgan Stanley Banker to Revive Phibro Name
text: Oil prices may be depressed, but they have not stopped the longtime commodities trader Phibro from being resurrected.

headline: C.T.E. Is Found in an Ex-Giant Tyler Sash, Who Died at 27
text: When the former Giants safety Tyler Sash was found dead at age 27 of an accidental overdose of pain medications at his Iowa home on Sept. 8, his grieving family remained consumed by a host of unanswered questions about the final, perplexing years of Sash’s life.
