headline: Six Cleveland Officers Fired for Role in Killing of Couple
text: Cleveland officials fired six police officers on Tuesday for their roles in a fatal 2012 pursuit in which 137 rounds were shot at a car with two unarmed black people.

headline: Donald Trump’s Campaign Says He’ll Skip Debate
text: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa — Moments after Fox News announced the lineup for Thursday’s Republican debate, Donald J. Trump said Tuesday that it was pretty “irrevocable” that he would skip the event, which takes place just days before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Feeling South Africa’s Beat in Pantsula
text: Pantsula, a dance that is more like a way of life, captivated Chris Saunders, who set out to document a subculture with roots in jazz and hip-hop.

headline: Suspect Is Charged in Milwaukee With Planning a Mass Shooting
text: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors on Tuesday announced the arrest of a Milwaukee man who they said was planning a mass shooting at a Masonic temple in the city.

headline: Hundreds Vanishing in Egypt as Crackdown Widens, Activists Say
text: CAIRO — After the security forces raided the home of Islam Khalil, a 26-year-old salesman, last summer, he seemed to vanish without a trace.

headline: Broadway Box Office Feels Storm’s Sting
text: Broadway’s box-office grosses dropped by a bruising 39 percent last week, the result of a blizzard that prompted the cancellation of all Saturday matinee and evening performances.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Campaign Says He Would Sit Out Unsanctioned Debate
text: Jeff Weaver, the campaign manager for Senator Bernie Sanders, said on Tuesday evening that Mr. Sanders did not want to participate in an unsanctioned debate next month because he could risk being denied participation in future debates.

headline: Rat Who Escaped Peril and Made It on Broadway Dies in a Fall
text: Rose, a white rat who escaped poison and roadside peril for a life in the theater, died in a fall at home on Monday night, just four days after she started acting in a Broadway hit.

headline: Still Buried in Baltimore, Some Dig Their Own Path
text: BALTIMORE — None of those snowplows that Baltimore leaders keep talking about ever made it to the 1200 block of West 37th Street in Hampden, a middle-class rowhouse community northwest of downtown.

headline: A Charged Blend of Law and Politics in a Texas Planned Parenthood Case
text: HOUSTON — A deputy had been shot and killed at a suburban gas station here the night before in an unprovoked attack. The Harris County district attorney, Devon Anderson, stood that Saturday afternoon in August next to the sheriff, on the verge of tears.

headline: Ted Cruz and Allies Work to Halt Donald Trump’s Gains
text: OTTUMWA, Iowa — On the campaign trail, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas assures Iowa Republicans that they can finally ignore the barrage of political attack ads on television.

headline: Zika Testing Is Urged for Some Newborns
text: Newborns should be tested for infection with the Zika virus if their mothers have visited or lived in any country experiencing an outbreak and if the mothers’ own tests are positive or inconclusive, federal health officials said Tuesday.

headline: Indictment Deals Blow to G.O.P. Over Planned Parenthood Battle
text: WASHINGTON — A grand jury’s indictment on Monday of two abortion opponents who covertly recorded Planned Parenthood officials is the latest, most startling sign that a Republican campaign against the group has run into trouble.

headline: Bill de Blasio Set to Campaign for Hillary Clinton in Iowa
text: Mayor Bill de Blasio will fly to Iowa this weekend to campaign for Hillary Clinton, a fellow Democrat and his former boss, in the final days of her close race against Senator Bernie Sanders in the state’s presidential caucuses.

headline: How Iran Rejoined the World’s Economy in Just 10 Days
text: What a difference 10 days make.

headline: Donald Trump Conducts Rare News Conference, and It Turns Testy
text: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa — Donald J. Trump on Tuesday night devoured another in the dwindling news cycles before the Iowa caucuses, as he excoriated a reporter for several minutes who was trying to ask him about his previous pro-abortion rights stance at a raucous news conference before a campaign event.

headline: Thornton Dial, Outsider Artist Whose Work Told of Black Life, Dies at 87
text: Thornton Dial, a self-taught artist whose paintings and assemblages fashioned from scavenged materials told the story of black struggle in the South and found their way to the permanent collections of major museums, died on Monday at his home in McCalla, Ala. He was 87.

headline: What Happened to Jane Mayer When She Wrote About the Koch Brothers
text: Out of the blue in the fall of 2010, a blogger asked Jane Mayer, a writer with The New Yorker, how she felt about the private investigator who was digging into her background. Ms. Mayer thought the idea was a joke, she said this week. At a Christmas party a few months later, she ran into a former reporter who had been asked about helping with an investigation into another reporter on behalf of two conservative billionaires.

headline: Several Days Later, Newark Is Still Feeling Blizzard’s Effects
text: NEWARK — Three days after a sprawling blizzard hit the East Coast, officials here said on Tuesday that they had made progress in restoring life to normal.

headline: Bernie Sanders and President Obama to Meet in Oval Office Wednesday
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will meet in the Oval Office on Wednesday with Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, offering presidential face-time just days before voting in the presidential campaign begins next week, White House officials said Tuesday evening.

headline: Who Needs Megyn Kelly? Ted Cruz Says He’ll Debate Donald Trump One on One
text: FAIRFIELD, Iowa — Seeking to insert himself into the latest Donald J. Trump-created campaign controversy, Senator Ted Cruz on Tuesday night challenged Mr. Trump to a “mano a mano” debate, suggesting that if the Republican front-runner was too frightened to face Fox News’s Megyn Kelly, the two candidates could face off without a moderator.

headline: Start Swimmin’
text: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — A good protest song should be general enough to call for the perpetual need for societal change, but passionately specific enough to allow generations upon generations take it as their own anthem. There were many that came out of the turbulence of the 1960s, but Bob Dylan’s “THE TIMES THEY ARE A-CHANGIN'” is probably the Platonic ideal of this genre.

headline: Former Twitter Executive Kevin Weil Is Expected to Join Instagram
text: Kevin Weil, a longtime Twitter executive, will soon join the photo-sharing service Instagram, according to two people familiar with the matter, joining the ranks of a company many consider one of Twitter’s main competitors.

headline: Police Testify on Housing Project’s Dangers at Officer’s Manslaughter Trial
text: The Brooklyn housing project where a police officer fatally shot an unarmed man, Akai Gurley, was notoriously dangerous, according to testimony drawn out on Tuesday by lawyers for the officer, Peter Liang.

headline: Albany Ethics Commission Adopts New Fund-Raising and Disclosure Rules
text: ALBANY — In its nearly five years in existence, the Joint Commission on Public Ethics has often battled a poor public image, a problem rooted in its odd voting rules and perceived lack of activity, something recently exemplified by its continuing six-month search for a new executive director.

headline: Ammon Bundy and 7 Oregon Protesters Held; LaVoy Finicum Is Reported Dead
text: JOHN DAY, Ore. — Ammon Bundy, the leader of an armed seizing of a federal wildlife refuge in rural eastern Oregon, was arrested and one person was killed Tuesday afternoon in a traffic stop in rural Oregon, the F.B.I. and the Oregon State Police said.

headline: Bronx Mother Charged in Death of Infant Whose Body Was Left in Woods
text: A Bronx mother whose conversation with a hospital worker led to the discovery of her 7-week-old son’s body north of New York City last month has been indicted on charges of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, prosecutors said.

headline: U.S. Appeals Court Allows Killing of Snowy Owls Near Kennedy Airport
text: A federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday that airport officials had the authority to kill migratory birds that posed a threat to planes at Kennedy International Airport.

headline: Thornton Dial (1928-2016)
text: Thornton Dial was a self-taught artist whose work from scavenged materials told the story of black struggle in the South.

headline: Psychic Who Bilked Man of More Than $550,000 Is Set Free
text: A court officer removed the handcuffs that bound the thin wrists of the former fortuneteller, and she raised her hands to wipe away tears, about to leave the courtroom a free woman.

headline: Knoedler Gallery Director’s Lawyer Says Other Experts Were Duped by Fake Rothko
text: The director of the Knoedler & Company gallery in Manhattan, which sold dozens of fakes as the work of modern masters, was not duplicitous, but duped by paintings so expertly forged that they also escaped detection by several prominent art experts, a lawyer for the director, Ann Freedman, told jurors in court on Tuesday.

headline: Without Carmelo Anthony, Knicks Dig In but Fade in Stretch Against Thunder
text: Carmelo Anthony had expressed a desire to renew acquaintances with Kevin Durant on Tuesday night. The Knicks, too, were cautiously optimistic that the soreness in Anthony’s left knee — his surgically repaired left knee — would dissipate enough to allow him to play against the Oklahoma City Thunder.

headline: Angelique Kerber, the Higher Seed, Upsets Victoria Azarenka
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The rankings suggest that Angelique Kerber’s 6-3, 7-5 victory over Victoria Azarenka in the quarterfinals of the Australian Open on Wednesday was not an upset. At No. 6 in the WTA’s world rankings, Kerber was 10 spots higher than Azarenka.

headline: Donald Trump, in Feud With Fox News, Shuns Debate
text: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa — Donald J. Trump and Fox News, the candidate who has reordered the Republican presidential race and the cable network of choice for many of the party’s voters, stared each other down on Tuesday over his demand that the news anchor Megyn Kelly be dumped from moderating Thursday’s debate, the last before Monday’s caucuses.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | inerrancy
text: inerrancy • \(ˌ)i-ˈner-ən(t)-se\ • noun

headline: Jets Lineman Avoids Jail
text: Sheldon Richardson will not go to jail for resisting arrest after a high-speed chase in his native Missouri, but he still faces a possible suspension from the N.F.L. for violating its personal-conduct policy. Richardson was sentenced to two years of probation and 100 hours of community service after he pleaded guilty in St. Charles County to reduced charges stemming from a July incident in which the police clocked him driving at 143 miles per hour.

headline: What to Watch Wednesday
text: The end is near — or is it? Five seasons in, Mike’s web of lies finally unravels in “Suits.” Child refugees talk about escaping war in Syria. And Jerry Seinfeld takes his weekly drive.

headline: 7th-Ranked Xavier Hangs on to Top No. 10 Providence
text: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — The Providence Friars played their 750th game at Dunkin’ Donuts Center on Tuesday night, a run dating to 1972, but it was the very first to feature two top-10 teams, the 10th-ranked Friars and No. 7 Xavier.

headline: John Jay Hooker Jr., Political Gadfly and Perennial Litigant, Dies at 85
text: After John Jay Hooker Jr. learned he had metastatic melanoma in January 2015, he began the last crusade of his quixotic career. He persuaded a Tennessee legislator to introduce a bill granting what Mr. Hooker called the “ultimate civil right” by legalizing doctor-assisted suicide. Typically, he also sued the state.

headline: Corrections: January 27, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: ‘블랙박스 사고법’ 과 ‘실패:과학이 성공적인 이유’
text: 지난 반세기 이상에 걸쳐 인지 편향에 대한 많은 사실을 밝혀왔음에도 불구하고, 노벨상을 받은 심리학자 대니얼 카너먼은 인간이 자신의 행동을 바꿀 수 있는 능력을 갖추고 있는가에 대해 매우 비관적이다. 2014년 <가디언>과의 인터뷰에서 카너먼은 심리학자인 스티븐 핑커 하버드대 교수에게 “인간의 본성에 타고난 결함이 있다는 가설은 인간이기에 지니고 있는 비극적인 면과 일맥상통하며, 인간으로 살아간다는 것은 곧 이 같은 비극을 안고 살아간다는 것을 뜻한다”고 말한 바 있다. 당시 핑커 교수는 카너만이 자신에게 미친 영향을 인정하면서도, 같은 자료로부터 180도 다른 주장을 끌어냈다. “인간은 교육, 제도, 계몽과 같이 우리의 한계를 극복할 수 있는 수단을 갖고 있다”는 것이 핑커의 의견이었다. 인간이 이성으로 저급한 본능을 억누를 수 있다는 핑커의 낙관주의는 2011년 저작 <우리 본성의 더 선한 천사들(The Better Angels of Our Nature)>의 기저에 깔린 주제이기도 하다.

headline: South Africa’s Pantsula Dancers Bring Life to the Streets
text: Pantsula, a dance that is more like a way of life, captivated Chris Saunders, who set out to document a subculture with roots in jazz and hip-hop.

headline: 36小时玩转伊斯坦堡亚洲区
text: 伊斯坦堡的亚洲区更加温和、葱翠、整洁。这裡有融合了土耳其多元文化的独特宫殿、迷人的美食以及时髦的夜生活。

headline: Iowa Will Go Down to the Wire for Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, Poll Suggests
text: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont remain deadlocked in Iowa less than a week before the caucuses, according to a new poll that shows the first nominating contest going down to the wire.

headline: South Africa’s Pantsula Dancers Bring Life to the Streets
text: Pantsula isn’t just a dance, but a way of life in Johannesburg’s townships. Small surprise then, that for the South African photographer Chris Saunders, a two-month magazine assignment to document it led to a six-year journey through his homeland.

headline: Lyft Agrees to Settle Class-Action Lawsuit With California Drivers
text: For more than two years, ride-hailing companies have fought with their drivers over the drivers’ employment status. Now, one of those companies has found a way to bury the hatchet.

headline: Friends and Refugees in Need
text: STOCKHOLM — Now in his last year in office, President Obama is in legacy mode. He has much to be proud of. But if he doesn’t want his achievements muddied by foreign policy, he’ll spend his last year redoubling his efforts to contain the Middle East refugee crisis before it goes from a giant humanitarian problem to a giant geostrategic problem that shatters America’s most important ally: the European Union.

headline: Henry Worsley and the Urge to Explore
text: When asked why he sought to cross the Antarctic unassisted and unsupported — with no supply drops or help from dogs, sails or any other source — Henry Worsley would say it was to raise money to help wounded soldiers. It indeed was that, and his adventure raised more than 100,000 pounds (about $142,000) for that worthy cause. But like the great explorers Mr. Worsley so admired, the quest that took his life was far greater and far harder to define.

headline: Boom or Gloom?
text: Whether the winner of the 2016 presidential election emphasizes optimism or pessimism, he or she will face some sobering economic developments.

headline: Subprime Reasoning on Housing
text: IT has become part of the accepted history of our time: The bursting of the housing bubble was the primary cause of a financial crisis, a sharp recession and prolonged slow growth. The story makes intuitive sense, since the economic crisis included a collapse in the prices of housing and related securities. The movie “The Big Short,” which is based on a book by Michael Lewis, takes this cause-and-effect relationship as a given.

headline: The Twinned Egos of Cruz and Trump
text: OSCEOLA, Iowa — For a few minutes I wondered if I’d wandered into the wrong barn.

headline: Mr. Obama’s Pardon Problem
text: The sudden resignation of the federal pardon attorney, Deborah Leff, an Obama appointee, is the latest evidence that until the clemency process is pried from the grip of the Justice Department, it will remain broken.

headline: The Ethics of a Child Pornography Sting
text: Should the F.B.I. have continued to operate a website to ensnare predators even though that allowed illicit images to be seen and spread?

headline: Britain’s Johanna Konta Credits Mind-Set for Her Rapid Rise
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The last Australian-born player in this year’s Australian Open main draw engendered no exuberant bursts of “Aussie, Aussie, Aussie, oy, oy oy” from the Rod Laver Arena crowd during her quarterfinal victory Wednesday. As much as the local populace yearned to stake its claim to that player, Johanna Konta, she is the Grand Slam title contender who got away.

headline: When the Hospital Is Not a Haven
text: There were ants crawling on my grandmother’s feet in the hospital. My mother and I slapped towels at the insects, scoured the rusted metal legs of the bed, moved my unconscious grandmother’s limbs to search every wrinkle of the dingy sheets. The ants were a portent, I thought. This was all my fault. My grandmother was going to die in this filthy hospital, far from everything she knew and loved, because of me and my insistence on medical intervention.

headline: Scalping Tickets to the Doctor? Woman in Beijing Has Had Enough
text: HONG KONG — Ticket scalpers can be a headache in China, raising the prices of concerts, train trips and more. But no scalpers are more detested than those selling tickets for hospital visits. A video of a woman in Beijing denouncing the practice circulated widely this week, as many others shared their own experiences.

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “These guys are so busy fighting one another that they’re only continuing to facilitate the rise of Trump and Cruz.”

headline: News Q’s | Tech’s ‘Frightful 5’
text: The following lesson activities are based on the column “Tech’s ‘Frightful 5’ Will Dominate Digital Life for Foreseeable Future.”

headline: Another Versace Introduces a Fashion Line in Paris
text: PARIS — Donatella was not the only Versace to present a collection during the couture shows this week.

headline: 7 Days, 1,500 Miles in Namibia
text: I woke to the gentle prodding of a flight attendant asking me to raise my window shade for the landing in Windhoek. I complied, and was immediately assailed: a bolt of white fury forced my eyelids to contract in submission, never to open again. Or, at least, not until it was time to deplane.

headline: Siri, Alexa and Other Virtual Assistants Put to the Test
text: WHEN I asked Alexa earlier this week who was playing in the Super Bowl, she responded, somewhat monotonously, “Super Bowl 49’s winner is New England Patriots.”

headline: Discovery of Burial Ground Backs a Less Conventional Version of Harlem’s History
text: Harlem’s African roots are at last coming to light.

headline: Iranian Released in Prisoner Exchange Finds Fault With Its Handling
text: Sitting in a federal prison, the Iranian-American former aerospace executive felt optimistic after years of frustration and despondency. His lawyers had filed what they regarded as a strong appeal, and he had reason to believe that his 2013 conviction, on illicit business dealings with Iran, might soon be reversed.

headline: Bernie Sanders at a Crossroads: Attack Hillary Clinton or Stay Positive?
text: MASON CITY, Iowa — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and his top advisers returned to Iowa on Wednesday evening having confronted a decision that will have lasting consequences for his presidential campaign and his political image: whether to open a new, tougher line of advertising against his rival Hillary Clinton in the closing days of the race for Iowa.

headline: Southport, Conn.: Historic, With an Aristocratic Air
text: The coastal enclave of Southport, Conn., is part of the town of Fairfield, but its identity is very much its own. More than 150 of its buildings, mainly houses, are protected within the Southport Historic District. The rich array of 18th- and 19th-century architecture, including many grand examples of Federal and Greek Revival styles, reflects the area’s affluence during its heyday as a seaport, and preserves the aristocratic air that still sets Southport apart.

headline: Student Question | What Are Your Healthy Habits?
text: Do you knit? Did you know that knitting can counter stress by inducing a relaxed state?

headline: Taliban Sabotage Cuts Major Power Source for Afghanistan Capital
text: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban have sabotaged a major power line in the northern province of Baghlan, officials said on Wednesday, cutting a supply of electricity from Uzbekistan to Kabul, the Afghan capital, and exposing a vulnerability in the nation’s rickety infrastructure at a time when the insurgency has government forces thinly stretched.

headline: R.B.S. Expects to Report an Annual Loss for 2015
text: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland said on Wednesday that it would report an annual loss for 2015 after taking a series of charges to close a deficit in its pension plan and to resolve past misconduct.

headline: Vietnam’s Communist Party Gives Old-Guard Leader a New 5-Year Term
text: HANOI, Vietnam — The Communist Party of Vietnam has chosen the incumbent general secretary as the country’s top leader for a second five-year term, the official Vietnam News Agency reported Wednesday.

headline: Bill Bryson’s ‘The Road to Little Dribbling’
text: “I watched the rain beat down on the road outside and told myself that one day this would be 20 years ago.” Why on earth would the weary traveler who consoled himself with this notion, marooned in a shuttered-tight, sodden Welsh mining town, even consider hitting the road again? Anyone who followed Bill Bryson on his trek around Britain in “Notes From a Small Island,” published here exactly 20 years ago, will instantly understand. From the very beginning, Bryson, an American from Iowa who has lived and worked and established a family on the far side of the Atlantic, has responded to his British surroundings with an irresistible mix of frustration and fascination. That first travelogue was inspired by what turned out to be a temporary move back to the United States. This new one, which begins with Bryson taking a challenging (and, he mischievously observes, not entirely accurate) test to qualify for dual citizenship, has him questioning how much he really understands modern Britain, “a country that I don’t altogether recognize.” Has he just become older and crankier? Or have the places he first knew as a young man really changed? There’s a simple way to find out.

headline: ‘The Age of Stagnation’ and ‘The Only Game in Town’
text: Even more than income inequality, slow growth sits firmly atop the leader board of global economic worries. Among the most prosperous countries — the Group of 7 — not a single nation is achieving an acceptable rate of expansion. Once formidable emerging countries are in disarray: Brazil and Russia have fallen into deep recessions, and China is, at best, decelerating; only India emits a soupçon of positive energy.

headline: Milos Raonic Crashes the Australian Open Semifinals Party
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — His serve might be a brute, but Milos Raonic has a sophisticated side.

headline: To Prevent Back Pain, Orthotics Are Out, Exercise Is In
text: Lower back pain is an almost universal if unwelcome experience. About 80 percent of those of us in the Western world can expect to suffer from disruptive lower back pain at some point in our lives. But if we begin and stick with the right type of exercise program, we might avoid a recurrence, according to a comprehensive new scientific review of back pain prevention.

headline: Arrests and a Death in a Confrontation With Ammon Bundy and the Police
text: Mr. Bundy, the leader of a seizure of a federal wildlife refuge in Oregon, was arrested and one person was killed in a traffic stop, the authorities said.

headline: Santander’s 4th-Quarter Profit Hit by $1.8 Billion in Charges
text: LONDON — Banco Santander of Spain said on Wednesday that its fourth-quarter profit was dragged down by one-time charges of 1.7 billion euros, or about $1.8 billion, including provisions to compensate consumers who were improperly sold a controversial insurance product in Britain.

headline: Morning Agenda: A.I.G. Spurns Calls for a Breakup
text: A.I.G. SPURNS CALLS FOR A BREAKUP | American International Group has decided to streamline itself, but it remains to be seen whether it can shake off the activist investors that have been pushing for a breakup.

text: Updated 9:04 a.m.

headline: Obama to Attend Event at Israeli Embassy Honoring Americans
text: Take President Obama, add the Oscar-winning director Steven Spielberg and some stories of Holocaust heroism made for the silver screen, and throw in Ambassador Ron Dermer, who has had a somewhat tumultuous relationship with the White House over the Iran nuclear deal.

headline: Democrats Hope to Turn Tables on Republicans Over Planned Parenthood Indictments
text: Democrats who have found themselves on the defensive over their support for Planned Parenthood say they believe they can now turn the tables on Republicans after two anti-abortion activists who conducted a sting on the organization were indicted in Texas.

headline: Studies Point to Inequalities That Could Strain Chinese Society
text: BEIJING — President Xi Jinping calls it his “China Dream” — a vision of a cohesive, equal society, increasingly wealthy and healthy, and happily wedded to Communist Party rule, ardent patriotism and traditional values. That vision, splashed on television and billboards everywhere here, has driven Mr. Xi’s vow that under his administration, Chinese society will become more equal and just.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Ad Features Cameo From Budding Baseball Star: His Grandson, 4
text: In the most recent ad from the Sanders campaign, sandwiched between scenes of Iowans going about their daily lives, is a quick clip of a small child crushing a pitch tossed underhand by Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

headline: Our Man in Iowa: Donald Trump Stirs the Pot, Again
text: Good morning from Iowa, where, five days from the caucuses, there are no politics-free zones, especially now that Donald J. Trump’s decision to boycott Thursday’s Fox News debate is sure to dominate conversations on Wednesday.

headline: Maison Margiela: Couture
text: John Galliano presents couture for Maison Margiela.

headline: We’ve Mapped Where Mainstream G.O.P. Candidates Are Most Popular (It’s Not the South)
text: Even as many Republican voters flirt with outsider candidates, a large minority of Republicans still supports one of the mainstream, traditional conservatives: Marco Rubio, Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, John Kasich and Carly Fiorina.

headline: Can I Call My Nonbiological Twins Black Because My Husband Is?
text: I’m a Caucasian woman married to an African-American man. Shortly after we married, I discovered that I couldn’t conceive my own biological children. We opted to ‘‘adopt’’ two embryos. (Couples who have successfully undergone in-vitro fertilization and don’t wish to have more children can donate remaining embryos to other couples.) I was soon pregnant and gave birth to twins. Based on the records of the fertility clinic, we know that our children are genetically mixed Hispanic and Caucasian. I am not comfortable being open about the origin of my children, except with family and close friends, until they are old enough for me to explain it to them. However, several times in the last three years, I’ve been asked about their race, most recently on a pre-K school application form. On this form, there is no option of ‘‘mixed race’’ or ‘‘other.’’ Therefore, I identified my children as black. Was this the right choice? Name Withheld, Chicago

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster
text: Sarah writes: My husband is an atheist. He recently informed me that for his next driver’s-license photo, he plans to wear a colander on his head and will claim to be a member of the Church of the Flying Spaghetti Monster. Please order him not to do this.

headline: Readers Respond: Oscars So White? Or Oscars So Dumb?
text: #OscarsSoWhite or #OscarsSoDumb?

headline: Laura Poitras Prepares ‘Astro Noise’ for the Whitney Museum
text: The images that open “Astro Noise,” Laura Poitras’s coming exhibition at the Whitney Museum of American Art, are striking, pleasing, and at first impossible to decipher. One shows rows of horizontal stripes intersected by curved lines swooping down diagonally; another looks to be some kind of airborne vehicle with a burst of light, or explosion, in front of it; a third has the vague suggestion of sound waves across the canvas.

headline: In Rio, the Work Goes in Before the Party Goes On
text: Near midnight on a steamy weeknight in January, midsummer in Brazil, a stretch of Estrada do Galeão in Rio de Janeiro was closed to traffic. On the crowded sidewalk, in the ghoulish light of streetlamps and shadows, vendors sold beer in bottles and meats on sticks. Above the graffiti-marked doors of storefronts shuttered until morning, silhouettes stood on balconies and in windows.

headline: Buffalo in the City
text: The paparazzi must be pleased with the vogue for buffalo plaid — with all the acres of fabric, deep red and black thickly crisscrossing, marking their quarry clearly. Have you recently breezed through the celebrity-photo pages? Reese Witherspoon snapped, leaving her car in a parking lot, while wearing a buffalo-plaid shirt and a smart skirt. Gwen Stefani, spotted toting her toddler to church, has bundled the boy in a logger shirt. Here we have Kylie Jenner — that ‘‘Keeping Up With the Kardashians’’ fixture — in a buffalo-plaid shirtdress of shocking blue. Pictures of the dress stimulated such demand that its manufacturer rushed it back into production.

headline: China Urging Afghanistan to Restart Peace Talks With Taliban
text: BEIJING — Chinese officials are urging the government of Afghanistan to restart peace talks with the Taliban after the last round of discussions collapsed, the Chinese Foreign Ministry has said.

headline: The Right-Wing Attack on India’s Universities
text: Varanasi, India — I met Sandeep Pandey days after he was sacked from his position as a visiting professor at a prestigious technical institute at Banaras Hindu University. We sat in a dreary guesthouse on the university campus. Mr. Pandey had just finished a long train ride. With his wrinkled kurta pajama and rubber slippers, he was every bit the picture of an old-fashioned Indian leftist.

headline: Donald Trump’s Shunning of Fox Debate Could Be Seen as Fight or Flight
text: The Trump show played for at least one final time on Tuesday before the Iowa caucuses. As has often been the case, the reviews were mixed.

headline: Tour and Hotel News: Culture in Portugal, Movie Scenes in Jordan
text: EXPLORING THE CULTURE OF PORTUGAL, PAST AND PRESENT

headline: ‘2666,’ a Most Difficult Novel, Takes the Stage
text: CHICAGO — “2666,” the Chilean writer Roberto Bolaño’s darkly enigmatic, wildly digressive, sometimes densely philosophical and above all extremely long final novel, has awed, mesmerized, baffled and exasperated readers around the world since its posthumous publication in 2004.

headline: John Kerry Urges China to Curb North Korea’s Nuclear Pursuits
text: BEIJING — Secretary of State John Kerry warned China on Wednesday that North Korea was moving ahead with an effort to manufacture a nuclear weapon small enough to fit atop a long-range missile that could reach American shores, and said the United States “will do what is necessary to protect the people of our country.”

headline: Another Kind of Girl
text: In this short documentary, a 17-year-old Syrian films an intimate portrait of life in her refugee camp.

headline: Another Kind of Girl
text: When I arrived at the Za’atari refugee camp in Jordan three years ago, I was overwhelmed. My family left our village in the region of Syria where the revolution began, after the area was bombed. My mother and six younger siblings and I suddenly became eight of the world’s 4.5 million Syrian refugees, and we have been living with 80,000 of them in our camp ever since.

headline: His Guardian Angel Was Packing
text: Dear Diary:

headline: Shell Shareholders Approve Acquisition of BG Group
text: LONDON — In one of the first energy mergers in the era of low oil prices, Royal Dutch Shell shareholders on Wednesday approved the acquisition of the BG Group, the Britain-based oil and gas producer, for about $50 billion.

headline: Ai Weiwei Says He’s Closing Danish Exhibition in Protest of Refugee Law
text: The dissident artist and activist Ai Weiwei said on Wednesday that he would close his current exhibition at the Faurschou Foundation in Copenhagen in protest of a new law allowing Denmark to confiscate refugees’ valuables to help pay for their stay in the country.

headline: John Kasich Is Called an ‘Obama Republican’ in New Hampshire Ads
text: MANCHESTER, N.H. – Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has steadily gained ground in the New Hampshire polls, drawing few attacks from his opponents as they have fought among themselves.

headline: The Meat Mavens' Waiting Game
text: The five-hour line at Franklin Barbecue in Austin, Tex., has become a rite of passage and a bonding experience for meat connoisseurs far and wide.

headline: Want Some of This Texas Barbecue? Get in Line. For 3 Hours or Longer.
text: AUSTIN, Tex. — At Franklin Barbecue, people pull up at dawn or shortly thereafter and spend their breakfast hours waiting for lunch.

headline: Elie Saab: Couture
text: Elie Saab’s couture 2016 collection.

headline: Facebook Building a Network for Virtual Reality
text: MENLO PARK, Calif. — When Facebook releases its fourth-quarter earnings results on Wednesday, it is likely to announce it shows well over eight billion videos a day. It is certainly a big number, but video is most likely a means to an end for Facebook.

headline: What You Get for … $950,000
text: This week’s properties include a townhouse near the Hudson, a contemporary in Tucson and a condo in Honolulu.

headline: $950,000 Homes in New York, Arizona and Hawaii
text: HUDSON, N.Y.

headline: French Justice Minister Quits Over Plan to Strip Citizenship From Terrorists
text: PARIS — The French justice minister, one of the most outspoken and progressive voices in the government, resigned on Wednesday after a clash over a proposal to strip the citizenship of French-born dual nationals convicted of terrorism.

headline: Rihanna Releases ‘Work’ From Long-Awaited Album ‘Anti’
text: For most of her career, Rihanna has been an artist on a tight schedule. Between 2005 and 2012, the pop star released an album each year except one (2008), with the last four coming like clockwork every November.

headline: New York Philharmonic Taps Jaap van Zweden as Its Next Maestro
text: The New York Philharmonic announced on Wednesday that it was turning to Jaap van Zweden, an intense, exacting Dutch conductor, to be its next music director and guide it through the costly renovation of its hall, two seasons of exile and, if all goes well, a triumphant return to Lincoln Center.

headline: What You Need to Know About the New York Philharmonic’s Next Music Director
text: The New York Philharmonic announced on Wednesday that the Dutch conductor Jaap van Zweden would be its next music director. Here are some key facts about him.

headline: Jaap van Zweden and the Future of the New York Philharmonic
text: When Alan Gilbert said in February that he would step down as music director of the New York Philharmonic in 2017, one of the first names bandied about was Jaap van Zweden. On Wednesday, Mr. van Zweden was announced as Mr. Gilbert’s successor, a decision I wouldn’t have anticipated last year.

headline: Trevor Noah Writing a Memoir About His Youth in South Africa
text: You’re not really a late-night satirist until you’ve parlayed your television gig into a lucrative book deal, and now Trevor Noah can say that he is truly a member of the club.

headline: Archaeologists in England Tackle Mystery of Prehistoric Village’s Rapid Demise
text: WHITTLESEY, England — No one knows why a catastrophic fire tore through the small settlement that rose by a river channel, incinerating the homes of several families and sending burning timbers crashing into the marsh below. It might have been an accident, an attack by enemies or even some sort of ritual.

headline: German Cabinet Backs Measures to Ease Deportation of Criminals
text: BERLIN — The German cabinet endorsed measures on Wednesday that would make it easier to deport many noncitizens convicted of crimes, responding to outrage over the sexual assault of hundreds of women by foreigners on New Year’s Eve and growing skepticism about the government’s ability to accommodate more than one million asylum seekers.

headline: A Villa in Dubrovnik With Sea Views
text: Built in 1910, this three-bedroom house is on the market for $2.73 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... Croatia
text: A VILLA IN DUBROVNIK WITH SEA VIEWS

headline: No Need to Fret, Apple Is Doing Fine
text: Let’s get this out of the way first: Despite what you may have heard, the iPhone is not dying. Neither, by extension, is Apple.

headline: Nexstar Clinches Deal to Acquire Media General
text: After months tangled in a three-way merger drama, the Nexstar Broadcasting Group has agreed to acquire Media General for more than $2.1 billion.

headline: Daily Report: The iPad’s Blaze of Glory
text: Remember the iPad?

headline: Under Pressure, SunEdison Gives David Einhorn’s Fund a Board Seat
text: SunEdison, the renewable energy company, was once the darling of the hedge fund world. Big-name investors like Steven A. Cohen, Leon G. Cooperman and David Einhorn rode the stock as it soared to ever increasing heights. And then it crashed.

headline: 1891: Rave Reviews for Fabre Drama
text: Over four thousand patriotic Frenchmen and Frenchwomen enthusiastically applauded ‘‘Jeanne d’Arc,’’ a drama by M. Joseph Fabre, music by M. Benjamin Goldard, which was given last night at the Châtelet. The plot of necessity follows the story of the Maid of Orleans, from her departure to arouse the King from his lethargy to the stake at Rouen. It is treated in a poetic way and the tirades placed in the heroine’s mouth are of the loftiest strain and full of the most patriotic spirit. All of this is set in the midst of a splendid mise-en-scène. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Jan. 28, 1891

headline: Protecting Personal Information From Virtual Assistants
text: Q. I was going to try Cortana, Microsoft’s version of Siri, but to use it, you have to allow Microsoft access to your location, your contacts, voice input, information from email and text messages, browser history, search history, calendar details “and other information.” Naturally, I declined. Why does Microsoft need so much personal information and what does Microsoft do with it?

headline: An Invitation Into the Shadowy World of Match Fixing
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — I was walking to my neighborhood Starbucks in Washington one morning last year when I received a Facebook message request from “Ben Rotenberg.”

headline: That’s Not Just a Bear You Hear in ‘The Revenant’
text: The river, the battles, that bear. Most distinctly that bear. The sound editors and mixers on “The Revenant,” about a frontiersman’s battle for survival, had many elements to consider when crafting the sonic universe of the punishing 19th-century West in Alejandro G. Iñárritu’s film. Their work has paid off with several Oscar nominations.

headline: New York City Ballet to Perform in Paris in Summer
text: There are about to quite a few more Americans in Paris, dancewise.

headline: Let It Snow, Let It Snow … and Paul Ryan’s Live Stream Captured It
text: Paul D. Ryan, the speaker of the House, has a nifty camera set up on his Capitol Hill balcony, which is used to live-stream all of his events. So it was decided that last weekend’s snowstorm would be streamed, too.

headline: Food Testing Start-Up Looks to Stand Out With a New Wrinkle
text: Nothing unnerves consumers more and drives them away from a restaurant, food or beverage faster than a flurry of headlines about people being sickened by dreaded bacteria like E. coli or listeria.

headline: Donald Trump Aide Is More Conditional About Skipping Debate
text: Donald J. Trump’s campaign manager used slightly less absolute words on Wednesday about Mr. Trump’s plans to skip Thursday night’s Republican presidential debate, saying he didn’t “think” there was any way the candidate would change his mind about attending the event on Fox News.

headline: Hillary Clinton Says Some Americans Might Have to Pay More Into Social Security
text: DECORAH, Iowa – Hillary Clinton said on Tuesday that new revenue was needed to shore up Social Security and openly mused about lifting the cap on income subjected to Social Security taxes, a position championed by Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont.

headline: Try to Interview Google’s Co-Founder. It’s Emasculating.
text: I started as The New York Times’s Google beat reporter in August 2014. Shortly thereafter, I told the company’s public relations people that at some point I would love to interview Larry Page, the company’s co-founder. I’ve been waiting ever since.

headline: Italy’s Strange Choice to Hide Its Art
text: Anyone receiving a special visitor understands the desire to be a gracious host. But there’s no point in beating around the bush here: Italian officials have gone to an absurd length in kowtowing to President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on his first visit since the lifting of economic sanctions as a result of the nuclear deal.

headline: Living in Southport, Conn.
text: The coastal enclave offers a rich array of 18th- and 19th-century architecture that reflects the area’s affluence during its heyday as a seaport.

headline: 5 Ex-Brokers Cleared in London Libor Trial
text: LONDON — In a major setback for British prosecutors, a jury on Wednesday acquitted five former brokers of charges that they helped a onetime trader at UBS and Citigroup manipulate an important benchmark interest rate known as Libor.

headline: Italians Mock Cover-Up of Nude Statues for Iranian’s Visit
text: ROME — A decision to cover up nude statues from Roman antiquity during a visit by President Hassan Rouhani of Iran has drawn ridicule and scorn in Italy — much of it directed at the Italian government — and spurred a debate about the national identity.

headline: Should The Times Have Been a Tougher Watchdog in Flint?
text: Updated, 4 p.m.

headline: Red Bulls Defender Matt Miazga Likely Headed to Chelsea
text: Defender Matt Miazga, who became a regular in the Red Bulls’ lineup as a teenager and made his United States national team debut in November at age 20, is set to be acquired by Chelsea of England’s Premier League, according to a person with knowledge of the negotiations.

headline: Recipes for Midweek (and Mozart)
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Human Rights Watch Denounces Europe Over Migrant Crisis
text: LONDON — European governments have allowed widespread fears about migration and terrorism to erode their commitment to civil rights and liberal ideals, according to a new report by the advocacy group Human Rights Watch.

headline: With Corbis Sale, Tiananmen Protest Images Go to Chinese Media Company
text: Corbis, the photography archive owned by Bill Gates that includes some of the most famous pictures ever made, has sold its image and licensing division to a Chinese company.

headline: Introducing Sutton Foster, the 40-Year-Old Ingénue of ‘Younger,’ Again
text: It’s the rare ingénue who gets to play the newbie role twice. But Sutton Foster, the star of the stealth hit sitcom “Younger,” is having her breakout moment as a spunky young heroine on the rise — some 13 years after she was plucked from chorus-line obscurity for an award-winning turn on Broadway.

headline: Super Bowl Challenges Wisdom of Crowds and Oddsmakers
text: When the betting line was first announced for this year’s Super Bowl, the Carolina Panthers were favored by 3½ points in many places. Quickly that line moved to 4 and then to 4½, and it is even listed at 5 or 5½ in some places.

headline: 1941: French Leaders Must Take Oath
text: VICHY — All French Cabinet ministers, secretaries of state and other high functionaries and notables will henceforth take an oath of allegiance personally to and in the presence of the Chief of the French state, binding themselves to ‘‘discharge their duties for the welfare of the state according to the laws of honor and probity.’’ This is provided for by a constitutional law, promulgated by Premier Marshal Henri Pétain today [Jan. 27]. By virtue of this act the highest state officials will be personally responsible to the Chief of State for their official acts and will be liable to suffer in their persons and in their property for their misdeeds in office. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Jan. 28, 1941

headline: Pardon Plea by Adolf Eichmann, Nazi War Criminal, Is Made Public
text: JERUSALEM — After he was convicted and sentenced to death in Israel for his role in the annihilation of millions of Jews by Nazi Germany, Adolf Eichmann pleaded for his own life.

headline: Shooting at Seattle Tent City Coincides With Mayor’s Homelessness Speech
text: As Seattle’s mayor delivered a speech about homelessness on Tuesday night, a grim reminder of the crisis was unfolding in another part of the city as five people were shot — two fatally — at a makeshift homeless encampment known as the Jungle.

headline: ‘One Minute Sculptures’ Invade the Schindler House
text: LOS ANGELES — In the participatory vein of Yoko Ono’s instruction pieces but decidedly less dreamy, Erwin Wurm’s “One Minute Sculptures” are blueprints for visitors to enact their own short performances, using directions and household props — a bucket, board, shoe or sweater, for instance — provided by this Vienna-based artist. For nearly two decades he has been staging these so-called sculptures mainly in galleries and museums, where the absurdity of placing a bucket on one’s head disrupts the rite of fine art consumption. Now he is bringing the series to the MAK Center for Art and Architecture here, with an exhibition in its historic Schindler home from Thursday through March 27.

headline: Oklahoma Resists Push for Enrollment in Affordable Care Act Coverage
text: OKLAHOMA CITY — A resolute band of insurance counselors, undeterred by the politics of health care in this staunchly conservative state, is increasing its efforts to find people who are uninsured and enroll them in coverage before the Affordable Care Act’s third annual open enrollment period ends on Sunday.

headline: Mrinalini Sarabhai, Indian Classical Dancer and Choreographer, Dies at 97
text: Mrinalini Sarabhai, an Indian dancer and choreographer who brought ancient South Indian dance forms into the 20th century and infused her work with social commentary, died on Jan. 21 at her home in Ahmedabad, in western India. She was 97.

headline: Elton John, Still Rocking Out (and Speaking Out) With a Flourish
text: LOS ANGELES — After 47 years in the spotlight, more than 250 million albums sold, six Grammys, a Tony, an Oscar and a knighthood, Elton John still gets the jitters when he steps onstage. Striding to his piano at the Wiltern here in a blue, rhinestone-dusted suit to play songs from his new album, “Wonderful Crazy Night,” for the first time, he surveyed the crowd of die-hard fans and music-industry insiders fretfully.

headline: Black Drivers in Florida Face Far Stricter Seatbelt Enforcement, Report Says
text: MIAMI — Black drivers in Florida were stopped and given tickets for not wearing seatbelts nearly twice as often as whites who drove on the state’s roads in 2014, according to a report by the American Civil Liberties Union released Wednesday.

headline: Bach, Reich, Bartok, Beethoven and More
text: BEETHOVEN, HAGEN: ’33+1’

headline: Robert Tuggle, Longtime Archivist of the Metropolitan Opera, Dies at 83
text: Robert Tuggle, who as the longtime archivist of the Metropolitan Opera helped create a digital database that includes details from every performance since the Met opened with Gounod’s “Faust” on Oct. 22, 1883, died on Sunday in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: Video Review: The New XF, a Jaguar Light on Its Feet
text: BEFORE 2008, Jaguars with more than two doors had distinct designs as British as Highclere Castle. Then the XF arrived. Crisp and contemporary, it quickly became Jaguar’s best-selling car. Now, for its second generation, it has taken the approach that less is more.

headline: Jean Paul Gaultier: Couture
text: The latest couture designs from Jean Paul Gaultier.

headline: Irregular Heartbeats? Coffee May Not Be So Bad for You
text: People with irregular heartbeats are often advised to give up caffeine, but a new study suggests they may not have to forgo their coffee.

headline: Review: ‘Imagining the Imaginary Invalid,’ About Absence and Art Making
text: Like a slightly dotty professor addressing a lecture hall, Marylouise Burke paces the stage and talks of Molière. He wanted to be a tragic actor, she tells us in her cartoon voice, but his stutter sent him into comedy instead.

headline: Mike Birbiglia Has a New Show at the Lynn Redgrave Theater
text: The stand-up comic Mike Birbiglia has earned a reputation as a great storyteller, through performances on the podcast “This American Life” and in his Off Broadway show (and later, movie) “Sleepwalk With Me,” but this might have obscured his skill as a joke teller.

headline: 3 More Arrests in Oregon as Protest Leader Says ‘Go Home’
text: PRINCETON, Ore. — The armed occupation of a wildlife refuge in eastern Oregon, which flashed into violent confrontation with law enforcement on Tuesday when eight members of the group were arrested and one was killed, appeared to be unraveling on Wednesday night when the jailed leader of the siege advised his followers to go home.

headline: Saying ‘We Are All Jews,’ Obama Honors Americans’ Lifesaving Efforts in Holocaust
text: WASHINGTON — In a German prison camp 71 years ago, Master Sgt. Roddie Edmonds stared down the barrel of his Nazi captor’s pistol and refused to say which of his fellow prisoners of war were Jewish.

headline: New and Old at Armani Privé and Maison Margiela
text: PARIS — Taxi cab drivers are striking in Paris, protesting the rise of Uber. On Tuesday, the air traffic controllers were, too. By the catwalks, editors and clients were arguing over whether Giorgio Armani’s new favorite color was mauve, as his Armani Privé show notes claimed, or lilac, as it seemed, or maybe even lavender. Shades of the notorious Internet dress dispute of almost a year ago. Plus ça change, and all that. What’s new?

headline: Report Faults E.C.B. in Irish Banking Collapse
text: DUBLIN — The European Central Bank placed an “inappropriate” debt burden on Irish citizens in 2010 when it refused to force bond investors to share losses from troubled banks, a parliamentary committee report on the country’s banking collapse said on Wednesday.

headline: Facts & Figures: Donald Trump’s Long Obsession With People Laughing at America
text: Just how much does Donald Trump talk about people abroad laughing at America? The Washington Post went back through his public statements and found he’s brought up the laughing issue at least 103 times, starting as early as 1987.

headline: French Justice Minister Steps Down
text: A French government spokesman reacted to the resignation of Justice Minister Christiane Taubira after she clashed with others in government over a controversial counterterrorism proposal.

headline: Caity Lotz Comes Back From the Dead as the White Canary
text: In CW’s “Arrow,” Caity Lotz played Sara Lance, a.k.a. the bloodthirsty Canary, who met her demise in Season 3. But it turns out that her character is more like a cat with nine lives.

headline: Regulatory Legislation
text: To the Editor:

headline: New Albums From Zaperoko, Teresa Cristina and Negative Example
text: 30 ANIVERSARIO

headline: The Zika Virus Leaves Salvadoran Women in a Serious Bind
text: To the Editor:

headline: British Tax Deal With Google Puts Government on Defensive
text: LONDON — When it was announced last Friday, Google’s agreement to pay 130 million pounds in back taxes was welcomed by the country’s chancellor of the Exchequer, George Osborne, as a “major success.”

headline: Rights Groups Seek Inquiry of Revoked Passports at U.S. Embassy in Yemen
text: A Brooklyn bodega owner, a naturalized citizen from Yemen, spent more than two years in stateless limbo after the United States Embassy in Sana confiscated his passport in 2013.

headline: Sugar-Coated Specialties for 90 Years
text: Schmidt’s Candy, in the Woodhaven section of Queens, has served handmade sweets since the current proprietor’s grandfather opened it in 1925.

headline: How to Experience David Bowie’s New York
text: David Bowie was a New Yorker for over 20 years. In Bowie years, that is practically an eternity considering the multitude of lives he lived — musically, geographically and otherwise — since he set out to become a star in the late 1960s.

headline: Scientists Move Closer to Understanding Schizophrenia’s Cause
text: Scientists reported on Wednesday that they had taken a significant step toward understanding the cause of schizophrenia, in a landmark study that provides the first rigorously tested insight into the biology behind any common psychiatric disorder.

headline: Schmidt’s Candy, a Sweet Spot in Queens
text: Somewhere in Woodhaven, Queens, there is a man with a wife named Zaida. Margie Schmidt of Schmidt’s Candy on Jamaica Avenue may not remember his name, but she knows what Zaida wants for Valentine’s Day. “Butter crunch, graham, milk-chocolate-covered pretzels, pretzel nuggets,” according to a list taped to a wall in the store’s back room.

headline: Lady Leshurr Brings Her Haughty English Rap to New York
text: There’s Lady Leshurr, walking toward the camera through single, continuous takes in her series of five videos, “Queen’s Speech,” collectively watched more than 37 million times last year. A deft rapper from Birmingham, England, real name Melesha O’Garro, Lady Leshurr keeps a conversational, demure tone as she administers put-downs and Internet meme jokes to the camera; crisp and haughty, she cracks on your hygiene, your friends, your whole world. (“I can’t stand girls who take their heels off when they’re in a rave,” she raps in Episode 3. “I’ll step on your big toe, just to remind you how to behave.”) Grime — English rap — remains fairly obscure in the United States, despite flickers of interest from Kanye West and others. (Last August, Erykah Badu put up Episode 3 on her Facebook page with the message “ILL.”) But Lady Leshurr, making mixtapes since 2009, is packaged and ready. She makes her New York debut at the Gramercy Theater at 8 p.m. on Saturday, Feb. 6. (venue.thegramercytheatre.com.)

headline: Beethoven String Quartet Cycle at Lincoln Center
text: While it’s hard to argue that the world — especially the little slice of it known as New York City — needs another Beethoven string quartet cycle, only the most churlish will be able to resist the draw of the one opening this week at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center. For the encyclopedically minded, the chronological order will be reassuring. For those craving variety, there’s the appeal of watching five different ensembles tackle this marathon in relay formation.

headline: A Radical Reinterpretation of ‘Swan Lake’
text: Choreographers keep peering into “Swan Lake,” searching for new themes in its symbolic waters. The latest to do so is Dada Masilo of South Africa, whose “Swan Lake” combines Tchaikovsky’s old ballet with modern realities. Although Ms. Masilo’s version, to a collage combining Tchaikovsky and contemporary music, establishes a carnival atmosphere and satirizes balletic conventions, it focuses on sexual politics.

headline: A Television Movie Revisits Charles Manson
text: It’s been almost 47 years since the murders orchestrated by Charles Manson in California. For younger generations to know about those crimes and understand the shock of them requires some passing-down of the story. A made-for-TV movie on Saturday, Feb. 6, on Lifetime tries to do this, and its cast embodies a passing-down tradition of its own: It includes several young actors following in a parent’s footsteps.

headline: Karl Lagerfeld Presents an Eco-Friendly Chanel Haute Couture Collection
text: The designer showed a series of nature-inspired looks, with organic accents and embellishments.

headline: The Metropolitan Museum Turns Detective With Jan van Eyck
text: In 1435, Philip the Good, Duke of Burgundy, praised his Flemish court painter, Jan van Eyck — one of the early Renaissance’s masters of pinpoint, every-hair-is-there realism — as having no equal in “art and science.”

headline: Adolf Eichmann’s 1962 Letter to President Yitzhak Ben-Zvi of Israel
text: A handwritten letter dated May 29, 1962, by Adolf Eichmann to the president of Israel asking for a pardon and commutation of his death sentence for war crimes was released to the public for the first time on Wednesday.

headline: F.C.C. Proposes Changes in Cable Set-Top Box Market
text: WASHINGTON — The cable set-top box, long a scourge of consumers and a moneymaker for cable companies, appears set for a makeover.

headline: Spanish Supreme Court Orders Bankia to Repay 2 Investors in Its I.P.O.
text: MADRID — The Spanish Supreme Court ordered Bankia on Wednesday to reimburse two small investors for misleading them during its 2011 initial public offering.

headline: Viktor & Rolf: Couture
text: Viktor & Rolf presents couture 2016.

headline: Iconic Images in the Corbis Library
text: Corbis sold its enormous archive, which includes a treasure house of famous historical photographs, to a Chinese company, Visual China Group.

headline: Joseph Fiennes Will Play Michael Jackson in British Comedy
text: The actor cast to play Michael Jackson in a comedy for British television is Joseph Fiennes.

headline: Senate Begins Debate on Comprehensive Bipartisan Energy Bill
text: WASHINGTON — The Senate on Wednesday started debating its first comprehensive energy legislation since the George W. Bush administration, a bipartisan measure meant to update the nation’s power grid and oil and gas transportation systems to address major changes in the ways that power is now produced in the United States.

headline: Warming Up to Sale at Artists & Fleas
text: The weather outside is frightful, but merchants are making shopping this week so delightful. Shake off the cold at Artists & Fleas, which is ringing in the last days of its “Not So Secret Sale” with a Last Chance Sip and Shop event Thursday from 6 to 9 p.m. Scoring deep discounts of up to 70 percent on items like sea glass necklaces ($22, originally $38) and photo prints of vintage toys ($13, originally $26) from a variety of clothing, accessories, art and home-goods vendors will be even nicer with a glass of bubbly or a Sixpoint beer in hand. At Chelsea Market, 88 10th Avenue.

headline: Letter by Adolf Eichmann to President Yitzhak Ben-Zvi of Israel
text: Handwritten in blue ink on lined paper, the 1962 letter from Adolf Eichmann, the Nazi war criminal who oversaw the lethal logistics of the Holocaust, to the president of Israel, Yitzhak Ben-Zvi, repeats part of Eichmann’s defense from his four-month trial: He was a lower-level official following orders, and he should not be held accountable for the crimes of his superiors. The letter was written in German on the day that Eichmann’s appeal was denied by Israel’s Supreme Court. Here is an English translation:

headline: Facebook Video Gives Account of Oregon Arrests
text: A man who claimed he was traveling with members of a protest group during a fatal traffic stop in Oregon on Tuesday said the man who was shot dead, LaVoy Finicum, had charged at police officers.

headline: A January Pause, but Fed Affirms Plan for Gradual Rate Increases
text: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve entered 2016 with a fairly straightforward plan to gradually increase its benchmark interest rate so long as job growth remained strong.

headline: Ulyana Sergeenko: Couture
text: Ulyana Sergeenko’s vision for couture 2016.

headline: France Restricts ‘Salafistes,’ Film on Islamic Radicals
text: PARIS — The French Culture Ministry ruled Wednesday that a new documentary film on Islamic radicals was unsuitable for minors, saying that it offered images of violence that were “sometimes unbearable” and interviews with members of Al Qaeda and other extremist figures that provided a platform for propaganda.

headline: A Director Follows Acclaim for ‘Tangerine’ With a Film for Kenzo
text: Sean Baker, a filmmaker whose fame has hitherto resonated mostly underground, broke the surface in 2015. “Tangerine,” his microbudget Los Angeles picaresque tale about two transgender women of color working an unbecoming strip of Santa Monica Boulevard near Highland Avenue, found its way onto year-end best-of lists and has been steadily collecting awards and nominations.

headline: Health Wonks and Bernie Bros
text: So Charles Gaba, whose excellent site ACA Signups has been a huge secret resource for those of us covering health reform, is getting the Bernie Bro treatment. Never mind his long service to the cause of covering the uninsured (and his declaration that he’ll support either candidate in the general): his carefully laid-out explanation of his support for Hillary Clinton’s incremental approach means that he’s a corrupt tool of the oligarchy.

headline: Wounded Warrior Project Spends Lavishly on Itself, Insiders Say
text: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — In 2014, after 10 years of rapid growth, the Wounded Warrior Project flew its roughly 500 employees to Colorado Springs for an “all hands” meeting at the five-star Broadmoor hotel.

headline: Chris Hemsworth Is the New Face of Australia
text: “Would you rather dance naked for Donald Trump, or would you rather have Donald Trump dance naked for you?” Curtis Stone, an Australian chef and television personality, asked a countryman, the film star Chris Hemsworth, on Monday night.

headline: Alphabet Program Beats the European Human Go Champion
text: Artificial intelligence researchers are closing in on a new benchmark for comparing the human mind and a machine. On Wednesday, DeepMind, a research organization that operates under the umbrella of Alphabet, reported that a program combining two separate algorithms had soundly defeated a high-ranking professional Go player in a series of five matches.

headline: Key Measure of a 5-9 College Star: 25.3 Points a Game
text: ROCHESTER, Mich. — There is a moment in nearly every Oakland University basketball game when Kahlil Felder stuns everybody in the arena. It can be a fast-break block from behind on a taller opponent, when Felder’s outstretched hand reaches halfway up the backboard square. Or an ankle-breaking crossover dribble that leaves an opponent tumbling to the floor. Or Felder’s cleanly swishing a 3-pointer, only four steps in from the halfcourt line, over a frozen defender.

headline: Donald Trump Finds New City to Insult: Brussels
text: LONDON — He incensed Paris and London by saying that some of their neighborhoods were so overrun with radicals that the police were too scared to enter.

headline: With Bowling Alley Visit, Hillary Clinton Closes a Circle in Iowa
text: ADEL, Iowa — Closing a circle on her Iowa presidential campaign, Hillary Clinton stopped in at a bowling alley here on Wednesday owned by Bryce Smith, a 23-year-old she met on her first visit to the state as a 2016 candidate.

headline: Frank Quattrone to Step Down as C.E.O. of Qatalyst
text: Nearly a decade ago, Frank P. Quattrone, the star investment banker who took Amazon and Cisco Systems public in the 1990s, returned to the deal scene with a boutique investment bank catering to Silicon Valley.

headline: LaVoy Finicum: ‘I Would Rather Die Than Be Caged’
text: JOHN DAY, Ore. — A week into the armed occupation of a wildlife refuge in eastern Oregon, LaVoy Finicum, an Arizona rancher and father of 11 who became a de facto spokesman for the protesters, took a seat in the compound and contemplated how the standoff might end for him.

headline: After Oval Office Meeting, Bernie Sanders Says Obama Is ‘Evenhanded’ in Primary Race
text: Senator Bernie Sanders praised President Obama on Wednesday for being “evenhanded” in the Democratic primary campaign after the two men met for more than 45 minutes in the Oval Office.

headline: When Your Neighbor’s Drone Pays an Unwelcome Visit
text: As a columnist who tests a lot of technology, I often write about my own experiences. But what happened last week was downright surreal.

headline: Couple’s Lawsuit Is First Test for Same-Sex Marriage in China
text: CHANGSHA, China — The two young men met through an online chat group. They began seeing each other every day. Long walks in the park. Movies and barhopping. Dinner with grandparents.

headline: Maureen Chiquet Is Leaving as C.E.O. of Chanel
text: PARIS — Twenty-four hours after Chanel’s Paris couture show was called among the best of the season, the company confirmed that Maureen Chiquet, chief executive of Chanel and one of the few women at the helm of a global luxury business, would leave at the end of this month.

headline: Valentino: Couture
text: Couture designs from Pierpaolo Piccioli and Maria Grazia Chiuri.

headline: For Bloomberg, Ambition Vies With Caution
text: ONCE again, Michael R. Bloomberg is eyeing a run for the White House. Once again, he’s got the political world buzzing, the pundits pontificating. Once again, the country is waiting for him to decide yea or nay.

headline: Trial of Ivory Coast’s Laurent Gbagbo Will Test International Criminal Court
text: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast — To some of his countrymen, Laurent Gbagbo is nothing more than an executioner who oversaw the killings and rapes of dozens of people. To others, he has become a martyr and a hero who deserves freedom.

headline: One-Thing Shops: Pop-Up Books, Madrid
text: Inspired by Borges and Chandler, José Luis Pereira dedicated almost a decade to writing short stories, with works published in various literary anthologies — “but like every writer, I wanted to have my own bookshop, too,” he says. “And not just a generic bookshop, but a place of wonders where I could offer fellow literature lovers much more than the usual best sellers.” For four years, he did just this, running a small store specializing in short story collections and hosting occasional readings and workshops in the inner-city Malasaña neighborhood of Madrid. “Then the economic crisis began,” he recalls.

headline: Returning, Again, to American Drawing in the 1960s
text: “Starting in the late ’60s, I think that drawing took a new form,” says the abstract painter Dorothea Rockburne. “For the most part, but not always — certainly not with Matisse — drawing had been a way of pre-thinking the structure in a painting. But drawing is not the orphan child of painting; it is a deep, material way of working.” Rockburne eyes the catalogue for the Museum of Modern Art’s 1976 exhibition “Drawing Now,” organized by Bernice Rose, folded over the armrest of her couch. “Drawing is exquisite, and Bernice picked up on that in her show, and Kate did, too.”

headline: App Smart | The Dating Game
text: Apps like Happn, Bumble and Glimpse offer an alternative to Tinder.

headline: Video Feature: Finding a Valentine, With a Tap or a Swipe
text: ALL the cute red hearts, chocolates, flowers and poetry can get irritating this time of year if you’re searching for someone special. It doesn’t have to be that way. Technology continues to make it easier to find a romantic match, and many of the best tools are mobile apps.

headline: Europe Raises Pressure on Greece to Tighten Its Borders
text: BRUSSELS — The European Union authorities on Wednesday raised pressure on Greece to step up its efforts to slow the flow of migrants and tighten control of the bloc’s external borders, the first step in a process that would allow some countries to its north to extend their border controls for up to two years.

headline: Facebook Reports Soaring Revenue, Buoyed by Mobile Ads

text: Plus: The mood ring’s makeover, Lena Dunham on the campaign trail and reversible bags, furry charms and abstract watches from Opening Ceremony and Fossil.

headline: For Blizzard Damage, Turn to Your Homeowner’s Policy
text: Atlantic Coast residents digging out from last weekend’s blizzard may be relieved to know that a standard homeowner’s insurance policy covers most types of damage caused by winter storms.

headline: News Analysis: Why Donald Trump Walked
text: It was a blustery and dramatic move, 48 hours before the final Republican debate until the Iowa caucuses: Donald J. Trump stormed out in a rage at Fox News, jeopardizing the network’s ratings and overtaking political headlines.

headline: Department of Justice Reaches Agreement With Ferguson
text: WASHINGTON — An agreement between federal officials and leaders in Ferguson, Mo., released Wednesday seeks to overhaul the city’s beleaguered justice system. It calls for ending unlawful arrests, ensuring that the courts are independent of prosecutors and preserving people’s right to film police officers.

headline: In Book, Xi Jinping Taints Ousted Rivals With Talk of Plots
text: BEIJING — The strip lighting and plastic chairs of the Xinhua bookstore on Dongdaqiao Road don’t invite people to linger, and the government-owned store, in the basement of a mall, was deserted on Monday afternoon.

headline: ‘Carol’ and ‘Transparent’: Women in Love, Then and Now
text: In the second season of “Transparent,” a quick scene gave me one of the most ecstatic highs I’ve had watching almost anything recently.

headline: Doctors Who Get Sued Are Likely to Get Sued Again
text: One percent of all doctors account for 32 percent of all paid malpractice claims, and the more often a doctor is sued, the more likely he or she will be sued again.

text: Photos from Germany, Poland, Greece and China.

headline: Review: Facing Marriage and Befriending a Squirrel in ‘The Portable Veblen’
text: One of the great pleasures of reading Elizabeth McKenzie is that she hears the musical potential in language that others do not — in the manufactured jargon of economics, in the Latin taxonomy of the animal kingdom, even in the names of our own humble body parts (who knew about the eye’s “zonule of Zinn”?). Her dialogue has real fizz and snappity-pop. It leaves a bubbled contrail.

headline: Review: Matan Porat Plays an Improvised Score to ‘The General’
text: Timing, momentum and pluck: That’s pretty much all that the young hero of Buster Keaton’s silent movie “The General” has going for him as he sets off to retrieve his locomotive, his girl and his honor in this madcap Civil War comedy from 1927. Timing, momentum and fierce technical chops were the main qualities the pianist Matan Porat brought to the stage on Tuesday evening at the 92nd Street Y when he performed an improvised score  to “The General” that was as propulsive, vivid and fun as the film itself.

headline: Talking to Christo About His Floating Piers
text: Christo, the artist known for large-scale public works like “The Gates” in Central Park, wasn’t exactly sure how to begin his lecture at a Manhattan school on Tuesday night. “I’m thinking of what Jeanne-Claude would say,” he said, referring to his wife and artistic partner, who died in 2009. “I miss her all the time, because my English is very poor, and my French is very poor. She was always talking.”

headline: With Purchase of BG Group, Shell’s Chief Bets on Oil Resurgence
text: Royal Dutch Shell’s chief executive, Ben van Beurden, can breathe easier after shareholders backed his big gamble that oil prices would rebound. Only 17 percent of investors voted against his $50 billion takeover of the BG Group on Wednesday.

headline: The Oscars and Race: A Stir Over Rules to Change the Academy
text: When the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences unveiled 20 all-white acting nominees this month, the furor was immediate. The #OscarsSoWhite hashtag, created last year, returned in force, and there was talk of an Oscar boycott. Then, last week, the academy declared that it was doubling its diversity push and ending guaranteed lifelong voting rights.

headline: Manhattan Construction Worker Injured in Fall Down Elevator Shaft
text: A worker was critically injured at a construction site in Manhattan on Wednesday after he lost his balance on a ladder and fell into an elevator shaft, plummeting four stories and landing on metal bars, the authorities said.

headline: Review: ‘All Balanchine II’ by New York City Ballet
text: Shall we blame the weather? The all-Balanchine program that New York City Ballet performed at the David H. Koch Theater on Tuesday went on as planned, but with a different cast — the one that had been slated for the preceding Saturday’s matinee. That show was canceled at the last minute because of the blizzard. Might this extremely rare change of plans have thrown the dancers off a little? The brilliance of the evening flickered.

headline: At Giorgio Armani Privé, a Delicate Couture Collection in Shades of Mauve
text: The designer’s feminine spring/summer 2016 collection included tulle, organza, silk — and jewels on everything from crinoline lace dresses to socks and stockings.

text: Couture from the designer who created Rihanna’s gown for the 2015 Met Gala.

headline: Theranos Lab May Pose Threat to Patient Safety, Regulator Says
text: A federal regulator has found that a lab run by Theranos, the Silicon Valley laboratory that promised to perform blood tests with a simple finger stick, violated several clinical standards, including one it said posed a threat to patient safety that had to be immediately corrected.

headline: Review: Florist Offers Skeletal Songs That Find Strength in Damage
text: “The Birds Outside Sang”

headline: Review: Alessia Cara, Voice for Outsiders, Becomes an Insider
text: Wallflowers have a champion in Alessia Cara, the 19-year-old Canadian singer and songwriter who headlined Webster Hall on Tuesday night. Ms. Cara’s lyrics pivot from self-doubt to self-affirmation in songs like “Wild Things,” which declares, “Don’t wanna hang around the in crowd/The cool kids aren’t cool to me.” The hit that sold out the club for Ms. Cara is “Here”: a jazzily sung, finely detailed depiction of a party she wishes she’d never attended. She calls herself an “antisocial pessimist” and sings on the chorus, “I ask myself, what am I doin’ here?” It’s far and away the best song on her 2015 debut album, “Know-It-All” (Def Jam).

headline: Bernie Sanders Insists He’ll Keep Pledge to Release Medical Records Before Iowa Caucuses
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has said that he plans to release his medical records before the Iowa caucuses on Monday. But with just five days to go, his campaign is not saying when exactly those records will be made public.

headline: January Letter From Government Regulators
text: A federal investigation of Theranos found in January that it violated several clinical standards, including one that it said posed an immediate threat to patient safety.

headline: Review: In ‘This Is Acting,’ Sia Adheres to Her Victim-to-Victory Formula
text: “This Is Acting”

headline: Review: ‘You, Me and the Apocalypse’ Looks at the End
text: There has been so much apocalyptic television over the years that once in a while the genre needs a blast of fresh air to disperse some of the gloom and earnestness. Last winter, the offbeat Fox comedy “The Last Man on Earth,” created by and starring Will Forte, provided it. On Thursday night, “You, Me and the Apocalypse” takes on the task, making the end of the world an unpredictably enjoyable ride, as it ought to be.

headline: Ben Carson’s Campaign Beset With Frustration, Disappointment and Grief
text: DES MOINES — As Ben Carson got ready for a television interview beside the pulpit of a Pentecostal church this week, campaign aides asked his supporters to move across the room and sit in the empty pews behind him.
