headline: Review: ‘God of Carnage’ Puts Parents in a Metaphoric Bull Ring
text: The ceramic red bull prancing on a shelf could be considered a symbol for the action that takes place before it, in a chic living room in Brooklyn.

headline: In Putnam County, a Humble Home for Arts on the Lake
text: Whether or not it qualifies as a trend, the conversion of former firehouses into arts centers has been going on across the country for years. Some of the repurposed buildings are stylishly hip, like the Wasserman Projects contemporary arts center in Detroit, and some are impressively grand, like the Firehouse Arts Center in Pleasanton, Calif.

headline: Review: Spice Kitchen in Mamaroneck Lives Up to Its Name
text: One of the first things you will see when you enter Spice Kitchen, a North Indian restaurant that opened in Mamaroneck in early September, is a lovely metal carving of Annapurna Devi, the Hindu goddess of nourishment. One evening we were seated beneath a mural of the Buddha at a comfortable banquette, and the ambience had a wonderfully calming effect, which, as it turned out, was very helpful because sometimes the patience of Job was needed when dining there.

headline: Review: Shan Shan Noodles in Parsippany Favors the Foods of Northwestern China
text: Food-obsessed souls like myself are on a perpetual quest to uncover a culinary treasure. The unspoken rule in the search for authenticity: The more unassuming the exterior, the more likely we will find an edible jackpot inside.

headline: Hot Toddies That Will Keep Long Island Winter at Bay
text: The weather during the holidays was unusually balmy, so Bobby Gulinello strung colored lights around South Shore Dive Pub & Kitchen and used a snow machine to simulate frost on the windows.

headline: Review: At Unionville’s Cure Restaurant and Bar, Bacon Is Basic
text: Cure Restaurant and Bar, in Unionville, is a hard place to pigeonhole. A lively, boisterous bar area occupies half its footprint, while the nearby dining room is the image of uncluttered refinement, with sufficient space between linen-draped tables to provide a sense of intimacy.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
text: “The Great Escape” is on TV, rendering all of Saturday’s other programming a pleasant superfluity. If “Dateline,” “Cops” or “Sex Sent Me to the E. R.” don’t grab your attention, go the other direction and stream the Wes Anderson film “Rushmore.”

headline: Fame Is Fleeting. The Wall Is Forever.

headline: Corrections: January 30, 2016
text: BUSINESS DAY

headline: At Some Restaurants in China, a Shortcut to Addictive Food: Poppies
text: BEIJING — It is no secret that fans of Chinese food often find it addictive. They speak longingly of the numbing spice of Sichuan peppercorn or the sour herbs found in Yunnan cooking.

headline: Angelique Kerber Upsets Serena Williams to Win Australian Open
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — At the Australian Open on Saturday, all that stood between Serena Williams and Steffi Graf was Angelique Kerber, who took 33 majors to reach her first Grand Slam final. Kerber was trying to become the first German to win a women’s major since Graf won in 1999. Williams was trying to join Graf as a 22-time major winner in singles.

headline: Fake Online Locksmiths May Be Out to Pick Your Pocket, Too
text: Maybe this has happened to you.

headline: Obama’s Budget Urges a Deeper Commitment to Computer Education
text: WASHINGTON — President Obama will call for spending $4 billion to help states pay for computer science education in the schools when he presents his 2017 budget to Congress, administration officials say.

headline: She? Ze? They? What’s In a Gender Pronoun
text: WASHINGTON — What happens when 334 linguists, lexicographers, grammarians and etymologists gather in a stuffy lecture hall on a Friday night to debate the lexical trends of the year?

headline: At Sundance, Rubbing Shoulders With A-Listers, for a Price
text: PARK CITY, Utah — Meet and greets with top D.J.s. Easy entry into celebrity-packed parties. Private rides to and from the most popular hotels, bars and restaurants in town, without Uber’s chatty drivers and ubiquitous surge pricing.

headline: Clinton to Attack Sanders in Iowa on Gun Control
text: Hillary Clinton will spend her last Saturday before the Iowa caucuses hitting Bernie Sanders on the issue that could potentially hurt him the most: guns.

headline: Miners in China Are Rescued After 36 Days Underground
text: BEIJING — Four miners have emerged alive after 36 days trapped 720 feet underground in eastern China, after a huge, intensely reported rescue effort in this country that has been plagued by mine disasters.

headline: Our Man in Iowa: A Signal of Who Might Win the Caucuses
text: CLINTON — Good morning from Iowa, where the campaigns have entered the final wind sprint to the finish line. As Donald J. Trump returns to the state, joining nine other Republicans and all three Democrats, campaign operatives and the news media will be anticipating one thing more than any rally: the release at 5:45 p.m. Central time of J. Ann Selzer’s final Iowa Poll.

headline: In India, a Small Band of Women Risk It All for a Chance to Work

headline: Bernie Sanders Is Making Surprising Gains With Less Affluent Whites
text: Bernie Sanders’s coalition once looked very familiar: He had strong support among well-educated and affluent liberal white voters of the sort who backed Barack Obama, Bill Bradley and Jerry Brown. He struggled among less affluent voters.

headline: ‘We Will Not Apologize’: Chronicling the Defiant Women of India
text: Eight months ago, on one of my first visits to the village of Peepli Khera, India, I saw a scene that captivated me, the way a character in a novel can sometimes captivate me.

text: Chuck Hagel, the former Republican senator from Nebraska who served as President Obama’s secretary of defense, says he is likely to back an independent presidential bid by Michael R. Bloomberg if Republicans nominate a candidate he considers unacceptable.

headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: Lessons From Earnings Season
text: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: 10 Children Among the Dead as a Migrant Boat Capsizes Off Turkey
text: GENEVA — One photo showed a small boy, perhaps 3 years old, dressed for a mild winter — dark blue pants and coat, a sky blue sweater for extra protection. The grown-up who had dressed him for the journey — barely five miles across the Aegean Sea — had cared enough to put on matching socks, with little blue cars. The boy was lying face up on the rocks. A winter hat, sky blue with a white pom-pom, covered his lifeless face.

headline: Hillary Clinton for the Democratic Nomination
text: For the past painful year, the Republican presidential contenders have been bombarding Americans with empty propaganda slogans and competing, bizarrely, to present themselves as the least experienced person for the most important elected job in the world. Democratic primary voters, on the other hand, after a substantive debate over real issues, have the chance to nominate one of the most broadly and deeply qualified presidential candidates in modern history.

headline: A Chance to Reset the Republican Race
text: The battle to be the Republican choice for president has been nasty, brutish and anything but short. The hope among some Republicans is that the Iowa caucuses on Monday and the New Hampshire primary on Feb. 9 will promote a candidate who can appeal to the half of their electorate that doesn’t support the two current front-runners.

headline: A Little Walmart Gift Card for You, a Big Payout for Lawyers
text: In this episode, we learn a new definition of the word “gift” and plumb the meaning of the word “coupon.” No, you don’t need a dictionary. But a sense of humor might help.

headline: Ve Neill, Oscar-Winning Makeup Artist: Putting a Face on Fantasy
text: Ve Neill  is an independent makeup artist for the movie industry in Studio City, Calif.

headline: U.S. Challenges China’s Claim of Islands With Maritime Operation
text: BEIJING — China on Saturday accused the United States Navy of violating its laws by sending a warship within the 12-mile territorial zone of an island it claims in the South China Sea after the Pentagon said a Navy vessel had conducted a freedom of navigation operation.

headline: Variety: Spiral
text: VARIETY PUZZLE — I love these Spiral puzzles. On the surface, they seem really easy, but keeping track of the entries going inward and outward can be tricky.

headline: New Weapon to Fight Zika: The Mosquito
text: Every weekday at 7 a.m., a van drives slowly through the southeastern Brazilian city of Piracicaba carrying a precious cargo — mosquitoes. More than 100,000 of them are dumped from plastic containers out the van’s window, and they fly off to find mates.

headline: Students Say Racial Hostilities Simmered at Historic Boston Latin School
text: BOSTON — With court-ordered desegregation of public schools unfolding violently across this city in the mid-1970s, Boston Latin, then about 90 percent white, began admitting more minority students, remaining a place of relative calm in a city engulfed in protest.

headline: Iowa Will Gauge Ardor to Upend Politics as Usual
text: DES MOINES — The presidential race hurtled over the weekend toward a watershed moment: voting that will start to reveal the true depth of Americans’ desire to cast aside traditional politicians and Washington-style compromise and embrace disruptive outsiders appealing to their passions.

headline: Kerber Keeps Cool in Australia, Long a Williams Safe Haven
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — You cannot accuse Serena Williams of not providing fair warning.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump Voters Share Anger, but Direct It Differently
text: DES MOINES — They are angry at a political system they see as rigged. They feel squeezed by immigration, or the power of big banks. They sense that America is heading in the wrong direction, but emphatically believe only their candidate has the strength and vision to change things.

headline: Start-Ups Take Rites From the Funeral Home to the Family Home
text: When people call Undertaking LA, they might ask a question like: “My mom just died of cancer in our home. We want to keep her until noon tomorrow. Is that legal? Is that O.K.?”

headline: Leadership Means Learning to Look Behind the Mask
text: I waited until it was too late to get the best feedback I ever received in my life.

headline: Meredith Wild, a Self-Publisher Making an Imprint
text: One chilly morning this month, Meredith Wild, the best-selling romance novelist, was sitting in her library in Destin, Fla., wrapped in a loose black sweater in front of a crackling fire. Most mornings, Ms. Wild writes her novels in this spot after her children leave for school, but that day she had other business to attend to. She had a call with a reality TV production company that is developing a show about her, and later, a conference call with a team at Waterhouse Press, the small imprint that is publishing her new novel in June.

headline: Uncomfortable Question for Ted Cruz on Obamacare Silences the Room
text: HUBBARD, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz is often asked about doing away with President Obama’s health care law. He is rarely pressed by voters on what will replace it.

headline: Anna Robbins
text: Anna Robbins is a costume designer best known for her work on “Downton Abbey,” which airs on “Masterpiece” on PBS.

headline: Honing Skills in U.S., a Group of Teenagers Is Fueling China’s Hockey Shift
text: A decade ago, when sporting interests in Beijing gravitated toward the coming 2008 Summer Olympics, a small group of boys began China’s hockey revolution by happenstance.

text: The comedian Louis C.K. pulled a Beyoncé on Saturday, releasing a new online show called “Horace and Pete” directly to fans with no prior warning.

headline: The Strip
text: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A Plague of Helicopters Is Ruining New York
text: IN recent years, New York City has invested over $2 billion in spectacular new waterfront parks. But that investment, and New Yorkers’ enjoyment of their parks and neighborhoods, is being ruined by an invasion of noisy, polluting tourist helicopters.

headline: Welcome to the Age of the Commando
text: A FEW months ago, my wife and I had dinner with a couple we didn’t know very well. It was awkward at first, but there was wine, and conversation soon followed. At one point, the wife asked about my tour in Iraq, where I served four years as a cavalry officer. I began talking about the desert, the tribal politics and the day-to-day travails of counterinsurgency. “That’s all fine,” the husband interrupted. “But tell us about the super-soldiers. The Special-Ops guys. That’s what people care about.”

headline: Here’s the Beauty of Trump
text: DES MOINES — THE White House has a strange, mind-warping effect on its occupants.

headline: Bernie Sanders, Made in Vermont
text: Rutland, Vt. — BERNIE SANDERS gained his largest margin of victory as a member of the House of Representatives the same year that Vermont experienced its fiercest conservative backlash. In the wake of a bruising fight over civil unions in 2000, Republicans regained the Vermont House and gave the popular Democratic governor, Howard Dean, his severest test.

headline: Calls for More Diversity in Academy Awards
text: Readers discuss the protests over the all-white nominees in the acting categories.

headline: Trump, Sanders and the Revolt Against Decadence
text: ONE of the puzzles of the 2016 campaign, unexpectedly defined by the ascent of a billionaire reality TV star and a septuagenarian Vermont socialist, is why now? Yes, voters are angry, yes, they’re exhausted and disgusted and cynical about everything. But why is everything boiling over in this particular cycle, in this presidential campaign?

headline: Is This the Oldest Image of the Virgin Mary?
text: THE Virgin Mary, the mother of Jesus, is the most revered woman in the Christian tradition. In the history of art, she appears almost as frequently as Jesus himself. But for the past 80 years, one of the oldest paintings of her may have been hiding in plain sight.

headline: Her Father Shot Her in the Head, as an ‘Honor Killing’
text: WHETHER it wins or not, the Oscar nominee with the greatest impact — saving lives of perhaps thousands of girls — may be one you’ve never heard of.

headline: How to Raise a Creative Child. Step One: Back Off
text: THEY learn to read at age 2, play Bach at 4, breeze through calculus at 6, and speak foreign languages fluently by 8. Their classmates shudder with envy; their parents rejoice at winning the lottery. But to paraphrase T. S. Eliot, their careers tend to end not with a bang, but with a whimper.

headline: Everybody’s a Critic. And That’s How It Should Be.
text: NEXT month, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences will complete its annual ritual of designating the best in two dozen cinematic categories. The Oscars have come under fire this year for the predictable, shameful racial homogeneity of their nominations, but that is not the only reason to complain.

headline: The G.O.P.’s Holy War
text: DES MOINES — IN the final, furious days of campaigning here, it was sometimes hard to tell whether this state’s Republicans were poised to vote for a president or a preacher, a commander or a crusader.

headline: Fall in Logging Leaves Myanmar’s Elephants Jobless
text: Shrinking forests and a ban on raw timber exports have left an uncertain future for Myanmar’s 5,500 or so pachyderms in captivity.

headline: Unemployed, Myanmar’s Elephants Grow Antsy, and Heavier
text: WA KALU PU, Myanmar — Dragging giant tree trunks up and down the steep hillsides of sweltering jungles is a tough job. But there is something worse, say owners of Myanmar’s logging elephants: having no job at all.

headline: De Blasio Arrives in Iowa to Help Hillary Clinton Before Caucuses
text: DES MOINES — Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York landed in this Midwestern city last spring as a man on a mission, delivering a fiery speech on the evils of inequality and calling on presidential contenders to adopt his liberal views.

headline: Jamie Murray Wins in Doubles; Andy Murray Has a Long Night, Too
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — It was after midnight, meaning it was officially Sunday, the day of his Australian Open singles final against Novak Djokovic, and Andy Murray was in the audience at Rod Laver Arena shooting video with his smartphone. On the court, Murray’s older brother, Jamie, paused in mid-interview to scold him. “Andy, you should be in bed,” he said.

headline: Why Sports Fans Risk Life and Limb for a Rolled-Up T-shirt
text: At Knicks games, it’s the 7th Avenue Squad. The Mets have the Pepsi Party Patrol. The Nets have the inanimate Team Hype. But every team in sports with any semblance of a marketing department has its own version of the Fan Patrol or Fun Police. This unnaturally peppy collective represents a cross between a cheerleading squad and the “motivators” at a bar mitzvah party. Their demeanor and high energy often totally at odds with the tenor of the game, they attempt to energize the crowd by cavorting with the mascot and dancing with kids on the Jumbotron and hosting the fan contest during breaks in the game. But the highlight of their shift comes when they launch T-shirts into the crowd.

headline: Icy Surface Ahead (Please Speed Up)
text: About 20,000 spectators flocked to Eagle River, Wis., known as the snowmobile capital of the world, for the annual World Championship Snowmobile Derby in January.

headline: The Iowa Push
text: With the caucus on the horizon, the presidential candidates blanketed the state with events.

headline: Remaining California Jail Escapees Are Captured in San Francisco
text: LOS ANGELES — The two remaining fugitives who escaped from a maximum-security jail in Southern California were recaptured in the Bay Area on Saturday, ending an eight-day manhunt, law enforcement officials said.

headline: Tentative Agreement Reached for More Democratic Debates, Aides Say
text: After days of jostling over whether to meet for more debates, and how many, aides to Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders have reached an agreement, of sorts, they said Saturday: The two will meet next week in New Hampshire and will hold three more debates thereafter.

headline: A Warrior Can Join the Likes of Chamberlain, Bird and Fat Lever
text: In the midst of the Golden State Warriors’ championship run last season, Draymond Green became nearly as famous for his offbeat personality as for his lockdown defense.

headline: John Kasich Courts New Hampshire Independents
text: KEENE, N.H. – Of all the Republicans campaigning in New Hampshire, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has appealed most explicitly to the state’s population of unpredictable independent voters and moderate Republicans, who play an outsize role in presidential primaries here.

headline: Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York, a Distinct Sight in Iowa, Rallies the Clinton Troops
text: DES MOINES — The tall man arrived at the house around noon, bending slightly to avoid a ceiling beam, and smiled at the sight of two dozen Hillary Clinton supporters in a sunlit living room.

headline: Donald Trump Offers to Let Children ‘Run Through’ His Plane While He Speaks in Iowa
text: DUBUQUE, Iowa — Donald J. Trump’s golden-lettered plane is one of the biggest toys in national politics. And he used it as such on Saturday, to keep children happy after waiting more than an hour in a chilly airport hangar for his first of three rallies today.

headline: As Deaths Mount, an Ever Expanding Recall
text: The Takata airbag recalls have mushroomed to an estimated 28 million inflaters in more than 24 million cars at 14 automakers.

headline: Takata’s Faulty Airbags Still Exact Toll as Recalls Lag
text: ROCK HILL, S.C. — The shrapnel from the Ford Ranger airbag punctured Joel Knight’s neck with so much force that investigators initially did not rule out a fatal shooting.

headline: Kenny Sailors, a Pioneer of the Jump Shot, Dies at 95
text: There was just one witness to the moment Kenny Sailors helped revolutionize the game of basketball — his brother, Bud — but by all accounts, no one has ever doubted their story.

headline: Iowa Official Criticizes Cruz Campaign Over Mailer
text: HAMLIN, Iowa — Iowa’s secretary of state chastised the presidential campaign of Senator Ted Cruz on Saturday for sending a mailer that he said violated “the spirit of the Iowa caucuses” and misrepresented state election law.

headline: Message to Buyers
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We last met up with Yaakov Bendavid nearly two years ago, when he was caught cheating by turning failing F grades to passing Ds. Today, Mr. Bendavid presents us with a list of warnings to buyers that are clued in a punny way. Caveat emptor. Five of the six theme entries make their debuts today, and some work better than others. I liked “Offer of free pillow fill?” for NO MONEY DOWN, “Desert supermarket?” for STORE IN A DRY PLACE and “Sign on the N.S.A.’s entrance” for INTEL INSIDE. For some reason, “Note on a watered-down assault indictment?” for BATTERY NOT INCLUDED made me cringe a bit.

headline: Republicans Attack Hillary Clinton Over Classified Emails
text: DES MOINES — With the final hours before the Iowa caucuses ticking away, Republicans are seizing on new and potentially damaging revelations about Hillary Clinton’s handling of sensitive information as evidence that she is unfit to be president.

headline: Liz Cheney to Run for Wyoming’s Only House Seat
text: WASHINGTON — Liz Cheney, the daughter of former Vice President Dick Cheney, has filed with the Federal Election Commission to run for Wyoming’s only House seat, a return to politics after her short-lived but much discussed bid for the Senate two years ago.

headline: Review: Louis C.K.’s ‘Horace and Pete,’ Mournful and Unshakable
text: Sometimes you don’t want to go where everybody knows your name. Sometimes it becomes oppressive — the history, the choking familiarity, the endlessly repeated fights. Sometimes you want to go just about anywhere else. But what choice do you have?

headline: Donald Trump Leads Ted Cruz in Top Iowa Poll
text: DES MOINES – Donald J. Trump has widened his edge against Ted Cruz in Iowa, according to a Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics poll on Saturday that shows the billionaire gaining momentum right ahead of Monday’s caucuses.

headline: Why This Is the Iowa Poll That Everyone Was Waiting For
text: Perhaps no political poll is more eagerly anticipated and receives more attention than the last Des Moines Register poll before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: One Dead and Several Wounded in Shooting at Colorado Motorcycle Expo
text: Shots rang out when a violent confrontation between biker gangs erupted on Saturday at a motorcycle show in Denver, leaving one person dead and several others injured, the police said.

headline: Greece Resists Its Role as European Union’s Gatekeeper
text: IDOMENI, Greece — On a recent weekday, 40 buses jammed into the parking lot of a gas station near the Macedonian border, carrying thousands of refugees who had survived a perilous crossing on wintry seas from Turkey.

headline: Now a Survivor, Rod Carew Weeps Without Shame
text: MINNEAPOLIS — The black vest that Rod Carew wears everywhere these days has pockets on both sides, giving him a choice of where to carry the battery-powered medical device that keeps him alive.

headline: Special Election Is Set for April to Fill Seats Left Vacant in Albany
text: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York said on Saturday that April 19 had been set as the date for a special election to fill four vacancies in the State Legislature, including seats left empty when Sheldon Silver, the former Assembly speaker, and Dean G. Skelos, the former Senate majority leader, were convicted on federal corruption charges last year.

headline: Screen Actors Guild Awards Red Carpet
text: Kate Winslet, Alicia Vikander and Brie Larson were among the celebrities walking the carpet at the awards ceremony on Saturday evening.

headline: Screen Actors Guild Awards Red Carpet
text: Laverne Cox, Kiernan Shipka and Ellie Kemper were among the celebrities walking the carpet at the awards ceremony on Saturday evening.

headline: Brett Brown and Steve Kerr: Coaches With Much in Common, Aside From Records
text: PHILADELPHIA — Steve Kerr and Brett Brown began to form their relationship during the 2002-3 season with the San Antonio Spurs. Kerr was in his final season as an N.B.A. player, and Brown was in his first season as the team’s director of player development. They took to each other instantly.

headline: Authorities Arrest Son of Ex-Leader in Sri Lanka
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — Sri Lankan authorities arrested a son of former President Mahinda Rajapaksa on money-laundering charges on Saturday, the government’s latest attempt to prosecute members of the previous administration, many of whom have been under investigation since Mr. Rajapaksa’s election defeat last year.

headline: Dispatches From the Final Dash of Presidential Candidates in Iowa
text: After hundreds of campaign stops and tens of thousands of television ads, candidates are crisscrossing Iowa this weekend on a final, frantic dash, cajoling the last undecided voters and energizing supporters to head to Monday night’s caucuses. Fending off drowsiness with Red Bull and Katy Perry songs, they are racing through a mind-muddying 55 events, from Dubuque in the northeast to Council Bluffs in the southwest, in a blur of speeches and handshakes.

headline: President Xi Jinping of China Is All Business in Middle East Visit
text: BEIJING — When President Xi Jinping of China traveled to the Middle East this month he dropped in on two regional rivals, Saudi Arabia and Iran, a feat few global leaders could pull off.

headline: Ted Cruz Counters Donald Trump With Targeted Approach in Iowa
text: URBANDALE, Iowa — Senator Ted Cruz’s leading Iowa supporters say his get-out-the-vote operation is the best they have seen for a presidential campaign here. He had better hope they are right.

headline: Myanmar’s Unemployed Elephants
text: Myanmar’s newly democratic government has banned the export of raw timber, to help fight deforestation. But that has idled thousands of the elephants that toil in the logging industry.

headline: Bernie Sanders Exudes Confidence About Iowa (and Elsewhere)
text: DES MOINES — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont ruminated on the final two questions asked of him about the Iowa caucuses as he rose from a table packed with reporters here on Thursday morning.

headline: Turkey Accuses Russia of Again Violating Its Airspace
text: Turkey on Friday accused Russia of violating its airspace for the second time in recent months, injecting fresh rancor into a relationship that has been badly strained since Turkish fighters shot down a Russian plane that entered the country from Syria in November.

headline: A Bloomberg Poll Finds Little Support for Michael Bloomberg
text: DES MOINES – A Bloomberg-sponsored poll, made public in extravagant Bloomberg style amid shrimp and champagne, delivered some sour news about Michael R. Bloomberg himself: Few Iowa voters like him as he weighs a third party White House run.

headline: Bernie Sanders Sings ‘This Land Is Your Land’ With Vampire Weekend
text: Bernie Sanders held a rally and concert at the University of Iowa tonight with thousands of students, whom he urged to vote for him on Monday and “make the pundits look dumb.”

headline: From Hillary Clinton, a Single Message Told Across the Decades
text: A rebuke to those who say that Senator Bernie Sanders is unswerving in his political stands, or that the former first lady adjusts hers to suit the moment.

headline: Tax Scams Are Targeting Uninsured, I.R.S. Warns
text: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service is warning consumers about tax scams involving the Affordable Care Act and penalties imposed under the law on people who go without health insurance.

headline: Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz, Influential Reform Theologian, Dies at 91
text: Rabbi Eugene B. Borowitz, a leading theologian of Reform Judaism who argued that the modern emphasis on reason and self-imposed ethics needed the undergirding of what he called a covenantal relationship with God, died on Jan. 22 at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 91.

headline: Iowa Anomaly: A Town Ignored by Candidates
text: EAGLE GROVE, Iowa — There is a high school auditorium here that could fit 200 people, give or take. Some wood-paneled furniture stores, a pharmacy, a three-garage firehouse and a popular deli dot downtown, looking like a postcard from America’s heartland, if not its heart.

headline: Hillary Clinton Criticizes Bernie Sanders and Ted Cruz on Healthcare
text: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Making her final push before the Iowa caucuses, Hillary Clinton staked out her position as the lone defender of the Affordable Care Act on Saturday night, warning that her Democratic rival, Senator Bernie Sanders, would scrap it and start over and that Republicans would hand healthcare back to insurers and drug-makers.

headline: ‘The Birth of a Nation’ Sweeps Top Awards at the Sundance Film Festival
text: Setting up an expected 2017 Oscar run, “The Birth of a Nation,” a searing slave-revolt drama, swept the top prizes at the Sundance Film Festival on Saturday night in Park City, Utah.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
text: Shia LaBeouf showed all of his movies at the Angelika Film Center in Manhattan in November. You can stream one of them. Elsewhere, Vice reports on the battle against the Islamic State, and “60 Minutes” investigates the increasing popularity of the United States as a place for corrupt officials and foreigners to stash money. And the search for Bigfoot trudges onward.

headline: Blair Thomson-Levin, Jason Oberman
text: Blair Elise Thomson-Levin, a daughter of Janice I. Thomson and Roy Levin of Palo Alto, Calif., was married Jan. 30 to Jason Andrew Oberman, a son of Nancy S. Oberman and Jeffrey L. Oberman of Weston, Conn. Steve Goldbloom, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Carneros Inn in Napa, Calif.

headline: Michelle Chin, Brandon Wong
text: Michelle Chin and Brandon Wong were married on Jan. 30 by the Rev. Donald Williams, a Presbyterian minister, at Coral Cove Villa on the beach in Discovery Bay, Jamaica.

headline: Michelle Isaacson, Jonas Curchack
text: Michelle Rebecca Isaacson and Jonas Aaron Curchack were married Jan. 30 at the Yale Club of New York. Rabbi Lev Herrnson officiated.

headline: Thayer Adams and Thomas McKenzie: A Lifelong Bachelor Turns the Page
text: Thayer Wendell Adams and Thomas William McKenzie were married Jan. 30 at the Ocean Reef Club in Key Largo, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Henley, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

headline: Annette Graumann, Chase Welles
text: Annette Graumann and Chase Bassett Welles were married Jan. 30 at Grace Church in New York. The Rev. Stephen C. Holton, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

headline: Katie Rogers, John Chinoransky
text: Katie Rogers and John Charles Chinoransky were married Jan. 28 at the Audubon House and Tropical Gardens in Key West, Fla. Liz Weinstock, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

headline: Maureen Trantham, Brian Turner
text: Maureen McCotter Trantham and Brian Hughes Turner were married Jan. 28 at the Manhattan Marriage Bureau. Edwina M. Townes, a staff member of the New York City Clerk’s office, officiated.

headline: Autumn Doerr, Lynn Malchow
text: Autumn Doerr and Lynn Malchow were married Jan. 29 at the Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center in Los Angeles. Roberto Longoria, a judge on the Superior Court of Los Angeles County, officiated in his chambers at the courthouse.

headline: Jacqueline Lonier, Andrew Dikman
text: Dr. Jacqueline Yuey Lonier and Dr. Andrew Evan Dikman were married Jan. 30 by Rabbi David Adelson at City Winery, an event space in New York.

headline: Christine Motley, Irtiaz Ahmad
text: Christine Marie Motley and Irtiaz Uddin Ahmad were married Jan. 30 in Monmouth Junction, N.J. Imam Shair Abdul Mani officiated at the home of Fatima and Fakrul Sayeed, an aunt and uncle of the groom. The ceremony incorporated Muslim and Christian wedding traditions.

headline: Sarah Corsaro, Matthew McGrath
text: Sarah Elizabeth Corsaro and Matthew Levin McGrath were married Jan. 30 in the Dahlgren Chapel on the campus of Georgetown University in Washington. Msgr. Robert Harris, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the groom, performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Daniel Levin, also a cousin of the groom, taking part.

headline: Kaneesha Parsard, Ryan Jobson
text: Kaneesha Cherelle Parsard, the daughter of Sheryl K. M. Parsard and Keston O. Parsard, both of Lynbrook, N.Y., was married Jan. 30 to Ryan Cecil Jobson, a son of Lisa R. Jobson and Dr. G. W. Mark Jobson of Woodstock, N.Y. Glossie Stone, a Pentecostal minister and a marriage officer for Jamaica, officiated at Hummingbird Hall in Montego Bay, Jamaica.

headline: Corrections: January 31, 2016
text: FRONT PAGE

headline: Quotation of the Day
text: “Now something that was supposed to save him killed him.”

headline: Applications Sought for New York Portfolio Review
text: Once again, an intense weekend of critiques, conversation and community will take place at the Fourth Annual New York Portfolio Review. It’s free, but space is limited, so apply now.

headline: Seeking Applications for the 2016 New York Portfolio Review
text: Whether you are a budding photographer trying to get a foothold in the profession, or a veteran looking for new challenges, The Fourth Annual New York Portfolio Review could provide the break you’re looking for. And it’s free — because we think that it’s the quality of the work that matters, not how much money you can pay.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing: Donald Trump, Oregon, Novak Djokovic
text: Here are the week’s top stories.

headline: Your Weekend Briefing
text: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.

headline: How Europe Protects Your Online Data Differently Than the U.S.
text: All the talk about data privacy can get caught up in political wrangling. But the different approaches have practical consequences for people, too.

headline: U.S. and Europe Fail to Meet Deadline for Data Transfer Deal
text: American and European officials failed on Sunday to reach an agreement over how digital data — including financial information and social media posts — could be transferred between the two regions.

headline: Terror Threats Thaw Budgets Across Europe
text: PARIS — A phalanx of soldiers wearing bulletproof vests and wielding machine guns fanned out beneath the Eiffel Tower on a recent afternoon, scanning the crowd for potential terrorist threats. Across the country, nearly 10,000 more armed troops patrolled streets around landmarks, stores and government buildings.

headline: 1891: Ernest Meissonier Dies
text: Meissonier is dead. The news spread throughout Paris yesterday as only sad tidings can. Most people had heard that this greatest of living painters — as he was until yesterday morning — was in ill-health, and had indeed been forced to resign the presidency of the National Society of Fine Arts in consequence.

headline: In Iowa, Voters on the Edges May Set Tone for Primaries
text: DES MOINES — Iowa, widely derided for being unlike the rest of the United States, was supposed to be irrelevant this year as the presidential race became nationalized — thanks to widely viewed televised debates and the rise of social media.

headline: Why the Iowa Caucuses Loom So Large
text: Iowa is overrun by presidential candidates and the media following them. The New York Times reporter Trip Gabriel explains why such a small state has such an outsize significance.

headline: Novak Djokovic Wins Sixth Australian Open to Tie Record
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — The Grand Slam was there for the taking in September in New York, and although Serena Williams faltered there and then faltered in the final in Melbourne on Saturday, a Grand Slam is still very much on the table.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Quiet Support Will Carry Iowa, Ex-Governor Predicts
text: WASHINGTON — Neither Bernie Sanders nor Donald J. Trump will repeat Barack Obama’s 2008 victory in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Coming of Age, Whether They Like It or Not
text: Shortly before my son’s bar mitzvah last fall, I purchased some Arnold Palmer lemonade/iced tea in what we call “the Man Jug.” It was part of a ritual created by my older son, Charlie, when he came home from his bar mitzvah service, chug-a-lugged the tea straight from the bottle, and proclaimed, “I’m a man, I can drink from the Man Jug.” His little brother, Theo, wasn’t going to miss this opportunity for himself.

headline: Nostalgia for a Dot-Com Casualty
text: Dear Diary:

headline: 1966: Belgian Miners Killed
text: HASSELT, Belgium — Two coal miners were killed and dozens wounded in a violent daylong clash with state police in Waterschei near here today [Jan. 31]. The first was killed by a bullet in the stomach as police stood off attacking miners, police said. The second was killed when police counterattacked.

headline: Our Man in Iowa: Polls Point to Donald Trump, as Do Odd Indicators
text: DAVENPORT – Good morning from Iowa, where there are many ways of trying to predict Monday night’s caucus results — candidates’ crowd sizes, the enthusiasm, the highly regarded Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics poll, which overnight showed Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton with small leads.

headline: For Victims, an Overloaded Court System Brings Pain and Delays
text: It had gone on for almost four years, Maxima Allen said as she sat on a hard bench in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn over the summer.

headline: SAG Awards Red Carpet
text: Kate Winslet, Alicia Vikander and Brie Larson were among the celebrities walking the carpet at the awards ceremony on Saturday evening.

headline: Syria Peace Talks Inch Ahead as Bombings Near Damascus Continue
text: GENEVA — As a suicide attack killed more than 40 people near a revered shrine in Syria on Sunday and government forces pummeled a besieged town, peace talks inched forward in Geneva, where a reluctant opposition delegation met for the first time with a United Nations mediator.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: ‘Spotlight’ Takes Top Screen Actors Guild Award
text: At the Screen Actors Guild Awards on Saturday night, the journalism drama “Spotlight” won the top prize: outstanding performance by a cast.

headline: Far From Home, Djokovic Is a Favorite Son
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — Novak Djokovic was trying to explain to the television studio hosts how he had managed to tie two Australian legends with his 6-1, 7-5, 7-6 (3) victory over Andy Murray in the Australian Open final Sunday. But he could not hear himself think.

headline: Bernie Sanders Says Tax Plan Would Not Hurt Democrats’ 2016 Prospects
text: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont was asked on “Meet the Press” on Sunday whether his health care plan, which would raise taxes to pay for more government benefits, would create a problem for House Democrats running for re-election in 2016.

headline: How Donald Trump Tried to Protect His Name From Others Who Shared It
text: “Bygones are bygones,” Jules Trump said, looking back on a legal skirmish that involved nothing more than what’s in a name: his name, or, specifically, the Trump Organization (Donald J. Trump) and the Trump Group (Jules Trump and his brother, Eddie).

headline: Sanders Sings With Vampire Weekend
text: Bernie Sanders joined musicians from Vampire Weekend to sing “This Land Is Your Land” at a rally in Iowa City, Iowa.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Campaign Says It Raised $20 Million in January
text: On the eve of the Iowa caucuses, Bernie Sanders’s campaign said Sunday is has already raised $20 million this month, an enormous haul that backs up the campaign’s assertion that it will have enough money for a long, hard-fought nominating fight against Hillary Clinton.

headline: Hillary Clinton Campaign Declined Bill de Blasio’s First Offer to Help in Iowa
text: DES MOINES — Hillary Clinton’s team declined Mayor Bill de Blasio’s initial offer to campaign in Iowa for her candidacy, the mayor said in an interview here on Sunday morning.

headline: Choice to Conduct Independent Tennis Review Has Ties to the Sport
text: MELBOURNE, Australia — At the announcement of an independent review into the tennis anticorruption program on Wednesday, Chris Kermode, chairman of the Association of Tennis Professionals, pledged that tennis would do more than a hollow internal inquiry.

headline: Barclays and Credit Suisse to Settle ‘Dark Pool’ Inquiries
text: Barclays and Credit Suisse will pay a combined $154.3 million to settle allegations that they misrepresented their private stock trading services.  The systems, known as dark pools, are supposed to offer a haven to traditional traders and investors from predatory trading behavior.

headline: Review: ‘Impractical Jokers’ Is Played for Laughs Live at Radio City
text: “Impractical Jokers” is just dumb fun, but what do you expect from a prank show in which loud comics accost strangers on the streets?

headline: ‘Kung Fu Panda 3’ is No. 1
text: Hollywood had a bumpy weekend. In its first three days of release, DreamWorks Animation’s high-stakes “Kung Fu Panda 3” may have left money on the table at home in search of riches abroad. “The Finest Hours,” yet another ocean disaster movie, failed to attract an initial audience big enough to justify its cost. And tumbleweeds blew through theaters playing “Jane Got a Gun,” produced by and starring Natalie Portman.

headline: O.J. Simpson Drama Depicts an Old Trial, and Renewed Tensions
text: For the last two decades, O. J. has been on ice.

headline: Email Issue Dogs Hillary Clinton on Eve of Iowa Caucuses
text: This is not what Hillary Clinton wanted to discuss the morning before the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Donald Trump Field Organizer Accuses Campaign of Sex Discrimination
text: DAVENPORT, Iowa — A former paid organizer for Donald J. Trump who was fired this month has accused his presidential campaign of sex discrimination.

headline: Trying to Separate Bill Cosby From Cliff Huxtable
text: Bill Cosby looked haggard and old as he stumbled on his way to the courthouse. And when his mug shot flashed across my screen, I felt a sharp stab of grief.

headline: Palestinian Officer Is Killed After Attacking Three Israeli Soldiers
text: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian policeman shot three Israeli soldiers, seriously wounding two, at a West Bank checkpoint on Sunday before being killed by soldiers, the Israeli military said.

headline: Battered by War, Iraq Now Faces Calamity From Dropping Oil Prices
text: BAGHDAD — Iraqis seeking to withdraw money from banks are told there is not enough cash. Hospitals in Baghdad are falling back to the deprivation of the 1990s sanctions era, resterilizing, over and over, needles and other medical products meant for one-time use.

headline: Restored Williamsburg Bell to Be Celebrated
text: Dionne Warwick, Esperanza Spalding and Danny Glover will be among the performers on hand Monday night at a gala concert honoring the restoration of the bell at the First Baptist Church in Williamsburg, Va., founded in 1776 by slaves and one of the oldest black churches in America.

headline: The Rev. John Romas, Leader of Greek Church at Ground Zero, Dies at 86
text: After St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church in Lower Manhattan was destroyed on Sept. 11, 2001, by the collapse of the World Trade Center nearby, the Rev. John D. Romas held his small congregation together as its worship services moved to Brooklyn and instilled in his parishioners the hope that they would live to see their church rebuilt. He, however, did not.

headline: Israel Approves Prayer Space at Western Wall for Non-Orthodox Jews
text: JERUSALEM — After years of rancor over rituals at the Western Wall, one of the holiest sites in Judaism, the Israeli government on Sunday approved the creation of an upgraded egalitarian prayer space there for non-Orthodox Jews.

headline: More Democratic Debates in the Works
text: The Democratic presidential candidates have asked for more debates, and it appears they are going to get their wish.

headline: How Moon Dust Languished in a Downing Street Cupboard
text: It was a space problem of sorts for the new British prime minister: where to put the minuscule sample of the lunar dust that America’s Apollo 11 astronauts had scooped from the surface of the moon in their giant leap for mankind?

headline: As Family Helped Build Betting System, It Witnessed Horse Racing History
text: Late Sunday afternoon, when the tote board went dark after the final race of the day at Aqueduct Racetrack, Pat Mahony called it a career, one he has cherished and one that has been part of his family history for more than a century. Like his father and grandfather before him, Mahony is a mutuels man.

headline: In Iran, New Battle Brews Over Contracts With Foreign Oil Giants
text: TEHRAN — A political battle is taking shape in Iran over any new foreign role in developing the country’s enormous oil wealth, only a few weeks after the Iranian nuclear deal with foreign powers relaxed tough economic sanctions.

headline: Pre-Iowa Notes
text: I don’t know what will happen in the caucuses tomorrow. Actually, I know what will happen on the Republican side: someone horrifying will come in first, and someone horrifying will come in second. The names are less clear.

headline: Twisting Inquiry Into Buenos Aires Bombing Takes New Turn
text: BUENOS AIRES — For more than two decades, an investigation into the suicide bombing of a Jewish center here in 1994 that killed 85 people has faced setbacks and controversy. It caused an intractable rift between Argentina and Iran. A former president has been put on trial, accused of orchestrating a cover-up. And a prosecutor involved in the case died last year in murky circumstances.

headline: The Rise and Fall of the Bush Campaign
text: The biggest stories of this young political year are the surprising surges of the outsider presidential candidates Donald J. Trump and Bernie Sanders, the Democratic senator from Vermont. Close behind is the possible collapse of the once-formidable front-runner, Jeb Bush.

headline: Review: ‘Quicksand,’ Robert Ashley’s Enigmatic Spy-Thriller Opera
text: Robert Ashley is no longer with us, but his voice — calm, mellow, reassuring, quizzical, amused, earnest — lives on. Surrounded by a shifting, unstable electronic haze, it is the only thing you hear at the Kitchen during “Quicksand,” the opera that he wrote in the final years before his death, at 83, in 2014.

headline: Facebook’s Sensible Ban on Gun Ads
text: Facebook’s decision last week to prohibit private gun sales on its social networking site and on its photo-sharing app Instagram should make it harder for convicted felons and other dangerous people to acquire deadly weapons. That’s a very good thing, especially considering the unwillingness of lawmakers in Congress to enact sensible gun safety policies.

headline: Jaap van Zweden, Philharmonic’s Maestro-to-Be, Sharpens His Baton
text: DALLAS — It was the morning after he had been named the next music director of the New York Philharmonic, and Jaap van Zweden was already back at work here at his current job, rehearsing the Dallas Symphony Orchestra in Mozart’s Symphony No. 39 with the fastidiousness — and relentlessness — for which he has become known.

headline: Boko Haram Burns Villages in Northeastern Nigeria
text: KADUNA, Nigeria — More than 50 people were killed in a series of raids on villages in northeastern Nigeria that officials say was the work of the Islamist extremist group Boko Haram.

headline: Review: ‘Quicksand,’ Driven by the Rhythm of Words, Light and Bodies
text: Told from the point of view of a wry, vodka-swilling composer and freelance spy, Robert Ashley’s “Quicksand,” a 2011 opera written as a novel, anticipates action from the start: “I’m sitting on the bathroom floor, leaning back against the sink. I have the gun in my hands.”

headline: Review: ‘The Grand Paradise’ Summons a ’70s Pleasure Palace
text: I had barely arrived for my tropical holiday in Brooklyn before I was deflowered. Yes, my lei, which had been hung welcomingly around my neck when I entered the resort called the Grand Paradise, was taken from me (gently) by a vulpine blonde in a pink satin bathing suit and pearls.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Feb. 1
text: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Jordi Savall and Juilliard415 Perform in ‘Shakespeare and Cervantes’
text: Cervantes and Shakespeare died 400 years ago, though not on the same day, as many continue to maintain. For Cervantes, the date on his tombstone — April 23, 1616 — may refer to his burial, and for Shakespeare, the same date was based on the Julian calendar; by the modern Gregorian calendar, it is May 3.

headline: Cartoonist Is Arrested as Egypt Cracks Down on Critics
text: CAIRO — A popular Egyptian cartoonist was arrested Sunday on charges of running a website without a license, the Interior Ministry said, in the latest escalation of a campaign to silence the government’s online critics.

headline: A Word With Spike Lee: ‘They Want to Rewind the Clock’
text: In his latest feature, “Chi-Raq,” Spike Lee tells the story of the epidemic of gun violence in Chicago through the eyes of a gangster’s girlfriend, who persuades women to withhold sex until their menfolk disavow firearms. During production last summer, the film made headlines when the city’s mayor, Rahm Emanuel, criticized the title, which borrowed a nickname Chicagoans had coined for their town’s violent turn.

headline: Simile and Metaphor as Critique: Jaap van Zweden Speaks to an Ensemble
text: Jaap van Zweden, who will become the music director of the New York Philharmonic in 2018, is known for his intense, demanding rehearsals. Drilling his current ensemble, the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, in a Mozart symphony last week, he used a battery of tools to coax out the sounds he sought: singing out phrases in his pure tenor voice, giving precise technical instructions, and, quite often, venturing into analogies.

headline: Trump or Cruz? Clinton or Sanders? Iowa Hears Last-Minute Pitches
text: DES MOINES — They have munched on pork chops in the heat of summer and hunted game in the dead of winter. Spouses and children have been dispatched as surrogates across the plains. But with the caucuses on Monday hours away, the presidential candidates are leaving nothing to chance, furiously crisscrossing Iowa and making direct appeals to voters to stand for them in the election’s first nominating contest.

headline: Review: In ‘No Más Bebés,’ Forced Sterilizations at an American Hospital
text: Outrage may be America’s leading source of energy right now, and it seems endlessly renewable. “No Más Bebés” adds to the supply but in an understated, melancholy way that leaves you more sad than angry.

headline: For the Vanguard Jazz Orchestra, Monday Becomes an All-Week Affair
text: The Vanguard Jazz Orchestra opened its first set at the Village Vanguard on a recent Monday night with a familiar blend of purring saxophones and punchy brass, carving up “Big Dipper” just as it had in its first performance in the same room almost exactly 50 years ago.

headline: Review: In ‘Maria Stuarda,’ Sondra Radvanovsky Makes a Vivid Impact
text: When an announcement is made that a singer is sick but will perform anyway, listener sympathy is sought for any potential flaws. But there was no evidence that Sondra Radvanovsky had a cold, as had been indicated, during her magnificent rendering of the title role of Donizetti’s “Maria Stuarda” on Friday evening, when David McVicar’s production returned to the Metropolitan Opera.

headline: Review: ‘Ostend: Stefan Zweig, Joseph Roth, and the Summer Before the Dark’ Revisits Moments in Exile
text: Not that long ago, most American readers had never heard of Stefan Zweig, even though he was one of Europe’s most popular authors — every bit as famous as Thomas Mann, certainly — at the sunny peak of his career.

headline: Four-Baggers
text: MONDAY PUZZLE — One of the things I like about Gary Cee’s crosswords is the nod to his profession as a radio D.J. and program director in most of, if not all, of his puzzles. He opens his puzzle today at 1 Across with AM/FM.

headline: Review: In ‘Saala Khadoos,’ a Female Boxer Rises From the Streets in India
text: You know the story or one like it: Underdog boxer from the mean streets is taken up by a coach, himself in need of redemption. Together, this scruffy pair hope to make it to the big championship.

headline: Man Slashed in Face After Argument on Harlem Subway Platform
text: A man was slashed in the face as he stood on the subway platform at 110th Street and Lenox Avenue in Harlem early on Sunday, after getting into an argument with a woman he did not know, the police said.

headline: John Kasich Relishes Attacks From Jeb Bush Backers in Iowa
text: SALEM, N.H. — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and his team have complained — and complained — about the attacks the outside group supporting Jeb Bush has lobbed their way.

headline: Condé Nast Adapts to New Forces, Leaving Some Employees Unsettled
text: A few years ago, Anna Wintour, David Remnick and Graydon Carter went to see S. I. Newhouse Jr., the man who turned Condé Nast into a gilded publishing empire and who handpicked them to lead its flagship magazines.

headline: Microsoft Plumbs Ocean’s Depths to Test Underwater Data Center
text: REDMOND, Wash. — Taking a page from Jules Verne, researchers at Microsoft believe the future of data centers may be under the sea.

headline: Two Virginia Tech Students Arrested in Girl’s Death
text: Two Virginia Tech students were arrested over the weekend in connection with the abduction and death of a 13-year-old girl whose remains were found on Saturday, school and law enforcement officials said.

headline: Theater Flashback: ‘Grease’ on Broadway
text: That hair! Their gum! Those songs!

headline: Swedish Police Foiled Planned Attack on Immigrants in Stockholm
text: HALMSTAD, Sweden — Scores of masked men dressed in black, some carrying wooden weapons, descended on the center of Stockholm, gathering near the entrance to the city’s main subway station.
